He has not properly investigatedNONMET the target's dining facilities .
The 63-year-old head of Pembridge Investments , through which the bid is being mounted saysNONMET , ‘ rule number one in this business is : the more luxurious the luncheon rooms at headquarters , the more inefficient the business ’ .

He regardsMET the charges as unfounded .

We have madeMET a bid of nearly £700m for a company with a book value of £200m — we've acknowledgedNONMET there is some extra worth there , but I can not seeMET the sort of value they are talkingNONMET about in property .

We would eventually likeNONMET to do it along with the management , within the philosophy we will imposeNONMET .
’ The Franklin philosophy was learntNONMET in the US leveraged buyout business at the side of Sir James Goldsmith .

‘ We stirredMET it up , yes , but we never lostMET any money for anybody and we never addedMET to the unemployment figures .

‘ The concept of the company does not interestNONMET me - it's the businesses that are important .
It does not matterNONMET whether or not DRG makesMET sellotape or Basildon Bond — it's of no consequence to anybody if somebody else makesNONMET them .
’ And there is always the ultimate unbundler's defence — that he will makeMET money for his backers .

Nicholas was known as ‘ the uncle of Europe ’ for his success in marryingNONMET his beautiful but penniless daughters into the grander royal houses of Russia , Serbia and Italy .
This furtheredNONMET his long-term ambition to ruleMET a large ‘ south Slav ’ kingdom when the Ottoman Empire finally collapsedMET .

Obituary : Virgil Thomson By PETER DICKINSON VIRGIL THOMSON was a composer and writer of originality , courage and wit formedMET by a unique mixture of American and French influences .
Thomson was bornNONMET in Kansas City in 1896 , studied at Harvard , and then mostly livedNONMET in Paris until 1940 .
His Missouri childhood gaveMET him access to Baptist hymns and church music , but at Harvard he was introducedMET to the writings of Gertrude Stein and the music of Erik Satie .
These influences laidMET the foundations for the blend of the naive and the sophisticated which is the hallmark of Thomson's maturity .
Like many young American composers he studiedMET with Nadia Boulanger , but after 1925 setMET out to achieveNONMET the ‘ discipline of spontaneity ’ which he foundMET in Stein's writings .
When he collaboratedNONMET directly with her in opera the result was of historical significance .
First cameMET Four Saints in Three Acts , produced in 1934 , and then The Mother of Us All ( 1947 ) , which demonstratedMET a new kind of plotless opera only now reachingMET a wider currency through the stage works of Philip Glass .
In Four Saints Thomson's informality was givenMET free reign since he first of all improvisedNONMET the music at the piano then , when it stuckMET , wrote it down to a figuredMET bass .
He saidNONMET : ‘ I had wonderedNONMET whether a piece so drenched in Anglican chant ( running from Gilbert and Sullivan to Morning Prayer and back ) could riseMET and sailMET .
’ But the resulting mixture of hymns , folksy tunes and recitatives — at times of intoxicating banality — was a sensation .
The opera , like Gershwin's Porgy and Bess the following year , usedMET an all-Black cast and the staging and choreography gaveMET it a British connection since it was by Frederick Ashton .
The Mother of Us All showsMET more continuity , but again much dependsNONMET upon production in what is still a largely non-narrative opera .
In 1936 , three years before Aaron Copland , Thomson startedNONMET writing film scores which were a model of unobtrusive clarity and pertinence , combiningNONMET American materials to suitMET documentaries such as The Plow that BrokeMET the Plains and The River with the musique d'ameublement approach of Satie .
His score for the film Louisiana Story was awardedMET the Pulitzer Prize in 1948 .
Another response to a visual stimulus was Thomson's series of musical portraits of people such as Picasso and Aaron Copland .
The first of these was writtenNONMET in 1928 and they numberNONMET about 150 .
Just as Thomson transferredMET Stein's literary abstraction to music , so these portraits unusually employMET the painter's technique of drawingMET the sitter from life : an ideal combination of Thomson's habit of immediate response with an actual subject .
The results are terse and sharply etchedMET , like the best line drawings .
Thomson could controlMET words with the same fastidiousness as notes .
He always feltMET that effective musical criticism beganMET by being well writtenNONMET , and he never lost his liveliness .
One never quite knewNONMET what he was goingNONMET to sayNONMET next .
He startedNONMET by writingNONMET occasional articles but in 1939 he wroteNONMET The State of Music , a trenchant and provocative assessment of the machinery of the musical profession at the time .
From 1940 to 1954 he wroteNONMET regularly for the New York Herald Tribune and four volumes of his notices have appearedMET in book form .
He wroteNONMET a fulsome 400-page autobiography , characteristically entitledNONMET Virgil Thomson on Virgil Thomson , and a personal survey , American Music since 1910 , appearedMET in 1972 , followedMET recently by a selected edition of his letters .
As both composer and critic he touchedMET both sides of the coin : A climate of receptivity is what the artist most desires .
It is also a thing that even the most experienced reviewer can not always offerNONMET .
Thomson's judgements about music were not always as accurate as his confident expression impliedNONMET : he invitedMET discussion .
Above all he restoredMET the focus of music criticism onto the music itself .
He madeMET no secret of his Francophile enthusiasms , in reaction to the earlier domination of American music by Germans , and he was one of the first writers to registerMET the importance of jazz .
He fearlessly attackedMET convention , which causedNONMET problems when he pitchedMET into established reputations .
It has becomeNONMET increasingly apparent that Thomson belongedMET to the American experimental tradition .
He anticipatedNONMET some of the enthusiasms of John Cage , whom he first metNONMET in 1941 .
A few years later Thomson recognised Cage as ‘ the most original composer in America , if not the world … ’ and Cage repaidMET the compliment by writingNONMET the works section of a monograph on Thomson .
But finally , in spite of their common roots in Satie and Stein , Thomson feltMET that Cage's aesthetic was destructive .
Thomson's songs containMET some of his finest work .
There are Stein settings , such as ‘ Portrait of FB ’ , but also cycles such as Five Songs from William Blake , Prayers and Praises and a cantata basedMET on poems by Edward Lear .
Thomson was also prolific in instrumental music on both chamber and solo scale .
For many years Thomson livedNONMET in New York in his apartment at the Chelsea Hotel .
From there , like a buzzard in its eyrie , he would makeMET forays round the US and abroad in spite of his advanced age .
He seemedNONMET a genial and indestructible landmark in the history of American music , in spite of defective hearing which had botheredMET him since the late Seventies .
He had a photograph of himself on his postcards and he signedNONMET his letters followingMET the original tailpiece ‘ everbest ’ .
Thomson cameMET from a generation of American composers which had to findMET its own way without benefit of university patronage .
In that kind of free market he thrivedNONMET and survivedNONMET — and so will the best of his work .
Obituary : Thomas Keller By HUGH MATHESON THOMI KELLER is the outstanding figure in the history of international rowing .
He was President of FISA ( Federation Internationale des Societes d'Aviron ) , the world governing body , for 30 years ; and most of this body's attitudes and practices reflectMET the force of his strict , but genial personality .
Most athletes first encountered him as a voice , bellowingMET in multi-lingual fury at officials who had broken rules or arrangements designedMET to makeMET racingNONMET safer or more fair .
He was electedNONMET to succeedNONMET Gaston Mullegg as President of FISA when he was 33 and still competing in the Swiss rowing team .
He did not loosenMET his links with the athletes when projectedMET upwards into the Presidency .
Provided their behaviour was sportsmanlike and safe , oarsmen found only encouragement and humour from a President who was always among them .
Keller's Zurich upbringing madeMET him into a skiier and sculler , and he racedNONMET for the Grasshopper club .
He competedNONMET for the Swiss cross-country and ski-jumping team at the Student Winter Games and later concentratedNONMET on single scullsNONMET .
In 1950 , he was Swiss scullsNONMET champion and finished third in the European championships before movingNONMET to Manila to workNONMET for his family's private multinational company , Eduard Keller Ltd , for four years .
On his return , Keller was Swiss champion again in 1955 and was bitterly disappointed when the Swiss choseNONMET to boycottNONMET the 1956 Olympics after the Russian intervention in Hungary .
FISA was then a relatively unimportant body which organised European and other championships and participatedMET in the running of Olympic regattas .
As a rich , forceful young man , Keller had been earmarkedMET as a likely future president , even before Mullegg was killedNONMET in an aircrash in 1958 .
Rowing was transformedNONMET in the breadth and depth of participation over the 30 years of his term .
He satMET on the appropriate boards of the International Olympic Committee and was President of the General Assembly of International Sports Federations for 17 years .
These positions were not heldMET for his own status but to promoteNONMET the cause of rowing where it neededMET clout .
He successfully defendedMET rowing as an Olympic sport and in 1976 introduced women's events , which have now expanded to six classes .
His personal preference for scullingNONMET over rowing assistedMET the introduction of quadruple scullsNONMET to world championship and Olympic competition .
Keller was madeMET a Steward of Henley Royal Regatta in 1976 , a time when the proliferation of new six -lane , still-water courses around the world , which had emergedMET under his guidance , seemedNONMET a threat to the regatta founded in 1829 .
But it was the spirit of Henley , with huge crowds enjoyingNONMET amateur sport , presented with administrative finesse , which Keller tookMET as the yardstick for the international circuit .
He lovedNONMET the place and he returnedNONMET every year to playMET an often small part as umpire of races between undistinguished clubs far below the Olympic standard he was obliged to administerNONMET .
He saidNONMET this summer that as he gradually woundNONMET down his involvement in sport , Henley would be the last thing he would give up .
During his term as President of FISA he gradually reduced his role in Eduard Keller Ltd and usedNONMET the company offices to provideNONMET a world headquarters for rowing .
The sport is now obliged to findMET income from the more normal sources of television and sponsorship , to replaceMET his largely unacknowledged private patronage .
In spite of his gift to the sport , Keller was anxious not to abuseMET his status as President and never wentNONMET to a rowing event unless invitedNONMET .
Because of this , he had never seenNONMET the Oxford and Cambridge boat race until this year .
He was enthralledNONMET by the entire proceeding and remarkedNONMET that only the English could makeMET a contest between two crews which would not rankMET in the World's top 10 into a bigger spectacle than the Olympic final .
The final task he setMET himself for his Presidency , which was due to endNONMET next year , was to weedMET out of the Regatta calendar all the rowing courses which could be madeMET unfair by the wind .
He had recently travelledNONMET from Tasmania to Norway in search of the perfect 2,000 metres of flat water .
It was a blessing that , in response to congratulations on the superb World Championship Regatta at Bled in Yugoslavia three weeks ago , he was able to replyNONMET , ‘ Yes … and best of all , the conditions were fair throughout ’ .

Scattered through the policy review are proposals to : Drastically alterNONMET the status and organisation of the Department of Trade and Industry ;  CreateNONMET two departments — a Department of Consumer Affairs , and a Department for Legal Administration ;  CreateNONMET a Department of Environmental Protection within the existing Department of the Environment ; SetMET up a plethora of new commissions and executive agencies ; SetMET up a Women's Ministry .

The only department which explicitly escapesMET unscathed is the one which Conservatives would most likeNONMET to abolishNONMET : the Department of Energy .
In virtually every case the aim of causingNONMET upheaval is explicitly declaredNONMET , because Labour's aim would be to upsetMET the bureaucratic order it inheritsMET .
New departments and quangos would , according to the review , be designedMET to actMET as irritants and antagonists within the Civil Service system .
But the policy review nowhere considersMET the overall effect of the individual changes proposed , or how they might be co-ordinatedMET .
Nor does it contemplateMET the knock-on consequences for Labour ministers of attemptingNONMET to implementNONMET their programme while rebuildingMET the governmental machine .
The ‘ medium term industrial strategy ’ which would formNONMET the centrepiece of Labour's economic policy would , according to the Productive and Competitive Economy review group , be ‘ administeredNONMET by a transformed Department of Trade and Industry ’ .
The review addsMET : ‘ What we now seekMET is a DTI which will have an equal , if not superior status , to that of the Treasury .
’ That approach would seekMET to knockMET out a keystone of Civil Service tradition .
Labour policy has long soughtMET to challengeMET the Treasury's dominance in government .
But its last effort — the Department of Economic Affairs , setMET up by Harold Wilson and headedMET by George Brown — ended in futile departmental and ministerial infighting .
There would in addition be a minister for Science and Technology at the newly supreme DTI , with responsibility for determing investment in research .
There is no mention in the education policy of how that might affectNONMET the Department of Education and Science .
But while the DTI would overrideMET the Treasury , a new ‘ powerful Department of Consumer Affairs ’ would antagoniseMET the DTI .
It would be headedMET by ‘ a minister of Cabinet rank ’ and act as ‘ the consumers ’ voice with other government departments ' .
Its remit for inter-departmental intrusion would be wide , with ‘ a watching brief over government action ’ and the ability to initiateNONMET consumer legislation .
Only the Women's Ministry would be givenMET equal license .
It would be able to ‘ requireMET each government department to reviewNONMET its policies , practices , and existing and proposed legislation ’ .
While new departments are bornMET and others extended , one of the oldest — the Home Office — would becomeNONMET a shadow of its present self .
Labour's proposed Department for Legal Administration would takeMET over responsibility for courts and tribunals ; court procedures ; organisation , training and appointment of the legal profession , magistracy and judiciary ; legal aid ; legal services ; and the Sentencing Council .
That would leaveMET the Home Office with policing , penal policy and the criminal law .

‘ Its main concerns would becomeNONMET food and the people who consumeNONMET it , not farming and those who produceNONMET it .

In some cases Labour's quangos mergeMET existing ones , or replaceMET well-established bodies .
The funding of higher education would becomeNONMET the responsibility of one body , rather than two .

But there would be new regulatory commissions and consumer councils for every utility , along with ombudsmen , and public interest commissioners appointedNONMET by the Secretary of State .
There would be Skills UK — a locally structured training commission — a Fair Wages Commission , a Health Technology Commission , a Health Quality Commission , an Education Standards Council , an Independent Sentencing Council , a Children's Commissioner , an Environmental Protection Executive , and a Social Insurance Fund administeredMET by … ‘ an independent commission ’ .

Ripping yarns and moral minefields : Allan and Janet talk Ahlberg talk to Celia Dodd about their bestsellers for children By CELIA DODD THESE days , no one questionsNONMET the importance of good books for the under- .
But books that appeal to adults too are just as important ; we are , after all , the ones who have to do the reading .
There are few things worse than being bludgeonedMET into readingNONMET a book you hateNONMET .
Story-reading should be one of the great joys of parenthood , a real meeting of adult and child minds .
With the Ahlbergs ' books , it very often is .
The husband-and-wife partnership behind such classics as The Jolly Postman , Burglar Bill and The Baby's Catalogue win children over with ripping yarns and a wicked sense of humour .
They win their parents over with a rose -tinted vision of the world which is decidedly reassuring .
Their books are usually setMET nostalgically in the past — the Thirties and Forties are favourite periods — and often featureNONMET the perennial characters of fairy tales and nursery rhymes .
Yet they are savedMET from sentimentality by the wry humour of both text and pictures .
The Ahlbergs have been accusedNONMET of not facing up to the harsh realities of life , of being too cosy and sweet , but their latest picture book , Bye Bye Baby , publishedNONMET today , breaksMET the mould .
In it , a small child roamsNONMET the streets , talkingNONMET to strangers , until he finally goes off with a woman who has been wandering about pushingNONMET an empty pram .
Curious subject matter for a children's picture book , you might thinkNONMET , and hardly guaranteedNONMET to winMET the approval of the gimlet -eyed children's book world .
But the Ahlbergs have no time for literal interpretations of their work .
How , they argueNONMET , would Alice , or The Wind in the Willows , standMET up against such scrutiny ?
The way to lookMET at Bye Bye Baby , they insistNONMET , is as a ‘ light , surreal comedy ’ .
‘ Certainly if you bringMET a literal interpretation to the story , it's a minefield , ’ Allan Ahlberg saysNONMET .
Bye Bye Baby getsMET away with its particular minefield thanks to the sleight of illustrator Janet Ahlberg's hand .
The visual inspiration for the book was the famous advert for Start-rite shoes , showingMET a small boy and girl walkingNONMET off down a tree- lined avenue — an innocent image if ever there was one .
The Ahlberg version featuresNONMET a solitary figure .
The advert gaveMET the story its vaguely Thirties setting .
The success of the Ahlbergs ' working relationship must have a lot to do with their long and happy marriage .
In spite of apparently incompatible personalities — she is small and shy , he is large and does most of the talking — they have an empathy which is essential to the way they workNONMET , a persistent mutual pestering .
The strength of the partnership is highlightedMET for Allan , who also worksNONMET with a number of other artists .
The time-consuming nature of Janet's part in the process , combinedMET with a bad back which preventsNONMET her spendingMET more than a couple of hours at the drawing board every day , meansNONMET she can not keep up with her husband's prolific output .
‘ With other illustrators , I workNONMET at a distance — we visitNONMET and phone , but there is a point at which I can't pesterNONMET them any more , ’ Allan saysNONMET .
They seeMET themselves not as author and illustrator , with separate roles , but as a partnership of ‘ book-makers ’ , contributingNONMET equally to the process .
Allan Ahlberg saysNONMET : ‘ In the past , a lot of children's books seemedNONMET to be the work of talented illustrators whose pictures looked brilliant framed in a gallery , but when you triedNONMET to readNONMET the book , there was nothing there , because the words startedMET as a coat-hanger to hang pictures on .
’ GivenNONMET the importance they placeMET on the interrelationship of words and pictures , the couple's working lives are surprisingly separate .
They claimMET to seeNONMET each other less than couples who goNONMET out to work , meetingNONMET for the occasional cup of coffee in the kitchen .
Their 10-year-old daughter , Jessica , who is likely to be seenNONMET with her head buriedMET in The Beano or a Roald Dahl novel , has providedNONMET the inspiration for many of her parents ' books .
As a baby , she was fascinatedNONMET by the Mothercare Catalogue , and so The Baby's Catalogue , which documentsNONMET the paraphernalia of the infant's small world in minute detail , was bornMET .
Allan's experience as a primary school teacher is another rich source of ideas .
The couple still maintainMET close links with local schools , where they spendMET hours researchingNONMET , sketching and absorbing jokes .
After 10 years of teaching Allan had had enough .
‘ I ranMET out of steam .
It's a killing job .
Little kids eatMET you alive , they wantNONMET so much physically and emotionally .
’ Every year he would have half a dozen nine- and 10-year-olds in his class who could barely readNONMET .
He treatedNONMET reading as a team effort , gettingMET them to readNONMET the Daily Mirror rather than the dull , babyish books on offer .
These days , he writesNONMET the books intended to helpNONMET children learnNONMET to readNONMET .
‘ A lot of books used in schools are technically readable but rather drab stories .
There's no reason why they shouldn't be funny or gripping even if they don't useMET many words .
’ Writing books for children is becomingNONMET increasingly complex , as the arbiters of the modern child's mores — librarians , teachers and publishers — layMET down ever more stringent criteria .
‘ The problem with children's books increasingly is that there are armies of people who are properly concerned with , for example , the way girls were always discriminatedNONMET against in the past , ’ saysNONMET Allan .
‘ That is bad , and must be thoughtNONMET about .
But people seemNONMET to thinkNONMET that stories are writtenNONMET to a prescription , that you sitNONMET down and sayNONMET , you don't wantNONMET it to be sexist , you don't wantNONMET it to be racist .
In reality you just inventNONMET a tale , as if you were sitting round a fire in a cave .
’ In fact anti-racism and anti-sexism seemNONMET to comeMET naturally to the Ahlbergs .
Their books are full of female breadwinners and New Men changing nappies and comforting bawling babies in the small hours .
Although they are a principled pair — they once turnedMET down the Smarties Award on moral grounds — the Ahlbergs rejectNONMET the notion of children's author as moralist .
‘ I would sayNONMET , just sitNONMET down and tellNONMET a good story , and to hell with the morality , ’ Allan Ahlberg declaresNONMET .
With that characteristically strong statement , he putsMET his finger on the secret of the Ahlbergs ' phenomenal success with adults and children alike .
The revolution the countryside needs : Christian Wolmar saysNONMET Britain is laggingMET behind in settingMET up ‘ telecottages ’ By CHRISTIAN WOLMAR THE information technology revolution has leftMET large swaths of rural Britain untouched .
The only computers in many villages are those ownedNONMET by the teenage boys of the affluent to playNONMET their wham-bam games .
Ashley Dobbs , an engaging young entrepreneur , is settingMET out to changeMET that by creatingNONMET a nationwide network of ‘ telecottages ’ .
This clever name , with its neat evocation of new and old , describesMET a concept which was developedNONMET in Sweden and is spreading to rural areas across the world .
In Mr Dobbs's words , a telecottage is ‘ a room in a village filled with computer communications that can be usedNONMET by local people to learnNONMET and workNONMET ’ .
The equipment consistsNONMET of , perhaps , four word processors , a modem , a laser printer able to produceNONMET artwork-quality output , a fax and a photocopier .
Software programmes for desk-top publishing , word processing , accounting and business planning are also essential .
Mr Dobbs , who is chairman of Telecottages UK , warnsNONMET possible users not to getNONMET boggedMET down with the technology : ‘ The equipment is a tool to overcomeMET what needsNONMET to be done .
People mustn't thinkNONMET that because there's a computer , they've gotNONMET to thinkNONMET of a use for it .
’ He reckonsMET there are no  shortages of possible uses — farmers can useNONMET it to do their accounts , women with child-care responsibilities can workNONMET in their own time on the word processors , publicity material for local craftsmen can be producedMET and so on .
This may sound utopian , but it has been borne out by the experience of existing telecottages .
So far about 100 have been establishedNONMET , mainly in Scandinavia but also in Japan and several third world countries .
As the network expandsMET , so do the uses .
The first was openedMET in the village of Vemdalen in the remote forests of Sweden in September 1985 .
The impact , according to Henning Albrechsten , president of Telecottages International who has been involved in their development since the outset , was immediate .
‘ By holdingMET open meetings for children and having the telecottage above the local store , people of all walks of life cameNONMET in - small-scale entrepreneurs and their spouses , shop assistants , craftspeople and children .
Now , 15 per cent of the village regularly usesMET telecottage and at least 20 per cent has takenMET courses  there .
’ Britain is laggingMET behind .
No telecottages have been establishedNONMET , but there are several initiatives in the offing .
The most advanced is a plan for five in the north of Scotland which will be fundedNONMET by the Highlands and Islands Development Board and British Telecom .
Colin Pavey of British Telecom hopesNONMET that they will be runningMET by the end of the year .
‘ Two would be business and three would be community-orientated and located in schools .
We are most interested in the idea of networking , sharingMET skills such as translation and usingNONMET them for distance learning .
’ Telephone cables  in the region are being upgradedNONMET to ensureNONMET they are capable of handlingMET faxes .
Mr Dobbs's more unlikely allies are the Women's Institutes .
Most of the workers in telecottages and many of the  users are women .
He saysNONMET : ‘ In villages there are many women with skills who aren't usingNONMET them because of child-care problems .
But they are interested in workingNONMET .
Users of telecottages are givenNONMET the key and people can useNONMET them at any time , which meansNONMET that women can comeNONMET in during the evening , early in the morning or whatever .
’ He is workingNONMET on a scheme with the National Federation of WI to organiseNONMET a competition to celebrateNONMET next year's 75th anniversary by offering 10 telecottages as prizes for its 9,000 branches and he is hopingNONMET the WI will establishNONMET a pilot telecottage near its college in Denman , Oxfordshire .
While telecottages should becomeNONMET self-financing once establishedNONMET , they do needNONMET initial subsidy .
The cost of providingNONMET the start-up equipment is in the order of £10,000 and Mr Dobbs thinksNONMET space is not much of a problem : ‘ There's usually the village hall or an empty shop .
’ Henning Albrechsten reckonsMET that it takesMET three years for a telecottage to be able to functionNONMET without subsidy .
In Scandinavia , with their mixed economies , money is always available , after a bit of persuasion , from both local and central government .
In Britain , the tight financial regime imposed on local councils and the reluctance of central government to takeMET on any new expenditure makesMET it necessary to seekNONMET funds from the private sector .
The only government support so far has been a recommendation by the Rural Development Commission , part of the Department of the Environment , to establishNONMET a pilot scheme .
Mr Dobbs sighsNONMET : ‘ This is a typically British bureaucratic response .
It's been provedNONMET elsewhere that they workMET .
We don't needNONMET pilots , we needNONMET telecottages .
’ As for the private sector , while BT may be happy to provideNONMET pump primingMET for five telecottages in the north of Scotland , it is not about to bankrollMET a nationwide network .
Nor , it seemsNONMET , is anyone else .
There is more at stake here than just bringingNONMET boxes of sophisticated equipment to remote areas .
As Mr Dobbs , who runsMET a country house restoration business from his home in Micheldever , Hampshire , saysNONMET : ‘ Villages are good places to liveNONMET and workNONMET .
The village is a fantastic institution and they makeMET people happier .
’ But the villages are dying , becomingNONMET suburbs or dormitories where few people work but many  sleepNONMET .
Employment in agriculture , still the main rural industry , fellMET from over a million in the mid-Sixties to under 100,000 now .
The aim of telecottages is to  createNONMET well-paid , flexible employment which will provideNONMET new jobs and makeMET existing rural industries more competitive .
The emphasis on high wages is important .
Villages are expensive to liveNONMET in and if they are to becomeNONMET vibrant communities again , local people must be able to earnNONMET enough to be able to continueNONMET living in them .
There is a wider impact , too .
The  abstract talk of commuting by rail or road being replacedMET by  information technology findsMET a concrete expression in the idea of telecottages .
Once people overcomeMET their fears about computers and beginNONMET to useNONMET them in telecottages , they acquireNONMET their own equipment .
Many may eventually be able to workNONMET from home rather than commuteNONMET to an office .
Henning Albrechsten saysNONMET : ‘ Modern information technology has givenMET people in remote regions the opportunity to overcomeMET their worst handicap ; their distance from the centres of learning and development .
’ He seesMET them as not only strengtheningMET small communities , but also as actually beginningNONMET to reverseMET the population flows from the countryside to the towns .
Britain , with its growing traffic problems , seemsNONMET an ideal place for the onset of this revolution .
Despite Mr Dobbs's tireless efforts , this is another revolution which Britain is likely to be viewingMET from the sidelines .

An atmosphere poisonedMET by mistrust By NICHOLAS ROE The disposal of toxic wastes is one of the most intractable problems facingMET industrialised societies .
Even though some of the most dangerous and persistent toxins , including polychlorinated biphenyls , PCBs , are no longer manufactured , quantities of them still existNONMET , and must be gotMET rid                  of .
But how ?
And where ?
On this page , Nick Roe visitsNONMET a plant which , despite strenuous public relations efforts , has failedMET to convinceMET its neighbours that it has comeMET clean .
And Richard North looksMET at current provisions for the destruction of PCBs , and at the history of British involvement in a rather uncomfortable growth industry The security guard at the entrance to one of Britain's mightiest hazardous waste disposal plants pressedNONMET a button and the gate openedNONMET .
Then he pressedNONMET another knob and a big toy doll in his office window droppedMET its trousers .
You had to laughNONMET .
Yet this was Rechem International's high incineration plant at Pontypool in Gwent , South Wales .
Hardly a laughing matter , surely ?
Beyond the barrier layMET some of the most toxic chemicals knownNONMET , awaitingMET destruction by fire .
What else ?
A vast , smoke-blackened furnace ; 100 people to do the work ; massive investment — the company spentMET £2m last year on cleaning up smoke emissions .
Plus a backdrop of houses coveringMET the valley walls on either side , a reminder that wherever industrialised societies decideMET to dealMET with their most intractable problems , they are unlikely to findMET a place to do so which is not in somebody's back yard .
Britain grindsMET out almost five million tonnes of hazardous waste each year , of which about 63,000 tonnes are so difficult to storeNONMET or treatNONMET that they are burntNONMET at high temperatures here in Gwent or at one of three other centres : Ellesmere Port ; Fawley , near Southampton ; and the unfortunately namedNONMET Killamarsh , near Sheffield .
Five more incinerators currently proposedNONMET in various parts of the country will double capacity .
Then there are the imports : 83,000 tonnes of toxic waste enter British ports annually for incineration or other treatment , a figure  which has increasedNONMET 20-fold in just eight years .
In these environmentally conscious times , this is an uncomfortable growth industry .
Liverpool dockers recently turned back parts of a 1,500-tonne consignment of Canadian PCBs ( polychlorinated biphenyls ) bound for this plant in Gwent .
In doing so , they underlinedMET a fact which is likely to attractMET more and more attention as tankers continueNONMET to shiftNONMET toxins from town to town , country to country : the waste chain is long .
It snakes in and out of ports , along our busiest highways and through our most crowded cities .

Law : Always takeNONMET along a friend to sueNONMET : Litigation can pay off even in the unlikeliest circumstances .
Stephen Gold explainsNONMET By STEPHEN GOLD WHEN things goNONMET wrong you can sueNONMET more often than you may thinkNONMET .
Money may not have changedMET hands .
Someone may have even done you a favour .
It doesn't matterNONMET .
As long as you can showMET that they owedNONMET you a legal duty to be careful and have been negligent , damages could comeMET your way .
There are a number of points to bearMET in mind .
Take up references before givingMET credit , lendingNONMET money , letting in tenants , taking on staff .
AskMET banks , building societies , former landlords , present and past employers .
If you relyNONMET to your detriment on a misleading reference which was givenMET negligently , you should be able to sueNONMET the referee .
The subject of a bad reference can sueNONMET the referee for libel but has to showMET the referee was up to no good : spite , ill or some improper motive will do .
TakeNONMET along a prosperous adviser on all shopping sprees , demonstrateNONMET a high degree of trust and strong reliance in what they sayNONMET and you may have unexpected protection should the seller goNONMET out of business and the goods fallMET to pieces .
A 26-year-old woman accountant who knewNONMET nothing about the mechanical side of vehicles askedNONMET her more knowledgeable friend to findNONMET a car for her .
She stipulatedNONMET that it must never have been involved in an accident .
The friend foundNONMET one at a garage .
Although he failedNONMET to checkNONMET it had been accident-free , he assuredNONMET the lady that this was the case .
She boughtMET it .
It had been in an accident and it was worthless .
In May last year the Court of Appeal upheldNONMET a judgment against the friend for more than £5,500 damages for negligence because he had owedNONMET the accountant a duty of care .
Your conservatory collapses as a result of negligence of the professionals who were engagedNONMET by the previous owner to put it up .
You can sueNONMET the professionals — builders , architects , surveyors or engineers — by courtesy of the Defective Premises Act 1972 , despite the fact that you never had a contract with them yourself .
There are strict time limits : generally , six years from when damage first occurredMET ; where the damage was initially ‘ latent ’ you are givenMET longer — three years from when you could have discoveredNONMET it , with a long stop of 15 years .
It may also be possible to claimNONMET damages against a local authority for negligently failingMET to ensureNONMET that construction work compliedMET with the relevant building regulations .
A solicitor failsNONMET to draw up a will within a reasonable time for a client who subsequently diesNONMET .
You loseMET the gift which the will would have madeMET .
You can sueNONMET the solicitor for what you would have collectedMET , had he done his job properly , because the law reckonsMET he owedNONMET you , as well as his client , a duty of care .
When you wantNONMET to borrowNONMET on a mortgage , the prospective lenders will have the property valued at your expense .
There is no contract between you and the valuer .
But if the valuer is negligent and you buyNONMET the property relyingNONMET on his report , you may still be able to sueNONMET him for damages .
This is what the House of Lords decided in two cases last April in spite of an attempt to getMET the valuers off the hook by a disclaimer which saidMET : ‘ I acceptNONMET that the valuer does not warrantNONMET anything stated in his report as being accurate … ‘ Alas , disclaimers may workMET if , for example , the property being valuedNONMET is industrial or an expensive house .
Disclaimers may also be usedNONMET by referees and others to robMET you of a claim for damages .
Whoever attempts to hideMET behind a disclaimer must proveNONMET it is fair and reasonable to do so .
But a disclaimer can never takeMET away your rights under the Defective Premises Act 1972 for the collapsing conservatory or preventNONMET anyone being suedNONMET for negligence which has causedNONMET death or injury .
Have we yet reachedMET the point at which we would be awardedNONMET damages against the Meteorological Office because we wentNONMET campingNONMET on the day of an unforecast hurricane ?
Or after we followedNONMET the duff advice of a legal journalist in a newspaper ?
Mercifully , we doubtNONMET it !

As a result of this rule , and many carefully orchestrated publicity campaigns , the motor industry's image has now changedNONMET from polluter to pal of the earth .
If you can affordNONMET an environmentally friendly G-registered runabout , then the flora , fauna and children of the British Isles will have a lot to thankNONMET you for .
But if you have a tight budget and a conscience , runningNONMET older cars on lead-free fuel becomesNONMET a much more complicated issue .
Without the presence of a lead compound , an engine's valve seats goNONMET unprotected .
This leadsMET to premature wear and plumes of blue smoke spewingMET from the exhaust .
The only effective remedy is to installNONMET hardened valve seats or a replacement cylinder head , both expensive options .
Less costly , but not entirely satisfactory , is the practice of makingMET every fourth tankful leaded petrol , which protectsNONMET the valve seats but rather defeatsMET the object .
Alternatively there are several chemical additives on the market which aimMET to provideNONMET a substitute for lead , although the case for these products has yet to be provedNONMET .
However , many cars builtNONMET within the last few years have hardenedNONMET valve seats , or alloy cylinder heads that needMET little ( simply a retune ) or no modification to useNONMET unleaded petrol .
Finding out which cars can and which can not is not difficult .
Esso filling stations have a free booklet listingMET most models producedNONMET since 1980 , as does the charity ClearNONMET ( 01-387 4970 ) , with more detail available in the Unleaded Petrol Guide ( Autodale , £2.99 ) .
LookingNONMET at those lists providesNONMET interesting reading and bears out the used-car trade's view that having a lead-only car could proveNONMET to be a liability .
It is not as if four-star leaded fuel is goingNONMET to be phased out tomorrow , but more and more buyers are askingNONMET : ‘ Does it takeMET unleaded ?
’ What is certain is that the pre-1989 Austin/MG range , all Skodas , Yugos and quite a few Lancias do not , which does not helpMET already depressed resale prices .
A 1985 Lancia Y10 ( lead only ) sellsNONMET for around £2,000 whereas the similar Fiat Uno 55 from the same year , converted to runMET on unleaded , is worth around £500 more .
A lead-only second-hand car is now worth about 10 per cent less than an unleaded equivalent .
In years to comeMET the percentage difference is likely to be much larger .
Even so , exotica such as lead-only Porsche 911s and Ferraris are unlikely to be part of this trend , so no bargains there I'm afraid .
More impressive are the Japanese manufacturers whose cars datingNONMET from the early Eighties can runMET on unleaded without adjustment .
FindNONMET a 1980 Toyota Corolla or 1982 Nissan Sunny that has not succumbedMET to rustNONMET , and you can buyNONMET with confidence .
On the home front , most Fords and Vauxhalls from at least the mid-Eighties can useNONMET unleaded .
If the ‘ greenness ’ of goingNONMET unleaded still seemsNONMET a bit of a grey area , it is possible to switchNONMET to diesel without a shadow of environmental doubt .
Diesel always has been lead-free and the only adjustments you needNONMET to makeMET are mental ones , because diesel-powered cars are no longer slow , smelly or noisy .
They also returnMET more miles to the gallon than their petrol equivalents , although service intervals are shorter .
But after the publicity on unleaded fuel there has been increased interest in used diesel power .
But rememberNONMET that these cars accrueNONMET , and can withstandNONMET , significantly higher mileages than petrol cars , 50-90,000 being the norm .
The tradition for diesel cars is far better establishedNONMET on the Continent and that is where the best buys comeMET from .
Perhaps the most successful maker is Peugeot , with a complete range of cars from the small 205 — around £3,000 for a 90,000-mile 1985 car — to the legendary 504 =estate , about £2,000 for a 1982 example .
The Germans are also fairly accomplished manufacturers , although a five-door 1980 Golf with a six-figure mileage will still costNONMET £1,500 .
Prestige comesMET in the shape of a Mercedes with the 240D or ‘ Stuttgart Taxi ’ , commanding £7,000 but returning unfailing reliability .
Even if lead levels in the atmosphere do not botherNONMET you , I am sure you will findMET the fact that unleaded petrol is 15p cheaper , and that diesel fuel boostsMET mpg by at least a third , most interesting .

How did you feelMET as you cameMET to the end of your working week yesterday afternoon ?
Boy , I had a thirst .
We sayNONMET we are thirsty when we meanNONMET that we fancyNONMET a glass of wine , a pint of beer , a gin and tonic or a shot of whisky — the pleasure of namingNONMET our poison — at the end of a busy day or tiresome week .
That is not thirst .
To enjoyNONMET it , we do not needNONMET to be dry : just in need of a restorative or relaxant , or maybe a focus for a social moment or brief encounter .
We callNONMET it ‘ thirst ’ in lieu of a more accurate description .
No , not more accurate : ‘ thirst ’ is not accurate at all as a description for this apparently indescribable condition .
It is a desire millions of us knowNONMET and share , yet for which we have no name .
This desire that can not findMET its name ( though it would dareMET speakMET it , if it could ) is pleasurable .
It is as enjoyable as feeling gently hungry or amorous .
No , not amorous : randy — we have a word for that .
Any of these conditions is pleasurable so long as there is a good likelihood of satisfaction in reasonably short order .
LetNONMET puritans and pessimists damnNONMET , disapproveNONMET or dismissMET these appetites ; that is their loss .
Those of us who enjoyNONMET them needNONMET only a name for each condition , so that we may discussNONMET them in expectation and in recollection .
ComeMET to thinkNONMET of it , neither hunger nor randiness hitsMET quite the spot .
Peckishness and lust , perhaps ?
Or does that sound like a firm of country solicitors ?
This is to digressNONMET .
What of this thirst that can be satisfied by an unquenching drink ?
Wine is not quenchingMET , but no less in demand for that .
TryNONMET to quenchMET your thirst with a light , fresh white and you will drinkNONMET enough to putMET you on your back .
Beer is , quite rightly , Britain's favourite Friday night drink .
It can momentarily bluntMET a thirst , but not altogether cutMET it .
The nearest to being quenching is the ‘ white ’ beer of Berlin .
Anything with even a modest smack of hops driesMET the palate ready for the next one .
So , of course , does alcohol itself .
It may for a moment seemNONMET to quenchMET but it dehydratesNONMET , as purportedly healthy abstainers are forever tellingNONMET me .
To quenchMET is more than to refresh although our lying , lascivious eyes tellMET us the two are the same .

No , refreshing .

Perhaps a shimmering dry Martini cocktail ( minimum dilution , stirred , not shakenNONMET ; and servedNONMET straight up ) looks even more refreshing , though its effect is that of a silver mallet .

The requirement for such pleasures is a matter of time and place , and it does not have to be Friday , Berlin or Strasburg , New York or San Francisco .
Not feelingNONMET thirsty , but fancyingNONMET a drink , has a world of moments .
Some Frenchmen startNONMET the day with a coffee and calvados .
The people of Munich callNONMET their version of Weissbier ‘ breakfast beer ’ and have it with a pair of coddled veal sausages .
New Orleans favoursMET a mid-morning milk punch , or its own variation on the gin fizz .

None of these requiresNONMET anything even approachingMET a thirst .

Port is immediately suggestedMET by Stilton ; cognac by coffee .
I do not fully appreciateNONMET the experience of an American late-night movie without a bourbon , or a book at bedtime without a single malt .
These are not moments of thirst … but nor are they causes of drunkenness ( unless one triesNONMET to packMET all such experiences into one day ) .
We do not drinkNONMET because we are thirsty .
Nor , if we are in civilised cast of mind , because we wishNONMET to becomeNONMET drunk .
A friend of mine saysNONMET that her body tellsMET her , without being askedMET , the season of the year .

If it were only a matter of alcohol , would a body careMET ?
People will nevertheless sayNONMET that the desire is for nothing more than alcohol .
So why not a pill or an injection ?
Because there would be no colour , no ritual , no time and place , no glorious variety .
Worst of all , there would be no aroma , taste , texture or finish .

Could we borrowMET , begNONMET or inventNONMET one ?
Answers in a bottle , please .

Same time , same place ?
It will be my turn to getNONMET them in , I thinkNONMET .

There are many things to thinkNONMET about before even the first tentative daffodil bulb is sunkMET into the ground .
The first and most important question to mull over as you gazeNONMET at your patch is : What is this garden for ?
If you startNONMET writing down some of the responses to that question , you will findMET you have along the way acquiredNONMET a ragbag of elements that will have an important bearing on the design .

If you do not knowNONMET what a tree or shrub is , exercise clemency and giveMET it a year's grace to demonstrateNONMET its worth before you turnMET it over to the axeman .

Single-car , articulated or double-decker , trams are one of the most reliable and enduring forms of public transport invented .

Last month it was announcedNONMET that Britain will getMET its first new- wave trams in 1991 .
DestinedMET to runMET in Manchester , they will relieveMET traffic congestion and help to reduceMET the levels of carbon monoxide in the city centre , outlying suburbs and satellite towns of Bury , Altrincham , Salford , Oldham and Rochdale .
In Britain , with the main exception of Blackpool ( not forgettingNONMET the single-deckers of the Isle of Man and Llandudno ) , trams had been largely relegatedNONMET to the history books .
Otherwise , the best place to seeNONMET working trams has been the tram museum at Crich in Derbyshire or else in old British Transport Commission films and Ealing comedies .
Trams disappearedNONMET from most British cities in the 1950s .
London's venerable red and cream double-deckers rumbledNONMET along the Thames embankment for the last time in 1952 .
Somehow the image of the tall , thin , mournful double-deck tram with its wooden body , slatted wooden seats and growling electric motor has stuckMET in the British mind .
Trams , it was believedNONMET until surprisingly recently , are old-fashioned .
They had something to do with fish and chips wrapped in newspaper , men in hats , National Health specs , smog and powdered egg .
They heldMET up the bright new diesel buses and , even worse , blockedMET the  progress of private motorists in bulbous Austins and lumpen Humbers in canyon like city thoroughfares .
They pickedMET up power from a spider ' s web of unsightly overhead wires .
They were inflexible in operation , draughty , and mobile reminders of TB epidemics with the enamelled ‘ Do Not Spit ’ signs screwed  to their bulkheads .
But the modern tram could hardly be more different .
It playsMET a key role in keepingMET city streets on the move and is even the object of the best modern designers ' desire .
In Milan , for example , the commission to designNONMET the new generation of ‘ Jumbo ’ trams , which wentMET into service in 1979 , was one that leading Italian architects and designers fought over .
After all , the Jumbo , a handsome and imposing articulated unit designedNONMET by architect , engineer and critic Klaus Giovanni Koenig , will be seenNONMET on the streets of Milan for the next half .
Spotlessly clean and popular , the Jumbo is a long-term advertisement for Koenig's design skills .
The modern tram is a green machine .
AssumingMET the power station at the end of the line burnsMET cleanly , the tram is virtually pollution free .
Standing at traffic lights a Koenig-designed Jumbo is , save for the chatter inside , completely silent .
The overhead wires are so slight that you have to lookNONMET hard to seeNONMET them .
Powers of acceleration and braking are remarkable , the latter far greater than any car .
But  sadly , there is no indication that the GMA consortium which will designMET , operateMET and maintainMET the first of the new generation British trams in Manchester will shareMET the looks of their Milanese counterparts .
Artists ' impressions showMET a tram that has more in common with the flat- faced , characterless light trains of the toy like Docklands Light Railway .
There is still time for GMA ( GEC , Mowlem , Amec and Greater Manchester Buses ) to considerMET employingNONMET an inspired architect or industrial designer .
After all , Mancunians and visitors to the Manchester conurbation are goingNONMET to have to lookNONMET at these mechanical millipedes for  well into the twenty-first century .
Now that buses are no longer designedNONMET to enhanceNONMET the streets they serveMET , Manchester has a chance to makeMET a fresh start with its trams .
Manchester is not alone .
Other British towns , Croydon and Southampton among them , are also consideringMET modern tramways .
These are all referredNONMET to as ‘ supertram ’ networks , the implication being that the new- generation tram is an altogether more dynamic form of transport than its pre-war predecessors .
What it really meansMET is that the new trams are a hybrid between street car and lightweight suburban train .
Although they will slipMET through the city centre servingMET the essential parts — shopping malls , leisure centres , theme parks , amusement arcades and museums — the Manchester supertrams will also headMET out of town on a mix of reserved track and existing railway lines .
The supertram is , in effect , a low replacement for British Rail's ageing fleet of suburban diesel multiple-unit trains , those rasping diesels which change gear to the accompaniment of voluminous clouds of acrid black exhaust fumes and the blessing of train spotters .
They will performMET some of the same functions , but they will not be an exact replacement for traditional trams .
And although the supertram concept will spreadMET through major cities during the next decade , Blackpool will still be alone in its use of traditional double-deckers .
The churches builtNONMET on wool : Angela Lambert enjoysNONMET the riches at the heart of East Anglia By ANGELA LAMBERT UNTIL six or seven years ago , outsiders associated East Anglia with fens , flatness and the vanished Edwardian nannies of Frinton .
Its old churches , green fields and long beaches were cherishedNONMET by the inhabitants of Essex , Suffolk , Norfolk and Cambridgeshire , but not yet on the tourist agenda .
Today , I was toldNONMET , villagers livingNONMET around the great wool churches of Lavenham and Long Melford have to barNONMET their doors and ignoreNONMET the knocking of tourists , who takeMET them for antique shops and offer to buyNONMET their furniture .
The tourists are right .
East Anglia on a sunny weekend is a place of matchless beauty .
Its villages lookNONMET too good to be true .
Lavenham and Long Melford , for example , have no telegraph poles , to preserveMET the timeless air that pervadesMET them .
Yet you only have to readNONMET Ronald Blythe's Akenfield to realiseNONMET that these picturesque , half-timbered cottages , often paintedNONMET the characteristic Essex pink ( pale salmon ) , ochre or spring-leaf green , are more prosperous now than ever in the ‘ real ’ past .
Many are still elaborately decoratedNONMET with pargeting , an ornate , patterned plasterwork practised in this area since the early thirteenth century .
Most of East Anglia's prosperity today is due to City commuters , the second-homes market and tourism .
The ideal hotel from which to exploreNONMET is Dedham Hall , set among tall trees in the Vale of Dedham , lookingMET directly across towards Dedham church on one side and Flatford Mill on the other : both paintedNONMET by Constable .
The hotel lies in five acres of fields and garden , and the Slingos , who ownNONMET it , makeMET the most of their beautiful surroundings by running painting courses for about £200 a week ( including breakfast and dinner ) , or £90 for a long weekend .
These are so popular that you will needNONMET to bookNONMET at least a couple of months in advance .
The other great joy of Dedham Hall is the food .
The Slingos have their own vegetable garden , chickens , ducks , sheep and cows .
Everything is home-grown , home-made and fresh : it tastesNONMET like forgotten food .
If Dedham Hall is fully booked — and it may well be — tryNONMET the best bed-and-breakfast we have ever foundNONMET , just a few miles away at the Old Vicarage , Higham , near Colchester .
It is a rambling Tudor house runMET by John and Margaret Parker , whose breakfast room and drawing room look out over a wonderful walled garden , beyond which fields of grazing cows stretchMET down to the river .
Another hotel that would makeMET a good starting point for a weekend — or longer — in East Anglia is the Black Lion at Long Melford .
It changedMET hands recently and is now runMET by Stephen and Janet Errington .
After dinner there , when the moon was full and low and deep orange , we walkedNONMET up the road from the hotel to Long Melford church .
Its vast walls of flint and glass and Gothic tracery were brilliantly floodlit and the churchyard cat , sleek and black as tar , greetedMET us querulously and ledMET us right round the church and through the gravestones at the back , glimmeringNONMET and pale in the moonlight .
We were quite alone and the great church , the size of a cathedral , was unearthly in its floodlit , moonlit beauty .
Long Melford is one of the wool churches that commemorateMET the wealth of East Anglia in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries .
Another is at Lavenham , 10 minutes ' drive up the road .
Just inside the front porch , a handwritten book is prefacedNONMET with the words ‘ This book has been compiledNONMET that something , more than their mere names , may be knownNONMET of the Lavenham men who gaveMET their lives for their country in the Great War .
’ This is followedMET by 50 or so names , each with a description .
The much-thumbed book is deeply moving , and setsMET the tone for a walk round this glorious building , which has seenMET the christenings , marriages and burials of the folk of the village for more than 600 years .
East Anglia is exceptionally rich in churches and cathedrals .
There are several splendid houses near Long Melford that would makeMET for a gentle afternoon's potter through the rooms and possessions of the rich of a few centuries ago .
The loveliest , to my mind , is Melford Hall , whose charming , octagonal Jacobean gatehouse is reachedNONMET along an avenue of clipped yew trees and , with its high windows floodingMET the octagon with light , is my fantasy of the ideal study .
Lavenham is often calledNONMET the finest medieval village in England .
It is an image of the world we have lostMET , its gently sloping streets convergingNONMET upon the market place .
Here standMET the early sixteenth-century timberedNONMET Guildhall , now a museum to 700 years of the cloth industry .
Next to it is The Little Hall , datingNONMET from the fourteenth century , with its floorboards gleaming with the patina of age , low-beamed ceilings and a tiny , unruly , charming walled garden .
Precisely next   door  to this is a restaurant calledNONMET The Great House .
Here , in the cool , pretty setting of the dining room that was once Stephen Spender's , you will be servedNONMET an exquisite three- course lunch for £9.50 , £6 for children .
The wine list is small but perfectly chosenNONMET .
The service is impeccable .
East Anglia has bookshops filled with titles like 101 Things For A Boy To Do … Constable landscapes … Gainsborough's house … to sayNONMET nothing of huge grey sweeps of empty beach from which , at Aldeburgh , you can buyNONMET goggle-eyed skate direct from the fishing boats as they comeMET out of the water .

A prayer for the brick cathedral facingNONMET St Paul's : Bankside Power Station is a masterpiece worth , preserving , Gavin Stamp arguesNONMET By GAVIN STAMP FROM the top of the dome of St Paul's Cathedral the view is no longer dominatedMET by City church steeples but by an intrusive cacophony of drab , characterless Sixties boxes .
One building stands out in this dispiriting panorama of post-war mediocrity : a dark powerful mass of brickwork with a tall central tower that standsMET right across the Thames from Wren's dome .
This is not an office block , nor a church — although its sublime form might suggestMET that its architect was adept at designingNONMET cathedrals .
It is , in fact , the now redundant oil-fired electric power station that sitsMET on Bankside next to the site of Sam Wanamaker's new Globe Theatre .
Bankside Power Station should never have been builtNONMET .
Its architect had spentMET the war years with fellow Royal Academicians planningNONMET the orderly and spacious London of the future , free of smoke and industry .
But , when askedNONMET in 1947 to replaceNONMET an old dirty power station that had been on the site since 1891 , he soon forgotMET such idealism and , like any architect , was glad to have the job .
The project was controversial and the power station was only permitted providingNONMET the smoke was clean and the building did not challengeMET the visual dominance of St Paul's .
So the single chimney roseMET only to 325ft , some 45ft below the height of the cross above the cathedral .
The irony is that had the tower been higher and had the teak ‘ scrubbers ’ been less efficient , the smoke would have goneMET straight up into the air .
As it was , the ‘ smokeless shimmer of vapour ’ was so cooledNONMET by cleaning that it driftedNONMET across the river to causeNONMET mischief with the leadwork on Wren's great dome .
Bankside Power Station should not have been builtNONMET .
But , as it was builtNONMET , it should not now be demolishedNONMET .
That is because it is a magnificent structure , the supreme architectural expression of the heroic , monumental phase of power station design and the creation of a great architect .
Bankside was the work of Sir Giles Gilbert Scott , OM , the architect of Liverpool's Anglican Cathedral , the rebuilt House of Commons and some of the last vital products of the Gothic Revival .
He was a designer of extraordinary versatility , being responsible for the standard ‘ traditional ’ red telephone kiosk , Waterloo Bridge and several power stations .
Bankside representsNONMET the fullest realisation of his industrial aesthetic .
Scott's first venture into this unlikely field of design was at Battersea where , in 1930 , he was wheeledMET in as a famous knighted architect by the London Power Company to tryNONMET to makeMET acceptable the coal-fired monster power station to which the residents of Chelsea and Westminster were takingMET strong exception .
This was a brilliant move .
Scott was so successful in stylingNONMET the building in fine brickwork with ‘ jazz-modern ’ fluting ( as John Betjeman calledNONMET it ) that , when the Battersea ‘ A ’ station was openedMET in 1934 it was widely acclaimedNONMET as a supremely successful modern treatment of a building type that seemedNONMET quintessentially twentieth century .
When , in 1939 , The Architects ' Journal conductedMET a survey to findMET what were consideredMET the best modern buildings in Britain , Battersea was placedMET second — and was the favourite of such unlikely celebrities as Sir Kenneth Clark , Rebecca West and Charles Laughton .
Scott was so pleased with the style he had evolvedMET at Battersea , a treatment that humanised industrial forms without denyingNONMET their function , that he also used it on the Guinness Factory at Park Royal , west London .
At Battersea , Scott could not alterNONMET the basic design of the building and he much disliked the ‘ upturned table ’ appearance createdNONMET by the four corner chimneys .
At Bankside , however , he was able to persuadeNONMET the engineers , Mott , Hay & Anderson , to gatherMET all the flues into a single ‘ slender tower or campanile ’ .
As a result , he was able to createNONMET a symmetrical , monumental composition of great power .
As at all his power stations , Scott facedMET the building in a fine Worcestershire brick that has weatheredNONMET to a lovely pinky-brown .
But there is nothing homely about the general effect .
Vast overlapping planes of brickwork are modelledNONMET with careful set-backs and subtle bands of detail .
The result is an expression of the monumental aesthetic of the early twentieth century , with strong American overtones .
When the campanile is seenNONMET from a distance , it seemsNONMET to belongNONMET to some strange Expressionist church one has not noticedNONMET before .
Not for nothing were such power stations describedNONMET as ‘ brick cathedrals ’ ; Bankside is the finest manifestation of this tradition .
Now it is redundant .
Smoke shimmers no longer from the tall tower .
But Bankside is nevertheless a sound structure which , like the best mills of the Industrial Revolution , is well worth preserving and is perfectly capable of adaptation for a new commercial use .
Such re-use is , of course , much encouragedMET by a building being listedNONMET , something which , until recently , was not possible with architecture of so recent a date .
Two years ago , however , the Department of the Environment at last beganMET the listing of post-war buildings in England that were more than 30 years old .
Bracken House , the former home of the Financial Times , becameNONMET the first candidate and English Heritage then submitted some 70 recommendations to the Department of the Environment ; these included Bankside .
This , however , was too much for the Government and , usingNONMET the excuse that public opinion was not yet ready to acceptMET the protection of many unpopular modern buildings , Lord Caithness , the Minister of State for the Environment , arbitrarily whittled down English Heritage's list to 18 buildings - excluding Bankside — although it representedNONMET a more traditional approach in the Fifties to the now-unfashionable Modern Movement .
However , Caithness himself stated that this first selection was ‘ in no way a definitive list … I have no doubt that others will be addedNONMET .
The important thing is that the Thirty Year Rule is in force and that we can respondMET to developing perceptions of our times .
’ Earlier this year , in my capacity as chairman of the Thirties Society , I askedNONMET Caithness's successor , Virginia Bottomley , to reconsiderNONMET English Heritage's recommendation of Bankside for listing .
My argument was that , as Michael Heseltine had so boldly listedNONMET Battersea Power Station in 1980 , it was illogical not to protectNONMET a much finer and more complete industrial work by the same architect .
Furthermore , the listing of Battersea had ensuredNONMET the building's survival for conversion to a new use — in that case , as an entertainment centre which the Prime Minister herself had praisedMET and inauguratedNONMET .
After two months ' silence , I was informedNONMET that ministers stoodMET by their decision .
I wroteNONMET back askingMET the reasons for this , pointingMET out that , if any large modern power station deservedMET to be listedNONMET , it was Bankside .
I have receivedNONMET no satisfactory reply .
Of course , I knowNONMET perfectly well why the Department of the Environment declinesMET to listNONMET it .
Listed building procedures might impedeNONMET the full commercial realisation of the site when the electricity industry is privatised .
Furthermore , British Rail has its eyes on the Bankside site for bringingNONMET up the spoil from the tunnel for Channel traffic which it is , so absurdly , drivingMET under the middle of London at astronomical cost .
Listing , in theory , is an objective assessment of architectural or historical importance which does not necessarily preventNONMET demolition .
In the case of Bankside Power Station , the ultimate ‘ temple of power ’ and a masterpiece of industrial architecture by a major twentieth-century British architect , our historic building system is being perverted for purely political reasons .

‘ HER DRESS HANGSNONMET HERE' : DE-FROCKINGMET THE KAHLO CULT Oriana Baddeley The 1990s have witnessedMET a shift in the art establishment's attitudes towards art producedNONMET outside of its traditional parameters .
The work of previously marginalised artists has becomeNONMET an area of rich speculation among art dealers pricedNONMET out of the ‘ modern masters ’ market .
Almost every year has witnessedMET the discovery of new artistic terrain — graffiti art , Soviet art , Australian art , the art of Latin America .
The major auction houses have movedMET with the times and have foundMET new ways of selling works which in both form and content would have provedNONMET an unstable investment a decade ago .
The current status of the work of the Mexican painter Frida Kahlo is a dramatic example of this change .
Once knownNONMET primarily as the wife of Diego Rivera , her reputation outside of Mexico now far supercedesNONMET his : since 1919 , sale room estimates of her work have risenMET from $40,000 to over $1 million , and in 1990 a work by Kahlo brokeMET all records at Sotheby's New York for a Latin American artist .
The enormous rise in the economic value of her work has developedNONMET in tandem with the increased critical and popular response to her particular blend of naive style and incisive content .
While the first wave of popular interest aroseMET with the 1982 Whitechapel exhibition instigatedNONMET by Laura Mulvey and Peter Wollen , it was the publication of Hayden Herrera's biography of Kahlo in 1983 which has ledMET to her current cult status .
Since that date she has been the subject of TV documentaries , a feature film ( ‘ Frida ’ by Paul Leduc ) , a stage play , numerous publications and the inspiration for designer clothing .
In May 1989 Elle magazine ranMET a 16 page feature on Frida Kahlo as the ‘ spirit of Mexico ’ ( Fig. 1 ) , while in Vogue ( Feb. 1990 ) there was a 10 page interpretation of ‘ the romance of Frida Kahlo's Mexico ’ ( Fig. 2 ) .
Almost as a logical outcome of this media blitz , it emergedMET in the summer of 1990 that Madonna , already a devotee of Kahlo's work , was commissioningNONMET a screenplay basedMET on Kahlo's life .
Fig. 1 .
Elle Magazine , May 1989 , p. 18–19 .
As with most artists who have becomeNONMET mythical personalities in the popular imagination , such attention has focusedMET primarily on the anecdotal and tragic details of Kahlo's admittedly fascinating life .
The passionate obsession with her husband Diego Rivera , her flamboyant appearance , but most of all her physical and emotional pain have comeMET to dominateMET responses to her work .
While Kahlo's art helpedMET her to dealMET with the vicissitudes of her life , for most audiences it is her life story which allowsMET access to her art .
In this one can drawMET obvious parallels to the appeal of Van Gogh , a traditionally popular artist recently made fashionable by the media attention generated during the centennial of his death .
The archetypal dropout/spiritualist becameNONMET an appropriate icon for the sixties revival of 1990 ' s long hot summer .
Yet despite the iconic status of Van Gogh's ‘ tragic ’ life , it is the appearance of his work by which he is ultimately signifiedNONMET , his thick impasto brush-stroke , his vibrant yellows , the urgency of his creative drive .
In the case of Kahlo the popular image is of the artist herself , the characteristic brows , the elaborate hair , the Mexican costume ( Fig. 3 ) .
It is primarily her appearance , not the formal language of her art , that has gracedMET the pages of Elle and Vogue magazines .
The Elle feature transposedMET the ‘ Kahlo style ’ to Kahlo lookalikes in contemporary clothing balancedMET around segments of Herrera's biography of the artist .
In the later Vogue piece only the style remained as the far more overtly sexual , Kahloesque models lounged and poutedNONMET in their ‘ Mexican ’ interiors .
There is a poignant irony in the way clothing , which on one level served to hideNONMET Kahlo's broken body , falls or is liftedNONMET by the model to revealNONMET a luxuriantly perfect physique ( Fig. 4 ) .
The visual references in the two magazines are as much from photos of the artist as from her work .
In both features she is also seenMET to embodyNONMET a wider set of assumptions about Mexico itself ; exotic , passionate , yet constantly struggling against pain and deceit .
While Elle , Vogue and subsequently The Independent ( Fig. 5 ) , stressedMET different facets of Kahlo's public persona , they all sharedMET the emphasis on ‘ her ’ , as an encapsulisation of stereotypical images of Mexico , rather than her work .
It is her body as the canvas , her appearance as art .
The art of self-expression becomesNONMET self-expression as art .
Fig. 2 .
Vogue , February 1990 , p. 130–1 .
Fig. 3 .
Elle Magazine , May 1989 , p. 28 .
Of course , the line between art and life is a particularly hard one to drawMET in Kahlo's case .
The majority of her work is self portraiture ; her aesthetic concerns grewMET from her fascination with the falsity of appearance .
Dressing up , role playingNONMET and masquerade form the conceptual basis of Kahlo's work .
In Self-Portrait with Cropped Hair ( 1944 ) ( Fig. 6 ) , she paintsNONMET herself wearingNONMET Rivera's suit , challenging traditional expectations of femininity and attemptingNONMET to appropriateMET his authority ( while simultaneously ) threatening castration ) .
More disturbingly , in The Mask ( 1945 ) ( Fig. 7 ) , she throwsMET doubt on too straightforward a reading of her self-portraits as revealing of her inner emotions .
Where does the mask fallMET : Does not the ritual repetition of those familiar features ‘ mask ’ far more than it uncoversMET ?
There is , however , an inevitable logic to the appropriation of her meticulously constructed image , a process which the artist was mockingNONMET as early as 1933 : ‘ … some of the gringa women are imitatingNONMET me and tryingNONMET to dressNONMET ‘ a la Mexicana ’ , but the poor souls only lookNONMET like cabbages and to tellNONMET you the naked truth they lookNONMET absolutely impossible .
' The ‘ impossibility ’ stemmedMET from the failure of such followers to recogniseMET the symbolic importance of Kahlo's choice of clothing , a failure also intrinsic to her recent magazine appearances .
The particularities of post-revolutionary Mexico are frequently subsumedNONMET by the decorativeness of the ethnic , by the generalised attractiveness of the radical avant-garde .
For Kahlo , however , choosingMET to donNONMET the costume of the Tehuana , as for example in Tree of Hope ( 1946 ) ( Fig. 8 ) , was to embody a powerful icon of cultural identity .
Mexican Indian dress is extraordinarily diverse and by and large geographically specific , varyingNONMET from region to region .
The Tehuana dress is by no means the most decorative variant or the closest to pre-Hispanic forms of clothing .
It is the mythology surroundingMET the women wearers of the costume which directedMET Kahlo's choice .
The ostensibly matriarchal society of Tehuantepec ledMET to the adoption of the Tehuana , in post-revolutionary Mexico , as the image of the strong Indian woman ; the undefeated counterpart to the despised ‘ Chingada ’ , who , conversely is the female embodiment of Mexico's hybrid post-conquest culture .
In a culture where sexual metaphors are frequently usedNONMET to conveyMET racial and political conflict , the Tehuana representsMET that aspect of Mexico's indigenous tradition unbowed by centuries of colonial and male rule .
Kahlo's adoption of Tehuana dress , while being an attractive disguise of what she sawMET as a less than perfect body , assertedMET both a feminist and an anti-colonialist position .

In Kahlo's work there is a powerful mix of these discourses , yet her role as an archetypal woman painter has comeMET to dominateMET responses to her work .
It is through her emergence as a cult painter of the feminist movement of the 1970s that her current reputation has evolvedMET .
Her work almost perfectly illustratesMET debates as to the nature of traditional exclusions of a woman's art .
The fascination with functions of the body , the analogies between artistic and physical creative processes , self-portraiture used to revealMET the female body as the site of patriarchal aesthetic discourse ; all of these mirrorMET the concerns of many women painters of the 1980s .
