In their formal language , Kahlo's works are exemplary of certain feminist arguments ; the adoption of the decorative , the intimate and non -fine art mediums revealsMET the restrictive nature of traditional definitions of ‘ high art ’ .
This ‘ appropriateness ’ of Kahlo's aesthetic to contemporary debate has tendedNONMET to removeMET her work from its historical context , to stressMET the collective and the cross-cultural .
Although this is not in itself to be dismissedMET as a tactic , it has diminishedNONMET the complexity of Kahlo's achievement as a specifically Mexican painter , operatingMET within the particularities of her historical moment .
More problematic is the way in which such a dislocation has ledMET to the acceptance of her ‘ Mexicanness ’ as mere decoration of the essentially feminist themes of her work , thereby defusingMET a substantial part of the art describedNONMET by Breton as a ‘ ribbon round a bomb ’ .
It is the ribbon that runsMET through the pages of Vogue , the glossy surface of the images in direct opposition to a work such as Kahlo's The Suicide of Dorothy Hale ( 1939 ) ( Fig. 9 ) .
In this painting , a memorial to a woman's tragic death is transformedNONMET into an indictment of the culture which destroyedMET her .
Hale's suicide becameNONMET a poignant metaphor for the oppressive nature of the social values of New York and North America in general .
The story behind Hale's death was one with which Kahlo obviously identifiedMET , and within which dress formed an important symbolic function .
Before jumpingNONMET from the window of her apartment , Hale had dressedNONMET meticulously in her most flattering dress , the corsage of yellow roses a gift from a male admirer .
In Kahlo's painting , the figure falls from the fantasy world she has inhabitedMET to the harsh bloodspattered reality of the street , literally comingNONMET down to earth .
Hale's eyes stareMET knowingly at the viewer , a human sacrifice to an alienated and consumerist culture .
The horizontality of her fallen body is juxtaposedNONMET to the vertical thrust of the apartment building .
She leapsMET from an architectural monument to a phallocentric world .
Although destroyedNONMET , she has also escapedNONMET .
The painting , dedicated to Hale's mother , was commissionedNONMET by a mutual friend of Kahlo and Dorothy Hale , the managing editor of Vanity Fair , Clare Boothe Luce .
The painting was agreedNONMET to by Luce in part to recompense for what she sawMET as her misjudgment of her dead friend .
Having lentNONMET Hale money to payNONMET her rent she had been angeredNONMET to discoverMET her spending enormous sums on an haute-couture dress , and refused to turnMET up not PRP but AVP + PRP; phrasal=[turn up] what , in retrospect , becameNONMET Hale's farewell party .
Later it was revealedMET that the money had comeMET from a different source .
A male friend had triedNONMET to dissuadeNONMET Hale from seekingNONMET a much needed job and had givenNONMET her a thousand dollars to buyNONMET ‘ the most beautiful dress in New York ’ , tellingNONMET her that what she neededNONMET was to findNONMET a rich husband .
On one level this work deals with a generalised ‘ woman's experience ’ , yet the metaphorical power of Dorothy Hale's dress derivesMET from Kahlo's use of clothing in her own self-portraits .
DressNONMET not only covers and decoratesNONMET the body but instilsNONMET in the wearer its own characteristic strengths and weaknesses .
Hale's black velvet dress is cursedNONMET because it representsNONMET the values of the ‘ Gringolandia ’ so hated by Kahlo .
In those paintings where Kahlo wearsNONMET European dress she is passive , weak and unable to controlMET her own destiny , but in the Tehuana costume she is strong , powerful , hopeful .
Unclothed , her body becomesNONMET yet more vulnerable , but as Jean Franco statesNONMET : The unclothed body is not a ‘ self but a socialised body , a body that is openedMET by instruments , technologizedMET , wounded , its organs displayedMET to the outside world .
The ‘ inner ’ Frida is controlledMET by modern society far more than the clothed Frida , who often marksMET her deviation from the norm by defiantly returningMET the gaze of the viewer .
Kahlo's naked body becomesNONMET not just the tortured self of her personal biography but a visual counterpart to the injured and defiled manifestations of Mexico's colonised past : La Llorona ‘ the weeping woman ’ of popular myth and La Chingada , the raped and abused mother describedNONMET in Paz's The Labyrinth of Solitude .
DescendedMET from an Aztec mother goddess , Llorona is a long-suffering mother figure , symbolic in a wider sense of the trauma of the Spanish invasion .
Driven mad with grief by the loss of her child , she is thoughtNONMET to wanderNONMET the streets weeping and  cryingNONMET out a ghostly memory of the pre-Conquest past .
At its most simple , La Chingada , as the mother of Mestizo culture is ‘ the Mother forcibly opened , violated or deceivedNONMET ’ .
The female soil possessed and misusedMET by the masculine force of the Spanish invaders .
The Indian Mexico raped and abusedMET by the conquistador yet bearingMET his bastard child .
The rhetoric of the Tehuana opposesMET the nihilism of traditional feminisations of colonial trauma , and assertsMET the potential of a dignified cultural resistance .

A major , though often ignoredNONMET , work by Kahlo demonstratesMET the cultural politics underlyingNONMET her art .
My Dress HangsNONMET There ( 1939 ) ( Fig. 10 ) is one of the artist ’ s most formally adventurous works , mixingMET photographic collage with paint to produceMET a critique of North American culture .
Kahlo does not appearNONMET in the work , her Tehuana costume hangsNONMET empty in the centre of the composition , suspended between a toilet bowl and a golfing trophy .
On one level My Dress … is a coda to Self-Portrait on the Borderline ( 1932 ) ( Fig. 11 ) of the previous year .
This small painting on metal , in the style of a Catholic votive image , showsMET the artist poisedMET between the technological inhumanity of a capitalist North America and the archaic fertility of Mexico .
InterwovenMET with these images are subtler references to the metaphorical borderlines which separateMET Latin American culture from that of Europe and North America .
This is done by a series of juxtapositions ; the past versus the present ; female nature versus masculine technology ; growth versus exploitation ; and in its very material presence , the traditions of fine art versus the popular .
At the same time the ambivalence of her own , and modern Mexico's position is manifestedNONMET in the figure of the artist .
The paper flag of her homeland is contrastedNONMET to the modernity of the cigarette held in her other hand .
The red and green of the Aztec necklace linksMET it compositionally with the indigenous plants to the ‘ south ’ of the painting , the pink colonial-style dress tonally blendingMET with the skyscrapers to the ‘ north ’ .
My Dress … again suggestsMET a conflict , but the ambivalence is goneMET .
Nature has been banishedMET , technology and its concomitant values reign over a harshly masculine world .
Three elements referMET to the female presence , all of them dealingMET with an essential lack .
The empty dress , a peeling poster of Mae West and in the far distance the Statue of Liberty .

The physicality so characteristic of Kahlo's work is missing , no flesh , no blood , just the tawdriness of the peeling poster and the hollow reminder of lost Liberty .

The US setsMET its compass on two trading oceans Notebook .
By Edited by Alex Brummer CANBERRA may seemNONMET an awful long way from exchanges on the floor of the House of Commons over the European Monetary System .
But were it not for the  perceived economic might of a more unified Economic Community , the dozen or so nations of the Pacific Rim , who have been meetingMET in Australia , might not have botheredMET .
The first , albeit tenative , steps towards formingMET a new Pacific-based economic union display an astute awareness of the way events are movingMET within Europe : movements with which Number 10 has yet to comeMET to grips .
Not so long ago it seemedNONMET as if the world was to divideMET into three main trading blocks : the EC basedMET around the West German economy ; a Northern American block basedMET around the US-Canadian free trade area , and a Pacific unit incorporatingNONMET the Asian tigers with Japan and the yen at the centre .
But the Metternich-like skills of the US Secretary of State , Mr James Baker , are ensuringNONMET that America maintainsMET a strong stake in each forum .
It firstly boldly askedMET for a seat at the top table at the European Community : a suggestion rudely rebuffedNONMET .
The US has talkedMET of a genuine North American free trade zone incorporatingNONMET the US , Canada and Mexico which would have the best of all worlds with high skills and a cheap labour force south of the Rio Grande .
Now it is makingMET a third bid for influence .
It has turnedMET up in Canberra with Japan to  developNONMET Asia Pacific Economic Co-operation ( APEC ) and a new 12-nation organisation which will mimicMET the role of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development in Europe .
Preliminary steps takenMET to conductMET studies on trade , technology and investment flows in the region may seemNONMET insignificant .
But Mr Baker plainly viewsMET it as otherwise .
He notedMET that the Canberra meeting ‘ is the start of something which could growMET into a very significant development not only for the region but for the global economy .
’ If the more economically puny ASEAN countries ( Indonesia , Malaysia , Singapore , Brunei , Thailand and the Philippines ) were to buryMET their reservations , then the high growth from other partners , including such tigers as Thailand and South Korea alongside the more mature economies of Japan and Australia , could meanNONMET a dynamic coalition .
It would then be up to the US and Canada to decideMET whether they wantNONMET to faceMET towards the Atlantic or Pacific — or be caughtMET between two great trading oceans .

THE QUESTION of just who would even wantNONMET to be a partner with the US was underlinedMET last night as the American Administration headedMET for default for the first time in its history .

22COMMENT THE GUARDIANWednesday November 8 1989 More than just another disaster .
THIRTY FIVE people diedNONMET and others were maimedNONMET for life in the Clapham rail disaster in December last year because work was done in a slovenly , haphazard way and was then leftMET unchecked .
The disaster was all the more stunning because people had comeMET to assumeMET that such things didn't happenNONMET .
In most years , rail deaths are few : in some there are none at all .
Clapham , indeed , accountsNONMET for nearly half the 77 fatalities of the last ten years : compareNONMET that with the 5,000 deaths and 300,000 injuries every year on the roads .
Yet yesterday's report on the Clapham crash , confirming the picture which emergedMET throughout the Hidden inquiry , makesMET an event which seemedNONMET at the time totally unexpected look almost inevitable .
This was a system hopelessly under strain .
Under strain for a start because it was technically ill-equipped to avertMET disaster or to copeMET with the consequences when disaster struck ; under strain from commercial pressures which , as the inquiry putsMET it , ‘ compromised ’ safety ; under strain above all because the people on the spot couldn't or wouldn't copeNONMET , were weary from gruesome working hours ( the senior signal technician who headsMET the list of the culpable had had only one day off in the past 13 weeks ) , lackedNONMET adequate training , or simply couldn't be bothered .
The bulk of the blame for all that is placedMET on British Rail , which knowingly permitted these things to continue .
Though individuals are nailedMET , the greatest villain of all is the system .
In a desperately competitive climate , where anyone bright and competent could goMET down the road and pickMET up a better paid job with kinder hours and more congenial working conditions from someone like British Telecom , the railways ranMET a service dependent on people who belongedNONMET to a narrow and inbred working culture , with outdated procedures of training and promotion , and an institutional reliance on overtime workingNONMET , whose wholly disgraceful dimensions are symbolisedMET by the fact that maximum weekly hours were only recently cutMET to 72 hours a week .
The Transport Secretary , Mr Cecil Parkinson , assuredNONMET the Commons yesterday that financial considerations would not standMET in the way of implementingNONMET Sir Anthony Hidden's 93 recommendations .
On the technical side ,  remedial work is in many cases already on the way .
But the  job of liftingMET the standards of people employed , givingMET them  proper training , and payingNONMET a wage which breaksMET dependence on overtime and liftsMET morale : this together must far exceedMET the costs of the technology , and it isn't by any means clearMET what the bill will be or where the money will comeMET from .
All of which is not just a problem for a properly penitent British Rail : it's a problem for government too .
Government fixesMET the format in which BR has to workMET ; and if , as the Hidden report attestsMET , many of its problems today reflectMET lack of past planning , lack of farsighted investment , livingMET from hand to mouth , then that is not just BR's doing .
Government compoundsMET all these problems when it setsMET down working parameters which failMET to reflectMET the value the country getsMET from a system that is runMET efficiently , can shiftMET people to destinations with exemplary speed and safety — as Europe consistently demonstratesMET .

THE nation's ambulance service was in manifest chaos yesterday .
There was no service in London , with all 71 stations and 455 vehicles off the road .
The only accident and emergency relief was providedNONMET by the police , part-time St John ambulance volunteers runningNONMET 20 vehicles , and the Red Cross .
Outside the capital , accident and emergency services were being providedNONMET in most areas , but the ban on emergency work was tightenedMET .
The service was facingMET its biggest crisis since the ambulances cameMET to a stop in the Winter of Discontent ten years ago .
Like Labour in 1979 , the Conservatives have putMET military ambulances on standby .
They move in today .
What has goneMET wrong ?
There are three key causes of the shambles : Mr Kenneth Clarke ; the failure to separateMET emergency from non-emergency work ; and the Whitley Council negotiating machinery .
The Health Secretary accusedMET the unions of ‘ posturing and pretendingMET ’ to runMET a 999 service yesterday .
He was right .

The move was signalledMET last week and , true to their promised response , management suspendedMET the workers involved in the disruption .

Yet it was Mr Clarke , not Mr Nichol , who was involved in the critical decisions — the cash limit for the NHS , the 6.5 per cent offer to ambulance workers ( comparedMET to seven per cent for nurses , eight per cent for doctors and nine per cent for ancillary workers ) ; and today's introduction of military ambulances .
Ambulance workers on emergency work do deserveNONMET a much higher increase .
They have progressedMET far beyond routine first aid .
Their paramedical skills coverMET highly technical procedures : intubation , infusion and defebrillation .
The crews are able to resuscitateNONMET heart attack patients , replaceNONMET fluid intraveneously after severe blood loss , and insert tubes to maintainNONMET air supplies in unconconscious casualties .
Yet the ambulance worker is only being offeredNONMET £10,000 , when a fire officer is being givenNONMET £13,000 and a Metropolitan police constable can earnNONMET £25,000 .
But only two million out of the 20 million journeys which ambulance crews carryMET out each year are emergency  calls .
Nine out of 10 are routine calls , many of which could be carriedMET out by mini cabs .
Mr Duncan Nichol wantsNONMET to separateMET the emergency from the non-emergency work .
He is right to pursueMET this line .
Wiltshire and Northumbria have already shownMET how much can be achievedNONMET .
The ramshackle Whitley Council negotiating machinery is the other reason why the ambulance workers have lost out .
Until this year , the three independent review bodies which makeMET recommendations for nurses , doctors and the professions alliedMET to medicine have givenMET much higher awards than the Whitley Councils .
As Lord McCarthy notedMET some 13 years ago , the management side of the councils compriseNONMET ‘ employers who do not payNONMET and paymasters who do not employNONMET .
’ A much more flexible system which would allowMET local managers to negotiateNONMET local rates — on a national pay spine — is neededNONMET .
A crisis ; an agenda for reform and honesty .
One Mr Clarke can not duckMET away from if he wantsNONMET to avoidMET a second Winter of Discontent .. Opening , closing .

Parliament urged to thinkMET again on housing issue : .
Queen's Bench Divisional Court Sandwell Metropolitan Borough Council v Bujok Before Lord Justice Watkins and Mr Justice Hutchison November 2 1989 IF a dwelling house is in such a state of disrepair as to be prejudicial to health or a nuisance , the tenant may layMET an information against his landlord allegingNONMET the existence of a statutory nuisance under the Public Health Act 1936 .
The tenant is not obliged to ensureNONMET that the landlord is aware of the defects in the premises or to giveMET the landlord an opportunity to remedyNONMET the defects before commencingNONMET legal proceedings .
Although that is the position in law , the court emphasisedMET that as a matter of common sense a tenant should first complainNONMET to the landlord before exercisingMET the right to prosecuteNONMET .
The facts .
Mrs Bujok and her family occupiedNONMET a house as council tenants .
In September 1988 Mrs Bujok laidMET an information against the council allegingNONMET the existence and continuance of a statutory nuisance under section 92(1) of the Public Health Act 1936 .
It was allegedNONMET that the council , being the owners of the premises , were the persons by whose act , default or sufferance the nuisance aroseMET .
Prior to layingMET the information Mrs Bujok had not servedMET an abatement notice upon the council or informedNONMET them of the alleged defects in the premises .
The justices heldMET Mrs Bujok was not requiredNONMET to ensureNONMET that the council were aware of the defective state of the property prior to layingMET the information .
The council appealedMET by case stated .
The legislation .
Section 92(1) of the 1936 Act definesMET ‘ statutory nuisances ’ as ‘ any premises in such a state as to be prejudicial to health or a nuisance ’ .
The decision .
Mr Justice Hutchison saidNONMET the 1936 Act primarily envisagesMET a system where the local authority has a power and a duty to tryMET to secureMET that premises are not in a state which constitutesNONMET a statutory nuisance .
Action is initiatedMET by the service of an abatement notice requiringNONMET remedial work .
If the person in default failsNONMET to complyNONMET with an abatement notice the local authority is obliged to makeMET a complaint to the magistrates .
If the complaint is provedNONMET , a nuisance order is madeMET requiringNONMET the defendant to getMET the necessary work done .
Effectively the sequence is that the person in default is toldNONMET what is wrong and is requiredNONMET to putMET it right .
He is givenMET an opportunity to do so , and if he does not , he is subject to sanctions by the court to compelNONMET him to do so .
The problem arisesMET in connection with section 99 which adaptsMET or appliesMET the provisions to cases where an individual rather than the local authority wishesNONMET to makeMET the complaint .
Need he serveMET an abatement notice ?
The authorities plainly establishNONMET that he need not and can not do so .
Does that meanMET he may layMET an information and bringMET the matter before the magistrates without first puttingMET the person alleged to be in default on notice of what is alleged ?
The council arguedMET that a landlord , particularly one such as a local authority , can not realistically be expectedNONMET to have a system of inspection of all its premises and in practice is entitled to dependNONMET upon notification by its tenants .
For Mrs Bujok it was arguedNONMET that the 1936 Act was designedMET to secureMET in the interests of the community at large that statutory nuisances did not existNONMET .
It was submittedNONMET that an owner can not turnMET his back on his property because when he purchasesNONMET and >takes on the responsibility of letting , he knowsNONMET the property will in the course of time deteriorateNONMET .
He must therefore satisfyNONMET himself on a regular basis that it does not constituteNONMET a statutory nuisance .
In Warner v Lambeth London Borough Council ( 1985 ) 15 HLR 45 , 50 , Lord Justice Glidewell saidNONMET a private person could layMET an information allegingNONMET the failure to abateNONMET a statutory nuisance without first giving notice requiringNONMET abatement .
Therefore in the present case the justices cameMET to the correct conclusion .
His Lordship reachedMET that decision without enthusiasm because it seemedNONMET that as a matter of common sense , notice should be givenMET in such circumstances before criminal proceedings were launchedMET .
Lord Justice Watkins saidNONMET he agreedNONMET with reluctance .
It was surely repugnant to common sense that in this area of legal activity a local authority should be prosecutedNONMET by one of its tenants without first being givenMET the opportunity by that tenant to remedyNONMET the consequences of a neglect to repairNONMET the dwelling that the tenant occupiedNONMET .
In law there was no doubt that Mrs Bujok was entitled to commenceNONMET proceedings without givingMET notice of the state of the dwelling to the council .
But in every other conceivable way that action was entirely wrong .
Endless trouble to many people in courts and council offices and much money could be savedMET by the giving of notice of disrepair .
If the council did not reactMET to that notice , then would be the time for the tenant to exerciseMET the right to prosecuteNONMET .
Parliament should giveMET fresh thought to enactingMET a provision placingMET an obligation upon a council tenant to giveMET notice to the council before being permittedNONMET to commenceNONMET proceedings .
Appearances : John Cherryman QC instructedNONMET by Sherwood & Co for the council ; Elizabeth Norman instructedNONMET by Michael Arnold & Co , Oldbury , for Mrs Bujok .

Referee : R Gifford ( Llandradach ) .. Prototyping is crucial to systems development , arguesNONMET Ian Richards TailoredMET to fitMET .
IN SYSTEMS development nothing is more fundamental than assessing user requirements .
If you don't knowNONMET what the system is requiredNONMET to do ; you don't knowNONMET anything .
But many system developers are unable to assessMET requirements properly .
They seemNONMET to thinkNONMET that you can askNONMET a businessman what his requirements are and getMET an answer that amountsMET to a draft system specification .
A doctor doesn't ask his patient what treatment to prescribe .
The patient can explain only what the problem is .
It is the doctor that provides the remedy .
If you askNONMET a user what sort of system he wantsNONMET you will be metMET with a blank look .
A user may have a deep knowledge of business problems , but knowingNONMET little about computers , has no idea how they should be tackledMET .
Yet , analysts are heardNONMET askingNONMET time and again , ‘ TellNONMET me what you wantNONMET .
We've goneMET away from the days of systems imposedMET by the  data processing department , this is goingNONMET to be a system for the users .
’ But of course the users don't knowNONMET what they wantNONMET , so they end up gettingNONMET another duff system .
An effective analyst providesNONMET the same service to the business as the doctor provides to the patient .
He finds out what the needs of the business are , and prescribesMET the cure .
The user tellsNONMET the analyst what the problems are , and the analyst decidesNONMET , at least in broad terms , what the user requiresNONMET .
But the analyst has one great advantage over the doctor .
Once the user becomesNONMET familiar with the proposed system , helpful comments comeMET thick and fast .
‘ Oh , this will be of great help in orderingNONMET raw materials , but sometimes we getNONMET part deliveries , could we have an extra facility to dealMET with those ?
And sometimes non-standard discount is givenMET , a pig to dealMET with on the old system , but if you could addNONMET one extra input box on that screen there … And what about orders not deliveredNONMET on time ?
If we could listNONMET those we'd have advance warning of shortage problems on the assembly lines two months before they occurNONMET .
Now that would be a great leap forward .
’ Unfortunately you can not reachMET this stage until you have developedNONMET a prototype system .
And you can't developNONMET a prototype system because the users haven't gotMET a clue what they wantNONMET .
Most of them are probably muttering , ‘ I'm too busy to getNONMET involved in this sort of thing .
What's wrong with the old system anyway ?
’ The only way to developNONMET a prototype is for the analyst to getMET inside the head of the user and , thinkingNONMET like a user , decideNONMET what sort of system is requiredNONMET .
Of course , the initial system will not be perfect .
The analyst can not hopeNONMET to understandNONMET the business as well in a few weeks as the user does after many years .
But once the user seesMET the system , channels of communication will openMET .
Instead of persuadingNONMET the user to specifyNONMET requirements , the analyst will be drivenMET by the user to meetMET key needs .
Good system development goesMET through two distinct phases .
Initially the analyst does all the work , leadingMET the user towards a system he thinksNONMET is right for the business .
But once the user seesMET the potential of the system , a change in attitude takesMET place .
The process becomesNONMET demand drivenNONMET by the user .
The analyst is then forcedMET on the defensive , explainingNONMET why new features can not be includedNONMET because they are technically difficult or prohibitively expensive .
Traditionally , systems were validatedNONMET by users agreeingNONMET functional specifications .
In theory , validation meantMET that the user had readNONMET the specification , imaginedNONMET how the system would workMET in practice , and agreedNONMET the design .
It was only when usingNONMET a ‘ test ’ version of the system ( available just before the planned implementation date ) that difficulties would comeMET to light , and a host of change requests be issuedNONMET .
The advent of fourth generation languages ( 4GLs ) has madeMET system development much easier .
With a 4GL an initial prototype can be putMET together quickly .
This meansMET feedback is obtainedNONMET early in the development process , and the system can growMET around the user's requirements .
Crucial to the development process is the relationship builtMET up between the analyst and the user .
The best systems ariseMET when both have a deep understanding of each other's jobs .
Many developers use business analysts to ensureNONMET that the development team maintainMET a proper focus on business requirements .
But this can be counter-productive , as it cutsMET off communication between the systems analyst and the user .
Too much specialisation is bad for systems development ; it feedsMET the temptation to getNONMET engrossedNONMET in technical difficulties and forgetNONMET about the underlying business needs .
If you should strollNONMET into a pub and meetNONMET an analyst and a user talkingNONMET about work , and you can not tellMET one from the other , they have probably developedNONMET a successful system together .
Ian Richards ' book , How to UseNONMET a Computer to ImproveNONMET Your Business , has just been publishedNONMET by Graham & Trotman ( £8.95 paperback ; £16 hardback ) .

PAGE Edoardo Amaldi .
Ragazzi of distinction : .
IN December , 1943 , the men workingNONMET feverishly to createNONMET the first American atomic bomb sentNONMET a team of ‘ spooks ’ to Naples .
One of their main assignments was to contactNONMET Edoardo Amaldi , a physicist thoughtNONMET to be in hidingNONMET near Rome .
Six months later , the day before Rome's liberation by the Allies , Amaldi was foundNONMET .
He was interviewedNONMET by Moe Berg , then one of the most famous baseball players in America .
Berg was also an agent of the Office of Strategic Services , which was later to giveMET birth to the CIA .
His job was to convinceNONMET Amaldi to packMET his bags because there was a ship waitingMET at Naples to takeMET him to the United States .
Amaldi's presence there had been soughtNONMET by two other Italian colleagues , also physicists .
His mentor , Enrico Fermi , later to be calledNONMET ‘ the father of the bomb ’ , and Emilio Segre ( who diedNONMET in California earlier this year ) .
Amaldi dodgedMET the American invitation , perhaps because ( with Rome liberated ) Fermi's mantle in physics had fallenMET on his young shoulders and there were younger minds to teachMET .
He woreMET that mantle well at Rome University until his retirement in 1978 .
But Amaldi never really retired nor grewNONMET old .
He keptMET regular hours in the university's physics building , spokeNONMET at scientific meetings this year in Moscow and Washington .
As President of the Accademia Nazionale dei Lincei he had deliveredMET the welcoming address on Tuesday to a symposium of scientists .
He then orderedNONMET a car to callMET for him the next morning for a similar occasion and was felledMET by a stroke while waitingNONMET for the lift .
Amaldi grew up in a small town in Lombardy , and tookMET his doctorate in physics from Rome at the remarkably early age of 21 .
In 1929 , he becameNONMET one of the ragazzi di Via Panisperna — the street where Fermi's ‘ kids ’ carried out their own experiments under the master in their own under-financedNONMET lab .
Emilio Segre was one kid , and Bruno Pontecorvo , later to defectNONMET from Britain to the Soviet Union , another .
It is interesting to noteMET that the ‘ pope ’ — as the kids called Fermi — ‘ because he's always right ’ , was only seven years older than Amaldi .
Amaldi astoundedMET his group in October 1934 with his discovery that by slowing down , rather than accelerating , neutrons , he could provokeMET intense nuclear reactions .
He heldMET a chair in physics from 1937 until his retirement publishing more than 150 papers on atomic and nuclear physics .
He was awardedMET honorary degrees by Algiers , Glasgow and Oxford .
He becameNONMET a founder , and active executive , of the European Centre for Nuclear Research in Geneva .
I had the pleasure of two long talks last year with Professor Amaldi about his knowledge of what the German physicists were doing with their atoms during the war years .
Apart for his incongruously white hair , Amaldi seemedNONMET to have the mental lucidity and expected energy of a man half his age .
His modesty , consideringNONMET his world-wide fame in his field , was endearing .
I knewNONMET almost nothing about physics but we sharedMET some jokes about the Rome telephone system .
In 1949 , Amaldi wroteNONMET to the Italian prime minister askingMET for permission to produceNONMET and sellNONMET sealing wax for letters , ‘ so that we may raiseMET neededNONMET funds for our physics lab ’ .
The reply cameMET from an under-secretary who saidMET that the present funding was consideredNONMET adequate and the commercial undertaking would be ill-advised .
It was signedNONMET by Giulio Andreotti , the present prime minister .
George Armstrong Edoardo Amaldi , born Carpaneto Piacentino September 5 , 1908 ; diedNONMET Rome , December 5 , 1989 .
Midwife at the birth of a state .
THE INTIFADA is a people's unarmed revolution against occupation .
Its two main slogans , repeatedNONMET countless times in the directives issuedMET by the underground leadership , are freedom and independence .
It has employedMET a dual strategy to achieveNONMET these two objectives .
First , a comprehensive civil disobedience campaign was begunNONMET by which people severed , or minimised , all the contact points by which they were boundMET to the Israeli occupation authority .
This campaign includedNONMET resignations of Palestinian officials from public posts , the boycott of Israeli goods and products , and the refusal to payNONMET taxes and fines .
Partial and full strikes , demonstrations , sit-ins , conventions … all these have in fact only constituted the outer layer of an inner mechanism of civilian rebellion .
The second , and complementary , part of the Intifada strategy concentrated on the construction of an indigenous national authority .
As Israel's authority was being liftedMET , the population beganNONMET  creatingNONMET an alternative authority of their own .
Popular committees were establishedNONMET in villages , refugee camps , suburbs , streets , in fact in every community .
Some headway was madeMET in expanding self-sufficiency , whether through utilisingNONMET more land for agriculture , developing home economies , or encouraging local manufacturers and products .
Villages and refugee camps were thus being  developedNONMET into ‘ liberated ’ or ‘ independent ’ areas , if not militarily , then at least psychologically , politically and infrastructurally .
Bloody clashes would occurNONMET whenever armoured units raidedNONMET these villages , stormingNONMET through makeshift defensive road blocks and respondingMET to rocks being thrownNONMET with live bullets and tear gas ; but no sooner would these army units be goneMET than authority would revertNONMET to the village residents .
Palestinian flags would be raisedNONMET on minarets and church spires , road blocks would again be erectedNONMET , and life in all its aspects would once again be runMET by the local leadership .
The structure of the developing national authority has been both diffuse enough to preventNONMET it from being destroyedMET by any one single sweep of arrests ( there have been more than 50,000 arrests since the Intifada's outbreak ) , and coherent enough to allowMET for the existence of a unified resistance strategy .
While the entire network of popular committees , local institutions and the general public constitute the field commanders in the battle of civilian disobedience and of constructingMET a political infrastructure , a rotating Unified National Command acts in the role of field-general , issuingNONMET a bi-monthly directive outliningMET policy and determining specific resistance programmes .
A high level of mobility in the structure allowsMET for continuous interchange of roles and ideas , and retainsMET for the Unified National Command the closeness to grass roots that is requiredNONMET to makeMET it truly reflectMET people's wishes and sentiments .
THIS expanded network of popular committees and institutions makingMET up the Unified leadership is infusedMET by tens of thousands of activists who belongMET to , or identifyMET with , the different factions of the PLO .
In effect , therefore , the PLO existsMET at all levels of organisation within the occupied territories .
Thus the Palestinian national movement both inside and outside the occupied territories is an organic whole .
The pattern of the Intifada has been cyclical .
Thrusts of resistance ( mass demonstrations , resignations , tax rebellions , etc ) would comeMET in crests .
The pattern is determinedNONMET by a wide variety of factors , including what the Israeli army does .
But the relation is complex , not uni- directional .
Harsh measures — puttingMET an entire community under an absolute curfew for a continuous lengthy period of time , demolishingNONMET homes , uprootingNONMET olive or citrus trees , physical intimidation and terror  tactics employedMET by raiding army units , shooting , killingNONMET , cuttingMET off water or electricity supplies and telephone links to villages or towns , mass arrests , intimidatory interrogation techniques — can either  createNONMET a temporary lull or activateMET an eruption .
The army never knowsMET which it will be .
It is as if it is walking through a minefield .
The wave like pattern of the Intifada , its pains and sufferings , are all reminiscent of the process of birth .
The metaphor is apt , as Palestinians regardMET themselves as engaging in a process of givingMET birth to their independent Palestinian state .
Through their revolution , the masses are both mother and midwife to the birth of this state .
The Intifada is the midwife of freedom .
Through it , Palestinians are strugglingMET on a daily basis to shakeMET off Israel's authority and to constructMET their own .
The struggle reflectsMET a revolution in mass consciousness , by which people have comeMET to realiseNONMET that ideas and aspirations must be embodiedNONMET in manifest acts if reality is to be changedMET .

In this process of state building , many stages have been coveredMET .
The Declaration of Independence issuedMET by the Palestine National Council ( PNC ) on November 15 last year constitutesNONMET a major landmark along this road .
Its significance lies in its double message : that the aim of the Palestinian struggle is the establishment of Palestinian independence , and that this independence is regardedMET as being not at Israel's expense .
This has been a constant theme of Intifada policy : that we wishNONMET to buildMET ( Palestine ) , not to destroyMET ( Israel ) ; that we wishNONMET to achieveNONMET freedom ( for our people ) , not to depriveNONMET others ( Israelis ) of it ; that we wishNONMET to protectNONMET and saveNONMET lives ( ours ) , not to endangerNONMET the lives of others ( Israelis ) .

How can the process of state building be developedNONMET ?
If the PNC Declaration of Independence constitutedNONMET a major landmark in this process , the time has comeMET to embarkMET on another major step , that of declaringMET the setting up of a state or government structure .
AN ESCALATION of the Intifada in this direction would serveMET two purposes at once .
First , it would consolidateMET the structures of the developing national authority which is competing to replaceMET the occupation authority .
Second , it would consolidateMET the image and essence of the Intifada as a constructive , not a destructive , force .
Naturally , to embarkMET on such a step is not necessarily to succeedNONMET immediately in realisingNONMET it .

Arresting or deportingNONMET the tens of thousands of Palestinian professionals who would be employedNONMET in perfectly apolitical , harmless and humanitarian jobs can only further isolateMET the Israeli Government .

HOMICIDE This chapter deals with the approach of the criminal law to behaviour which causesNONMET or risks causingNONMET death .
Murder , manslaughter , and several other offences are discussedMET , and one recurrent issue here is whether English law respondsMET proportionately to the different degrees of culpability manifested in cases where death is causedNONMET .
7.1 DEATH AND FINALITY For practical purposes , the culpable causingNONMET of another person's death may fairly be regardedMET as the most serious offence in the criminal calendar .
There is an argument that treason is a more serious offence , since it strikesMET at the very foundations of the State and its social organizations , but treason is so rare that it is surely permissible to treatNONMET homicide as the most serious form of crime .
The reason for this is not difficult to findMET : the harm causedNONMET by many other crimes is remediable to a degree , whereas the harm causedNONMET by homicide is absolutely irremediable .
Even in crimes of violence which leaveMET some permanent physical disfigurement or psychological effects , the victim retainsMET his or her life and , therefore , the possibility of further pleasures and achievements , whereas death is final .
This finality makesMET it proper to regardMET death as the most serious harm that may be inflictedNONMET on another , and to regardMET a person who choosesNONMET to inflictNONMET that harm as the most culpable of offenders , in the absence of some excuse or justification .
Although many deaths ariseMET from natural causes , and many others from illnesses and diseases , each year seesMET a large number of deaths causedNONMET by ‘ accidents ’ , and also a number causedNONMET by acts or omissions which amountMET to some form of homicide in English law .
For 1987 the statistics showMET that there were some 20,000 accidental deaths , of which some 7,000 occurredNONMET in the home , 6,000 at work , and 5,000 on the roads .
By comparison , the number of deaths recorded as criminal homicide was 600 , which includesMET all the murders and manslaughters .
This figure is relatively small when comparedNONMET with many American cities , but that is no cause for satisfaction .
There are still awkward questions to be confrontedMET .
For example , are we satisfiedNONMET that the 600 deaths recorded as homicide are in fact more culpable than all , or even most , of the deaths recorded as accidents ?
In other words , does English criminal law pickMET out the most heinous forms of killingNONMET as murders and manslaughters , or are the boundaries frozenMET by tradition ?
Another question is whether the criminal law ought not to be wider in its application to activities which carryMET some risk of causingNONMET death than in other spheres .
Thus , even if it would be excessive to sweepMET large numbers of the deaths now recorded as ‘ accidents ’ into the law of homicide , there may be sufficient justification for creatingMET or enforcing offences designedMET to ensureNONMET safe conditions of work , safe goods , safe buildings , and so on .
It was arguedNONMET in Chapter 2 that the criminal law ought to spreadMET its net wider where the potential harm is greater .
It will be seenMET that English law does this up to a point , and in the process seemsNONMET to acceptMET social -defence arguments as reasons for departingMET from several of the principles setMET out in Chapter 3 .
7.2 REQUIREMENTS OF CRIMINAL HOMICIDE English law distinguishesMET between the offences of murder and manslaughter , as we shall seeNONMET , but the two crimes do have certain common elements .
It must be provedNONMET that the defendant's act or omission causedNONMET the death of the victim within a year and a day .
( The requirements of causation in the criminal law are discussedMET elsewhere .
) The ‘ year and a day ’ rule is a legacy of times when medical science was so rudimentary that , if there was a substantial lapse of time between injury and death , it was unsafe to pronounceMET on whether the defendant's conduct or some other event causedNONMET the death .
Nowadays the problem is quite the reverse : medical science is generally able to determineMET whether D's conductNONMET causedNONMET the death , and innovations such as life -support machines meanNONMET that life can be prolongedNONMET for months and years in some instances .
In one recent case the victim of a stabbing diedNONMET two and a half years after the incident , having been keptMET on a life- support machine for almost the entire time .
In principle , it seemsNONMET unjust that a homicide conviction should not be possible in such a case , if all the other elements can be establishedNONMET and only the ‘ year and a day ’ rule stands in the way .
But the rule was confirmedNONMET by the Criminal Law Revision Committee in 1980 , on the ground that a defendant should not be leftMET in peril of a homicide conviction indefinitely .
Surely prosecutorial discretion should be enough to preventNONMET unfair convictions years after the event .
The rule itself is out accord with modern medical conditions and should be abolishedNONMET .
DEFINING MURDER : THE INCLUSIONARY QUESTION ( a ) The Procedural Context If causingNONMET death is to be regardedMET as the most serious harm that can be inflictedNONMET , it would seemNONMET to followMET that the most blameworthy form of homicide should resultNONMET in the highest sentences imposedMET by the courts .
Indeed , many systems of criminal law imposeMET a mandatory sentence for murder ( or whatever the highest form of homicide is calledMET in that system ) .
In some jurisdictions this is a mandatory sentence of death .
In others , such as those in the United Kingdom , it is the mandatory sentence of life imprisonment .
Why should this penalty be mandatory , and not at the discretion of the court as in other offences ?
One argument in favour of the mandatory sentence of life imprisonment is that it amountsMET to a symbolic indication of the unique heinousness of murder .
It placesMET the offender under the State's control , as it were , for the remainder of his or her life .
This is often linkedMET with a supposed denunciatory effect — the idea that the mandatory life sentence denouncesMET murder as emphatically as possible — and with a supposed general deterrent effect , in declaringMET that there is no mitigation of sentence available for this crime .
It might also be arguedNONMET that the mandatory life sentence makesMET a substantial contribution to public safety .
None of these arguments is notably strong , let alone conclusive .
The mandatory penalty does indeed serveMET to markMET out murder from other crimes , but whether the definition of murder is sufficiently refined to captureMET the worst killings , and only the worst killings , remainsMET to be discussedMET below .
Whether the life sentence is regardedMET as a sufficient denunciation in society dependsNONMET on the public's perception of what life imprisonment meansNONMET : if it is widely believed that it resultsNONMET in an average of nine years ' imprisonment , the effect will be somewhat blunted .
The same appliesNONMET to the general deterrent argument : its effectiveness dependsNONMET on whether the penalty for murder affectsNONMET the calculations of potential killers at all , and , if it does , whether life imprisonment is seenMET as significantly more or less severe than the alternative of a long , fixed- sentence .
As for public protection , this dependsNONMET on executive decisions with regard to release ; it failsMET to takeMET into account whether it is necessary for public protection to keepNONMET ‘ lifers ’ in for so long .
This bringsMET the discussion to a crucial point : what does the sentence of life imprisonment mean in practice , and what would be the alternative ?
What it meansNONMET is that the time of release from prison is determinedNONMET by the Home Secretary , on the advice of the Parole Board and the Lord Chief Justice , rather than by the judge at the trial .
In procedural terms , therefore , the life sentence involvesNONMET a transfer of function : normally it is the judge who determinesNONMET the sentence ( or at least its upper limit , since earlier release on parole may be possible ) , whereas a life sentence entrustsMET that function to the executive , who must first ascertainNONMET the opinions of the Lord Chief Justice and the trial judge .
The Home Office is not boundMET by those opinions , and appearsNONMET to departMET from them frequently .
In 1983 the Home Secretary imposed restrictions on the release of persons servingMET life for murders of police- and prison-officers , terrorist killings , murder during robbery , and the sadistic or sexual murder of young children , fixingMET a minimum of twenty years ' imprisonment for these offenders .
Whatever the justifications for introducingMET this policy , it servesMET to underlineMET the fact that sentencing in murder cases is enactedMET without each case being consideredMET individually , after hearingNONMET representations from the offender's counsel , and without a sentence announced in court and subject to appeal .
At present , the executive takesMET decisions to releaseNONMET some murderers after only a few years and to keepNONMET others in prison for extremely long periods .
Should those decisions not be takenMET by the courts , in the same way as other sentencing decisions ?
The answer sometimes givenMET is that murderers should be treatedNONMET differently because they are particularly dangerous : anyone who choosesNONMET to killNONMET once can chooseNONMET to killNONMET again .
But this argument will seemNONMET less persuasive when we have discussedMET cases of manslaughter by reason of diminished responsibility : where a murder is reducedMET to manslaughter , the judge has a wide sentencing discretion and may , according to the facts of the case , selectNONMET a determinate prison sentence , a hospital order , or life imprisonment .
Those who killNONMET and are convicted of manslaughter by reason of diminished responsibility are no less dangerous than those convicted of murder , and yet the judge has sentencing discretion in one case and not in the other .
Considerations of this kind have ledMET the House of Lords Select Committee on Murder and Life Imprisonment to recommendNONMET the abolition of the mandatory sentence for murder .
In its place would be a sentencing discretion , which judges would useNONMET , in many cases , to markMET the relative heinousness of the murder by a determinate prison sentence .
In cases where life imprisonment was thoughtNONMET to be the appropriate sentence , the trial judge would still specifyNONMET — in open court — the number of years to be spentMET in prison , takingMET the gravity of the offence into account , and release would be determinedMET by a judicial tribunal .
Such a reform would bringMET improvements in natural justice without loss of public protection .
( b ) Degrees of Homicide English criminal law has two degrees of homicide , murder and manslaughter .
Many American jurisdictions have three degrees of murder — first- degree murder , requiringNONMET premeditation , and second- and third- degree murder , coveringMET lesser shades of culpability .
In England there has been a proposal that we should do away with all these distinctions , leavingMET a single offence of criminal homicide .
That proposal , if implementedNONMET , would shiftMET almost all the decision-making in homicide cases from the trial to the sentencing stage : the only issue of any consequence in most cases would be the sentence to be imposedNONMET , and all the distinctions now drawnMET at the stage of criminal liability would be reflectedMET in the sentence alone .
The jury would have no role in most homicide cases , since a plea of guilty would be the norm .
Contrast this with the position in jurisdictions where there are three or more degrees of homicide : pleas of guilty to first- and second -degree murders would be less frequent , since there would be the possibility of argument in court ( if no bargain was struckMET beforehand between prosecution and defence ) , and the defence might succeedMET in persuadingNONMET the jury to reduceMET the degree of the killing .
Moreover , the borderlines between the various degrees would raiseMET questions of law , which would provideNONMET much opportunity for legal argument and for appeals .
The result would be that killings were classified and labelledMET in a more refined way , but at the cost of lengthy trials and mounting legal-aid bills .
That cost is not difficult to justifyNONMET where capital punishment is the penalty for first- degree murder .
Where there is no capital punishment , however , the question of how many degrees of homicide it is desirable to have calls for careful weighing of the principle of fair labelling ( seeNONMET Chapter 3.3 ( l ) ) against the cost and time arguments mobilisedMET by the policy of efficient administration ( seeNONMET Chapter 3.3 ( m ) ) .
The structure of the English law of homicide is rather strange .
Although there are two offences , murder and manslaughter , the latter includesMET two distinct varieties : ‘ voluntary ’ manslaughter ( killings which would be murder but for the existence of defined extenuating circumstances ) ; and ‘ involuntary ’ manslaughter ( killings for which there is no need to proveNONMET any awareness of the risk of death being causedNONMET , but for which there is thoughtNONMET to be sufficient fault to justifyNONMET criminal liability ) .
The arguments therefore tendMET to focusMET on three borderline questions : What is the minimum fault requiredNONMET for conviction of murder ?
What conditions are neededNONMET to reduceMET murder to manslaughter ?
And what is the minimum fault requiredNONMET for a conviction of manslaughter .
( c ) Requirements for Murder In English criminal law there are now two alternative fault requirements for murder : an intent to killNONMET , or an intent to causeNONMET grievous bodily harm .
What do these requirements meanNONMET ?
Do they extendMET the definition of murder too far , or are they too narrowMET .
Intent to killNONMET may be regardedMET as the most obvious and indisputable form of fault element for murder , but to some extent that dependsNONMET on the meaning of ‘ intent ’ .
This has been the subject of a number of House of Lords decisions , and yet the definition is still not clear and settledMET .
Probably the most accurate statement would be that a person intendsNONMET to killNONMET if it is his or her purpose to killNONMET by the act or omission charged , or if he or she foreseesNONMET that death is practically certain to followMET from that act or omission .
In this way , both purpose and foresight of practical certainty are regardedMET as part of the definition of intent , although there are other statements suggestingMET that foresight of practical or ‘ virtual ’ certainty is merely evidence from which intent may be inferredNONMET .
How would this testNONMET be appliedMET ?
In many cases the word ‘ intent ’ is usedNONMET without elaboration , but there are some for which a full explanation of the meaning of intention is necessary .
A fairly typical set of facts is providedNONMET by Nedrick ( 1986 ) , where D had a grudge against a woman and had threatenedNONMET to ‘ burn her out ’ .
One night he wentNONMET to her house , poured paraffin through the letter-box and on to the front door , and setMET it alight .
One of the woman's children diedNONMET in the ensuing fire .
When asked why he did it , D repliedNONMET : ‘ Just to wake her up and frightenNONMET her .
’ A defence of this kind , a claim that the purpose was only to frightenNONMET and not to causeNONMET harm , requiresNONMET the full definition to be putMET to the jury .
The question is : granted that D's purpose was to frightenNONMET , did he nonetheless realizeNONMET that it was practically certain that his act would causeNONMET death or grievous bodily harm to someone ?
The jury should answerNONMET this by drawing inferences from the evidence in the case and from the surrounding circumstances .
What about the alternative element in the definition , an intent to causeNONMET grievous bodily harm ?
This has considerable practical importance , since this is all that the prosecution has to proveNONMET in order to obtainNONMET a verdict of guilty of murder .
It must be shownMET that the defendant intendedNONMET ( which , again , includesMET both purpose and awareness of practical certainty ) to causeNONMET really serious injury to someone .
The House of Lords confirmed this rule in Cunningham ( 1981 ) : D struckNONMET his victim on the head a number of times with a chair , causingNONMET injuries from which the victim diedNONMET a week later .
D maintainedMET throughout that he had not intendedNONMET to killNONMET , but there was evidence from which the jury could inferNONMET — and did inferNONMET — that he intendedNONMET to causeNONMET grievous bodily harm .
The House of Lords upheld D's conviction for murder : an intent to causeNONMET really serious injury is sufficient for murder , without any proof that the defendant intended , or even contemplatedMET , the possibility that death would resultNONMET .
Does the ‘ grievous bodily harm ’ rule extendMET the definition of murder too far ?
If the point of distinguishing murder from manslaughter is to markMET out the most heinous group of killings for the extra stigma of a murder conviction , it can be arguedNONMET that the ‘ grievous bodily harm ’ rule drawsMET the line too low .
In terms of principle , the rule requiresNONMET justification because it departsMET from the principle of correspondence ( seeNONMET Chapter 5.2(a) ) , namely that the fault element in a crime should relateNONMET to the consequences prohibitedNONMET by that crime .
By allowingMET an intent to causeNONMET grievous bodily harm to sufficeNONMET for a murder conviction , the law is violatingMET a general principle , turningMET the most serious of its offences into a constructive crime .
Why should it be necessary to ‘ constructMET ’ a murder conviction out of this lesser intent ?
There are arguments in favour of this : death is final , murder is the gravest crime , and there is no significant moral difference between someone who choosesNONMET to causeNONMET really serious injury and someone who setsMET out to killNONMET .
No one can predictNONMET whether a serious injury will resultNONMET in death — that may dependNONMET on the victim's physique , on the speed of an ambulance , on the distance from the hospital , and on a range of other medical and individual matters .
If one person choosesNONMET to causeNONMET serious injury to another , it should be presumedNONMET that he or she realizesNONMET that there is always a risk of death , and such cases showMET a sufficiently wanton disregard for life as to warrant the label ‘ murder ’ if death results .
The counter-arguments , which would upholdMET the principle of correspondence , are that breach of that principle is unnecessary when the amplitude of the crime of manslaughter lies beneath murder , and also that the definition of grievous bodily harm includesMET a number of injuries which are most unlikely to putMET the victim's life at risk .
In the leading case of Cunningham Lord Edmund-Davies ( dissentingNONMET ) gaveMET the example of breakingNONMET someone's arm : that is a really serious injury , but one which is unlikely to endangerNONMET the victim's life .
So in practice the ‘ grievous bodily harm ’ rule goesMET further than the arguments of its protagonists would supportMET .
Would it be right , then , to confineMET the fault element in murder to an intent to killNONMET ?
That would have the merit of simplicity , but would it strikeMET the right note socially ?
There are powerful arguments in favour of sayingNONMET that there are other killings where an intent to killNONMET can not be establishedNONMET , and yet where the moral or social culpability is equal to that in most intentional killings .
Of course , one can not be adamant about whether they meritNONMET the label ‘ murder ’ , because that is a question of drawingMET the line between murder and manslaughter , which is not susceptible of any precise resolution .
It is hard to argueNONMET conclusively that the category of murder should be smaller or larger ( unless the death penalty or a mandatory life sentence followsMET ) ; it is a question of social judgment .
LetNONMET us briefly considerMET some of the possibilities .
The fault element for many serious offences is intent or recklessness : why should this not sufficeNONMET for murder ?
The question is whether all killings in which the defendant is aware of the risk of death are sufficiently serious to warrantNONMET the term ‘ murder ’ .
One answer sometimes givenMET is that they are not , because a driver who overtakesNONMET on a bend , knowingly takingMET the risk that there is a car travelling in the opposite direction , should not be labelledMET a murderer if a collision and death happenNONMET to ensueNONMET .
This example assumesMET that a sympathy for motorists with overwhelm any tendency to logical analysis .
One might askNONMET whether motorists are ever justifiedNONMET in knowingly takingMET risks with other people's lives .
Yet if the example is modifiedMET a little , so that the overtaking is on a country road at night and the risk is knownNONMET to be slight , it becomesNONMET questionable whether the causing of death in these circumstances should be labelledMET in the same way as intentional killings .
This is not to suggestNONMET that motorists should be treatedNONMET differently .
The point is rather that , even though knowingly takingMET risks with other people's lives is usually unjustifiable , takingMET a slight risk is less serious than intentionally causingNONMET death .
In discussingMET the boundaries of murder , we are concerned with classification , not exculpation .
To classifyNONMET all reckless killings as murder might be too broad , but the point remainsMET that some reckless killings may be thoughtNONMET no less heinous than intentional killings .
Can a satisfactory line be drawnMET here ?
One approach would be to drawMET the line by reference to the degree of probability .
Murder is committedNONMET in those situations where D caused death by an act or omission which he knewNONMET had death as the probable or highly probable result .
A version of this test of foresight of high probability is usedNONMET in several other European countries ; it was introducedMET into English law by the decision in Hyam v. DPP ( 1975 ) , but abandoned in Moloney ( 1985 ) on grounds of uncertainty .
A second approach is to frameMET the law in such a way as to makeMET it clear that the court should makeMET a moral judgment on the gravity of the defendant's conduct .
Section 210.2 of the Model Penal Code includesMET within murder those reckless killings which manifestNONMET ‘ extreme indifference to the value of human life ’ .
Scots law treats as murder killings with ‘ wicked recklessness ’ , a phrase which directsMET the court's attention to the circumstances of the killing .
Both the Model Penal Code test and the Scots test may be reducedMET to circularity , however , for when one asksNONMET how extreme or how wicked the recklessness should be , the only possible answer is : ‘ wicked or extreme enough to justifyNONMET the stigma of a murder conviction ’ .
Admittedly , the Model Penal Code does containMET a list of circumstances which may amountMET to extreme indifference , which assistsMET the courts and increasesMET the predictability of verdicts in a way that Scots law does not , but the essence of both approaches is that there is no precise way of describingNONMET those non-intentional killings which are as heinous as intentional killings .
Their protagonists argueNONMET that the law of murder is so important socially that derogation from the principle of maximum certainty should be allowedNONMET in favour of more accurate labelling by the courts ; opponents argueNONMET that the principle of maximum certainty is neededNONMET here specifically to reduceMET the risk of verdicts basedNONMET on discriminatory or irrelevant factors , such as distaste for the defendant's background , allegiance , or other activities .
A third , more precise formulation derivesMET from the recommendations of the Criminal Law Revision Committee in 1980 , namely , that a killing should be classifiedNONMET as murder in those situations where there is an intention to causeNONMET serious injury coupled with awareness of the risk of death .
Neither an intention to causeNONMET serious injury nor recklessness as to death should be sufficient on its own , but together they restrictMET one another , producingMET a test which both satisfiesMET the criterion of certainty and marks out some heinous but non-intended killings .
A fourth approach , adoptedMET by English law until 1957 and still in force in many American jurisdictions , is some form of felony-murder rule : anyone who killsNONMET during the course of a felony ( or , more restrictively , a serious crime of violence ) or whilst resisting arrest should be convictedNONMET of murder .
Thus statedNONMET , there is no reference to the defendant's intention or awareness of the risks : the fact that D has chosenNONMET to commitNONMET rape , robbery , or another serious offence , and has causedNONMET death thereby , is heldMET to constituteNONMET sufficient moral grounds for placingMET the killing in the highest category .
Plainly , this is a form of constructive criminal liability : the murder conviction is constructedMET out of the ingredients of a lesser offence .
Presumably the justification is that D has already crossedMET a high moral/social threshold in choosingNONMET to commitNONMET such a serious offence , and should therefore be heldMET liable for whatever consequences ensueNONMET , however unforeseeable they may be .
The objections would be reducedMET if awareness of the risk of death was also requiredNONMET : in other words , if the test were the commission of a serious offence of violence plus recklessness as to death .
The effect of that test would be to pickNONMET out those reckless killings which occurredNONMET when D had already manifestedNONMET substantial moral and legal culpability , and to classifyNONMET them as murder .
Four alternative approaches have been describedNONMET , and many others could be listedNONMET .
The point is that the traditional concepts of intention and recklessness do not , of themselves , appearNONMET to be sufficiently well focusedMET to markMET out those killings which are the most heinous .
The law must resortMET to some kind of moral and social evaluation of conduct if it is to identifyMET and separateMET out the most heinous killings .
Many people might thinkNONMET that a person who causesNONMET death whilst usingNONMET an unlawfully held firearm or explosives ought to be convictedNONMET of murder because there is , generally speaking , no excuse for usingNONMET such dangerous equipment .
Some of the people thus coveredMET would be armed robbers , others would be terrorists .
The armed robber might sayNONMET that he had no intention of usingNONMET the firearm , that he carriedNONMET it with him simply to frightenNONMET the victim , and that it went off accidentally : if the jury believesNONMET that , should he be convictedNONMET of murder ?

But their work is hamperedMET by lack of money .
So far they have receivedMET nothing from the Government , little EC assistance and are runningMET out funds donatedMET by individuals and industry .
The researchers , headedMET by Dr Margaret Klinowska , a Cambridge biologist , and David Goodson , an expert on acoustic engineering at Loughborough University , sayMET new data showsMET that plastic sound reflectors to fishing nets can warnMET dolphins of hazards .

UsingNONMET equipment donatedMET by Racal , the scientists have analysedNONMET recordings of the ‘ clicking ’ dolphins makeNONMET while hunting .
Observations of Freddy ledMET them to concludeNONMET that dolphins use sonar while hunting .
They emitNONMET an intense , broad-band ‘ click ’ or pulse of sound .
Echoes of the signal alertMET them to possible prey , at ranges up to 80–90 metres in shallow waters .
Mr Goodson , who becameNONMET interested in the sonar capacity of dolphins after hearingNONMET one while swimmingNONMET off the Welsh coast , has experimentedMET with various shapes of sound reflectors .
The most promising is eliptical , about 3½in long .
The theory is that its internal air pocket will ‘ bounceMET ’ back the dolphin's sonar signal , regardless of the direction of approach .
Last autumn , Dr Klinowska , Mr Goodson and their team putMET the theories into practice .
In the Moray Firth , they placedNONMET a ‘ headline barrier ’ , from which they had suspendedNONMET reflectors at two-metre intervals .
The movement of dolphins around the barrier was observedNONMET , usingNONMET electronic equipment to monitorNONMET sonar activity .
‘ The results exceededNONMET our expectations , ’ saidNONMET Mr Goodson .
Dolphins swimmingNONMET near the barrier alteredNONMET their behaviour to avoidNONMET it , the result , the scientists believeNONMET , of them detectingMET sonar echoes from the reflectors .
Dr Klinowska saidNONMET that , although it was necessary to be cautious about the findings , a combination of reflector devices and some modification of fishing gear might reduceMET deaths .
But the Moray Firth experiments were only possible after the naturalist Dr David Bellamy helpedNONMET secureMET a donation from the Co-operative Wholesale Society .
