a Non-punitive Paradigm of Probation Practice : Some Sobering Thoughts L.R. SINGER Lawrence Singer is an Assistant Chief Probation Officer with Merseyside Probation Service .
Beforehand he workedNONMET as a probation officer for Berkshire Probation Service and later as a research officer for Somerset Probation Service where he undertookNONMET the research reported here .
The paradigm which is describedNONMET originatesMET from doctoral research into generic probation practice and has been presentedMET in a book Adult Probation and Juvenile Supervision : Beyond the Care-Control Dilemma ( 1989 , Gower ) .
SUMMARY The Government White Paper Crime , Justice and ProtectingNONMET the Public proposesMET a radical change for probation practice .
Henceforth probation work will no longer be an alternative to punishment but an alternative form of punishment .
This article challengesMET the conceptual and practical appropriateness of applyingMET the notion of punishment to the probation context .
Probation officers , it is arguedNONMET , are concerned with establishingNONMET rules for probationers and not inflictingNONMET pain on them .
An alternative non-punitive paradigm of probation practice is describedNONMET .
The paradigm is basedMET on the joint supervisory aims of support and surveillance which are implementedNONMET through the methods of counselling , assistingNONMET , directingNONMET , and monitoring .
To illustrateMET the paradigm , reference is madeMET to an alcohol education course developedNONMET for offenders in trouble through drink .
The efficacy of the alcohol project and the non-punitive paradigm is demonstratedNONMET by the results reportedNONMET from a three year evaluation study coveringMET 152 offenders .
The article concludesMET with an affirmation of the disciplined but non-punitive character of current probation work and arguesMET that , to successfully protectNONMET the public and reintegrate offenders into the community , the probation officer's employment of established social work knowledge , skills , and values is a strength not a weakness .
The aim of this article is to challengeMET the assertion contained in the White Paper Crime , Justice and ProtectingNONMET the Public ( Home Office , 1990a ) that probation practice can be conceivedMET of as a form of punishment in the community .
Issue will be takenMET with the appropriateness of applyingMET the concept of punishment to the probation context through reference to a demanding and successful probation project concerned with offenders in trouble through drink .
In describingNONMET the project , a non-punitive model for understanding probation practice will be developedNONMET .
This non-punitive paradigm will provideMET a framework for contrastingNONMET the efficacy of current practice with future plans inappropriately to transformMET probation work into ‘ a new approach to punishment in the community ’ ( p. 18 , para. 4.3 ) .
The punitive approach anticipated for the Probation Service in the White Paper is underpinnedMET by a definition of punishment that residesMET ‘ in the restrictions on liberty and in the enforcement of the orders ’ .
The White Paper goesMET on to emphasizeMET : ‘ It is the loss of liberty involvedNONMET in carryingNONMET out the terms of the order rather than the activities carriedNONMET out during the order which is the punishment ’ ( p. 18 , para. 4.4 ) .
Notwithstanding the popular appeal and political capital to be derivedNONMET from such a humane -sounding statement , this definition is nevertheless at variance with the traditional understanding of the meaning of punishment .
Discourses on punishment and dictionary definitions of the term clearly specifyNONMET the central feature of punishment as being the infliction of pain rather than the loss of liberty per se ( Hudson , 1987 ) .
The conceptual and practical implications of this discrepancy will be examinedNONMET in the third and final section of this article .
Beforehand , however , consideration will be givenMET first to the probation project and second to its evaluation .
In these sections punishment will be understoodNONMET to meanNONMET the infliction of pain and the review of the project will seekMET to demonstrateNONMET that the probation practice describedNONMET is not only more demanding but also more effective than this traditional understanding of punishment .
At a time when the Home Secretary is invitingMET the Probation Service to ‘ moveMET centre stage in the Criminal Justice System ’ ( NACRO , 1990 , p. 17 ) it may seemNONMET misguided and unnecessarily pedantic to takeMET issue with the White Paper's notion of punishment .
Punishment is just a word after all : nothing more than convenient political rhetoric meritingNONMET only lip service from probation managers and practitioners poisedNONMET at the ‘ window of opportunity ’ .
However , this failsNONMET to acknowledgeNONMET a fundamental axiom of social work practice ; namely that language not only reflectsMET but also shapes social reality .
As Davies ( 1981 ) has pointedMET out , speech is the basic tool of the social worker .
What we sayNONMET influences what we thinkNONMET and in turn , what we do .
If punishment is assimilatedMET into the probation glossary it will inevitably influenceNONMET the sort of practice the Service undertakesMET .
In the sections to followMET the stark question is therefore putMET ‘ Is the Probation Service in the business of inflictingNONMET pain ?
’ and the answer which unfoldsMET may be summarizedNONMET ‘ No , because it neither aspiresMET nor wishesMET to !
’ THE PROJECT : MORE DEMANDING THAN PUNISHMENT Government concern about the problem of drink-related offending is as old as the Probation Service .
Indeed , as Bochel ( 1976 ) has shownMET , the establishment of a Probation Service in England and Wales was inextricably linkedMET with work undertakenNONMET with offenders in trouble through drink .
Almost a century later the new approach to punishment in the community outlinedMET by the White Paper once again presentsMET alcohol misuse as a key problem requiringNONMET community-based intervention .
‘ Alcohol ’ , the White Paper states , ‘ is implicatedNONMET in a wide variety of crimes , drunken driving , offences of public disorder and domestic violence ’ ( p. 21 , para. 4. 14 ) .
In describingMET its vision of effective supervision the White Paper goesMET on to noteMET : offenders takeMET part in alcohol education programmes so that they can learnNONMET to drinkNONMET sensibly .
They learnNONMET about the relative strength of different drinks , the amount which is safe to consumeNONMET , and the pitfalls to avoidNONMET ( e.g. competitive drinking and buyingNONMET ‘ rounds ’ ) ( p. 37 , para. 7.11 ) .
As a summary of alcohol education programmes , this is something of a simplification .
However it does provideMET a useful introduction to the origins of the Alcohol Education Course reported here .
Furthermore , it highlightsMET the suitability of referringNONMET to this type of project for testingMET out the appropriateness of applyingMET the notion of punishment to probation practice .
In 1985 the management of Somerset Probation Service was facedMET with the fact that nearly one in three of the offenders supervised in their area were either knownNONMET to be or suspected of misusing alcohol ( Singer , 1985 ) .
Aware of practitioners ' frustration in not being able to workNONMET effectively with these problematic clients , Probation management , in partnership with the voluntary sector , determined to developNONMET an Alcohol Education Course ( AEC ) .
By 1986 , when social inquiry report monitoring information coveringMET 1,257 offenders indicated that the problem of drink-related offending was virtually as great for pre- as for post-sentence clients , that is , alcohol was citedNONMET as a pre-offence problem in twenty-nine per cent of cases , a specialist project worker had been appointedNONMET .
Towards the end of 1986 an AEC was launchedMET and has been runningMET ever since .
The aim of the course is to educateNONMET offenders about alcohol to facilitateNONMET a lasting change in their subsequent use of this drug .
This aim is underpinnedMET by three interrelated objectives and it is not without significance how they complementNONMET and serveMET to implementNONMET the White Paper's own trinity of ‘ aims of supervision ’ , that is , protection of the public , prevention of reoffending and successful reintegration of the offender in the community ( p. 35 , para. 7.3 ) .
These were : 1 .
To increaseMET knowledge about alcohol so that future alcohol use can be more informed and therefore more prudent .
2 .
To instilNONMET or reinforceMET responsible drinking attitudes and behaviour .
3 .
To encourageMET the maintenance of , or , where appropriate , a reduction to a personally and socially safe level of alcohol unit intake .
To meetMET these objectives the AEC has a structured programme involvingNONMET group and individual contact , that is , six group sessions sandwichedMET between one-to-one interviews held immediately before and after the group con act contact .
The initial one-to-one meeting , held with one of the two group leaders , servesMET to clarifyNONMET what participants can expectNONMET from the course and what is expected of them .
A standard contract which coversMET conditions of attendance and an agreement to completeNONMET various assignments between group sessions is signedNONMET by each participant .
The final interview entailsMET a personalized review of the course , as well as the formulation of a follow-up plan to be undertakenNONMET with the offender's supervising officer .
The course employsMET a variety of materials and techniques including the use of checklists , magazine and newspaper clippings , quizzes , videos , brainstorm exercises , discussions , drink diaries , and role plays ( Menary , 1986 ) .
The AEC is primarily intendedNONMET for young adults subject to a probation order with a special condition of attendance ( Schedule 11 4A(II) Criminal Justice Act 1982 ) and reflectsMET the fact that most Somerset offenders in trouble through drink commitMET serious offences and/or possessNONMET a substantial number of previous convictions .
In short , they are seriously at risk of committingMET further offences and becomingNONMET trappedNONMET in the revolving door of custody .
The development of the Somerset AEC both accords with and constitutesNONMET a practical example of the Home Office's recent guidance to sentencers : In recent years the probation service has devotedNONMET increasing resources to supervisingMET the more serious and persistent offenders .
Probation orders which are combinedMET with constructive , disciplined and effective programmes of supervision are increasingly being usedNONMET for offenders who standMET to receiveNONMET custodial sentences ( 1990b , p. 35 ) .
From the description of the AEC already givenMET the demanding and disciplined nature of the course can be appreciatedNONMET .
However , the course is not punitive ; it is not concerned with the infliction of pain .
Instead , it is concerned with the establishment of rules .
This is plainly evident from the section of the contract signedNONMET by each participant where what is expected of them is speltMET out : You will be expectedNONMET to keepNONMET a drink diary throughout the course , and makeMET attempts at reducingNONMET the amount you drinkNONMET if it is greater than accepted healthy drinking levels .
You must be willing to be helpedNONMET and help others — your experiences will be useful to other group members .
You must attendNONMET 8 sessions ( these will consistNONMET of : an introductory session , six group sessions and a final assessment interview ) .
You must not drinkNONMET before the session .
You must be on time — lateness will countMET as an absence .
Unlike the prison inmate , AEC participants can not sitMET back and passively do their time .
Probation practice is not , however , solely concerned with the establishment of rules .
As has been demonstratedNONMET elsewhere with regard to the generic probation setting ( Singer , 1989 ) , the supervision of offenders involvesNONMET two overarching aims : namely support and surveillance .
Support refersNONMET to anything which is saidNONMET or done to helpNONMET the offender solveNONMET or mitigateNONMET their personal or social problems : surveillance to anything which is saidNONMET or done to induceNONMET the offender to conformNONMET to socially acceptable standards of behaviour .
These aims are implementedNONMET through the practice of four distinguishable but related methods .
In terms of support , there is counselling and assistingNONMET : in terms of surveillance , there is directingNONMET and monitoring .
Each of these four methods are employedMET during the eight sessions .
Although summarizedNONMET as an alcohol education course , the sessions are not just concerned with givingMET information but also with enabling participants to makeMET practical use of it .
In the first group session the counselling method is registeredNONMET in the course tutor's notes ( Menary , 1986 ) by the explanation : ‘ This session aimsMET to getMET participants to considerNONMET the subject of alcohol in ways they had not thoughtNONMET of in the past ’ ( p. 3 ) .
During this session the importance of monitoring is also emphasizedMET : Drinks exercises introduceMET the notion of measurement , concentration of alcohol content ; information which will be necessary to carryNONMET out the recording of alcohol consumption throughout the duration of the course ( p. 3 ) .
In the fifth group session entitledNONMET ‘ Focus on the Individual ’ , the counselling and the monitoring combine with the directing and assisting methods .
At the start of the session the tutor's notes makeMET clear that directing extendsMET beyond enforcingNONMET the conditions of attendance : This session allowsMET for an in depth examination of the drinking diaries over the last five weeks — identifyingNONMET the risky circumstances or situations … .
The aim at the end of the session is to encourageNONMET participants to makeMET rules for their future drinking which will leadMET to a lessening of identified problems ( p. 4 ) .
Similarly , the assisting extendsMET beyond simply providingNONMET handouts of useful information : It is important that participants are providedNONMET with the skills to reduceMET their drinking levels or handle more effectively ‘ pub centredNONMET ’ problems .
The use of role play , incorporatingNONMET previously discussed difficulties ( i.e. homework assignment session 4 ) in ‘ real ’ or setMET up situations providesNONMET an opportunity for testingNONMET these skills .
Probably the best illustration of the assisting method in action during the course comesMET in the fifth session when Somerset practitioners takeMET the logic of workingNONMET with the problem in the community to its ultimate conclusion .
In the second half of the session , course leaders sponsor participants to an evening at the pub for the purpose of practising drinking skills and purchasing non-alcoholic drinks .
The counselling , assistingNONMET , directingNONMET , and monitoring on the AEC giveMET substance to the aims of support and surveillance and provideNONMET the basis for establishingNONMET a model of probation practice .
Punishment has no place in this model .
Instead the AEC can best be understoodNONMET as an example of a non-punitive paradigm of probation practice .
Twenty years ago the Advisory Council on the Penal System observedMET that notions of punitiveness do not accordNONMET with ‘ the British concept of probation as an alternative to , rather than a suspension of , punishment ’ ( quotedNONMET in Bochel , 1976 , p. 238 ) .
Twenty years later the AEC demonstratesMET that this remainsNONMET no less true now than it was then .
But does the AEC workMET ?
BRINGINGMET FOSSILS BACK TO LIFE In this chapter some of the ways in which palaeontologists determineNONMET the way fossil animals livedNONMET are describedNONMET , reanimatingMET the dead fragments to buildMET up a living creature .
Since popular ideas of life in the past are often foundedMET on vividly coloured reconstructions of ‘ The World in the Jurassic Period ’ and the like , it is important to rememberNONMET that these imaginative scenes are all inferences from bones , and similar fragments .
In fact there is nothing fixedMET about such interpretations , because the way the fossils are understoodNONMET may changeMET over the years , but it is usually some time before new discoveries percolateMET into the popular presentations .
Even the most solid-looking dinosaurs may have changedMET their habits in the last few years !
Many different lines of evidence may be used to flesh out the bare bones of the fossils .
The first of these is the evidence of the rocks from which the remains were recoveredNONMET .
The sediments themselves revealMET much about the environment of deposition , as was shownMET in Chapter 3 .
It is important to establishNONMET whether the fossil animal actually livedNONMET in the environment which furnishedMET its sedimentary cover , or whether its remains were sweptMET in from some other place .
Fortunately it is usually easy to spotNONMET such intruders .
The type of sediment and the associated fossils will showMET whether the environment was marine , freshwater or terrestrial , providingNONMET the basic information into which the ecology of the animal has to be accommodatedMET .
The sediments themselves may have preservedMET some of the tracks leftNONMET by the animal ( p. 20 ) to giveMET direct evidence of its past activities .
From the tracks alone it is possible to be certain of the bipedal stance of certain dinosaurs , and to measureNONMET their stride .
The character of the rocks , and their setting in the past geography at the time when they accumulatedNONMET , diagnosesMET the climatic setting in which the extinct fauna livedNONMET , and climate imposesMET certain restraints on possible modes of life .
Savannah animals differNONMET from those of tropical rain forests , and these again from inhabitants of the tundra at high latitudes .
LookingNONMET at the fossil animal itself , the first necessity is to reconstructNONMET it as accurately as possible from its fragmentary remains .
Sometimes this is a very complex business , particularly for vertebrates with numbers of small bones .
To proceedMET from the reconstruction to an assessment of probable life habits two different but complementary approaches are used .
One method attempts to compareNONMET the structures of teeth or limbs or some other feature of the extinct animal with living analogues .
These do not have to be biologically related organisms .
The basic argument is that structuresNONMET that are closely similar were probably adaptedNONMET to a similar function .
Sometimes these similarities are quite obvious : the ferocious teeth of a predatory dinosaur are a sure indication of hunting habits , with hardly a glance at the fangs of living mammalian carnivores .
But the structure and functioning of grinding or chewing teeth in other mammals , in which opposing teeth co-operateMET in action , and which can be matchedNONMET in extinct , unrelated mammals , is a much more subtle matter , involvingNONMET detailed studies on the operation of living dental systems to helpNONMET elucidateNONMET the functioning of fossil ones .
The technique of ‘ hunt the analogue ’ is a favourite one practised by palaeontologists , but it is certainly not a foolproof one , because there are many fossil animals that defyMET comparison with living organisms , and some analogues do not standMET up to detailed scrutiny .
The second method triesMET to analyseNONMET the structure of the fossil almost as if it were a piece of engineering .
If the fossil is constructedNONMET in a certain way , then there are only a limited number of ‘ jobs ’ that the structure could performMET .
The idea here is to decideNONMET which of the possibilities is the most likely one .
This assumesMET that nature only manufacturesMET efficient designs .
For the most part this is a reasonable assumption to makeMET .
Most animals today do seemNONMET to have bodies that accord well with the functions they have to carry out to surviveNONMET : flyers are aerodynamically efficient , active swimmers have suitable streamlining , herbivorous mammals have teeth appropriateNONMET for grinding plant food , and so on .
Ideally one could constructNONMET a model of the fossil to test out these various functions in experiments , but the number of examples where the analysis has been pursuedMET this far are limited .
Of course it can never be knownNONMET whether the right answer has been reachedMET ( unless somebody dredges up a ‘ living fossil ’ from the depths of the ocean ) — there are only varying degrees of probability .
But the best answers are probably obtainedMET where the functional design of the fossil points to the same life habits as a living analogue , and where both are consistent with the geological circumstances in which the fossil remains occurNONMET .
SWIMMING TRILOBITES There are thousands of different kinds of trilobites .
All of them were marine and all of them are extinct .
Since many kinds of trilobites co-existedNONMET at any one time they were probably occupying different ecological niches , >behavingNONMET in different ways , correspondingNONMET with the wide variation in shape that they showMET .
We can useNONMET the methods describedNONMET above to elucidateNONMET some of these occupations , and getMET a glimpse , albeit an imperfect one , of the trilobite as it livedNONMET .
I will takeMET an example where all the methods can be usedNONMET , and where all point in the same direction , so that the answer is probably correct .
Most trilobites were broadly oval-shaped being rather longer than wide , not greatly convex , and with eyes that occupyMET perhaps a quarter of the length of the head .
There are a few trilobite species , however , with enormous , globular eyes ( seeNONMET below ) .
By examiningNONMET the way these animals were putMET together it is possible to suggestNONMET a likely mode of life .
Giant-eyed Ordovician trilobite , seenNONMET from the top and side .
Twice its natural size .
Enlargement showsMET a section through the lenses to showMET the direction of the field of view .
We can takeMET the eyes first .
The trilobite eye was of a compound type , and each lens was madeMET up of a calcite crystal .
From the optical properties of this mineral we knowNONMET that the lens was able to interpretMET light coming from a direction more or less at right-angles to the lens surface .
So we can deduceNONMET what the field of vision of our globular-eyed trilobite was , by lookingNONMET at the directions in which all the lenses face .
It turnsMET out that our animal was able to seeNONMET in almost every direction — upwards , downwards , sideways and forwards , and even backwards , because the eyes bulgedNONMET out beyond the line of the rest of the body .
Most other trilobites have a predominantly lateral field of view .
If the animal lived on the sea bottom , it seemsNONMET unlikely that it would have eye lenses specialized for lookingNONMET downwards , and we beginNONMET to suspectMET that the animal habitually dweltNONMET above the sea floor .
Other features of its shape are consistent with this .
At the – edge of the eyes are a pair of long spines , and these point downwards at a steep angle , at very awkward attitude for restingNONMET comfortably on the sea floor .
Most ‘ normal ’ trilobites have a more or less horizontal rim around the forward margin , which may have restedNONMET on the sediment surface .
The thorax of the large-eyed trilobite is remarkably long comparedNONMET with the average trilobite ( compareNONMET Fig. 33 ) .
The convex , middle part of the thorax containedNONMET the musculature that operatedMET the appendages ( which , as usual , are not preservedNONMET ) , and the relatively large volume of this region showsMET that the musculature was powerful .
The construction of this giant-eyed trilobite suggestsMET that it livedNONMET an actively swimmingNONMET life well above the bottom , and possibly in the surface waters of the sea .
Of course because there are no living trilobites we can not findMET direct confirmation of this hypothesis , but we can lookMET for other arthropods that have the same modifications of the eyes , for example , in the present day oceans .
The analogy is foundMET in such ocean-going amphipods ( a kind of ‘ shrimp ’ ) as Cystosoma , which also has enormously expandedNONMET eyes , lookingNONMET like headlamps , comparedNONMET with its bottom-dwelling relatives ( seeNONMET above ) .
In fact many of the arthropods that inhabitNONMET the water column have large , globular eyes of this kind .

Giant-eyed living crustacean ( Cystosoma ) If it is correct that our trilobite lived above the sea bottom , actively swimmingNONMET in the water , there are certain predictions we can makeMET about its geological occurrence which can be testedNONMET by lookingNONMET in the rocks .
Most bottom-dwelling trilobites preferred to liveNONMET at a particular water depth , or on a particular type of sea bottom ( mud , sand or lime ) .
No such restriction should applyNONMET to our large-eyed species ; it should be foundMET with all other different kinds of trilobite assemblages without preference .
This has been provedNONMET in several places : in some arctic localities it is foundMET with trilobites that livedNONMET at great depths in the muds of the Ordovician ocean , while in Canada the same species occursNONMET mixed with the inhabitants of the shallow-water seas , where limestones were accumulatingNONMET .
By the same token the free-swimming trilobite may be expectedNONMET to have a very wide geographical distribution , for oceans would be no barrier to it .
And again this provesNONMET to be the case : our example is foundNONMET in Arctic Canada , in the high Arctic island of Spitsbergen , thousands of miles away in what is now the desert country of Nevada and Utah in the United States , in western Ireland , in Russia , and in northwestern Australia .
So in this case the different sources of evidence all point in the same direction , whether derivedNONMET from a detailed consideration of the way the trilobite is constructedMET , or by analogy with living animals with similar adaptations , or from the evidence of the rocks or the distribution of the fossils .
These giant-eyed trilobites of the Ordovician were active swimmers in the surface waters , as near certainly as we can ever knowNONMET .
There are all kinds of different questions we can askNONMET about the life habits of these trilobites , which are not subject to the same kind of careful scrutiny .
What did they eatNONMET , for example ?
Because we do not have the legs preservedNONMET , it is not possible to seeNONMET how the mouth appendages functionedNONMET in feedingNONMET , and neither are the stomach contents preservedNONMET .
So here there are only more or less likely speculations .
Active swimmers in the surface waters of the present oceans are likely to feedNONMET directly on the plankton , and the trilobites may have had a method of harvestingMET large quantities of minute food .
Or they may have been hunters after larger prey , in which case when appendages are eventually discoveredNONMET they may proveNONMET to have adaptations for grasping and manipulatingNONMET larger food .
Puzzles remainMET , even though we can be certain of the rudiments of the story .
CONTROVERSY AMONG THE GIANT DINOSAURS The giant sauropod dinosaurs like Brachiosaurus were the largest land animals the world has seenMET they weighedNONMET more than 80 tonnes and present quite different problems in the interpretation of their life habits from the diminutive trilobites .
Such spectacular animals have obviously attractedMET much attention , and one might supposeNONMET that the problem of how they livedNONMET would have been satisfactorily solvedNONMET long ago .
Most of the popular books showingMET the Mesozoic giants in their natural setting portrayNONMET them wallowingNONMET about in swamps flankedNONMET by deep vegetation , their bodies largely under water .
Surely an animal of this bulk , it was arguedNONMET , must be partly supportedNONMET by water , and their relatively inconsequential teeth must have been adaptedNONMET for chewingNONMET on the kind of soft , luxuriant vegetation that flourishesNONMET in and around swamps .
Because their nasal openings were on the top of their heads they could even continueNONMET to breatheNONMET if it becameNONMET necessary ( seeNONMET p. 115 ) to totally submergeNONMET .
Recently the life habits of the giants have been lookedMET at in a way that disprovesMET most of these traditional notions .
ConsiderNONMET the structure of their legs .
The sauropods have relatively long , pillar- like legs , resemblingNONMET those of the elephant , the largest living land animal , and may have been well adaptedNONMET for supportingNONMET the huge bulk of the animal .
The feet of the sauropod are small ( relatively speaking !
) , with short , stubby toes , yet animals that walk on soft mud tendMET to have spreading feet to distributeNONMET their weight more evenly .
It is difficult to seeMET how the compact feet of the sauropod could avoidMET becomingNONMET stuck fast in the soft , muddy bottom of a lake .
If the dinosaur did , after all , liveNONMET on dry land , then the long neck could have usefully functionedNONMET to allowMET the animal to browseNONMET the high foliage of trees ( seeNONMET p. 116 ) .
It has been suggestedNONMET that an animal of the size of Brachiosaurus could not have breathedNONMET under water because of the pressure on the lungs .
Their fossil remains seemNONMET to occurNONMET with other animals and plants , which are generally acceptedNONMET as terrestrial .
There is even some evidence from the tracks they have leftNONMET behind that Diplodocus and its allies moved about in herds .
They may have been the gigantic reptilian analogue of the elephant , and it may be no coincidence that the elephant also has its nasal openings on top of the skull , with the nostrils in this case sitedMET at the end of the trunk it has been suggestedNONMET that some sauropods may have had a proboscis of some sort .
The balance of evidence seemsNONMET to be swinging away from the original idea of swamp-dwelling giant dinosaurs to fully terrestrial habits .
But other aspects of the dinosaur living habits are still more strongly debatedNONMET .
In the last few years a powerful controversy has arisenMET over whether the dinosaurs as a whole were cold-blooded , like all living reptiles ( and there is no doubt that dinosaurs were reptiles ) , or warm-blooded , resemblingNONMET mammals in this respect .
Cold-blooded animals have to ‘ warmMET up ’ before they can be fully active ; that is why lizards and snakes baskNONMET in the sun in temperate climates .
For this reason they can not copeMET with climates having greatly extendedMET winters .
Warm-blooded animals have the same body temperatures at all times , and can be more continuously active , but they useMET far more energy — and hence needNONMET more food — than cold-blooded animals of the same size .
The posture of many dinosaurs , and particularly the carnivorous theropod dinosaurs , was fully erect with the legs beneath the body , and unlike the sprawling legs of living reptiles ( seeNONMET p. 116 ) .
The long back legs of such hunters lookNONMET highly suitable for running , and as they did so the long tail may have been heldNONMET erect as a kind of counter-balance ( seeNONMET p. 116 ) .
For any kind of prolonged activity , warm-bloodedness would have been a distinct advantage .
Under the microscope even the bone structure of these dinosaurs looksNONMET more like that of living mammals than cold-blooded reptiles .
On the other hand it can be arguedNONMET that the sauropods like Brachiosaurus were so large , and with a relatively small surface area through which to coolNONMET comparedNONMET with their enormous volume , that their cooling rate could have been slow enough to allowMET them to sustainNONMET more continuous activity than smaller , living reptiles .
It has also been arguedNONMET that the small mouths of the giants simply could not have downedNONMET enough food to supportMET a warm-blooded metabolism , particularly plant food that needsNONMET a lot of processing before it becomesNONMET available as energy .
The armoured or plated dinosaurs includeNONMET some species that seemNONMET too heavily burdenedNONMET with protective armour to have been very active , but this does not necessarily meanNONMET that they had to be cold-blooded .
Protagonists of the warm-blooded theory will showNONMET some of the horned dinosaurs chargingNONMET over the Cretaceous plains like furious reptilian rhinoceroses !
One idea about the life habits of the dinosaur giants , publishedNONMET in Joc and Colette at the Natural History Museum in 1935 The warm-blooded supporters tendMET to allyNONMET themselves with the supporters of a theory about the relationships of the dinosaurs .
This is that the dinosaurs , or a close dinosaur relative , includedNONMET the ancestors of the living birds .
Some of the smaller , and most certainly highly active dinosaurs were about the size of a chicken , and there is more than a passing similarity between a running ostrich and the kind of reconstruction that showsMET fleet-footed , running dinosaurs .
The point is that birds themselves are warm-blooded , like mammals , and if birds and dinosaurs are as closely relatedNONMET as now seemsNONMET likely , then it obviously increasesNONMET the likelihood that the dinosaurs themselves may have been warm-blooded .
The pros and cons of this theory are the subject of much contentious debate by experts , but it would probably be correct to sayMET that the greater number of specialists believeNONMET that at least the more bipedal of the dinosaurs , including small and large carnivores , were warm-blooded , active animals .
A lot of the argument among the authorities on these animals is about the equivalence or otherwise of certain bones in dinosaurs and bird skeletons ( and particularly the Jurassic bird Archaeopteryx ) ; this makesMET for rather dry reading for the layman .
But the end- product is the accurate reconstruction of the Jurassic and Cretaceous terrestrial world , over which the dinosaurs were indisputably dominant .
Action and Inaction in the Cities Susanne MacGregor and Ben Pimlott The essays in this book do not amountMET to a programme : but they are intendedNONMET to provideNONMET a springboard for  one .
The aim is to analyseNONMET a problem which economic growth alone has failedMET to cureMET — and to considerMET possible new forms of public  action .
The biggest single difficulty in drawing attention to urban poverty is that it is not new , but simply — in some of its most worrying manifestations — getting worse .
Like the poor themselves , the inner city has long been with us .
Ever since the Industrial Revolution created a mass urban society , the conditions of the poorest city dwellers have givenMET rise to anxiety among the better  off .
The inner city has been variously regardedMET as a  cause for moral outrage , a threat to public order , or as a stain on the nation's conscience .
Meanwhile bad housing , bad sanitation , lack of education , and other perennial ills associatedNONMET with overcrowding and poverty have been routinely denouncedNONMET by political leaders and social reformers .
A central objective of the post-war welfare state was , indeed , to alleviateNONMET the problems of the urban poor , over whom Beveridge's Five Giants ( WantNONMET , Disease , Ignorance , Squalor , and Idleness ) had for so long held sway .
In the early 1940s and 1950s , the belief was widely held that a combination of government intervention — in the form of town planning , housing and health programmes , and the provision of social security — and permanent male full employment , together with an increase in real wages , would reduceMET suffering due to poverty to manageable proportions .
The 1964 Labour Government was electedNONMET on a tide of impatience at the slackening pace of social reform , but also of optimism that little more than economic growth , fuelledMET by technological change , was neededNONMET to removeMET the main causes of urban deprivation ( MacGregor , 1981 ) .
DisillusionNONMET swiftly followedMET .
The work of Peter Townsend and others showedMET that , far from presidingNONMET over the elimination of poverty , the Wilson Government actually failedMET to preventMET some of its features from worsening ( Townsend and Bosanquet , 1972 ) .
Evidence beganNONMET to mountMET that much of the social welfare paternalism of the post-war period had createdNONMET almost as many problems as it solvedMET .
Neither the Butler Education Act of 1944 , nor the introduction of comprehensive schools , preventedMET a high proportion of children from under-MET .
Post-war reconstruction and housing programmes seemedNONMET to do nothing to preventMET , and seemedNONMET even to encourageMET , a rise in crime and mental illness .
Meanwhile , in many parts of the country , a problem as old as cities themselves — tension between cultural groups , between earlier immigrants and newer ones , between black , brown , and white , and ( increasingly ) between large sections of urban youth and the police — cameMET to be identifiedNONMET as the key inner-city issue .
Rising unemployment turnedMET a lingering and growing malaise into a crisis .
As in the United States , so in Britain it was an outbreak of violence that dramatically brought the plight of the inner cities to public notice .
In the early 1980s , at a time when manufacturing industry was collapsing and the outlook for the unskilled looked particularly bleak , frustration boiledMET over in a series of riots in London , Bristol , Birmingham , Liverpool , and elsewhere .
All were spontaneous outbursts : none , contrary to some claims , were politically inspired or orchestratedMET ( except in Northern Ireland where urban problems existedNONMET on a grander , more devastating scale , and where there was a unique heritage ) .
Many had an ‘ ethnic ’ dimension , in the sense that many of the rioters were black .
Unlike , however , the 1958 Notting Hill riots , few of those involvedNONMET were immigrants — the vast majority were British born .
And the disturbances could not strictly be calledNONMET racial : the most prominent feature was that of violent clashes between young people and the police .
The problems , however , were not confinedMET violent upheavals of this kind .
Paul Harrison's Inside the Inner City : Life under the Cutting Edge focused on Hackney , a London borough rankedMET among the worst  off on any scale of urban deprivation ( Harrison , 1983 ) .
Harrison describesNONMET ( p. 369 ) the way in which the inner urban powder-keg leadsMET to a vicious circle , with many victims , but few individual villains : The police force face the virtually impossible task of keepingMET the lid on the explosive mixture of ingredients that the dynamics of British society have assembledMET in the inner city .
This mixture , heatedMET by recession and high unemployment , inevitably generatesMET a high level of crime .
This necessitatesNONMET , in turn , a far more numerous and ubiquitous police presence than in other kinds of area , far more frequent unpleasant contact with the public as potential suspects , and far greater opportunities for police misjudgment or abuse .
The inevitable sufferers , of course , are the poor , of whom those who actually commitMET the offences that concern the police are a tiny minority and whom , indeed , it should be the purpose of the police to protectNONMET .
Not only are the most disadvantaged on the receiving end of most crime , arguesNONMET Harrison , they also have to putNONMET  up with the heaviest police presence .
They are more likely to be stoppedNONMET and searchedNONMET , and to be the victim of mistaken arrest or conviction .
At the same time , the residents of the poorest areas have to sufferMET , in a way that is not true of those who liveNONMET elsewhere , a growing fear of attack on themselves or their property .
Improved police methods might helpMET , writesNONMET Harrison , to containMET the problem .
But , without other changes , the result is likely to be a ‘ society of barricaded self-defence , and a steady erosion of civil liberties ’ .
And he concludesNONMET , ‘ of all the warnings that the inner city has to offerMET for the direction British society is takingMET , this is perhaps the most sinister ’ .
Harrison's vision of a nightmarish future for inner cities , locked in a cold or hot war between have-nots and the forces of public order , was echoedNONMET by Robert Chesshyre ( 1987 , p. 95 ) , who concludedNONMET that by the late 1980s : The basic social contract , whereby citizens enjoyMET certain rights — including health care , decent education and housing and a job — in return for which they observeMET the rule of law , was breakingMET down .
As a consequence an underclass was evolvingMET — football hooligans , muggers , inner city rioters — somewhat more frightening than their Dickensian forebears because they were mobile and all too visible .
Recently , of course , there has been an added dimension — part media-and-politician inflated , part real : drugs .
The spiral in drug abuse and trafficking , with direct consequences for the AIDS epidemic , has createdNONMET a new kind of alarm .
The early 1980s witnessedMET a radical change in patterns of heroin takingNONMET , alongside the global increase .
Smoking heroin ( ‘ chasingMET the dragon ’ ) was one feature of the upsurge .
Another was the increased  availability of , and demand for , cocaine .
Sensational media and police reports in 1989 seemedNONMET to suggestMET an increased use of ‘ crack ’ among young people in parts of south London , Liverpool , and Birmingham — with attendant fears that this particularly dangerous substance might becomeNONMET widespread , as it was reportedNONMET to be in parts of the United States .
for the moment , however , the pattern of drug abuse in Britain remains as varied as ever — with home -produced drugs such as amphetamines as serious a problem as those that hitMET the headlines .
It is a symptom of public anxiety about urban squalor — and , less creditably , of class and racial prejudice — that ‘ drugs ’ and ‘ inner cities ’ are automatically linkedMET in the popular consciousness ( MacGregor , 1989a ) .
Nevertheless , drug-taking and more particularly the disruptive social consequences of addiction , are especially serious in areas of city poverty ( Burr , 1989 ) .
In short , if life was always harder in the inner cities than elsewhere , and if conditions may temporarily have been alleviatedNONMET by the impact of the welfare state and rising incomes , the last decade has been widely representedMET as a period of deterioration .
Moreover , few would disputeNONMET that this apparent decline is a reality : the first words of the Prime Minister herself , after the result of the 1987 election was knownNONMET , were an acknowledgement of the challenge posed to Government by the ‘ inner cities ’ .
What has been lackingNONMET however — as well as the political will to do something — has been any shared agreement on the cause .
Can the problems of urban poverty be blamedNONMET on individual pathology ?
On feckless parents and grandparents ?
Or on the social or physical environment — the replacement of companionably unhygienic slums by soulless tower blocks with broken lifts ( Coleman et al .
, 1985 ) ?
Or would a simple injection of resources transformNONMET Kafkaesque honeycombs into happy living-spaces , with a consequent decline in inner-city ills ?
‘ A duke can liveNONMET comfortably in a castle , after all ’ , the architect Cedric Price is quotedNONMET as sayingNONMET .
‘ You and I would dieNONMET of frostbite .
Same building — just a matter of money and management ’ ( Parkin , 1989 ) .
The view that only ‘ outstanding management ’ could meetMET the problem was heldMET by the Audit Commission ( 1987 ) .
The picture paintedMET by the Commission's report on inner London is as gruesome as any ever presentedMET ( and is itself revealing of common prejudices in its choice of indicators of deprivation ) : In some London boroughs , unemployment among young men exceedsNONMET 45% ; in some places , among young blacks , it exceedsNONMET 60% .
More than one child in three is bornNONMET into a single parent family .
Half the school leavers have no O levels or their CSE equivalents .
Homelessness , housingNONMET conditions , crime are worsening year by year , as the cycle of urban deprivation becomesNONMET more established ( p. 1 ) Drawing on North American experience , the Commission concludedMET that ‘ poor management was an important contributory factor to New York's problems ’ , and sought to applyMET the same lessons here ( p. 2 ) .
The Government's post-1987 initiatives have , to some extent , reflectedMET  a diagnosis basedMET on the need for better management — though on the principle that central authorities can provideNONMET a firmer grip than local ones — but combinedMET with an anti-collectivist belief in the restorative powers of capitalism .
Leech and Amin ( 1988 , p. 14 ) summarizeNONMET this approach , not unfairly , in the following terms : the encouragement of private investment and the liberation of the market ; the containment of the forces of social discontent ; the control of the powers of the local authorities ; and the encouragement of the movement of the wealthy into the inner city thus creatingNONMET buffer areas of Tory support , accentuatingMET inequalities and injustice and ( hopefully though not necessarily ) reducingMET the potential for conflict among the urban poor .
The main thrust of the Government's policy is containedMET in the January 1988 White Paper on Regional Policy and the Enterprise Economy , in the new Employment Training programme , and especially in the March 1988 Action for Cities programme — all resting on wider reforms to local government structure and finance , and to education and housing .
The most striking feature of this package , apart from its aim actively to involveNONMET employers and entrepreneurs , is a sharp reduction in the role of local government .
Despite the contemporary tone of much of Action for Cities , the programme's heritage can be tracedMET to the early 1960s studies which providedNONMET the basis for the 1965 Milner–Holland Report on housing and the 1967 Plowden Report on education , as a result of which general improvement areas and education priority areas were establishedNONMET .
The 1970s ‘ Urban Programme ’ had a social , rather than economic , emphasis and was administeredMET by the Home Office .
It was initiatedNONMET partly in response to the furore causedNONMET by Enoch Powell's 1969 ‘ rivers of blood ’ speech , much as disturbances at the 1976 Notting Hill Carnival promptedMET further steps on the part of the  Department of the Environment — ‘ A riot makesMET a much bigger impact on government thinking ’ , as Donnison ( 1987 ) has pointedMET out , ‘ than any amount of earnest and accurate research ’ .
The Urban Programme consistedNONMET of grants and initiatives under the 1969 Local Government Grants ( Social Need ) Act , which was intendedNONMET as a flexible instrument to provideNONMET supplementary help to local authorities in the fields of housing , education , and health .
Originally , the Programme supplementedNONMET existing central and local government schemes designedMET to meetMET special needs in urban areas .
The scope was extendedMET in an ‘ enhanced ’ Urban Programme , which includedNONMET economic and environmental as well as social projects , and was specifically directedMET at the inner urban areas where the problems were most severe .
Earlier , the change of emphasis from a ‘ social ’ to an ‘ economic and environmental ’ focus had been reflectedMET in a switch of responsibility for the Programme from the Home Office to the  Department of the Environment .
The ‘ enhanced Programme resultedNONMET from the 1978 Inner Urban Areas Act , basedMET on a White Paper , publishedNONMET the previous year , on Policy for the Inner Cities ( DoE , 1977 ) , the first comprehensive policy statement on the subject to acknowledgeNONMET it as a definable and cohesive problem .
The White Paper drewMET on studies conducted earlier in the decade in Liverpool , Birmingham , and London which pointedMET to a debilitating flight of capital and skilled labour from the critical areas of deprivation .
A key aspect of the 1977 White Paper was the stress it placed on the wider effects of poverty : that it was not just those with acute needs who sufferedNONMET .
It arguedMET that in talkingNONMET about inner cities it was vital to thinkNONMET in terms not just of individuals , but of society ; that the multiple deprivations of the worst hit areas affectedNONMET all the residents ; that the consequences includedNONMET a pervasive sense of neglect and decay , a decline in community spirit , a low standard of neighbourhood facilities , and an increase in crime and vandalism ; and that , without government intervention , the future was one of reduced job opportunities , deteriorating housing , and a decline in public services .
The document , and the legislation that derived from it , pointed to a positively discriminatory approach : with both central and local government supplementingNONMET existing programmes in such a way as to strengthenMET local economies , as well as the physical and social environment .
Such measures constitutedMET the present Government's heritage , when it tookMET office in 1979 .
None of them , of course , anticipatedNONMET the scale of the problems which were causedNONMET by the slump and collapse of much of what remainedMET of inner urban manufacturing industry in the early 1980s .
Neither , at first , did the incoming administration foreseeMET the impact of rising unemployment , which was to be especially serious among the urban young .
True , the new Secretary of State for the Environment laid stress , from the outset , on the need for economic regeneration , and indicatedMET his sympathy for the voluntary in the tackling of urban problems .
The previous Government , however , had already pointedMET to the need to revitalizeMET urban economies , and at first the shift was more rhetorical than real .
Michael Heseltine ( 1987 , p. 138 ) has since claimedNONMET that ‘ we setMET a new objective : to makeNONMET the inner cities places where people would wantNONMET to liveNONMET and workNONMET and where the private investor would be willing to putMET his money ’ .
Partnership becameNONMET his slogan — the partnership of public and private brains and money .
A new Urban Development Grant was devisedNONMET , to pump-prime with public funds schemes which would then attractMET private investment .
Heseltine's vision was of ‘ partnerships which recogniseMET that there are some things that only governments can payMET for , but also that the ingenuity and flexibility of the private sector is indispensable ’ ( p. 156 ) .
He claimsNONMET that serious work on inner-city policy beganNONMET in 1979 : but it was , undoubtedly , the riots of 1981 , coincidingNONMET with the biggest drop in employment and job vacancies since the war , which gaveMET impetus to the new approach .
Urban Development Corporations were introducedNONMET in 1981 in London Docklands and Merseyside , and the Urban Development Grant cameMET in late the following year .
Conservative instincts were , of course , to minimizeMET — within the ‘ partnership — state involvement and expenditure , relative to that of private enterprise .
Yet , the irony of the early 1980s — as a deteriorating , but perennial , urban problem rapidly became the most acute aspect of the crisis of mass unemployment — was that a Tory government , willy-nilly , foundMET itself presidingNONMET over an increase in state intervention through a variety of agencies .
The increased scale of operations also ushered in another fashion of the 1980s — new management structures .
Thus in 1985 City  Action> Teams were introducedNONMET to each ‘ Inner City Partnership ’ area to co-ordinateMET the work of the three government  departments involved .
Task forces , meanwhile , were directedMET to tackleMET youth unemployment .
By 1986/7 the Urban Programme was supporting 1,380 starter units and 400 business startsNONMET in enterprise workshops .
It was providingNONMET 27,500 training places ( often in conjunction with the Manpower Services Commission ) : some 2,500 buildings were being improvedNONMET ; estate action aimed to tackleMET run down housing ; and a large number of new ‘ partnerships ’ ( which some might seeMET as subsidies , or discredited regional grants , in a new guise ) were in operation , in an effort to bringMET private investment to run-down urban areas .
By 1988 it was claimedNONMET that £200 million of Urban Development Grant and Urban Regeneration Grant had successfully ‘ levered ’ more than £800 million of private investment into the inner cities ( although how much of the latter sum might have been investedNONMET in any case is difficult to sayMET ) .
Meanwhile , there were other incentive schemes — Enterprise Zones , for example , and simplified Planning Zones , which aimedMET to liftMET tax and planning ‘ barriers ’ in order to facilitateNONMET investment .
Indeed , while with one hand tryingNONMET to holdMET down expenditure by local authorities , the Government foundMET itself by the late 1980s involved with the other hand in massive ear-marked spending on inner urban areas .
The Department of the Environment alone by 1988 was spendingMET half a billion pounds out of an Action for Cities total , involvingNONMET most Home departments , estimated at £3 billion .
Perhaps a Labour government would have spentMET even more : it would certainly have spentMET it in different ways .
It is a curious comment on Thatcherism , however , that the administration most committedMET to a reduction in the role of the state , and in the need for an independent private sector , has spentMET more on specific urban regeneration and employment schemes and incentives to private investment in urban areas than any other in recent history .
One of the most bizarre aspects of government policy has been the effective murder of the voluntary sector , and its appropriation , by subterfuge , into the Tory version of the corporate state .
Conservatives have always laudedNONMET the ‘ voluntarist ’ principle in welfare , and encouragedMET it from platforms .
FacedMET , however , with the catastrophic increase in unemployment and the need to occupyMET large numbers of workless people without directly employingNONMET them ( which would have runMET counter to the economic doctrine which had ledMET to the redundancy of many of them in the first place ) , the Government poured money into any ‘ voluntary ’ agency willing to putMET in a bid for government-funded cheap labour .
One result was the triumphant expansion of some charitable organizations , which rejoicedMET both at their new-found importance and at the Government's munificence .
Another was the transformation of many such bodies , already heavily subsidized from public funds , into de facto agencies of the state , which financedMET them and indirectly determinedMET their policy .
Nowhere was the impact of this clumsy sleight of hand more evident than in the inner cities , where voluntary organizations had been most active , and where the Government was most anxious for them to mopMET up unemployment .
However , the later withdrawal of government support , with the scrapping of the Community Programme as unemployment recededMET , leftMET many of these voluntary organizations high and dry .
The National Council for Voluntary Organizations ( NCVO ) has suggestedMET from a recent survey that around 3,000 projects had been affectedNONMET and had lostMET £285 million in funding ( MacGregor , 1990 ) .
There was , of course , a crucial element in the Government's anxiety : the high concentration of ethnic minorities in the areas of concern .
In 1981 nearly 40 per cent of ethnic minorities in the UK livedNONMET in ‘ partnership ’ or ‘ programme ’ areas .
There is a danger in readingNONMET back from this figure another stereotype , similar to the Pavlovian ‘ drug addiction/inner city ’ assumed link .
Some urban areas have serious problems without a major ethnic dimension ( Newcastle , Teesside ) ; not all members of ethnic minorities are poor or deprived .
Nevertheless , the high proportion of inner urban populations composedNONMET of people from ethnic minorities , and the high incidence among these groups of all the indices of poverty and social and environmental hardship — combinedNONMET with the specific problem of inter-racial rivalry , harassment , and tension — makeNONMET race and ethnicity an aspect that is central to any analysis of the inner cities and of any ameliorative approach .
MAKINGMET SENSE OF THE 1981 RIOTS Reactions to the riots have concentratedMET on a number of key variables that are saidNONMET to characterizeNONMET the localities in which the riots have occurredNONMET .
Lord Scarman's report on the 1981 disorders highlightedMET the importance of unemployment , urban deprivation , racial disadvantage , relations between young blacks and the police , the decline of civic consent , and political exclusion as the key issues .
Other reactions have concentratedMET on the issue of the interplay between inner-city decay and racial disadvantage in contemporary Britain .
Yet others have arguedNONMET that the unrest can be seenMET as a symptom of the breakdown of law and order in British society ( Gaffney , 1987 ; Hall , 1987 ; Keith , 1987 ) .
The main issues that were prominent in debates during 1980–1 were ‘ race ’ and ‘ law and order ’ .
This was by no means an accident , since throughout the 1970s a powerful body of media , political , and academic opinion had been constructedMET around the theme of how Britain was driftingMET into a ‘ violent society ’ , and how the basis of consent was being shiftedMET by the pressures of immigration and the growth of multi-racial inner city areas .
A glimpse of the impact of the 1980–1 riots at this level can be achievedNONMET through two important debates in Parliament .
The first tookMET place in the midst of the July 1981 riots , and had as its theme : ‘ Civil Disturbances ’ .
The tone of the debate was setMET by Home Secretary William Whitelaw's introductory statement in which he spokeNONMET of ( a ) the need to ‘ removeMET the scourge of criminal violence from our streets ’ , and ( b ) the urgency of developing ‘ policies designedMET to promoteMET the mutual tolerance and understanding upon which the whole future of a free democratic society dependsNONMET ’ ( Hansard , vol. 8 , 16 July 1981 : col. 1405 ) .
The ‘ scourge of criminal violence ’ was , Whitelaw arguedNONMET , a danger to the whole framework of consent and legality on which the political institutions of British society were basedMET .
In reply Roy Hattersley supportedMET the call for the immediate suppression of street violence , but warnedNONMET that the roots of such riots could not be dealtNONMET with until all people feltMET they had a stake in British society ( ibid. : cols. 1407–9 ) The second debate tookMET place on 26 November 1981 , on the publication of the Scarman Report , and had as its theme : ‘ Law and Order ’ .
The importance of the riots in pushingMET the law and order issue , and specifically policingNONMET , on to the main political agenda was emphasizedMET by the Liberal leader , David Steel , who arguedNONMET that ‘ urgent action ’ to preventNONMET a drift into lawlessness was necessary from both a moral and a political perspective ( Hansard , vol. 13 , 26 November 1981 : cols. 1009–11 ) .
A subsequent debate on the same issue in March 1982 was also full of references to the experience of 1981 , the impact of street violence , crime , decaying urban conditions , the breakdown of consent between the police and many local communities , and the spectre of ‘ more violence to comeNONMET ’ if changes in both policingNONMET tactics and social policy were not swiftly introducedNONMET ( Hansard , vol. 20 , 25 March 1982 : cols. 1107–81 ) .
The need to supportMET the police was acceptedNONMET by both the Labour and the Conservative speakers in the parliamentary debate on the riots , and was establishedNONMET as a benchmark for the official response to the riots long before the Scarman Report was publishedNONMET in November 1981 .
Any substantive disagreement centred around the issue of what role social deprivation and unemployment had in bringingMET young people to protestNONMET violently on the streets .
Intermingled with the discourses about race and law and order were constant references to unemployment , particularly among the young , and various forms of social disadvantage and poverty ( Solomos , 1988 , pp. 186–911 ) .
Throughout 1980 and 1981 debates about the riots in the media , in Parliament , and in various official reports hinged around the interrelationship between racial , law-and-order , and social factors .
The importance of this debate can be explainedNONMET , partly , by the political capital which the Opposition could makeMET from linkingMET the social and economic malaise of the country at large with violent street disturbances .
Conversely , throughout this period Government Ministers strenuously denied that unemployment and social deprivation were significant causes of urban unrest .
Although the Scarman Report is often takenMET to be the central text which arguesMET for a link between ‘ social conditions ’ and ‘ disorder ’ , the terms of the debate were by no means setMET by Scarman .
During both April and July 1981 vigorous exchanges tookMET place in the press and in Parliament about the role that deteriorating social conditions and unemployment may have playedMET in bringingNONMET about the riots .
During the 16 July parliamentary debate on ‘ Civil Disturbances ’ , Roy Hattersley's formulation of this linkage providedNONMET a useful summary of the ‘ social conditions ’ argument .
After some preliminary remarks about the Labour party's support for the police , he wentNONMET on to outlineMET his opposition to the view of the riots as essentially anti-police outbursts : I repeatNONMET that l do not believeNONMET that the principal cause of last week's riots was the conduct of the police .
It was the conditions of deprivation and despair in the decaying areas of our old cities — areas in which the Brixton and ToxtethNONMET riots tookMET place , and areas from which the skinhead invaders of Southall comeNONMET .
( Hansard , vol. 8 , 16 July 1981 : col. 1408 ) Much of the subsequent controversy about this analysis centred on the question of youth unemployment .
Hattersley had suggestedNONMET that the riots were a ‘ direct product ’ of high levels of youth unemployment , and a furious debate ensuedNONMET in both Parliament and the media about this assertion .
The final symbolic cue used to makeMET sense of the 1980–1 protests is more difficult to categorizeNONMET , but its basic meaning can be capturedMET by the term ‘ political marginality ’ .
While a number of discussions of the roots of urban unrest in the United States have notedMET the salience of political marginality in determining participation in violent protests ( Skolnick , 1969 ; Fogelson , 1971 ; Edelman , 1971 ; Knopf , 1975 ) , this issue has receivedMET relatively little attention in Britain .
Nevertheless , during the 1980–1 events and their aftermath the political context was discussedNONMET from a number of perspectives .
The Scarman Report , for example , located part of the explanation for the riots in the feelings of alienation and powerlessness which were experiencedNONMET by young blacks livingNONMET in depressed inner-city areas .
A successful policy for tacklingMET the roots of urban disorder was seenMET as one which soughtMET to involveNONMET all the community in dealingNONMET with the problems of each area so that they could comeMET to feelMET that they have a stake in its future ( Scarman , 1981 , para. 6.42 ) .
Where such arguments did not fitNONMET in with the overarching themes of race , violence and disorder , and social deprivation they were either sidelinedMET or pushed into the sub-clauses of official reports .
The Scarman Report , for example , containedMET the following policy proposal : ‘ I recommendNONMET that local communities must be fully and effectively involved in planning , in the provision of local services , and in the management and financing of specific projects , ( Scarman , 1981 , para. 8.44 ) .
Such a move towards greater political integration was seenMET by Lord Scarman as essential if the gap between inner-city residents and the forces of law and order was to be bridgedMET .
But the concern with overcomingMET political marginality remained on the sidelines of the main public debate because it questionedMET the perception of the rioters as drivenMET by irrational , uncivilized , and criminal instincts .
This did not , however , stopMET the question of political marginality and the need to reformNONMET existing policies from being raisedMET at all , as can be seenMET subsequently by the attempts after 1981 to introduceNONMET both locally and nationally measures which were meantNONMET to addressMET some of the grievances of the rioters and to ensureNONMET that further disturbances did not occurNONMET .
Aspects of these measures are consideredNONMET further on in the chapter .
PERSPECTIVES ON THE 1985 RIOTS Despite widespread predictions of further unrest in the aftermath of 1981 , the scale and the location of the 1985 riots seemNONMET to have surprised even some of the most astute commentators .
Handsworth , for example , was presentedMET even shortly before September 1985 as a ‘ success story ’ in terms of police — community relations .
The outbreak of violence in this area was therefore widely presentedMET as an aberration .
Similarly the spread of violence in London to areas such as the Broadwater Farm Estate in Tottenham was seenMET as a break from previous experience , which had centredMET on areas such as Brixton .
There are many continuities between 1980–1 and 1985 in relation to the common-sense images used in the press and television to coverMET the events .
But responses in 1985 were different , at least in terms of degree , and probably in relation to the extent to which the riots were seenMET as a ‘ race ’ phenomenon by a wider body of opinion .
The ambiguities and sub-clauses to be foundMET in much of the press coverage during 1980–1 had at least actedMET as a countervailing tendency against the more extreme forms of discourse which blamedMET the riots completely on black people .
During the 1985 riots and their immediate aftermath , the imagery of ‘ race ’ was usedMET by sections of the press without the sense of ambiguity which could still be foundMET in 1980–1 .
The ‘ silence over race ’ was breachedMET in 1980–1 , but in 1985 debate about racial issues was takenMET a step further .
Peregrine Worsthorne , for example , usedNONMET the ferocity of the confrontations in Handsworth , Brixton , and Tottenham to argueNONMET that there was a major question mark over the possibility of assimilatingNONMET the ‘ coloured population ’ into mainstream ‘ British values ’ ( Sunday Telegraph , 29 September 1985 ) .
To be sure there was still a strong response opposing Enoch Powell's call for repatriation , from all shades of political opinion , but the racialization of public debate about the 1985 riots wentMET much further than 1980–1 .
In this context it was the externality of British Afro-Caribbeans and Asians which was highlightedMET rather the racist institutions and processes which workedMET against blacks at all levels of society .
The usage of ‘ race ’ during the September-October 1985 period tookMET on new meanings , which had little if anything to do with the impact of racism as such , since the emphasis was on the cultural characteristics of the minority communities themselves .
After Handsworth part of the press response was to blameNONMET the riot on rivalry between West Indians and Asians , and even after the arguments were criticizedNONMET by local residents ; and community leaders , they were usedNONMET to ‘ explainNONMET ’ ' what happenedNONMET .
In addition , the question whether the cultures and values of the black communities , their family structures , and their political attitudes ‘ bred violence ’ was constantly raisedMET ( van Dijk , 1988 ) .
The actual facts ' of who was arrestedNONMET during the riots , whether black or white , were hardly debatedNONMET since it was assumedMET that they were mostly black and mostly unemployed and involved with crime ( Keith , 1987 ) .
The imagery of the ‘ black bomber , used in Handsworth was extendedMET to the notion that there were groups of alienated and criminalizedNONMET young blacks who sawMET the riots as a chance to engageMET in an ‘ orgy of looting ’ .
The Dear Report on Handsworth capturesMET this image and linksMET it to the social condition of young blacks : The majority of rioters who tookMET part in these unhappy events were young , black and Afro-Caribbean origin .
LetMET there be no doubt , these young criminals are not in any way representative of the vast majority of the Afro-Caribbean community whose life has contributedMET to the life and culture of the West Midlands over many years and whose hopes and aspirations are at one with those of every other law-abiding citizen .
We shareMET a common sorrow .
It is the duty of us all to ensureNONMET that an entire cultural group is not taintedMET by the actions of a criminal minority .
( Dear , 1985 , p. 69 ) This ‘ black ’ criminal minority was constructedMET not only into the leading force behind the riots , but sometimes as the only force .
Indeed , throughout September and October 1985 , and during the following months , the imagery of race continuedMET to dominateMET debate about both the causes and the policy outcomes of the riots .
As pointedMET out earlier , the ‘ social causes ’ argument was another major plank of public debate about the 1980–1 riots , particularly in relation to the highly politicized issue of unemployment .
During 1985 this issue was raisedMET once again , though by then the extent of mass unemployment and urban de-industrialization and decay was more stark than it had been in 198l .
Images of ‘ urban decay ’ , ‘ tinderbox cities ’ , and ‘ ghetto streets ’ linkedMET up with the images of ‘ race inequality ’ and ‘ black ghettos ’ to produceMET an analysis more complex but also more contradictory .
An interesting mixture of the various images was providedNONMET by a story in the Daily Telegraph under the headline : ‘ Broadwater Farm : Like the Divis Flats with Reggae ’ ( 8 October 1985 ) .
The Mirror describedMET the estate as ‘ Living Hell ’ , and quotedMET one resident as sayingNONMET that ‘ You ' ve no idea how awful daily life is ’ ( 8 October 1985 ) .
Such images were reworkings of arguments already usedNONMET about Toxteth in 1981 and Brixton in 1981 , but they were usedNONMET more widely than in 1980–1 .
Even the Daily Mail , which deployedMET the clearest use of ‘ race ’ and ‘ outside agitator ’ arguments , ranMET a major story on Broadwater Farm under the headline : ‘ Burnt-out hulks litterMET this concrete jungle … despair hangsMET heavy ’ ( 8 October 1985 ) .
A number of stories usingNONMET such imagery were runMET by both the quality and the popular press during this period , but similar arguments are to be foundMET in parliamentary debates ( Hansard , vol. 84 , 21 October 1985 , cols. 30-.46 , 388 ) , and even in official reports producedNONMET by the police on the riots in Birmingham and London .
The ‘ cities of inner despair ’ were conceivedMET as the breeding ground for disorderly protest , and however hard the Government triedNONMET to breakMET the causal link between the two , it was forcedMET to takeMET on board the need to restoreMET order not only through the police but through promises of help for the inner cities .
Much as in 1980–1 , the ‘ social causes ’ argument can not be seenMET separately from the broader debate about the future of the British economy and society .
The Government's record on unemployment was a heavily politicized issue , and just as in 1981 it vehemently deniedMET any responsibility for the riots through its pursuit of free-market policies .
But the Government did findMET a way of acceptingNONMET a link between the riots and social problems without bringingMET its main policies into the debate : namely by linkingMET the growth of violent disorder to crime and drugs .
The emphasis on ‘ crime ’ and the ‘ criminal acts ’ of the rioters in the official responses to the 1985 riots tookMET a general and a specific form .
The general form relied on the argument that the riots were not a form of protest against the insufferable social conditions of inner-city areas or the actions of the police , but a ‘ criminal act ’ or a ‘ cry for loot ’ .
This was an argument putMET most succinctly by Geoffrey Dear , Chief Constable of the West Midlands ( Dear , 1985 ) and by Douglas Hurd , the Home Secretary , in relation to Handsworth .
But it recurredNONMET as a theme in official and press responses to the other riots .
The specific form was builtMET upon the notion that the outbreak of violence in Handsworth and Brixton , in particular , was broughtNONMET about by ‘ drug barons ’ who sawMET the police attemptingNONMET to curbNONMET their activities and controlNONMET ‘ their territory ’ .
Numerous examples of this line of argument can be foundMET in Dear's report on Handsworth , and in press coverage during the riots .
TakingMET the specific argument about the role of drugs and ‘ drug barons ’ in stimulating the riots , this seemsNONMET to have servedMET two purposes .
First , it distancedMET the riots from the social , economic , political , and other grievances which had been linkedMET to them by locatingMET the cause outside the ‘ social problems ’ of inner-city dwellers and in the ‘ simple greed ’ of the drug barons to accumulateNONMET ‘ loot ’ .
Second , just as Dear's image of a few hundred ‘ young black criminals ’ was usedNONMET to explainNONMET what happenedNONMET in Handsworth , the problem of drugs was usedNONMET to explainNONMET what happenedNONMET at a national level .
The issue of drugs provided an everyday image , already a national issue through saturation media coverage and public debate , around which the police , the Home Office , and other institutions could depoliticizeMET the riots .
RespondingNONMET to the Handsworth events Douglas Hurd was movedMET to argueNONMET forcibly that such events were senseless and reflected more on those who participatedNONMET in them than on the society in which they tookMET place : ‘ The sound which law abiding people in Handsworth heardNONMET on Monday night , the echoes of which I pickedMET up on Tuesday , was not a cry for help but a cry for loot ’ ( Financial Times , 13 September 1985 ) .
The Chief Constable for the West Midlands , Geoffrey Dear , tookMET this argument further by pointingMET out that the day before the riots a successful carnival had takenMET place , with the support of local community leaders .
He drewMET the conclusion from this that the riot ‘ cameMET like a bolt out of the blue ’ ( Guardian , 21 November 1985 ) .
Such language focused attention on the individuals or groups who were ‘ breakingMET the law ’ , ‘ committingMET criminal acts ’ , and threateningMET the interests of the law-abiding ‘ majority ’ .
PART 2 Sociology and crime ExplainingNONMET crime : theories of criminality Most people have their own notions or theories as to what causesNONMET criminal behaviour .
For example , lack of discipline in the home , genetic defects , poverty , mixingMET with the ‘ wrong sort ’ have all been proposedNONMET as causes of criminality .
While such notions may all containsMET some elements of truth , they are by no means complete explanations of criminal behaviour .
This chapter will examineMET a range of theories which attemptMET to explainNONMET such behaviour .
Although the major theoretical explanations are coveredMET in the numerous introductions to the sociology of crime and deviance and to sociology generally , some review of these theories is necessary before embarkingMET upon an examination of specific , substantive examples of criminal behaviour .
As this is not a book on criminological theories , what followsMET will be a brief overview of a wide range of theories and explanations .
First , a word of warning might be in order .
It would be naive to expectNONMET to uncoverMET any ultimate explanation or basic cause for criminal behaviour , givenNONMET the extensive and diverse behaviour that is encompassedMET by the term crime .
SupposeNONMET , for example , that it could be provedNONMET that one cause of delinquency was lack of parental supervision .
It might still be necessary to askNONMET why delinquency occurredNONMET with one son or daughter but not another .
Also , there would be the further question of why the parents had not providedNONMET adequate supervision .
Perhaps this was because of their poor living conditions which would raiseMET the question of why they were in poor housing .
Was this because of governmental housing policy or a poor employment record on the part of the bread-winner of the family ?
Clearly , we are gettingMET further and further away from the causes of delinquent behaviour , and it is perhaps wisest to thinkNONMET in terms of causal processes when lookingMET at criminal behaviour .
Biological and psychological theories Before examiningNONMET the major sociological pespectives on crime , it is useful to referNONMET to theories from outside of sociology , from other academic disciplines .
Thus , we will lookMET initially at biological and psychological theories .
Biological theories Biological ( or physiological ) explanations are basedMET on the notion that some individuals are predisposedNONMET to criminal behaviour because of their genetic make-up .
The individual criminal is bornNONMET so ; and this is usually putMET down to ‘ faulty chromosome patterns ’ , or , more vaguely , to ‘ hereditary traits ’ .
The most famous exponent of this approach was the nineteenth-century Italian physician , Cesare Lombroso .
