In his book L'Uomo Delinquente , Lombroso developedNONMET a complex description of what he calledMET the ‘ born criminal ’ , who could be recognisedNONMET by a variety of physical characteristics , in particular facial characteristics — for example large jaws and ears , and high cheek bones .
In the medical faculty at the University of Rome there is a gallery of portraits of splendidly ugly delinquents who were usedNONMET to illustrateMET Lombroso's theory .
To useNONMET his own language : Thus were explainedNONMET anatomically the enormous jaws , high cheek bones , prominent superciliary arches , solitary lines on the palms , extreme size of the orbits , handle shaped or sessile ears found in criminals , savages and apes , insensibility of pain , extremely acute sight , tattooingNONMET , excessive idleness , love of orgies and the irresistable craving for evil for its own sake … These explanations seeMET the delinquent individual as inherently more prone to criminal behaviour than the non-delinquent .
They have been widely criticisedNONMET and rejected by sociologists .
Lombroso's work , for example , was basedMET on his examination of people in prison in Italy .
This would , necessarily , ignoreMET the fact that many criminals do not goNONMET to prison , and that , perhaps , people in prison are not always criminal .
Most advocates of biological theories do not expressMET themselves in the same bizarre language and style as Lombroso , and such theories of crime are not merely historical relics that diedMET with Lombroso .
In a major study of institutionalised delinquents ( delinquents in some form of custody ) in the USA in the 1950s , Sheldon and Eleanor Glueck foundMET that delinquent boys were twice as likely to have a mesomorphic build , a chunky , muscular phsique , comparedNONMET with non-delinquent boys .
However , the fact that the study was restrictedMET to institutionalised delinquents limitsNONMET the validity of the association between body build and crime and delinquency .
It may be that tougher delinquents are more liable to be putMET away than fragile looking ones .
Furthermore , it has been foundMET that the association between delinquency on the one hand and height , weight and physique on the other is greatly reduced once social , background factors are takenMET into account .
For example , lower working-class people are more likely to be mesomorphic as a result of their diet and continual manual labour , and this class grouping is more likely to be foundMET representedNONMET in the criminal statistics .
With regard to the links between criminal behaviour and inherited characteristics , there have been a number of theoretical explanations suggestingMET an association between criminality and particular personality characteristics .
An example of this more sophisticated biological approach is the work of Hans Eysenck , who has arguedNONMET in a series of studies , that there is a link between genetically basedNONMET personality characteristics and criminal behaviour .
He maintainsMET that there is a link between characteristics such as extroversion and criminal behaviour .
An individual's degree of extroversion or introversion is inheritedMET , determinedMET by his or her genetic make-up .
The link with crime foundMET by Eysenck was that when prisoners were testedNONMET for extroversion , more extroverts were foundMET than in the general population .
Eysenck then arguesNONMET that extroversion is the inherited basis of criminal behaviour .
Extroverts takeMET longer to learnNONMET the rules of society , they are more likely to breakMET them , and thus more likely becomeNONMET convicted criminals .
As with Lombroso's work and the Gluecks ' study discussed above , by startingNONMET with institutionalised criminals , it is assumedMET that all prisoners are criminals and that most criminals do , in fact , goNONMET to prison .
The people who getNONMET caughtNONMET and imprisoned may not be a representative picture of all criminals .
The major problem facedMET by theories suggestingMET a link between genetic make-up and criminal behaviour is the difficulty of distinguishing between genetic and environmental effects .
While some genetic influence can not be ruled out , just what is inheritedMET remains very unclear .
Psychological theories These theories shareMET certain similarities with biological explanations .
They stressMET the link between criminal behaviour and specific personality traits or characteristics .
Psychological theories , however , seeMET these characteristics as a result of unusual or abnormal experiences , rather than as inheritedMET .
Thus , as with biological theories , crime is seenMET as pathological ( a disease ) , as something to be lookedMET at from the medical point of view .
However , psychological causes are seenNONMET as treatable , whereas biological causes markMET the individual for life .
In those cases there is no possible treatment , one is bornNONMET a criminal .
Many psychological theories referMET to faulty parent-child relationships , such as abnormal experiences in early childhood having a lasting effect and influence on personality .
Studies in this area have indicatedMET that too strict or too lax parental attitudes increaseNONMET the risk of delinquency ( the work of John Bowlby , for example ) ; they have foundMET that if a young child is deprived of close personal relationships with parents or parent figures then ‘ problem behaviour ’ is more common .
It is well established that in the delinquent-prone , home discipline is more liable to be too lax , strict or erratic .
However , it is patently obvious that parents can be a good or bad influence and example for their children , and this fact can hardly be usedNONMET to explainMET present patterns of crime .
The majority of offenders do not comeNONMET from disturbed or broken homes , and many broken homes do not produceMET delinquents .
Of course , this last point does not showMET that there is no link between parent-child relations and crime and delinquency .
The problem with assessingMET the influence of parental and family dimensions , such as weak supervision or parental criminality , is the fact that they are closely linkedMET to various aspects of social and economic disadvantage , such as poverty , overcrowdingNONMET and poor housing .
And it may be that these disadvantages helpNONMET to causeNONMET parental difficulties , and hamper good parenting .
We can hardly do justice to the wide scope of psychological theories here , but there are some basic ideas and assumptions which underlie such theorizing .
These stressMET the importance of family relationships and upbringing during the early years , and concludeMET that anti-social , and by implication criminal , behaviour results from faulty personality development .
To summariseNONMET , these biological and psychological theories holdMET that the criminal is a particular type of person , apart from the rest of society and with a special predisposition toward criminal behaviour .
They are basedMET on the idea that criminal behaviour is either inheritedMET or a consequence of unique , individual experiences .
Before we lookMET at sociological explanations it might be useful to askNONMET yourself , or to discussNONMET with colleagues , whether you feelMET that criminals are different ‘ types ’ of person .
While there are , no doubt , predispositions toward criminal behaviour , and clearly certain characteristics are inheritedMET , most sociologists would rejectNONMET these ‘ individual pathology ’ sort of theories .
They lackNONMET convincing supporting evidence .
While some offenders sufferNONMET from mental disorders the vast majority do not .
Furthermore , if criminals are abnormal then it followsMET that a large proportion of the population must also be abnormal .
For numerous studies have shownMET that a high percentage of the population have committedNONMET criminal offences , in particular high proportions of juveniles , and it is difficult to believeNONMET that they are all different or abnormal .
Sociological theories We saidNONMET above that sociologists would rejectNONMET non-sociological explanations of crime .
This is not because such explanations are ‘ wrong ’ , but because they are incomplete or inadequate .
In Chapter One , it was stressedMET that crime can not be consideredMET aside from its social context , that it is dependent on society definingNONMET certain actions as criminal , and on the reaction of others to such actions .
Potential Applications Overview Ian Masser GivenNONMET the extent to which geographic information management is applications driven , it is important to considerMET in some depth the characteristics of some potential application fields .
In the process it will be necessary to examineMET not only the extent to which geographic issues feature on the policy issues agenda in these fields but also the institutional context which governsMET decision-making and the extent to which data are available for research and policy analysis purposes .
Questions on data availability are likely to be particularly important where users are heavily dependent on secondary sources .
In situations of this kind provisions governing access and format may exertMET powerful constraints on the use that can be madeMET of these data .
The first four chapters in this part examineMET issues relatingNONMET to geographic information handling in terms of four potential applications fields .
The authors were askedNONMET to reviewNONMET the current state of the art in their fields with particular reference to the likely requirements of the future policy issues agenda in terms of the demands that they makeMET on geographic information management .
Authors were also askedNONMET to evaluateNONMET critically the state of geographic information provision in terms of the needs of users and to considerMET the impact of user requirements on the development of geographic information handling methodology .
In this way the chapters in this part present a number of perspectives which essentially complement and amplifyMET the discussion in the previous part .
In this case , however , methodological issues are tackledMET from a largely user standpoint , whereas in the previous part they were viewedMET as substantive problems in their own right .
In effect the product of the discussion in both parts is a matrix where the methodological issues are listedMET along one axis and particular applications fields on the other .
Figure 8.1 summarizesMET the main features of this matrix .
There are important differences between the chapters in this part both in the nature of the demands that they makeMET on geographic information and also in the relative importance that is attachedMET to geographic criteria as against other issues by planners and decision-makers in these fields .
The first three chapters dealingMET with environmental monitoring , natural and technological hazards and settlements and infrastructure applications makeMET use of a very wide range of geographic information .
A major feature of these applications is the extent to which they involveNONMET overlays of a variety of information drawnMET from different sources on a topographic map base .
for this reason they makeMET particularly heavy demands on current GIS technology both because of the size of the data  sets and the diversity of the data structures that are involvedNONMET .
Brown's chapter on geodemographics discussesMET an application field where primary data collected for operational purposes are typically evaluatedNONMET in relation to secondary data derivedMET from sources such as the Census of Population .
The range of data sets involved and the demands that are madeMET on GIS technology in applications of this kind are often more limited than those of previous applications fields .
However , this is offsetNONMET by the demands that are madeMET on spatial analysis and modelling methodology .
Rhind's chapter on environmental monitoring and prediction discussesMET the role of geographic information management in promotingNONMET sustainable development on a global scale in the context of the issues identifiedMET in the Brundtland report .
It pointsMET to the impact that the findings of global environmental research are likely to have on most sectors of the UK economy .
This contribution also indicatesMET the wide variety of groups that are involved in monitoringNONMET environmental change and drawsMET attention to the role that the European Community is increasingly playingMET in co-ordinatingMET these efforts .
One of the examples of work in progress discussesMET research that has been carried out for the European Commission as part of the CORINE Project .
This highlightsMET the challenges for research in a field categorizedNONMET by a lack of data for some countries , varying definitions and standards in use , and unreasonably high user expectations .
The chapter as a whole drawsMET attention to a number of key methodological issues that are involved in environmental monitoring and prediction .
These includeMET the highly specialized nature of much of the technical analysis , the limited capacity for checkingNONMET the accuracy of many of the findings of this kind of research and the consequent need for the development  of knowledge- based inference machines for extractingMET useful information from secondary and often proxy data .
In Chapter 10 Gatrell and Vincent considerNONMET a wide range of natural and technological hazards including industrial hazards , risk assessment , hazardous waste disposal , emergency planning , natural hazards and environmental epidemiology .
The substantive content of much of this research straddlesNONMET the social , environmental and mathematical sciences .
To modelNONMET the dispersal of a plume of toxic gas generatedNONMET by a chemical explosion and its impact on the surrounding area , for example , an understanding of atmospheric dispersion models , epidemiology and population distribution would be requiredNONMET .
In applications of this kind the authors argueNONMET that geographic information management in general and GIS in particular have an important role to playNONMET and they giveNONMET a number of examples from research in progress to illustrateNONMET the current state of the art in this field .
The discussion of operational problems and prospects further amplifiesNONMET many of the issues raisedNONMET in preceding chapters , particularly with respect to the problems causedNONMET by the dependency on secondary data sources and the need for much more detailed geographic information to overcomeNONMET some of the problems associatedNONMET with linkingNONMET data sets .
Like most of the other contributors to this section , Gatrell and Vincent seeNONMET decision support systems as a major area for future development in the geographic information management field .
Given that ‘ most GIS are rather dumb systems , requiringNONMET intelligent , very computer literate users ’ , managing natural and technological hazards meansNONMET that this knowledge base must be builtNONMET into the system so that it can be utilizedNONMET quickly by untrained users after a disaster has takenNONMET place or in an emergency .
The settlement and infrastructure field is also characterizedNONMET by a wide range of users with a great diversity of interests .
These includeNONMET not only central and local government but also major utility companies and transport suppliers .
According to Shepherd these users shareNONMET a common need for up-to-date information on the amount , capacity and condition of urban land , transport networks , utilities , hospitals , schools and other major communal facilities .
In addition to these data requirements , such users are also interested in developingNONMET their capabilities for modellingNONMET the changing relationships between the supply and demand for infrastructure in the context of both public and private sector decision-making .
Shepherd , more than any other contributor to this section , drawsNONMET attention to the extent to which current efforts in the geographic information management field are constrainedNONMET by the highly fragmented nature of both data suppliers and users both in sectoral and spatial terms , the great diversity of data sets in varying formats and the difficulties presentedNONMET by institutional factors such as copyright provision , data ownership and the control of access to data .
Digital data occupyNONMET a central position in this applications field and a number of examples are givenNONMET to illustrateNONMET the extent to which their development has been hamperedNONMET or facilitated in various countries by the policies of the organizations with responsibility for digital data provision .
In Chapter 12 Brown reviewsNONMET the development of geodemographics from its origins in the computer-based social area analysis of US census tract data from 1950 onwards .
He describesNONMET the features of the four main systems that are currently in use in the UK and illustratesNONMET their application with reference to examples drawnNONMET from retail analysis and store location , market research , credit rating and target marketing .
Brown demonstratesNONMET the extent to which the growth of research activities in this field has ledNONMET to the emergence of improved cluster analytic methods for the multidimensional classification of people according to the type of area in which they liveNONMET .
In the last part of this contribution , Brown identifiesNONMET a number of priorities for future research .
Like Gatrell and Vincent and Shepherd before him , he is concerned with the lack of detailed geographical information particularly in this case with reference to the years between censuses .
Spatial linkages also feature prominently in Brown's discussion which amplifiesNONMET many of the points made in the earlier contribution from Openshaw in Chapter 3 .
The analysis points to the need for the development of a fuzzy geodemographics methodology which takesNONMET account of the effects of different types of spatial errors .
Other major research priorities for the future in this applications field are the development of response-modelling techniques to exploreNONMET the factors affectingNONMET consumer choice .
This is particularly important in a field where many of the demands madeNONMET by users are highly specializedNONMET in nature .
In summary , then , as fig. 8.1 showsNONMET , many of the issues raisedNONMET by this review of geographic information handling in the four potential application fields are essentially complementary to those discussedNONMET in the part on methodological developments .
Spatial analysis features particularly prominent on the research agenda relatingNONMET to natural and technological hazards and geodemographics .
Questions relatingNONMET to data integration emergeNONMET as being particularly critical in terms of environmental monitoring and settlement and infrastructure applications .
Spatial linkages and questions relatingNONMET to spatial representation feature prominently in the settlements and infrastructure and geodemographics fields .
The evaluation of error propagation is a matter of considerable significance in the environmental monitoring and settlements and infrastructure fields .
Finally , in all applications fields , the findings of the reviews above suggestNONMET that there is a need for improvements in user interfaces of all kinds .
This is particularly evident in the demand for the development of knowledge-based decision support systems and modelling capabilities .
Such demands highlightNONMET the extent to which geographic information management must be regardedNONMET as a means to an end rather than an end in itself when viewedNONMET from the standpoints of the needs of planners and decision-makers .
The final chapter in this section roundsNONMET off the discussion of applications-related research with an examination of organizational issues that need to be takenNONMET account of in handlingNONMET geographic information .
Campbell presentsNONMET a conceptual framework for the analysis of the organizational issues involvedNONMET in the development and implementation of GIS .
This contribution cuts across many of the questions relatingNONMET to particular applications that were raisedNONMET in preceding chapters and drawsNONMET attention to the dangers of neglectingNONMET institutional and personal considerations in practice .
All too often , as the experience of many mature applications indicatesNONMET , technical and data-related matters dominateNONMET the system development phase and technically elegant solutions are devisedNONMET which failNONMET to takeNONMET enough account of user needs and capabilities .
Campbell discussesNONMET the role of geographic information in organizations and the process of GIS diffusion drawing upon research from a variety of social science disciplines .
The findings of the analysis are summarizedNONMET in two sets of research questions for all applications fields .
In this way she setsNONMET out a research agenda for applications-related research which servesNONMET a similar function to the spatial analysis research agenda set out by Openshaw at the beginning of Part Two .
Environmental monitoring and prediction David Rhind Introduction Monitoring of the state of and the changes in the environment is now universally recognizedNONMET as being of profound importance to mankind ( Tickell 1986 , 1989 ) .
This awareness is most obviously manifestedNONMET by the frequent appearance of press reports on ozone depletion , on the greenhouse effect and possible global warming , on nitrate pollution , on deforestation in the Tropics , on decreasing biological diversity and on many other environmentally related topics .
Usually these reports concentrateNONMET on prophecies of a forthcoming Armageddon but many also describeNONMET a dire contemporary situation .
Thus the algal bloom off the Italian Adriatic shore in 1989 is reckonedNONMET to have causedNONMET the holiday trade and local fisherman losses runningNONMET into tens if not hundreds of millions of pounds .
More globally , the Brundtland Report ( WCED 1987 ) notedNONMET that , in the 900 days during which the World Commission was at work , 1 .
The African drought putNONMET the lives of 35 million people at risk and may have killedNONMET 1 million of them ; 2 .
The Bhopal accident killed 2000 and injuredNONMET 200 000 more ; 3 .
The Chernobyl disaster caused environmental damage across Europe ; 4 .
A chemical fire in Switzerland causedNONMET toxic materials to be transportedNONMET by the Rhine at least as far as the Netherlands ; 5 .
At least 60 million people diedNONMET of diarrhoeal diseases causedNONMET by malnutrition and dirty water .
As a consequence of these and other disasters , of rapid and world-wide broadcasting of them and of the concerned action of many individuals , the environment is now ‘ movingNONMET fast up the political agenda ’ ( Patten 1989 ) .
The then Prime Minister also emphasized the political awakening to the environment in statements such as : ‘ it is possible that with all these enormous changes ( population , agricultural , use of fossil fuels ) concentrated into such a short period of time , we have unwittingly begunNONMET a massive experiment with the system of this planet itself ’ ( Thatcher 1988 ) .
The political concern is not altruistic .
Mrs Thatcher , a recent convert to environmental conservation , clearly held the opinion that environmental problems are not only soluble but that solvingNONMET them can be shownNONMET to be cost-effective : In the past when we identifiedNONMET forms of pollution , we have shownNONMET our capacity to actNONMET effectively .
The great London smogs are now only a nightmare of the past .
We have cutNONMET airborne lead by 50 per cent .
We are spendingNONMET £4 billion on cleansingNONMET the Mersey Basin alone , and the Thames now has the cleanest metropolitan estuary in the world .
Even though this kind of action may costNONMET a lot , I believeNONMET it to be money well and necessarily spentNONMET because the health of our economy and the health of our environment are totally dependent upon each other … .
The Government espousesNONMET the concept of sustainable economic development .
Stable prosperity can be achievedNONMET throughout the world provided the environment is nurturedNONMET and safeguardedNONMET ( Thatcher 1988 ) .
The primary official manifestation of this UK commitment to the environment has been the government's White Paper ( HMSO 1990 ) .
While criticizedNONMET by many on the grounds that it had few ‘ teeth ’ and representedNONMET a compromise between the DoE and all other departments ( notably those of Agriculture and of Transport ) , it was none the less a major achievement .
Its main sections dealtNONMET with the government's approach to the environment ( nationally , at the European level and globally ) , the nature and effects of the greenhouse effect , environmental problems in both rural and urban areas ( especially in relation to land-use matters ) , pollution control and enhancingNONMET awareness of environmental matters .
Central to this approach is saidNONMET to be an emphasis upon guidance from the best available scientific evidence .
There is also a clear recognition of the need for monitoring and modelling of the state of the natural and man-influenced environment .
Though there has been a change of Prime Minister and of the Secretary of State for the Environment since the publication of the White Paper , the environmental cause seemsNONMET as strong as ever .
Thus , The Times of 17 December 1990 reportedNONMET that a group of 40 of the most senior Civil Servants had metNONMET the previous weekend to discussNONMET ‘ ways in which the government machine could respondNONMET better to national and international problems such as the threat of global climate change ’ .
Pearce et al. ( 1989 ) have arguedNONMET that the effects of government , commercial and other actions on the environment can and should be assessedNONMET on a cost/benefit basis and this seemsNONMET likely to be the basis on which at least the UK government will proceedNONMET .
GivenNONMET such a lead , it is scarcely surprising that British scientists have soughtNONMET to demonstrateNONMET the practical and financial consequences of environmental events and processes ; Table 9.1 , for example illustratesNONMET their perception of the importance of global environmental research to the UK domestic economy .
If it now seemsNONMET self-evident that monitoring of the global environment is necessary , indeed is even vital , the prediction of what is likely to happenNONMET is almost as important : the 170 000 people in the Maldives are understandably worried about the prospect of global sea-level change since no part of the islands is more than 2 m above present sea-level !
Yet , as we shall seeNONMET below , the prediction of the activities of natural and man-influenced environmental systems requiresNONMET an understanding of the interaction of processes that , in many cases , we simply do not yet have .
Even monitoring of the present is very imperfect , as witness the order of magnitude variations in estimates now current for deforestation rates .
This chapter , then , attempts to reviewNONMET some of the problems in environmental monitoring and prediction , describesNONMET some of the relevant scientific and organizational activities and looksNONMET ahead to what is likely to happenNONMET next .
The nature of environmental processes Notwithstanding Mrs Thatcher's confidence that we can ‘ fixNONMET ’ environmental problems , the difficulties associatedNONMET with a task even as apparently simple as monitoringNONMET a state variable are considerable .
Some of the reasons for this — the difficulty of decidingNONMET on appropriate proxy variables and on economical yet non-biasing temporal and spatial sampling frameworks , takingNONMET account of the relative importance of aperiodic and rare events as comparedNONMET to near-continuous processes , processingNONMET the vast volumes of data usually involvedNONMET and organizingNONMET the multidisciplinary and ( often ) multinational researchers involved — are discussedNONMET briefly later .
Even at this stage , however , it is important to stressNONMET that we have a very incomplete understanding of many processes in the natural environment .
The next section therefore attemptsNONMET to summarizeNONMET what we do knowNONMET ; it is derivedNONMET chiefly from the Earth System Sciences Committee ( ESSC ) ( 1988 ) .
Temporal and spatial scales of operation Even ignoringNONMET the effects of man , earth system processes operateNONMET at a variety of spatial and temporal scales ( seeNONMET Fig. 9.1 ; seeNONMET also Rosswall et al. 1988 ) .
Thus microclimate effects can have major short-term implications for local populations ( such as those broughtNONMET about by the photochemical smogs of Los Angeles ) , are often applicable only over areas of a few hectares or less and may operateNONMET on a diurnal cycle .
In contrast , soil creation ( cf.NONMET soil degradation ) may requireNONMET hundreds or thousands of years .
In between are variations in phenomena such as El Nino .
The sampling theorem indicatesNONMET that we must sampleNONMET these phenomena at a frequency of no less than half their wavelength if we are to avoidNONMET bias in measurement .
In this chapter , the primary concern is with changes occurringNONMET over time spans from minutes to centuries and from spatial wavelengths from about 1 m to about 100 km .
It is , however , impossible to separateNONMET out processes actingNONMET at different scales and over different periods : a single volcanic eruption lasting hours or days sometimes leadsNONMET to dustNONMET and gas being ejectedNONMET into the atmosphere over a period of months and this in turn may leadNONMET to global climatic fluctuations over years or decades .
Conversely , a large-scale and long-period phenomenon such as the movement of tectonic plates can leadNONMET to local stress accumulation and to its release by an earthquake in a few seconds and with highly local effects .
This therefore has the following consequences : 1 .
We should knowNONMET something about the periodicity of the variables we are monitoringNONMET if we are not to riskNONMET either unnecessarily detailed data collection or aliasing of trends ; 2 .
Since we knowNONMET that the periodicity of some variables is longer than the monitoring already carriedNONMET out by human beings , we must makeNONMET use of surrogate or proxy variables to extendNONMET our range of knowledge ( such as via tree rings , palynology , oxygen isotope ratios from ice cores and geomorphological evidence of environmental change ) ; 3 .
Since we are not yet able to predictNONMET all the interactions which may be important in a study of environmental problems , collectingNONMET potentially useful data as well as those believedNONMET central to the problem under study is often wise ; 4 .
We must acceptNONMET that most data collection exercises will inevitably be a compromise on the grounds of cost and hence less than perfect data sets will be producedNONMET ; 5 .
Irrespective of the use of surrogates , monitoringNONMET environmental processes only makesNONMET sense over time-scales which are extendedNONMET by human standards ( hence the IGBP ( seeNONMET below ) is designedNONMET to runNONMET for two or three decades ) ; 6 .
Changes in political priorities may simply resultNONMET in the need for informed guesswork if suitable data are not available .
Much attention will be givenNONMET throughout this chapter to monitoringNONMET the environment on a global basis .
This is not merely because of its topical nature .
The main reason is that — though some problems are local and are best studiedNONMET that way — many others ( even involvingNONMET a limited geographical extent ) are best understoodNONMET within a global framework .
Thus no meteorologist would attemptNONMET to forecastNONMET the weather 2 or 3 days ahead without usingNONMET a mathematical model basedNONMET on observations from all around the world .
Moreover , recent work has shownNONMET that much of the heat energy in the seas of the North Atlantic ( every square kilometre of which givesNONMET off as much energy as a nuclear power station and hence influencesNONMET our weather ) is absorbedNONMET from sunlight in the tropical Pacific and is carriedNONMET by ocean currents through the Drake Passage and up into the Atlantic .
Thus , to understandNONMET some local and many regional , national and continental and all global environmental events , we needNONMET to have a global perspective and holdNONMET global databases ( Rhind and Mounsey 1989 ; Mounsey and Tomlinson 1988 ) .
In no way , however , does this invalidateNONMET the need for microscale studies — for instance , while global data sets may indicateNONMET the extent of algal blooms and may suggestNONMET causes of them , only detailed study of the algae themselves can provideNONMET understanding of why the bloom is occurringNONMET .
The processes themselves A major complication , however , is that the environment can rarely be treatedNONMET as in a laboratory experiment .
GivenNONMET this , determiningNONMET the nature of the interactions between the variables becomesNONMET a matter of major difficulty .
Figure 9.2 is takenNONMET from ESSC ( 1988 ) and is an attempt to showNONMET the interactions between environmental processes , as well as the indicators and implications of change in the state of the environment .
In essence , the figure can be summarizedNONMET as showingNONMET processes within the physical climate system and within the biogeochemical one , these systems being interwovenNONMET by the global role of water and increasingly affectedNONMET by human activities .
The main components of the first system are well knownNONMET : the atmosphere is its engine and atmospheric circulation is drivenNONMET by differences in solar heating between the equatorial and polar regions .
We are , however , becomingNONMET ever more aware of the massive influence of oceans on our climate ; research into ocean/atmosphere interactions is now a priority .
In ocean dynamics studies , important topics are heat storage , circulation and the role of sea ice .
Atmospheric circulation ( and , in turn , precipitation and temperature ) is also greatly affectedNONMET by the balance of thermal energy at the land surface , itself affectedNONMET by the vegetation and terrain characteristics .
The biogeochemical system embracesNONMET the totality of the movements of the key elements essential to life — carbon , nitrogen , oxygen , phosphorus and others — through what has been describedNONMET as the total earth system .
The oceans and their biota playNONMET a central role in the carbon and nutrient cycles ; global ocean circulation is also critical to the global carbon budget .
Trace gases in the atmosphere are key components of the cycles of such elements as carbon , nitrogen , oxygen , sulphur and the halogens ; as is now well knownNONMET , their concentrations are much influencedNONMET by biogenic and anthropogenic activities and the concentrations of such gases as carbon dioxide , ozone , methane , nitrous oxide and the chlorofluoromethanes ( CFMs ) strongly affectNONMET radiative transfer and provideNONMET a link with the physical climate system .
A particular cause for concern is that the concentrations of the two main CFMs is increasingNONMET by about 5 per cent per annum while the equivalent figures for methane , nitrous oxide and carbon dioxide are 1 , 0.4 and 0.3 per cent .
Finally , the chemistry of the stratosphere is dominatedNONMET by the photochemical production and catalytic destruction of ozone .
There are several important ways in which biogeochemical processes can influenceNONMET climate and hence habitability ( except where the latter is maintainedNONMET at enormous cost ) .
If , for instance , the concentrations of certain trace gases ( seeNONMET above ) continueNONMET to increaseNONMET , it has been predictedNONMET that the earth's surface temperature will increaseNONMET by an amount comparable to that since the last major phase of the most recent glaciation ( about 18 000 years BP ) — though there is some dispute about the magnitude of the likely change .
The converse case — the effect of physical climate changes on biogeochemical processes — is also of obvious importance : changes in annual averages and cycles of temperature and precipitation , together with the probabilities of extreme events such as prolonged droughts or frosts , are major determinants of terrestrial ecosystem type , at least in areas largely unaffected by human activity .
Human-induced changes to the environment have increasedNONMET rapidly as a consequence of growing population numbers and of numerous developments in technology .
fossil fuel combustion , for instance , has ledNONMET to increased concentrations of sulphate in precipitation ( ’ acid rain' ) and many rivers , lakes and estuaries have been greatly affectedNONMET by phosphates from agricultural , urban or industrial sources .
It should be stressedNONMET , however , that — while the outlines of human activities are clear — there are still many uncertainties : for instance , we knowNONMET that the atmospheric concentration of carbon dioxide has risenNONMET about 9 per cent since 1959 .
But calculations of the total carbon releasedNONMET by fossil fuel combustion implyNONMET that , if all such carbon remained in the atmosphere , the concentration would have increasedNONMET by twice as much .
The absolute difference between the two figures seemsNONMET to be due to two different factors : absorption by the oceans and other reductions in carbon stocks in living biota , the latter being strongly affectedNONMET by human activities since the Industrial Revolution .
Does God playNONMET dice ?
Much environmental prediction is predicatedNONMET upon a logical positivist or Newtonian deterministic basis .
The environmental systems are effectively regardedNONMET as machines whose workings can all be discoveredNONMET , described in differential equation form and whose future activities can thus be predictedNONMET in detail if their initial states are knownNONMET .
An argument by many atmospheric physicists , for example , is that shortcomings in the accuracy of weather prediction over periods of more than a few days largely results from the unsophisticated nature of existing models , the lack of suitable data and inadequate computer power ( seeNONMET Fig. 9.3 , derivedNONMET from Tyler 1989 ) .
In contrast , the advocates of chaos theory ( e.g. Stewart 1989 ) argueNONMET that some natural systems are so sensitive to tiny stimuli that even ‘ the faint beat of a butterfly's wing could be the ultimate trigger for a hurricane ’ .
In essence , they argueNONMET that tiny differences in the initial conditions of many systems can leadNONMET to widely different outcomes since the systems exhibitNONMET stochastic behaviour within a deterministic framework .
If so , there is little chance of makingNONMET accurate long-term forecasts of these systems .
This has been recognizedNONMET by , among others , ESSC ( 1988 ) .
The authors of that report accepted that there is a theoretical limit of 2–3 weeks in explicit prediction of day-to-day fluctuations in weather because of the influence of small-scale turbulence within the large-scale dynamics ; such limits implyNONMET that medium and long-term prediction must inevitably be stochastic .
To complicateNONMET matters still further , however , it seemsNONMET at least possible that the components of the earth system may best be predictedNONMET deterministically at some spatial and temporal scales but stochastically at others and that the basis of prediction will differNONMET for different components .
As an example , atmospheric temperature shows marked day-to-day variability , a strong seasonal cycle with some year-to-year variations , a weak minimum variability for 10–20 year averages and then increased variation again at longer time-scales ( ESSC 1988 ) .
It need hardly be pointedNONMET out that coping with such multiple databases on which modelling is to be carriedNONMET out is not a trivial exercise .
Finally , it is perhaps worth concludingNONMET this section by emphasizingNONMET that there is still much controversy among the scientific community about the magnitude of many of the effects being discussedNONMET .
In general , the research work of the international groups of scientists , including those involved in the Inter-Governmental Committee and in the UK's Inter-Agency Committee on Global Environmental Change , has progressively reducedNONMET the magnitude of the predicted effects of , for example , global warming .
In givingNONMET the 1990 Robens Coal Science Lecture at the Royal Institution , Sir John Mason ( a former Director of the Meteorological Office ) urgedNONMET caution in interpretingNONMET the results of the massive atmospheric and oceanic modelling exercises ; as the equilibrium models are refined to takeNONMET account of the thermal lag in oceans , etc. , lower values of predicted changes are likely .
Thus , while almost all scientists are — at the time of writing — convinced from the evidence that change in climate is under way and that regional effects may be much greater than the global average , the magnitude of the latter is now thoughtNONMET likely to be about half of what was predictedNONMET only 5 years ago .
Who is involvedNONMET and what is goingNONMET on ?
If we considerNONMET the environment in the broadest sense , much monitoring of it has been in progress for many years and by an enormous diversity of organizations in the UK ; these includeNONMET the DoE , the Forestry Commission , the Nature Conservancy , the Health and Safety Executive , local authorities , the component members of the Natural Environment Research Council ( such as the Institute of Terrestrial Ecology and the British Antarctic Survey ) , individuals or research groups in academia , the CEGB , the Friends of the Earth , and UK Centre for Economic and Environmental Development ( CEED ) ( 1989 ) .
The diversity of monitoring organizations seemsNONMET just as great in other countries ; numerous multinational organizations , both quasi-governmental ( e.g. the UN Environment Programme ( UNEP ) ) and non-governmental ( e.g. the International Union for the Conservation of Nature ( IUCN ) and the International Institute for Environment and Development ( IIED ) ) are also active in the field .
Moreover , commercial monitoring of the environment is now also routine , notably to predictNONMET crop yields in the main grain-growing areas and hence facilitateNONMET the buying of futures .
The international scientific involvement Scientists have both promotedNONMET and respondedNONMET to the increasing interest in the environment .
Thus , at the global scale , the International Council of Scientific Unions ( ICSU ) has endorsedNONMET the setting up of the International Geosphere Biosphere Project ( IGBP ) to ‘ describeNONMET and understandNONMET the interactive physical , chemical and biological processes that regulateNONMET the total Earth system , the unique environment it providesNONMET for life , the changes that are occurringNONMET in that system and the manner by which these changes are influencedNONMET by human actions ’ ( Report of ad hoc Planning Group for IGBP 1986 , quoted in IGBP 1988 ) .
Priority in the IGBP is intendedNONMET to be givenNONMET to those areas which deal with key interactions and significant changes on the time-scales of decades to centuries , that most affectNONMET the biosphere , that are most susceptible to human perturbations and those that will most likely leadNONMET to a practical , predictive capability for global change .
This is to be putNONMET into operation by concentratingNONMET on four themes : 1 .
DocumentingNONMET and predictingNONMET global change ; 2 .
ObservingNONMET and improvingNONMET our understanding of dominant forcing functions ; 3 .
ImprovingNONMET our understanding of interactive phenomena in the total Earth system ; 4 .
AssessingNONMET those effects of global change which will be large scale and cause major modifications to both renewable and non-renewable resources .
By 1990 , IGBP had progressedNONMET as far as definingNONMET a set of seven core projects ( IGBP 1990 ) addressingNONMET these four themes .
In addition , plans for regional research centres and for the data and information systems for IGBP ( knownNONMET as IGBP-DIS ) had been announcedNONMET .
The latter are particularly relevant to this chapter .
BasedNONMET in Paris and workingNONMET under Professor I. Rasool , it is intendedNONMET to concentrateNONMET on managerial and policy aspects of the task in the first 2 years ( 1990–92 ) but then to expandNONMET considerably thereafter .
Tasks agreed for the IGBP-DIS includeNONMET makingNONMET available a ‘ directory of data directories ’ modelledNONMET on NASA's Master Directory , providingNONMET data sets for education and training and undertakingNONMET a land cover pilot study .
Until 1990 , remarkably little interaction had takenNONMET place between the ‘ hard science ’ and the social science communities on global monitoring and prediction .
It is noteworthy , however , that the Royal Society madeNONMET a plea for just this type of multidisciplinary work in its submission on greenhouse gases to the House of Lords ' Select Committee on Science and Technology ( Royal Society 1989 : 40 ) .
Fortunately , in addition to the actions of the world ‘ hard science ’ community , a parallel effort is now being initiatedNONMET by social scientists ( Fuchs 1989 ; Jacobson and Price 1990 ) .
Currently this is organizedNONMET and sponsoredNONMET by the International Social Science Council ( ISSC ) , the UN University and the International Federation of Institutes of Advanced Studies .
Its objectives are to : 1 .
ImproveNONMET scientific understanding and increase awareness of the complex dynamics governing human interaction with the total Earth system ; 2 .
Study , exploreNONMET and anticipateNONMET social change affectingNONMET the global environment ; 3 .
IdentifyNONMET broad social strategies to preventNONMET or mitigateNONMET undesirable impacts of global change or to adaptNONMET to changes which are unavoidable ; 4 .
AnalyseNONMET policy options for dealingNONMET with global environmental change and promotingNONMET the goal of sustainable development .
Jacobson and Price ( 1990 ) provideNONMET a useful summary of the ways in which human factors contributeNONMET to , and are affectedNONMET by , likely global changes ; in particular , they stressNONMET the importance of the data-handling issues and the role of GIS in copingNONMET with some of the problems of data integration and manipulation .
The ISSC proposedNONMET its own work programme in the Human Dimensions of Global Change in late 1990 .
While these organizations intrinsically have a world-wide membership and are concerned with research into global environmental change , others shareNONMET the same interest but from a more restricted geographical base .
A leading example of this is the European Science Foundation which has sponsoredNONMET research programmes in both the physical and social science aspects of environmental change ( ESF 1990 ) .
Governmental and political involvement The spread of environmental awareness is readily demonstratedNONMET : in 1972 , 26 countries had environmental and natural resource management agencies whereas , a decade later the number was 144 ( WEC 1985 ) .
In most countries , the governmental and political concern with the environment has comeNONMET somewhat later than that of scientists or concerned lay people : the early development of the Green Party in the Federal Republic of Germany is something of an exception .
Such a commitment to the environment is , none the less , both welcome and necessary if resources are to be madeNONMET available to tackleNONMET existing , let alone forthcoming , environmental problems .
The ‘ conversion ’ of the UK government has been briefly describedNONMET earlier ; it is manifestedNONMET in their July 1989 commitment to spendNONMET £10m. on climate change research in 1989/90 and the confident request to them from the Advisory Board for the Research Councils ( ABRC ) for an extra £11m. in 1990 and £13m. in the two succeeding years for additional environmental research .
Perhaps the most significant development of all , however , is the increasing role of the European Commission .
Their role in bringingNONMET environmental impact assessment ( EIA ) on to the statute book is well knownNONMET , but the Commission has now madeNONMET a proposal ( CEC 1989 ) for the ‘ establishment of the European Environment Agency and the European Environment Monitoring and Information Network ’ .
The Commission arguesNONMET that there is at present no monitoring of environmental quality and trends on a European scale , nor any guarantee that the results of environmental monitoring will be comparable on a Community-wide basis ( a realization broughtNONMET about through the CORINE programme described later ) .
The objectives of the new agency would be to assistNONMET the Community and the Member States to achieveNONMET the goals setNONMET out in the Treaty of Rome and in successive environmental action programmes ; it must also , however , be seenNONMET in the context of the European Council's adoption on 2 December 1988 of the Rhodes Declaration on the Environment and the environment chapter in the Single European Act which comesNONMET into effect in 1992 .
The detailed specific roles of ‘ the System ’ ( comprisingNONMET both agency and network ) are envisagedNONMET as : 1 .
To provideNONMET the Community , the Member States and participating third countries with the objective ( sic ) information requestedNONMET for the formulation and implementation of sound and effective environmental policies ; 2 .
In particular , to provideNONMET technical , scientific and economic information requestedNONMET by the Commission in its tasks of identification , preparation and assessment of the implementation and results of environmental action and legislation ; 3 .
To stimulateNONMET the development and the application within the agency of techniques of environmental modelling and forecasting in order that adequate preventative action can be takenNONMET at the appropriate time ; 4 .
To helpNONMET ensureNONMET the harmonization and comparability of environmental data in the Community as well as the integration of European environmental data into international environmental monitoring programmes , such as those establishedNONMET within the framework of the United Nations and its system of agencies .
Considerable stress is laidNONMET by the Commission on collaboration with national data-gathering agencies and with states adjacent to the Community's borders .
It is envisagedNONMET that the totality of activities will extendNONMET the existing State of the European Environment report ( CEC 1988 ) through addressingNONMET the issues of the quality and sensitivity of the environment and also the pressures upon it .
Priorities for the new agency includeNONMET study of atmospheric emissions and quality , water resources and quality ( including the marine environment ) , soil erosion and pollution and important land resources , and biotopes and nature conservation .
At the time of writing , the proposal has been approvedNONMET and discussions are in progress on the location of the agency's headquarters .
It seemsNONMET certain to have major and growing effects upon environmental monitoring and prediction in Europe and on the policies of component governments .
Yet this is by no means the only plan which the Community has in relation to the environment : Directorate-General XII ( that for Science , Research and Development ) has publishedNONMET details of an extensive R&D programme ( CEC 1990a ) and the Commission as a whole ( CEC 1990b ) has madeNONMET public its plans to developNONMET regular official statistics of the environment .
The private sector Certain aspects of environmental monitoring have long been carriedNONMET out by the private sector , notably that of crop states on a world-wide basis .
DerivedNONMET from satellite imagery at comparatively low resolution , predicted yields for different crops in different nation states becomeNONMET of commercial value .
However , significant resources are also being madeNONMET available by the private sector where there is no immediate commercial gain : thus IBM UK Ltd has donatedNONMET £3.5m. of computing equipment to UNEPNONMET and IBM in general is actively supporting other R&D which can be expectedNONMET to facilitateNONMET ‘ sustainable development ’ : IBM Europe , for instance , has investedNONMET $16m. in its Bergen scientific centre to makeNONMET it the focal point for the company's environmental modelling and a centre for information on the environment and sustainable development .
On a more modest basis , IBM UK have agreedNONMET to fundNONMET a pilot global population database being builtNONMET in Birkbeck College to permitNONMET assessment of the impact of environmental change on the world s population .
Many other companies , of course , are supporting environmental work but IBM seemsNONMET almost to be unique in its corporate commitment to useNONMET of high technology for facilitatingNONMET ‘ sustainable development ’ .
Some examples of environmental monitoring projects The local scale At the local scale , it is usually impossible to neglectNONMET the effects of multiple processes operating .
An example of environmental modelling and prediction where the interactions between different processes and dynamic feedback is takenNONMET into account is givenNONMET by Haber and Schaller ( 1988 ) .
Their work formedNONMET part of one UNESCO Man and Biosphere ( MAB ) project , carriedNONMET out in the Berchtesgaden National Park in Bavaria .
FollowingNONMET Holling ( 1978 ) and Grossman ( 1983 ) , they conceptualizedNONMET the man/environment relationship at a series of hierarchical levels : 1 .
The lowest , or process , level , is directly and ( usually ) obviously connectedNONMET to perceived reality .
Thus processes and interrelationships are mostly obvious , simple and linear ; data are usually readily available and may be voluminous .
This level is readily handledNONMET in commercial GIS ; , 2 .
The intermediate , or dynamic , level is concerned with less frequent and often irregular events , e.g. a temporary lack of water because of fire , frost or excessive demand from an increasing populace .
Characteristically , the data used may be more difficult to obtainNONMET and are usually more spatially aggregated ; modelling software which permitsNONMET feedback loops is essential ; 3 .
The top , or strategic , level is the most difficult to exploreNONMET ; the external influences are often unpredictable by formal means .
Relevant data are therefore difficult to identifyNONMET and scenario building is one of the few approaches available .
The Haber and Schaller approach is to ‘ soft-couple ’ these different levels and their accompanying approaches usingNONMET an ecological balance model .
Results of runningNONMET this with different scenarios includeNONMET ‘ time slice ’ maps of possible outcomes and of the exchange of material and energy within the study area .
While ultimately qualitative , it seemsNONMET to offerNONMET a method for copingNONMET with different types of process and incorporatingNONMET stochastic and truly random events .
The national and continental scale : the CORINE project The CORINE programme representsNONMET the product of much activity by the European Commission's Directorate-General ( XI ) for the Environment .
It originatesNONMET from an Italian request to the Council of Ministers in 1973 to identifyNONMET environmentally ‘ balanced ’ and ‘ unbalanced ’ areas in the Community ; the first attempts to do this were unsuccessful and , though by 1981 it was clear that a new approach basedNONMET on an environmental information system was the most promising one , funding for this was not securedNONMET until 1985 .
A 4-year experimental programme to ‘ collectNONMET , co-ordinate and ensureNONMET the consistency of information on the state of the environment and natural resources in the European Communities ’ was setNONMET up and labelled CORINE .
The objectives of CORINE were to be achievedNONMET through bringingNONMET together existing data holdings in the member states , developing methods for holdingNONMET , analysingNONMET and presentingNONMET the data , and encouragingNONMET the exchange of data .
A number of priority areas were identifiedNONMET , including biotopes of importance for nature conservation , acid deposition and its effects on soils and biotopes and the protection of the environment of the Mediterranean region ( Briggs and Martin 1988 ) .
Many achievements can be claimedNONMET by the CORINE project team .
As a result of some 40 sub-projects involvingNONMET all the Member States ( and often several groups within each one ) , databases of topography , soils , water resources and quality , biotopes , atmospheric emissions , climate , soil erosion and administrative boundaries have been builtNONMET up for the whole Community and can be interrelated ; other data sets ( such as land cover , derivedNONMET from satellite imagery ) have already been compiledNONMET for some of the Member States .
Various aspects of the CORINE project have been describedNONMET in papers by Rhind et al. ( 1986 ) , Wiggins et al. ( 1987 ) , Briggs and Martin ( 1988 ) , Briggs and Mounsey ( 1989 ) and CEC ( 1990c ) .
For the present purposes , however , the key findings are : 1 .
Many necessary data sets were unavailable for reasons of administrative inadequacies , confidentiality constraints , cost or non-collection in certain countries ; 2 .
The unavoidable reliance upon existing data sets ledNONMET to many problems due to non-harmonization even of commonly used variables , e.g. eight different definitions of potential evapo-transpiration were in use in the Member States and ‘ maximum temperature ’ at each weather station was definedNONMET in at least four different ways ; 3 .
The compilation of a spatially coherent database from mapped information compiledNONMET by different organizations at different scales and on different topographic bases ( seeNONMET Rhind and Clark 1988 ) is often difficult ; 4 .
User expectations are often unreasonably high ; use of administrative computing systems encouragesNONMET bureaucrats to believeNONMET that environmental data can just as readily be analysedNONMET and usedNONMET to supportNONMET decisions .
The ‘ fuzzy ’ nature of much geographically distributed data , the inherent errors in it , the effects of the processing algorithms used and the assumption of known interactions between variables ensuresNONMET that completely routine use by unskilled users is unlikely to be possible in the foreseeable future ; 5 .
More detailed data are requiredNONMET for particular tasks as the role of CORINE growsNONMET .
The European Commission's proposal for an environment agency ( seeNONMET above ) will subsumeNONMET the CORINE team and databases .
The global scale : NASA and GEMS/GRID Without question , the largest ‘ player ’ in the global environment arena is NASA .
The organization has initiatedNONMET many of the schemes which now are under discussion — the IGBP , for instance , has been strongly influencedNONMET by NASA proposals .
A summary of current activities and future plans is givenNONMET in NASA ( 1988b ) .
By way of example , current programmes are collectingNONMET global data on stratospheric ozone , on sea-surface and sea-ice variables and on the earth's radiation budget .
Approved future programmes includeNONMET the Upper Atmosphere Research Satellite , the NASA Scatterometer and the joint NASA/CNES Ocean Topography Experiment .
In addition , however , funding has recently been approvedNONMET for a much more ambitious scheme — the Earth ObservingNONMET System ( EOS ) .
This is conceivedNONMET not as a set of hardware but as a comprehensive information system focused on the needs identifiedNONMET by the ESSC ( seeNONMET above ) and anticipatingNONMET somewhat those of IGBP .
It will collateNONMET data from the two proposed space station polar platforms , one European Space Agency platform , a Japanese one and also from the manned space station .
On this basis , a data flow of no less than 1 terabyte ( i.e. 10&sup12 ; bytes ) /day is anticipatedNONMET by the mid-1990s .
A major user of NASA data and skills has been the UN Environment Programme .
formedNONMET in the wake of the 1972 Stockholm conference , UNEPNONMET soon spawned the Global Environment Monitoring System ( GEMS ) as well as an international register of potentially toxic chemicals and a global network of sources to locateNONMET and provideNONMET technical , scientific and management information on the environment .
The need for a mechanism to handleNONMET the global environmental data was definedNONMET in the early 1980s and the Global Resources Information Database ( GRID ) resultedNONMET .
Mooneyhan ( 1988 ) has describedNONMET the progress of the pilot stage of GRID which culminatedNONMET in approval for a full operational phase ; GRID is now involved in integratingNONMET , storingNONMET and exploitingNONMET a variety of global environmental databases , mostly acquiredNONMET from NASA .
In addition to the work being carriedNONMET out in the UNEP HQ at Nairobi and in the GEMS/GRID site in Geneva , a series of GRID regional nodes are now being setNONMET up world-wide , each equippedNONMET with the same hardware and software and local subsets of the data .
The first of these is in Bangkok and another is to be openedNONMET in Latin America .
Moreover , national nodes are also being setNONMET up ; the recent IBM gift to GRID ( seeNONMET above ) has ensuredNONMET that powerful microcomputers have been installedNONMET in many African countries , together with national and continental data sets .
Training of unskilled staff to operateNONMET this equipment and to exploitNONMET the scientific data is now a major role for GRID staff .
Technical aspects and problems It followsNONMET from much of the above that there are major challenges in use of environmental data .
These are best consideredNONMET by itemizing characteristics of contemporary environmental monitoring and prediction : 1 .
The use of secondary data , rather than primary data collectedNONMET by the data analyst ; 2 .
The need , at least with data on the terrestrial environment , for an inference process to extractNONMET useful information from the secondary ( and often proxy ) data ; 3 .
The data volumes collectedNONMET are often voluminous even by the standards of contemporary computing facilities ; 4 .
The analyses carried out are often arcane in detail to all but a small group of ‘ high priests ’ ; 5 .
We have only a limited capacity for checkingNONMET the accuracy of many environmental monitoring results , let alone of predictions .
Some of these characteristics are now addressedNONMET in slightly more detail ; it will be obvious that such problems meritNONMET a paper in themselves .
Remote sensing as a data collection process As the need for more extensive , high-resolution yet consistent and up-to-date data becomesNONMET more pressing , increased use of remote sensing seemsNONMET inevitable .
No other data collection methodology obviatesNONMET the short distance variation in data sets inducedNONMET by variations in data collection and aggregation methodology typically encounteredNONMET between adjacent nation states .
The problem is now recognizedNONMET , especially in Europe , and strenuous efforts are being madeNONMET to harmoniseNONMET the data sets ( e.g. through the use of standard classifications , such as that for land use producedNONMET by the Conference of European Statisticians in 1989 ) .
At present , however , ground-collected environmental data are far less than ideal .
RecognizingNONMET this , NASA ( 1988a ) concludedNONMET that forthcoming global science projects would needNONMET land surface altitude data at three resolutions : 1 km resolution in XY and 10–100 m resolution in Z on a global basis , 100 m XY resolution and 1–10 m resolution in Z for regional databases and 10 m XY resolution and 0.1–1 m in Z for local studies .
They arguedNONMET that existing maps and digitized files from them are unable to meetNONMET these needs at global or regional scale and only remote sensing could helpNONMET in the short term : the availability of stereometric data from the French SPOT satellite has already ledNONMET to proposals for automated creation of global digital elevation models with a spatial ( XY ) resolution of about 30 m ( Muller 1989 ) .
For many terrestrial purposes , however , a substantial inference process must takeNONMET place to convertNONMET the radiometric measurements into useful information ( in contrast , more direct measurements of sea state , etc. are possible ) .
The value of this information is inherently dependent upon the quality of the inference process and that in turn dependsNONMET upon the complexity of the scene , the spatial , temporal and spectral resolution of the sensors and the particular algorithms used .
Thus far , for instance , accuracies of land cover ( let alone what is often neededNONMET , i.e. land use ) determinedNONMET from Landsat and SPOT imagery for the UK have rarely been higher than 70 per cent unless trivial classifications ( e.g. built/unbuilt land ) have been usedNONMET .
One solution to this is to ‘ densifyNONMET ’ the ground control and another is to useNONMET contextually basedNONMET classifiers rather than the traditional , spectrally basedNONMET ones .
But the ground conditions in some parts of Europe makeNONMET good results extremely difficult to obtainNONMET : some areas of Portugal , for instance , have field sizes of only a few metres and exhibit multi-level and multi-seasonal cropping .
A further difficulty is the cost of the data in relation to its anticipated benefits .
Relatively few cost/benefit studies have yet been carriedNONMET out except in such areas as crop prediction and ocean navigation ( where they are generally shownNONMET to be highly advantageous in savingNONMET someone else's money ) .
It may be that a study commissioned from contractors by the British National Space Centre will provideNONMET useful evidence on the cash value of remote sensing ; it is particularly timely in view of the appointment of Professor Pearce ( seeNONMET above ) as the adviser to the UK Secretary of State for the Environment .
Other work on assessment of costs and benefits of such data have been carriedNONMET out for the French government by Professor Didier ( 1990 ) .
Finally , since data are often costly to acquireNONMET , it followsNONMET that summaries of them e.g. The State of the European Environment report ( CEC 1988 ) and the Environmental Data Report of the UN EP ( GEMS MARC 1989 ) are of considerable value .
Equally , the ‘ signposting ’ role now being adoptedNONMET by UNEP's GRID project — which is expected to offerNONMET on-line access to a catalogue of environmental data sets and details of the responsible agencies in 1991 — is to be welcomedNONMET .
The data problem and partial solutions The lack of harmonization of definitions and methods of collection of environmental data have already been outlinedNONMET above .
In the European Community of 12 nation states , for instance , no less than eight procedures for calculatingNONMET potential evapo-transpiration have been in use !
The need for harmonization is obvious and , in this respect , must followNONMET from the successful pioneering achievements of EUROSTAT in harmonizingNONMET the definitions in trade , demographic and other ‘ social science ’ statistics ( seeNONMET CEC 1990b ) .
An additional and severe problem is that the volumes of data which are already collectedNONMET are huge by the standards of only a decade ago .
By 1995/96 , they will be very much greater , notably from the EOS programme .
NASA has announcedNONMET plans to collectNONMET up to 1 terabyte ( 10&sup12 ; bytes ) /day .
Since remote sensing data sets ( especially those pertaining to terrestrial areas of the globe ) typically needNONMET much pre-processing to calibrateNONMET , transformNONMET and then performNONMET an inference process and hence convertNONMET measurements of the radiation reflected or emittedNONMET by small areas of ground into useful ( e.g. land cover ) data , the processing power requiredNONMET is goingNONMET to be formidable .
Other , non-remote-sensing data sets are smaller in volume but more complex in structure and in their characteristics .
To holdNONMET all of the 1/50 000 scale topographic map coverage alone for the European Community would probably requireNONMET about 3 terabytes of storage .
Parenthetically , the form in which the data may be heldNONMET can affectNONMET dramatically the scale of the problem faced .
It would be technically possible , for instance , to holdNONMET in less than 1 terabyte detailed information for every individual in the world , akin to that collected about everyone in the UK through the Census of Population .
In practice , legislation generally forbidsNONMET such data being heldNONMET thus and distributedNONMET in anything other than area aggregate form ; the cross-tabulations commonly employedNONMET ( e.g. to giveNONMET tables of population numbers brokenNONMET down by age and sex ) often resultNONMET in a great multiplication of the data volumes .
This all presents major problems of data storage , handling ( especially for global data sets ) , display and dissemination .
Fortunately , technical developments have ensuredNONMET that the increase in computing power per unit cost has been growingNONMET at about an order of magnitude every 6 years over the last three decades .
Indeed , this may grossly under-representNONMET the present situation : the rapid spread of UNIX-based systems seemsNONMET to facilitateNONMET competition and , at the time of writing , performance of workstations per unit cost seemsNONMET to be increasing at about 50 per cent per annum .
Moreover , the advent of low-cost , high-density-storage devices like CD-ROMs may well makeNONMET substantial data setsNONMET available even to those with modest computing power : a CD-ROM , for instance , can holdNONMET about 600 megabytes ( i.e. 10&sup6 ; bytes ) , can be reproducedNONMET currently for about £1 and read on a device costingNONMET about £400 .
Yet , despite such revolutionary changes in technology , novel solutions will still be requiredNONMET to makeNONMET effective use of the new data sets .
One such solution is Goodchild and Yang's ( 1989 ) scheme for a hierarchical spatial data structure to handleNONMET data for the spherical earth .
A particular problem is that little or no quantitative regard has been paidNONMET until recently to the effects of quality variation in environmental data .
The literature of the last few years is throngedNONMET with papers proposingNONMET that these must be takenNONMET into account — but with few realistic proposals on how this is to be achievedNONMET .
Goodchild ( 1988 ) has madeNONMET perhaps the best summary of the problem and possible solutions to date .
Finally , relatively little emphasis has been givenNONMET to the management of data as a corporate resource , available to a wide community : many environmental data are collectedNONMET on a project-by-project basis and ‘ lost ’ once the urgency of the initial research is over .
However , the 1990 report of the Data and Facilities Working Group of the UK Inter-Agency Committee on Global Environmental Change argued strongly that planning for the dissemination and maintenance of such data was a vital role .
It also notedNONMET that ownership of and access to environmental data was a policy matter of the greatest importance ; this may be more difficult in ‘ within country ’ data than with global data since the latter are often already the subject of international exchange agreements at zero cost .
Global environmental research and the social sciences Thus far , the emphasis has been very much on the natural science aspects of environmental monitoring and prediction .
That is unremarkable since the anticipation of such problems and assessments of some of their causes and magnitudes can only be madeNONMET by environmental scientists .
Yet the consequences of any significant changes are a matter of the utmost concern to planners and to politicians at all levels , the quantification of the costs and benefits of alternative policy strategies is very much a matter for economists , and the adaptation of societies to massive change is a particular interest to sociologists and others .
For geographers — who spanNONMET the conventional ( and now archaic ) dichotomy between the natural and the environmental sciences — all of these aspects needNONMET to be wovenNONMET together to anticipateNONMET the likely spatial patterns of the effects of massive change , the redistributions in trade , health and wealth which they will bringNONMET about and the ‘ knock on ’ effects these consequences themselves will have on society and the environment .
For social scientists , then , environmental monitoring and prediction are a matter of considerable significance , especially as ‘ globalization ’ of markets and economies proceeds .
The Economic and Social Research Council ( ESRC ) commissionedNONMET two reports on global environmental change to guideNONMET or at least informNONMET the allocation of research funding .
These reports ( Pearce 1990 ; Turner 1990 ) may be takenNONMET as informed views from at least the economists in the UK social science community on the social science aspects of global environmental change .
Pearce ( 1990 ) , for instance , presentedNONMET an economist's views of the high-priority topics for research as followsNONMET : 1 .
The theory and practice of international agreements , viewed in a game theory context ; 2 .
The theory of optimal behaviour under scientific uncertainty ; , 3 .
Cost-benefit frameworks , especially for dealingNONMET with man-induced climatic effects ; 4 .
Definition of the impacts of climate change on eastern Europe and the developing countries ; 5 .
Appropriate policies on non-carbon dioxide greenhouse gases ; 6 .
Assessment of the ecological values of tropical forest ; 7 .
Economic instruments for reducing greenhouse gases ; 8 .
The international politics of climate change ; 9 .
National and global energy options givenNONMET the greenhouse effect ; 10 .
Trade and global change .
Turner ( 1990 ) arguedNONMET that the priorities are as followsNONMET : 1 .
The socio-economic consequences of sea-level rise ; 2 .
Techniques for the valuation of environmental resources and effects ; 3 .
An assessment of management tools , institutional adaptation and policy integration in regard to global environmental change ; 4 .
Studies of agriculture in relation to climate change ; 5 .
Understanding of how environmental issues and technical change interactNONMET ; 6 .
The interrelationship between environmental ethics and economics .
There is , then , no shortage of social science research which is claimedNONMET to be necessary if we are to copeNONMET with environmental change .
Some of it is being carriedNONMET out : in March 1991 ESRC announcedNONMET a £6m programme of research on Global Environmental Change .
However , perhaps most critical of all in the early stages is social science practice rather than researchNONMET .
In the USA at least , there needsNONMET to be an improvement in scientists ' understandings of how to influenceNONMET the allocation of funding for remedial measures or for further research ( seeNONMET Kitsos and AsheNONMET 1989 ) .
All too often , it seemsNONMET that the coupling of an as yet imperfect scientific understanding to policy-making is tenuous ( seeNONMET Table 9.2 ) .
Fortunately , considerable high-quality work has already begunNONMET on the legal , political and institutional aspects of global environmental change ( seeNONMET , for instance , Nitze 1990 ) .
What next ?
The contents of this chapter have scarcely touchedNONMET upon such important environmental research as the World Ocean Climate Experiment or the World Climate Research Programme .
Nor has there been any discussion of the growing requirement in the UK ( as elsewhere ) to carryNONMET out an environmental impact assessment for all major developments .
The consequences for some nations or subgroups in a population of being without access to environmental data or the tools for analysingNONMET them while others have such access are potentially profound — as the European Commission has recognizedNONMET in issuingNONMET a directive on public access to environmental data ( CEC 1990d ) — yet space limitations have also precludedNONMET their discussion .
Despite these shortcomings dictatedNONMET by the space available , what has been saidNONMET should be sufficient to illustrateNONMET the enormous and diverse scope of environmental monitoring and prediction .
Such is its diversity that measuringNONMET the total expenditure on it seemsNONMET quite impossible and the number of ‘ actors ’ already involvedNONMET is vast .
What is clear , however , is that monitoring is rarely a simple exercise , that the time-scales of the sponsors of monitoring and environmental research are rarely long term though most science is inevitably of this nature and that the increasingly multinational nature of such work necessitatesNONMET a degree of management not always present in local or nationally basedNONMET schemes .
In these circumstances , it is scarcely surprising that there is evidence of international and interdisciplinary dispute , as Terney ( 1989 ) has chronicledNONMET in regard to IGBP .
Moreover , as Newby ( 1990 ) has pointedNONMET out , the complexities of environmental research have createdNONMET a new kind of relationship between research and policy : ‘ in the past , … the relationship was predicatedNONMET on the belief that science provided decision-makers with objective ‘ hard ’ facts on which to baseNONMET their soft , value-ridden policies … .
But now we findNONMET scientists deliveringNONMET only ‘ soft ’ , uncertain ‘ facts ’ to decision-makers facingNONMET ‘ hard ’ decisions .
’ Yet , even if all of this causesNONMET great uncertainty among scientists , it is still a reasonable prediction that a decade ahead will seeNONMET both environmental monitoring and prediction treatedNONMET as an everyday need and activity in major organizations .
