We shall also seeNONMET the existence of binding requirements upon national governments — certainly in the European Community — to collectNONMET at least basic environmental indicators in a harmonized form ( CEC 1990b ) .
More than that , it seemsNONMET highly likely that the social science aspects of environmental problems will underpinNONMET the actions of governments and international agencies .
Perhaps the single most important conclusion to be drawnNONMET from this review is that the monitoring , modelling and management of the global environment are tasks which uniquely requireNONMET the integration of skills and techniques from many disciplines .
BuildingNONMET such research teams is essential .
UnderlyingNONMET it all , however , is one obvious fact : that the gathering and analysis of geographically distributed environmental data formNONMET the necessary starting-point for ensuringNONMET the success of our future on earth .

Managing natural and technological hazards Anthony C. Gatrell and Peter Vincent Introduction Few areas of the application of GIS technology can be as socially significant , or environmentally relevant , as the management of emergencies and disasters due to natural and technological hazards .
Whether attemptingNONMET to constructNONMET a database of resources for use in planning responses to nuclear emergencies , developing optimal routes for schedulingNONMET the safe transport of hazardous substances , or monitoringNONMET the health implications of a disaster , GIS can assistNONMET in identifying possibilities and formulatingNONMET solutions .
The 1990s have been declaredNONMET the International Decade for Natural Disaster Reduction .
LetNONMET us hopeNONMET that G1S can , in some small way , help mitigateNONMET the suffering and hardship felt by all those afflictedNONMET by the effects of hazards which , as we have learntNONMET with bitter recent experience in the UK , can occurNONMET in an untimely fashion in the most improbable of places .
Research on hazards is multidisciplinary and straddlesNONMET the social , environmental and mathematical sciences .
If , for instance , we wishNONMET to modelNONMET the dispersal of a plume of toxic gas resultingNONMET from a chemical explosion , assessNONMET its possible impact on human health and evaluateNONMET likely evacuation scenarios of the population at risk we would requireNONMET , for example , a knowledge of atmospheric dispersion models , epidemiology and population distribution .
Some researchers suggestNONMET that hazards ( and emergencies that might resultNONMET ) can be regardedNONMET as either natural or technological .
We shall elaborateNONMET on this simple division below but suggestNONMET here that the wealth of literature on the former ( seeNONMET , for instance , Burton et al. 1978 and Perry 1981 ) has yet to be matchedNONMET by a similar volume of work on the latter .
There are signs that this imbalance is being rectifiedNONMET ( Zeigler et al. 1983 ) .
Hazard research , like few other GIS application areas , is not only stretchingNONMET the present technology to its limits but is a quite remarkable focus of international effort into several important research-related areas such as expert systems and simulation studies .
In this sense the scene is clearly one of hazard problems lookingNONMET for improved GIS rather than for GIS lookingNONMET for good problems , as is all too often the case .
Hazard research What are hazards ?
Formally , a hazard can be definedNONMET as : ‘ a physical situation with a potential for human injury , damage to property , damage to the environment , or some combination of these ’ ( Health and Safety Executive 1989 : 30 ) .
A hazard is a threat which , givenNONMET a set of circumstances , may becomeNONMET translated into a realized event .
What we chooseNONMET to callNONMET this event dependsNONMET upon factors such as its magnitude : we speakNONMET for instance of accidents , emergencies , disasters and catastrophes , each of which carriesNONMET connotations concerning the scale of the event and each of which will have a set of human and/or environmental consequences .
On 30 March 1956 one of the most powerful volcanic disturbances this century , the Bezymianny eruption , occurredNONMET .
Few people noticedNONMET the event as it tookNONMET place in an uninhabited part of Kamchatcka and causedNONMET no known casualties .
In contrast , the extrusion of a small volume of lava from a secondary cone on the slopes of Tristan da Cunha becameNONMET the focus of global interest when , during October 1961 , the island's lobster processing plant was smotheredNONMET and the 300 people of the island's only settlement were evacuatedNONMET to the UK .
These two contrasting events emphasizeNONMET the central fact that even natural hazards are not definedNONMET solely by the characteristics of the event but by the interaction of those events with the human occupation of the threatened area .
As notedNONMET above , the simple division of hazards is between those which are natural and those which are technological or human-induced .
Each of these may be further subdivided and the typology shownNONMET in Fig. 10.1 draws upon the classic work of Burton and Kates ( 1964 ) in separating geophysical from biological hazards and Zeigler et al. ( 1983 ) in distinguishing public ( or what we might callNONMET societal ) hazards from private ( individual ) ones .
The further subdivision of natural hazards is self-explanatory as is that of individual technological hazards .
Zeigler dividesNONMET the public hazards into those which result from the production of raw materials and manufactured goods , those which originateNONMET in transport and transmission and those which threatenNONMET the public in their role as consumers .
The United Nations Disaster Relief Organization ( UNDRO ) has producedNONMET a classification of disasters , derived on the basis of case data ( Table 10.1 ) .
UNDRO recognizesNONMET three basic types of disaster : accidents , natural events , and other disasters .
The differentiation of accidents from other types is useful in the context of emergency planning and is not so clearly conveyedNONMET by other hazard typologies .
However , the temptation in all classification exercises is to produceNONMET partitional schemes and this should really be resistedNONMET here .
It is more useful ( Johnson 1983 ) to adoptNONMET a non-partitional scheme ( fig. 10.1 ) that recognizesNONMET , for instance , food poisoning as both a personal and consumer hazard , or lead pollution ( e.g. from car exhausts ) as both a meteorological event and technological hazard ( both public and private ) .
An air crash ( as at Lockerbie ) affectsNONMET an entire community directly , as well as being an occupational hazard and risk to the individual traveller .
Hillslope failure ( as at Aberfan in South Wales in 1966 ) is a geomorphic hazard but may ariseNONMET because of raw material extraction .
Dutch elm disease is a floral hazard but is exacerbatedNONMET by the transport of infected logs .
Hohensemer et al. ( 1983 ) makeNONMET the important point that hazards are multidimensional in nature and suggestNONMET 12 dimensions along which any hazard may be scoredNONMET ( seeNONMET Table 10.2 ) .
These factors will , of course , be important in decidingNONMET on the role that GIS can playNONMET in hazard monitoring and emergency planning .
For instance , some events will persistNONMET briefly , have immediate consequences , minor transgenerational effects and have little or no potential for non-human mortality ( an air crash is an example ) .
Others , such as a chemical explosion involvingNONMET the release of a toxic gas , may persistNONMET for a week or more , have delayedNONMET consequences , may affectNONMET a future generation if the toxic chemical is mutagenic and may have a significant impact on plant and animal populations .
There may be more scope for a GIS approach in the latter than in the former situations .
The Hohensemer scheme is not , however , beyond criticism .
for example , can hazards really be thoughtNONMET of as having any intentionality ?
Industrial hazards and risk assessment Once hazards have been identifiedNONMET there may followNONMET efforts to assessNONMET the hazard risk .
By ‘ risk ’ we understandNONMET ‘ the likelihood of a specified undesired event occurringNONMET within a specified period or in specified circumstances ’ ( Health and Safety Executive 1989 : 30 ) .
It may , of course , be easier to quantifyNONMET risk for natural hazards because of historical records and statistical estimation of recurrence intervals .
Technological hazards are more unpredictable and may be extremely rare , so that it becomesNONMET difficult to useNONMET probability concepts to quantifyNONMET risk , especially those which relyNONMET on notions of relative frequency .
The identification of chemical hazards requiresNONMET that the locations of sites be knownNONMET , together with the dangerous substances stored or processed there .
In the UK ( seeNONMET Petts 1988 for a splendid overview ) the Health and Safety Executive must be notifiedNONMET of sites where hazardous substances in excess of threshold limits are handledNONMET .
Such substances and thresholds includeNONMET , for instance , 25 tonnes of flammable liquid petroleum gas and the explosive sodium chlorate , and 10 tonnes of toxic chlorine gas .
Some 1600 installations are notifiable , along with thousands of kilometres of pipelines ( mostly high-pressure natural gas transmission lines ) .
FollowingNONMET a number of major accidents involvingNONMET industrial activities ( including those at Flixborough , Humberside in 1974 ; Beek , the Netherlands in 1975 ; and Seveso and Manfredonia in Italy in 1976 ) , the EC issuedNONMET a Directive on Major Accident Hazards .
The Directive , which is commonly referredNONMET to as the ‘ Seveso ’ Directive , was issuedNONMET in June 1982 and in the UK its requirements were embodiedNONMET in the Control of Major Accident Hazard ( CIMAH ) Regulations ( 1984 ) .
Among other things , these regulations requireNONMET operators of hazardous installations to drawNONMET up on-site and off-site emergency plans and to giveNONMET information to members of the public who liveNONMET or work near such installations ( Houston 1987 ) .
There are presently about 300 CIMAH sites .
However , many potentially hazardous chemical installations are not coveredNONMET by such regulations .
Clearly , a plant which storesNONMET 1 tonne less than is requiredNONMET for notification slips through the net , while large numbers of handling sites ( warehouses , for instance ) are not coveredNONMET .
The regulations have obvious implications for G1S work , as illustratedNONMET below .
In Halton Borough , Cheshire , for instance , there are 13 notifiable installations , with over 20 000 people livingNONMET within the defined ‘ consultation zones ’ ( PettsNONMET 1988 ) .
It is also relevant to pointNONMET out here the work of the Health and Safety Executive in developing techniques for quantitative risk assessment ( Health and Safety Executive 1989 ) .
Such techniques includeNONMET the use of a ‘ risk assessment tool ’ ( RISKAT ) , inputs to which includeNONMET data on wind direction and speed ; the output of which is a map of calculated risk contours .
In societal risk assessment ‘ it is also necessary to inputNONMET data on the distribution of population around the installation .
This can be a difficult and time-consuming process , and inevitably some simplifying assumptions are neededNONMET ’ ( Health and Safety Executive 1989 : 17 ) .
Again , the G1S implications are clear and are discussedNONMET below .
Hazardous waste disposal The disposal of both nuclear and non-nuclear wastes has provedNONMET to be of major public concern in recent years .
The rather clumsy handling by NIREX of the search for sites to storeNONMET low- and intermediate-level wastes , together with very recent worries about the import of toxic wastes such as polychlorinated biphenyls ( PCBs ) , are but two examples of such concern in the UK .
However , while the former has been givenNONMET considerable attention by geographers ( summarizedNONMET by Openshaw et al. 1989 ) there has been relatively little such work in the UK on the disposal of non-nuclear wastes .
This contrastsNONMET with the situation in the USA ( Greenberg and Anderson 1984 ) , where the clean-up of abandoned sites is a priority .
Certainly , in terms of the volume of waste generated in the UK non-nuclear hazardous industrial wastes should be high on the environmental agenda ; while less than 1 million tonnes of all nuclear wastes were generatedNONMET in 1985–86 , 10 times that amount were generatedNONMET of hazardous wastes ( Openshaw et al. 1989 : 13 ) .
Attention should be drawnNONMET to the three Annual Reports of the Hazardous Waste Inspectorate ( now merged with other branches of the DoE to formNONMET Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Pollution ) .
These containNONMET some valuable material on disposal practices , and volumes of waste generated and disposed of by each waste regulation authority ( WRA ) — counties in England , districts in Wales , Scotland and Northern Ireland .
Each WRA is requiredNONMET to produceNONMET a waste disposal plan and these are startingNONMET to appearNONMET .
They too containNONMET useful material on , for instance , the locations of sites , though individual site licences must be consultedNONMET for details of what each is permittedNONMET to takeNONMET in the way of hazardous wastes .
What is not knownNONMET is information on the locations of former sites , at which quite toxic materials may have been dumpedNONMET , though recent work by Egger ( 1989 ) in Austria has mappedNONMET a vast number of such sites .
It is these , rather than existing , licensed sites which should be a focus of research activity , particularly when examiningNONMET possible links to ill health .
We simply do not have enough evidence yet to backNONMET up the claim that ‘ people are almost certainly ill , dead , or dying because of these sloppy waste disposal activities ’ ( Openshaw et al. 1989 : 12 ) .
Research is in progress , however , to assessNONMET possible health effects of poor incineration ( Diggle et al. 1990 ) .
Particular attention should be focusedNONMET on hospital incinerators , since these have been subject to Crown immunity for many years and most are technically ill-equipped to burnNONMET at sufficiently high temperatures for adequate disposal of wastes ( Gatrell and Lovett 1991 ) .
We needNONMET to produceNONMET an inventory of all such sites , together with a publicly available , comprehensive database on all sites acceptingNONMET hazardous industrial wastes .
Emergency planning It is convenient to retainNONMET the nuclear/non-nuclear distinction when discussingNONMET the background to emergency planning .
Nuclear emergency planning in the UK has been reviewedNONMET by Matthews and Pepper ( 1981 ) .
Nuclear power stations must prepareNONMET a plan and submitNONMET this to the Nuclear Installations Inspectorate and Health and Safety Executive for approval .
Evacuation plans are requiredNONMET to coverNONMET an area within a distance of 2.4 km ; these detailNONMET the roles to be playedNONMET by the emergency services .
The very narrow emergency planning zones contrast with those in the USA ( Collins 1981 ) , where planning is requiredNONMET up to 16 km from the site to coverNONMET exposure to radiation plumes .
Local authorities in the UK that have declaredNONMET themselves ‘ nuclear-free ’ have been highly critical of British planning , callingNONMET for an extension of emergency zones to at least 24 km .
Zeigler et al. ( 1983 ) should be consultedNONMET for material relatingNONMET to evacuation behaviour in the wake of the incident at Three Mile Island .
In the UK little work of any description seemsNONMET to have been done on human behaviour in the aftermath of releases of hazardous substances , nor is much available on public attitudes to emergency planning .
Indeed , no major studies of evacuation due to hazards have been undertakenNONMET in recent times and this is a widely recognized deficiency which no research funding body seemsNONMET willing to rectifyNONMET .
In the USA on the other hand , a good deal of useful research in these areas has been undertakenNONMET .
This research is broughtNONMET together in very useful reports producedNONMET by the Oak Ridge National Laboratory , Tennessee ( Sorenson et al. 1987 ; Vogt and Sorenson 1987 ) and the Disaster Research Centre , University of Delaware .
Perry ( 1985 ) has writtenNONMET an interesting book on emergency planning and evacuation , coveringNONMET both natural and technological hazards .
For him , comprehensive emergency planning and management involveNONMET : prevention , protection , response and restoration .
By prevention we understandNONMET the elimination or reduction in risk , perhaps by adequate zoning or safe routeing of shipments , for instance .
IncludedNONMET in protection are methods for detectingNONMET likely hazard events and in warningNONMET those likely to be affectedNONMET .
Response includesNONMET search and rescue ( including the need to copeNONMET with secondary threats such as contamination of water supplies after an explosion , or fire followingNONMET an earthquake ) .
As Perry and others have notedNONMET , relatively few resources are devoted to the first two aspects , the bulk goingNONMET to response and restoration ( rebuilding ) .
It should be clear from this brief description that these issues are inherently geographical .
In one of the few studies of evacuation behaviour after a non-nuclear hazard event Liverman and Wilson ( 1981 ) giveNONMET weight to this argument .
In 1979 a train carryingNONMET chlorine , liquid petroleum , toluene and propane was derailedNONMET in Mississauga , Ontario , causingNONMET a series of explosions .
This ledNONMET to the evacuation of 250 000 people which , although staggeredNONMET over several days , ledNONMET to great pressure on transport arteries .
An important finding was that many relied on their own transport and wentNONMET to stayNONMET with friends and relatives some distance away , rather than relyingNONMET on the 19 official evacuation reception centres .
Despite this , the evacuation was successful , partly because the accident occurredNONMET at a weekend and the immediately affected area was sparsely populatedNONMET .
In addition , the police were well prepared , stimulatedNONMET largely by implementingNONMET a plan designed more to copeNONMET with an emergency at the nearby Toronto International Airport than for the event in question .
It is not without interest to noteNONMET that in the USA there is a Federal Emergency Management Agency ( FEMA ) , established in 1978 , charged with dealingNONMET with all types of emergency planning and management .
In the UK there is no equivalent , though the spate of disasters in the past 4 years ( involvingNONMET over 1000 lives lostNONMET ) has ledNONMET to several calls for such a national body to be establishedNONMET .
Natural hazards In this short space it is not possible to goNONMET into any depth on the nature of particular natural hazards but only to highlightNONMET those aspects relevant to GIS .
Needless to sayNONMET , the study of natural hazards is important , a statement brought into sharp focus by the fact that natural hazards accountNONMET for up to 4 per cent of total deaths in the world each year ( Mitchell , 1974 ) .
In 1970 , for example , more than 200 000 people diedNONMET in the cyclone and flooding of Bangladesh and in 1979 the hurricanes David and Frederick causedNONMET more than $3bn damage in the USA .
Shah ( 1983 ) madeNONMET a comprehensive investigation of natural disaster reports for the period 1974–80 and concludedNONMET that both disaster frequency and magnitude ( measuredNONMET in terms of lives lostNONMET ) are increasing .
High death tolls are still a characteristic of less developed , low-income countries .
Surprisingly , fog is the third most important hazard in Europe after floods and volcanoes .
Research on natural hazards has a long tradition in geography goingNONMET back more than half a century .
Much of the impetus for such research aroseNONMET in the USA from observations on river basin management and the need to reduceNONMET flood damage .
The vast majority of natural hazards studies have ignoredNONMET the physical nature of the events per se and have concentratedNONMET on behavioural issues such as the perception and estimation of hazards .
This emphasis is partly due to the background of the researchers involvedNONMET ( many are human geographers and sociologists ) and partly because it is only really since the Second World War that major hazards have been monitoredNONMET systematically , culminatingNONMET , of course , in the last decade or so in the use of satellite technology .
Brief reference to two examples of natural hazards may illustrateNONMET the potential relevance of a GIS approach , applications of which are consideredNONMET below .
Jones et al. ( 1989 ) have examinedNONMET the distribution of some 8500 landslides in the UK .
Their maps showNONMET clearly an increased propensity for landslidingNONMET in the north and west of the UK .
More to the point , however , is the fact that this distribution can be modelledNONMET in terms of slopes , rainfall , rock types and so on .
In other words the actual hazard distribution can be understoodNONMET and areas at risk identifiedNONMET .
The potential benefits to insurance companies , engineers and planners are clear .
Second , a well-known winter hazard in the UK , with marked spatial localization , is fog .
Predictive models of its distribution have clear implications for road and air safety .
Perry ( 1981 ) describesNONMET a fog potential index that is a function of local topography , environmental features affectingNONMET fog formation and distance from standing water bodies .
Reliance is currently placedNONMET on a network of monitoring stations , often sparsely locatedNONMET and frequently outside fog-prone areas ; GIS could implementNONMET a predictive model basedNONMET on digitized map features and indeed the model could also be usedNONMET in site allocation studies for airports and the like .
The majority of natural hazard research has focusedNONMET on single hazards but of course any area may be prone to more than one hazard type .
This idea ledNONMET Hewitt and Burton ( 1971 ) to developNONMET the concept of ‘ all-hazards-at-a-place ’ .
To achieveNONMET this they concentratedNONMET on the whole spectrum of damaging events in an area and exploredNONMET their aggregate impact .
The implications for GIS in the development of ‘ hazardousness ’ indices are obvious and if time-series data are available there is the potential to produceNONMET a variety of probability maps .
The collection of historical data on natural hazards is important since it is clear that their spatial pattern variesNONMET through time .
Many areas that appearNONMET to be hazard-free on current maps may merely by passingNONMET through a temporary period of quiescence .
This is perhaps best illustratedNONMET with reference to earthquakes .
For example , in 1692 , the whole of southern England was affectedNONMET by an earthquake whose epicentre was locatedNONMET in what is now Belgium ; a good deal of minor structural damage was inflictedNONMET ( Morse 1983 ) .
Presumably the builders of the Channel Tunnel are aware of this ?
Environmental epidemiology This is , of course , a vast subject area , embracingNONMET the impact of the natural and technological environments on human health .
It coversNONMET , for instance , the associations between water and air pollution and ill health , links between geological and pedological environments and ill health , as well as associations between specific technological hazards ( e.g. high-voltage power lines ) and possible health effects .
We can only considerNONMET a small fraction of this work here ; little consideration is givenNONMET to occupational environments , for instance .
In the UK such research is widespread though there are specialist environmental epidemiology research institutes at Southampton and Cardiff ( fundedNONMET by the Medical Research Council ) , and others at the University of Surrey ( Robens Institute ) and at the London School for Hygiene and Tropical Medicine .
The latter houses the Small Area Health Statistics Research Unit ( SAHSRU ) , which has a specific remit to conductNONMET research into morbidity and mortality at local scales ( Elliot 1988 ) .
The SAHSRU liaisesNONMET closely with OPCS .
The kinds of databases usedNONMET by these groups are discussedNONMET below .
Greenberg ( 1983 ) and a collection of papers in Greenberg ( 1987 ) reviewNONMET some of the literature on environmental epidemiology .
It seemsNONMET worth statingNONMET at the outset that there are two ways geographical research in this general area can proceedNONMET .
One is to collectNONMET morbidity and mortality data ( usually the latter is more widely available , though the former more useful ) and to examineNONMET spatial distributions for clustering .
This has itself generatedNONMET a substantial literature ( seeNONMET the papers in Elliot 1988 for an overview ) and is nowhere better exemplifiedNONMET than in Openshaw's geographical analysis machine ( seeNONMET Ch. 2 ) .
We then search retrospectively for evidence of possible environmental associations .
An alternative approach is to beginNONMET by hypothesizingNONMET an environmental determinant of ill health and to collectNONMET data to testNONMET an explicit hypothesis .
If an association is suggestedNONMET then we would wantNONMET to collectNONMET data in other areas to assessNONMET the hypothesis further .
Of course , these two approaches are not clear-cut in practice ; in many cases the hypotheses of interest will have themselves been generatedNONMET by inductive mapping .
One example of an hypothesis which has been givenNONMET serious attention in recent years is the possible link between electromagnetic fields generatedNONMET by high-voltage power lines or supply cables and ill health .
Some work ( Perry et al. 1981 ) suggestedNONMET associations with mental illness and suicide , while others ( e.g. Wertheimer and Leeper 1982 ) have examinedNONMET links to various cancers , including leukaemias .
A good bibliography is providedNONMET in Perry and Pearl ( 1988 ) .
The Central Electricity Generating Board ( now privatized and split into two companies ) is fundingNONMET a large-scale , 2-year project to assessNONMET links to childhood cancer , while another recently announced study aimsNONMET to lookNONMET at links to sudden infant death .
One obvious problem , with implications for any GIS input , is that the effects are highly localizedNONMET , with little measurable field effect more than a few dozen metres away from the route centre-lines .
Accuracy of digital data collection ( either of the power lines or residential locations ) is paramount .
There seemsNONMET to be a growing interest in examining associations between ill health and the geological environment .
GIS workNONMET in this field ( e.g. Matthews 1989 ) is reviewedNONMET later , but we noteNONMET here the work of the applied geochemistry group at Imperial College ( responsible for a series of atlases on regional geochemistry ) and the existence of a Society for Environmental Geochemistry and Health .
One area of recent debate concernsNONMET radon gas and its links to lung cancer .
This is takenNONMET very seriously in the USA , where the Environmental Protection Agency estimatesNONMET that 10 000–20 000 deaths from lung cancer each year are due to radon gas exposure .
Estimates from Scandinavia suggestNONMET that 10–30 per cent of such deaths are causedNONMET by exposure to radon ( Richardson 1988 : 270–81 ) .
The gas is trappedNONMET in well-insulated houses and is producedNONMET by the decay of uranium in rocks and soil ; thus it has been measuredNONMET at high concentrations in parts of Cornwall and Devon .
There are great difficulties in assessingNONMET health effects , however , since exposure variesNONMET greatly from house to house within small neighbourhoods .
Carefully designedNONMET case-control studies are therefore requiredNONMET to measure the separate effect of radon exposure after controllingNONMET for smoking behaviour and other risk factors .
Other health concerns which might meritNONMET attention by those involved in the Regional Research Laboratory ( RRL ) initiative includeNONMET air and water pollution .
The debate about lead pollution from vehicle exhaust emissions is well knownNONMET ; less publicity has been givenNONMET to PAHs ( polychlorinated aromatic hydrocarbons ) , a ubiquitious product of combustion processes and knownNONMET to be carcinogenic ( Lioy and Daisey 1987 ) .
Research at the North West Regional Research Laboratory ( NWRRL ) aimsNONMET to createNONMET buffers around busy roads and junctions and to useNONMET data from the Cancer Registry to examineNONMET possible links between proximity to such sources of pollution and prevalence of lung cancer .
Those with an interest in health and air pollution should noteNONMET the availability of a very detailed database from the Warren Springs Laboratory , containingNONMET details of smoke and sulphur dioxide emissions at a large number of sites in the UK .
The possible link between nitrates in water and stomach cancer is the subject of much debate ( Beresford 1985 ) , as is the association between aluminium content and Alzheimer's disease .
The problems of assessingNONMET such links are , of course , huge , but there is scope for a contribution .
The role of GIS in hazard management scenarios — examples As we have already impliedNONMET , GIS has a role to playNONMET in all aspects of hazard research , from hazard monitoring , risk assessment and emergency planning to copingNONMET with an event and evaluatingNONMET its consequences .
The examples describedNONMET below illustrateNONMET all these , though as yet there do not appearNONMET to be many instances of disasters in the management of which GIS has playedNONMET a significant part .
Technological hazards , emergency planning and GIS A considerable amount of research has been undertakenNONMET to applyNONMET GIS methods to evacuation scenarios around hazardous sites .
Much of this research has concentratedNONMET on network analysis of the road system .
Reference was madeNONMET above to so-called CIMAH sites , major hazardous installations for which on-site and off-site emergency plans must be preparedNONMET .
Early research at the NWRRL focusedNONMET on developingNONMET a GIS for use by the police and county emergency planning officers in Cumbria that would aidNONMET in the management of a possible explosion at a chemical factory in Whitehaven , west Cumbria ( Vincent et al. 1988 ; Dunn 1989 ) .
The police requiredNONMET a portable system that could be implementedNONMET on an IBM-compatible microcomputer .
This was writtenNONMET at the NWRRL usingNONMET FORTRAN 77 and the Graphical Kernel System .
The GIS is menu-based and is exceptionally user-friendly ( Pl. 10.1 ) .
It opensNONMET with an outline map and the superimposition of the rather rigid zones usedNONMET by the emergency planners .
Full zoom facilities are available at any stage .
In any emergency it is of course vital to have high-quality data on the distribution of population and resources .
The system incorporatesNONMET digitized data on the distribution of all domestic and non-domestic properties in the town together with digitized road centre-line data .
Both sets of data were providedNONMET by Pinpoint Analysis Ltd , who are undertakingNONMET this digitizing task for the entire country .
Other spatially referenced data incorporatedNONMET into the system includeNONMET those on the distribution of schools , medical and transport services which can be displayedNONMET and supplementary information about them obtained .
The GIS permitsNONMET population estimatesNONMET to be madeNONMET for any arbitrary rectangular region on the map .
Most significantly , it incorporatesNONMET a shortest path algorithm which usesNONMET the road network to findNONMET optimal routes between user-defined start and end nodes .
Although predatingNONMET the RRL initiative by several years — and , indeed the emergence of GIS as a major research area — we should remindNONMET ourselves of Openshaw's work on appraisingNONMET nuclear reactor sites .
UsingNONMET what would now be calledNONMET GIS skills , Openshaw ( 1980 ) examinedNONMET over 13 000 1 km grid squares in the UK which intersectNONMET the coastline and relatedNONMET these to data from the 1971 Census ( which were madeNONMET available for such grid squares ) .
He demonstratedNONMET that there is an abundance of ‘ remote ’ sites , in contrast to the official view that such sites were increasingly hard to findNONMET .
He suggestedNONMET that in early spatial searches for sites ‘ only a small number were ever identifiedNONMET in the first place because rigorous searches could not be performedNONMET by manual means with poor quality data ’ ( Openshaw 1980 : 289 ) .
Heywood and Cornelius ( 1989 ) have shownNONMET how GIS can be usedNONMET for monitoringNONMET possible radiation releases and thus the relevance of GIS in nuclear emergency planning and monitoring .
They proposeNONMET a national radiological spatial information system and , in a pilot project in Cumbria , have integratedNONMET several layers of data within ARC/INFO to showNONMET what this might involveNONMET ( Fig. 10.2 ) .
Such data includeNONMET those from the Population and Agricultural Censuses as well as point data from rain gauge sites and radiation monitoring stations .
As an example , the system is usedNONMET to determineNONMET restriction zones for the movement of sheep after the explosion at Chernobyl in 1986 .
This is done by finding areas of high rainfall and parishes with high sheep populations .
The map overlay of point and area information showsNONMET generally good agreement with the restriction zones imposedNONMET by the Ministry of Agriculture , Fisheries and Food , with the exception of a small area to the south-east of Cumbria , borderingNONMET on Lancashire .
The British government carriedNONMET out a review of its arrangements for handlingNONMET nuclear accidents overseas followingNONMET the Chernobyl accident .
The DoE , through Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Pollution ( HMIP ) , was givenNONMET the task of co-ordinatingNONMET a national response plan , installingNONMET the radiation monitoring network and acting as lead government department in an emergency ( HMSO 1988 ) .
The monitoring network has becomeNONMET knownNONMET as the radioactive incident monitoring network ( RIMNET ) and has , as its prime responsibility , the detection of abnormal increases in radiation levels within the UK of the kind that might ariseNONMET from an overseas nuclear accident .
The full implementation of the RIMNET system will takeNONMET some time .
By the end of 1988 gamma radiation dose monitors had been installedNONMET at 46 meteorological stations as part of phase 1 of the development programme .
Radiation readings are takenNONMET every hour at each station and are transmittedNONMET to a central computer which analysesNONMET the data .
The current criterion for alert is two readings of more than three times normal background , either successively at the same site or simultaneously at two adjacent sites .
The dissemination of information in the event of an incident is dealtNONMET with at three levels : the first is the normal system of press notices ; the second is the use of teletext and viewdata ( Ceefax and Prestel ) to getNONMET direct to members of the public at their homes or places of work ; the third is the use of Telecom Gold electronic mail to getNONMET more technical details to various official bodies , such as water authorities ( Jackson 1989 ) .
Phase 2 of the RIMNET scheme will be completedNONMET by the end of 1991 when between 80 and 90 monitoring sites will have been establishedNONMET .
GivenNONMET very wide regional and local variations in deposition , questions must be raisedNONMET about the effectiveness of such a small network ; local authorities will needNONMET to supplementNONMET it with their own networks .
There are important analytical problems to be addressedNONMET concerning the siting of such monitoring equipment and these are elaboratedNONMET on later .
Abroad , Kaspar ( 1981 ) has discussedNONMET a computer-based exercise , with GIS overtones , involvingNONMET the simulated evacuation of the population living in the vicinity of the Neckarwestheim nuclear power plant in Baden Württemberg .
In the scenario he outlinesNONMET , an area affectedNONMET by radioactive releases is determined , the population within that area is allocatedNONMET to reception areas ( with capacity constraints ) , evacuation routes are identifiedNONMET and traffic restrictions implementedNONMET .
Little detail is providedNONMET , however , and it is thus difficult to evaluateNONMET his work fully .
Dangermond ( 1985 ) describesNONMET the use of the ARC/INFO NETWORK module for use in emergency planning situations .
He describesNONMET how a road network is digitized and subsequently analysed usingNONMET allocation , districtingNONMET and routeing algorithms .
Allocation determinesNONMET which arcs in the network will be allocatedNONMET to a particular node or centre ; districting makesNONMET it possible to outlineNONMET rapidly sets of polygons in order to defineNONMET specific areas of interest ( districts ) and to summarizeNONMET their characteristics ; routeing providesNONMET a minimum path algorithm through the network , the arcs of which can be assignedNONMET weights according to road conditions , road capacity and so on .
Dangermond givesNONMET several examples in his paper including the use of NETWORK for the allocation of emergency vehicles , optimum routeing of fire engines from garages to the accident scene and the movement of spills through sewers and river networks .
When combinedNONMET with the other facilities in ARC/INFO , quite complex disaster management scenarios can be handledNONMET .
For example , earthquake fault zones can be combinedNONMET with data on housing density and structural details to predictNONMET earthquake damage levels and these data then related to the network model .
Vincent ( 1989 ) illustratesNONMET the use of ARC/INFO and its NETWORK module for findingNONMET safe routes for chlorine transhipment on the road and rail systems of north-west England ( Pl. 10.2 ) .
In this case , population density data for a 1 km buffer on either side of network arcs were overlaidNONMET on the network itself so as to actNONMET as weights for the minimum path algorithm .
Chosen routes were those which minimizedNONMET population rather than distance .
Hazardous waste disposal There can be little doubt that a GIS approach has wide applicability in all sorts of location problems where the goal is to minimizeNONMET ( rather than , as conventionally , maximizeNONMET ) accessibility to a population .
A particularly good application is to the search for potential sites for the disposal of nuclear and non-nuclear ( but none the less hazardous ) wastes .
We discussNONMET here some relevant work on the siting of facilities for the disposal of nuclear wastes before examiningNONMET those for non-nuclear wastes .
The major contribution to informed debate about the search for sites for the disposal of nuclear wastes has comeNONMET from a group of geographers ( Openshaw et al. 1989 ) and a GIS approach to this problem can payNONMET high dividends .
The work of Carver ( seeNONMET Openshaw et al. 1989 : Ch. 7 ) is an interesting example .
One advantage is the ability to modelNONMET a range of alternatives by allowingNONMET particular criteria to enterNONMET or be omittedNONMET from the polygon overlay operation .
Conceptually , what is offeredNONMET is little more than an automated ‘ sieve mapping ’ that land-use planners have usedNONMET for many years , but the whole procedure is speededNONMET up by many orders of magnitude usingNONMET GIS software .
The authors examineNONMET both near-surface sites and deep repositories ( which useNONMET more restricted population criteria and allowNONMET offshore locations to enterNONMET ) .
Data layers includeNONMET geological maps , conservation areas , transport routes , petrochemical facilities and demographic data .
As different layers are addedNONMET sequentially we seeNONMET how the proportion of available land shrinks ( Pl. 10.3 ) ; for instance , when geological criteria are setNONMET in the search for a deep repository , 25 per cent of land area remainsNONMET and the addition of the population density layer reducesNONMET this to 24 per cent .
However , addingNONMET a proximity to transportNONMET constraint lowersNONMET this to 12 per cent ; and so on .
We can not pretendNONMET GIS is a solution to the political problems of negotiation and justification but at the very least the openness of the procedures goesNONMET some way towards satisfyingNONMET a worried public .
GIS research into site selection for non-nuclear hazardous waste has been almost exclusively conductedNONMET in North America and has yet to be matchedNONMET in the UK .
Jensen and Christiansen ( 1986 ) , workingNONMET in the south-eastern USA , useNONMET a raster approach ( with a pixel resolution of 20 m&sup2 ; ) and Boolean overlay to ‘ weedNONMET out ’ particular sites , such as those which are poorly drained , environmentally sensitive or inaccessible ( seeNONMET also Stewart 1987 ) .
Environmental monitoring of sites for the disposal of toxic waste is of particular concern in the USA .
The Comprehensive Environmental Response , Compensation and Liability Act ( CERCLA ) legislation of 1980 ( ‘ Superfund ’ ) requiresNONMET the cleaning up of the worst landfill sites , of which some 800 had been identifiedNONMET by the Environmental Protection Agency by 1986 ( Foresman 1986 ) .
A major worry has been the threat posedNONMET by groundwater pollution and some research has been conductedNONMET on usingNONMET GIS to monitorNONMET this ( Merchant et al. 1987 ; Barringer et al. 1987 ; von Braun 1988 ) .
This is an important topic since 95 per cent of rural households in the USA consumeNONMET only groundwater , while half the US population consumesNONMET at least some groundwater ( Merchant et al. 1987 ) .
Clearly , the research demands access to exceptionally good environmental data , usually in three dimensions .
As Foresman ( 1986 ) suggestsNONMET , we might expectNONMET remote sensing technology to playNONMET a major role .
Merchant et al. ( 1987 ) for example , useNONMET the image processing system ERDAS to constructNONMET an index of vulnerability to groundwater pollution ; this usesNONMET variables such as depth to water table , soil type , slope and so on ( seeNONMET Estes et al. 1987 for a similar approach ) .
Barringer et al. ( 1987 ) overlayNONMET data on soil type and geology with that of groundwater quality ( hardness and corrosivity measures ) and buildNONMET a linear model which showsNONMET that the background environmental variables are good predictors of the water quality indices .
Again , a raster-based approach is used .
A further example is work by von Braun ( 1988 ) who usesNONMET pMAP to lookNONMET at exposure of organic and metallic compounds in groundwater in the vicinity of Tucson airport , Arizona .
UsingNONMET plume models that predictNONMET the movement of contaminants she is able to intersectNONMET the results with data on current well locations and to assessNONMET which water supply areas are worst contaminatedNONMET .
OverlayingNONMET the results with residential location data providesNONMET ‘ maps delineatingNONMET location-specific exposures for each residence in each time-period ’ ( von Braun 1988 ; 1160 ) .
In principle , it is then possible to compareNONMET such ‘ doses ’ with epidemiological data , once again indicatingNONMET a link from a hazard event to assessment of health outcomes .
Attention should be drawnNONMET to Foresman's comment that the US Geological Survey ( USGS ) ( at the EROS Data Centre ) have successfully linkedNONMET ARC/INFO to a model of groundwater flow ( Foresman 1986 : 260 ) .
This kind of link between GIS and other modelling programs is to be warmly welcomedNONMET and parallels work at the NWRRL in linkingNONMET GIS and air pollution plume models .
Natural hazards and disaster management Several studies in recent papers have shownNONMET the effectiveness of GIS in mitigatingNONMET the effects of major natural hazards .
Berke and Ruch ( 1985 ) , for example , describeNONMET a GIS for assessingNONMET the impacts of hurricanes on the Texas Gulf coast .
Hurricane damage through high winds and tidal surges causesNONMET an immense amount of destruction and posesNONMET a major threat to many coastal communities in the USA .
It has been estimatedNONMET , for example , that during the mid 1970s some 50 million US citizens were subject to hurricane winds of over 160 km/h and 6 million were subject to hurricane surge ( Brinkman 1975 ) .
The system describedNONMET by Berke and Ruch ( 1985 ) is raster-based and has an interesting modelling component calledNONMET SLOSH ( Sea , Lake and Overland Surges from Hurricanes ) .
SLOSH is able to estimateNONMET still water surge by grid cell for various hurricane intensities , angles of approach to the shoreline , forward movement speeds and landfall locations .
Additional algorithms are usedNONMET to modelNONMET total building damage costs for each grid cell basedNONMET on water-depth and speed-depth rating curves .
Hobeika and Jamei ( 1985 ) describeNONMET the MASSeVACuation ( MASSVAC ) simulation software designed to analyseNONMET and evaluateNONMET traffic evacuation plans givenNONMET a natural disaster in an urban area .
The system comprisesNONMET three interrelated modules : community and disaster type characteristics module ; population distribution module ; network evacuation module .
The type of natural disaster determinesNONMET the time period within which the road network has to be evacuatedNONMET .
The control and management strategies are directly correlatedNONMET to each specific disaster scenario .
MASSVAC is quite flexible and various user-defined road network options are available such as : traffic signal timings on the road network ; one-way traffic ; reserved lanes for special vehicles such as those of the emergency services .
Hobeika and Jamei have testedNONMET MASSVAC on various evacuation scenarios for Virginia Beach City in order to determineNONMET evacuation times for flood and hurricane conditions .
In general , they suggestNONMET that the model provided reasonable and reliable evacuation times .
Southworth et al. ( 1989 ) have enhancedNONMET the MASSVAC model with the addition of a colour graphics module which they callNONMET MVOPL .
This module has been developedNONMET usingNONMET IBM's Graphics Kernel System and providesNONMET a number of display screens .
The most interesting are those which portrayNONMET population flows as scaled ribbons on the network diagram , and evacuation shelter capacities as bar diagrams .
The diagrams are updatedNONMET periodically during the course of the simulation .
In dry parts of the world , such as Australia , forest and bush fires are an important natural hazard and some attention has been givenNONMET to the ways in which GIS might helpNONMET examineNONMET their potential impacts .
Kessell ( 1988 ) describesNONMET a PC-based GIS called PREPLAN ( PRistine Environment Planning LANguage ) which is a natural area management , land-use planning and fire modelling system developedNONMET for the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service , PREPLAN comprisesNONMET four modules : a simple raster-based GIS ; a grid cell resource database ; a wide range of vegetation , fuel , fire behaviour , erosion and land-use models ; tabular , statistical and colour graphics output system .
With this system real-time fire growth can be modelledNONMET , takingNONMET into account changes in terrain , fuel and temporal changes in the weather .
Kessell pointsNONMET out that uncontrollable fires are recurrent phenomena in many parts of Australia , causingNONMET damage in the hundreds of millions of dollars and significant loss of life .
Systems such as PREPLAN can provideNONMET the user with sound models of the behaviour patterns of fire and are therefore of enormous value in land-use planning .
One of the most widespread natural hazards is flooding , and the potential for loss of property , risk to life and general social disruption is large .
One interesting example of a GIS approach to floodNONMET damage estimation is the ANUFLOOD package which was developedNONMET in the early 1980s followingNONMET detailed flood damage studies for flood-prone coastal towns in northern New South Wales , Australia ( Smith and Greenaway , 1988 ) .
The ANUFLOOD system requiresNONMET locational and building type data on individual properties , stage-damage curves relatingNONMET the average damage that would resultNONMET from overfloor flooding to differing depths for each property type , and lastly , flood frequency in terms of flood height expressedNONMET as a probability .
Output from the system is both tabular and graphical .
Of particular interest is the construction of maps showingNONMET the expected annual amounts of damage for gridded flood-prone areas .
ANUFLOODNONMET also containsNONMET modules which permitNONMET the investigation of various flood damage mitigation options , such as property height raising , levee construction and flood proofing .
Environmental epidemiology The possibilities sketchedNONMET above relateNONMET to emergency planning , the search for hazardous sites , and risk assessment .
To what extent can GIS helpNONMET if an event occursNONMET ?
What , for instance , of the health consequences ?
There is a rich tradition of epidemiological work in geography and with the increasing availability of spatially referencedNONMET medical data the scope for GIS applications is wide ( Gatrell 1987 ) .
For instance , Diggle et al. ( 1990 ) assessNONMET the hypothesis that cancer of the larynx is associatedNONMET with proximity to a now-closed incinerator and developNONMET a statistical model from the theory of spatial point processes to testNONMET this .
This would have been impossible without the link providedNONMET from postcoded data ( increasingly available from sources such as cancer registries ) to Ordnance Survey ( OS ) grid references .
Such a link is providedNONMET by the Central Postcode Directory , which matchesNONMET all 1.5 million unit postcodes in the UK to grid references .
When the cases of laryngeal cancer are comparedNONMET with a null distribution ( providedNONMET by the distribution of much more common lung cancer ) the hypothesis is given strong support .
Although the proposed method is novel , it is but one of an increasingly large number of methods designedNONMET to detectNONMET and model ‘ clusters ’ of disease ( seeNONMET , for example , Cuzick and Edwards 1990 ) .
The work of Diggle et al. ( 1990 ) examinedNONMET only a single point source , though it generalizesNONMET to multiple sources and to linear hazards as well .
As a second example of health work linked to hazardNONMET studies we may citeNONMET the research being conductedNONMET by Cross ( 1989 ) on childhood leukaemia .
There are numerous hypotheses concerning the aetiology of this disease ( from ionizing radiation to viral transmission ) and Cross's approach is to collectNONMET digital data designed to testNONMET some of these hypotheses and to useNONMET ARC/INFO to displayNONMET and analyseNONMET results .
For instance , one hypothesis concernsNONMET the role of electromagnetic radiation , a source of which is overhead high-voltage transmission lines as notedNONMET earlier .
If these are digitized and buffer zones constructedNONMET around them ( Fig. 10.3 ) we can quite easily testNONMET hypotheses about prevalence in such buffer zones as comparedNONMET with prevalence outside .
However , we should bearNONMET in mind the earlier point about the resolution of the data , since such electromagnetic effects have a very weak effect beyond perhaps 50 m ( Wertheimer and Leeper 1982 ) .
There has been a suspicion for many years that high rates of stomach cancer in parts of Wales may be linkedNONMET to soilNONMET chemistry , specifically such factors as zinc/copper ratios , and to leadNONMET content in water supplies .
Matthews ( 1989 ) has usedNONMET data from the Regional Cancer Registry ( morbidity rather than mortality data ) and data on trace elements to examineNONMET this link .
Since the latter are available for a 5 km raster the registration data are assignedNONMET to these grid squares usingNONMET the OS grid reference .
As with any such study there are the usual problems of ecological analysis and influences of migration , together with issues of separatingNONMET out the risk factors under investigation from possible confounding factors .
In the USA , Morrill's report on the beginnings of a $15m. study into the possible radiation doses received as result of radiation releases by the Hanford ( Washington State ) nuclear complex would seemNONMET to cryNONMET out for GIS skills to be appliedNONMET ( Morrill 1989 ) .
The research project will employNONMET plume dispersion models in order to modelNONMET dispersal by wind and will needNONMET to integrateNONMET this and other environmental data with detailed demographic records .
To some extent this line of approach was anticipatedNONMET by Johnson ( 1981 ) in his study of exposure to plutonium fall-out from the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant near Denver ( seeNONMET Zeigler et al. 1983 : 47–8 ) .
UsingNONMET soil samples he constructedNONMET a contoured risk surface and then mappedNONMET excess cancers in various distance bands , detectingNONMET a marked distance decay effect .
Research problems and prospects The work reviewed above suggestsNONMET that the application of GIS techniques to hazardNONMET assessment , emergency planning and environmental monitoring is both actually and potentially an important research area with many challenging problems .
Undoubtedly , the GISs of the 1990s will lookNONMET very different from their rather primitive ancestors .
Computer power is becomingNONMET cheaper , digital data more readily available , and GISs are becomingNONMET hybrid systems involvingNONMET other technologies .
In this last section we highlightNONMET some important research areas as we seeNONMET them .
Doubtless there are many others , such is the surge of interest in GIS technology .
Data availability We should first considerMET the availability and quality of data concerning the populations who may be at risk from the storage and transport of hazardous substances , from toxic air pollution , from flooding and so on .
Such data are crucial , either for assistingNONMET the emergency services to makeMET assessments about resources they needNONMET to deployMET in such events , or for high estimates to be madeMET of risk .
Within the public domain in the UK we must relyNONMET in general on data from the most recent Population Census , the lowest level being that for enumeration districts ( EDs ) .
As is well knownNONMET ( Rhind 1983 ) these containNONMET on average perhaps 150–200 households and 400–500 people .
The boundaries EDs have not been widely digitizedNONMET , unlike the higher level electoral wards .
However , the centroids of EDs are available as 100 m grid references and artificial ED ‘ polygons ’ can be createdNONMET if necessary .
In some instances such data will sufficeNONMET ; in many cases they will have to sufficeNONMET as nothing better is available .
But in some areas EDs are very extensive physical units and the shapes will be quite distorted .
Furthermore , the scales at which population estimates are often required means that even EDs are too coarse for risk assessments .
For instance , in performingNONMET its quantitative risk assessments the Health and Safety Executive will rarely dealMET with distances from hazardous sites in excess of 1 km ( PettsNONMET 1988 ) and census data will not offerMET sufficient resolution for accurate population estimatesNONMET to be madeMET .
It should be pointedMET out , however , that the National Radiological Protection Board currently usesMET 1 km grid square resolution population data from the 1971 Census in its radiological protection studies ( Hallam et al. 1981 ) .
It would seemNONMET that , despite the costs involvedNONMET , they should considerMET investing in the very detailed digital data ( PinpointNONMET Address Code ( PAC ) ) provided by Pinpoint Analysis Ltd .
This area of application would appearNONMET to be an obvious market for such a product .
A useful research exercise would be to compareNONMET the use of census and PAC data in derivingMET quantitative risk assessments and this is an interesting research problem .
Even with PAC data some assumptions would needNONMET to be madeMET about numbers of persons per household if good population estimates were to be madeMET .
More generally , we needNONMET to considerMET the availability of large databases for hazard studies and emergency planning and this is an area ripe for major initiatives .
In the UK we seemNONMET to be laggingMET well behind the USA in the construction of databases on hazardous sites and especially hazard events such as those involvingNONMET toxic releases .
For instance , Lioy and Daisey ( 1987 ) , in their work on the monitoring of toxic air pollution in New Jersey , constructMET what they term a ‘ microinventory ’ for each of three towns , comprisingNONMET the locations of chemical plants , metal processing plants , paint spray manufacturers and so on .
Some attribute information is available for these .
More closely linkedMET to GIS is work by McMaster and Johnson ( 1986 ) who performNONMET a very detailed inventory of hazardous materials ( both stored and transportedNONMET ) in Santa Monica , California .
Although the raster displays are very crude it is simple to answerNONMET spatial queries concerning the locations of people ( for instance , particular age groups ) within certain distances of toxic hazard sites .
We have data on some hazardous sites ( e.g. those regulatedMET by CIMAH ) in the UK but a much more comprehensive approach should be adoptedMET , especially if we are serious in the search for environmental associations with chronic diseases .
The same is true for toxic releases .
In the USA the Environmental Protection Agency producesMET an Acute Hazards Events Database while the Department of Transportation has a database recording details of 25 000 releases of toxic materials ; such details includeMET locational information , type and amount of material releasedMET , mode of release and resulting injuries or deaths ( Cutter and Solecki 1989 ) .
Can we not useNONMET GIS technology to constructMET ‘ risk mosaics ’ ( Zeigler et al. 1983 ) , at a variety of spatial scales , akin to Hewitt and Burton's ‘ hazardousness ’ of a place ?
In the UK only a handful of county emergency planning departments ( Cumbria , for instance ) have builtMET up resource databases in digital form and this needsNONMET to be promotedNONMET .
Further afield , we needNONMET to recognizeMET that some disasters ( most obviously Chernobyl ) will have implications for more than one country so that environmental monitoring should takeMET place with some kind of international co-ordination .
There will also be movements of hazardous cargoes across frontiers and there are clearly problems of risk assessment and planning for emergencies at or near international boundaries , or at sea and airports .
As notedNONMET above , the work of Fedra ( 1989 ) is a major step in this direction , and links need to be forgedMET between initiatives in the UK and the rest of Europe .
In terms of databases on hazardous wastes , attention has already been drawnMET to the waste disposal plans preparedMET by WRAs .
These giveMET details of present site locations and some indication of permitted wastes , though little or no information on closed and abandoned sites .
However , for details of disposal the individual site licences must be consultedMET .
The former Hazardous Waste Inspectorate operatedMET a large database on all sites , with details of permitted wastes , including allowable quantities .
The database was createdNONMET by a commercial company , AspinwallsNONMET Ltd .
There are numerous potentially usable databases for environmental epidemiological work .
OPCS , of course , is a major data repository for medical statistics and their various Monitor Series are of use , though only at the scale of district health authority and above ( seeNONMET Gatrell and Lovett 1988 for an example ) .
Regional health authorities will from time to time produceMET mortality data at ward level .
However , if cancers are of interest it is more appropriate to obtainMET data from regional cancer registries ; these data are morbidity rather than mortality data and are therefore more valuable .
The data are postcoded and may have some occupational details .
For example , we have receivedNONMET data from the Regional Cancer Registry in Manchester comprisingNONMET all cancers of the larynx and lung notified between 1974 and 1984 .
This large data setMET , to which grid references have now been addedNONMET , comprisesNONMET information about nearly 40 000 individuals .
It has now been copiedMET into INGRES , a relational database management system , permittingMET queries to be madeMET about subsets of the data ; for instance , all males between the ages of 25 and 64 suffering from laryngeal cancer .
Other data sources on cancers are independent registries of malignancies .
An example is that on leukaemias , managedNONMET by the Leukaemia Research Fund Centre in Leeds ( Alexander et al. 1989 ) .
It should be notedMET that there are frequently major discrepancies between the regional registries and the specialist registries , partly because the latter receiveMET notifications directly from consultants .
Indeed , workingNONMET directly with consultants provesNONMET invaluable in gainingMET access to high morbidity data .
Two other potential sources of data are worth mentioningMET .
First , attention should be drawnMET to the new directive from the Department of Health to regional and district health authorities to reviewNONMET the health of the population .
This meansNONMET in practice that district medical officers are chargedMET with preparingNONMET an annual report , presentingMET and interpretingNONMET epidemiological data , identifyingNONMET local health problems and evaluatingNONMET service outcomes .
Lancaster University is already heavily involved in the work of Preston District Health Authority in this area .
Second , family health service authorities ( FHSAs ) , are also requiredNONMET to takeMET on these roles , but from the viewpoint of primary health care services .
FHSAs ( which correspondNONMET to non-metropolitan counties and to metropolitan boroughs ) holdMET large databases on services providedNONMET by general practitioners ; for instance , uptake of immunization and screening for breast and cervical cancers .
Is it , we wonderNONMET , possible to contemplateMET bringingNONMET together some of these data sources to formMET a National Online Health Information System ( NOHIS ) , to parallelMET that for employment and unemployment ( Townsend et al. 1987 ) ?
This might includeMET data on morbidity and mortality , uptake of preventative medicine , service use and availability , at both primary and hospital level .
It would be a useful management tool , particularly in view of the reorganization takingMET place in the National Health Service .
It should not be forgottenNONMET that hazards themselves have geographical distributions yet there has been little effort in the UK to developNONMET public domain databases .
Are there hazard- prone areas ?
Is there a regional differentiation in hazard type ?
These are , of course , commercially important questions and a good deal of money is goingMET into the collection of such data by insurance companies .
One well knownNONMET database is Major Hazard Incident Data Service ( MHIDAS ) global industrial hazards database which is currently being developedNONMET by the Safety and Reliability Directorate on behalf of the Major Hazards Assessment Unit of the UK Health and Safety Directorate .
This system currently runsMET in dBASE II and containsMET in excess of 3000 items of professionally assessedMET information on major hazards coded into some 24 separate fields .
Unfortunately , the spatial referencing is poor and with some effort this could easily be remediedNONMET .
It is , for example , little use when recordingNONMET a chemical spill into an Egyptian river to have enteredMET into the appropriate field ‘ the Nile ’ — after all , this river is some 6480 km long !
Here , in our view , is a classic case of the absence of a geographical input renderingMET the data of limited value .
In some cases , good hazard data existNONMET but have simply not yet found their way into a GIS .
A case in point is inland and coastal flooding .
Most river authorities have detailedNONMET maps showingMET the geographical limits of floods in relation to their return periods .
Within the next decade , as the privatized water companies developNONMET their GIS , we shall seeNONMET a massive amount of data conversion in this area .
This development , together with the availability of digital terrain models , will allowMET quite sophisticated flood forecasting models to be developedNONMET within a GIS framework .
As sea-levels rise in the next 20–30 years due to the ‘ greenhouse ’ effect , this very practical use of GIS technology is likely to becomeNONMET commonplace and of considerable practical importance .
Spatial statistics Another way in which there needsNONMET to be a rapprochement between statistical methods and GIS is in the area of spatial sampling and estimation from spatial samples .
This is clearly an important issue in radiation monitoring as the discussion of RIMNET above impliesMET .
As an example , Peirson ( 1988 ) has reviewedNONMET the evidence on artificial radioactivity in Cumbria and showsNONMET maps of the distribution of certain radionuclides as contoured surfaces .
The point worth makingMET here is that there are many alternative schemes for interpolatingNONMET from irregular point data ( Lam 1983 ) .
One method in particular , krigingNONMET ( now available as part of the UNIRAS software ) , offersMET not only a contoured surface but also an estimate of the standard error at any point on the map .
Where this is high it suggestsMET that an additional sampling station might be set up .
Such techniques are now standard in environmental science ( seeNONMET Streit 1981 for an application to rainfall monitoring ) and need to be promotedNONMET vigorously in hazard studies ( Estes et al. 1987 ) .
Related to this problem is that of makingMET population estimates for new zones that result from overlay operations .
We may wantNONMET to countNONMET numbers livingNONMET within plumes , circles of fixed radius , buffer zones and so on .
Existing GIS techniques usually baseMET the estimates on area-weighted shares , so that a new polygon createdNONMET by ‘ slicingMET ’ an existing area in half is assignedMET half the population of that source unit .
This may be quite absurd in some cases , notably where population is spatially clusteredNONMET within a physically large ED .
At the NWRRL work is under way ( Flowerdew and Green 1989 ) to solveNONMET such problems usingNONMET the EM algorithm and the statistical modelling package GLIM , which has been interfacedMET with ARC/INFO .
Operations research methods and simulation While there is some research activity in linkingMET statistical models to GIS there would seemNONMET to be scope for further applications of operations research techniques to GIS problems .
Within some sophisticated GIS such as ARC/INFO there are some useful algorithms ( such as shortest path calculations ) , but GIS developers have in general failedMET to realizeNONMET the natural links between GIS functions and many operations research techniques .
Over the last 20 years or so a large theoretical literature has been developedNONMET to provideNONMET tools for the solution of many problems associatedNONMET with emergency planning ( Kolesar 1981 ) .
One important class of problems is the selection of locations for the emergency service units .
The choice of locations need not be for permanent bases , but can also includeMET dynamic repositioning of units as circumstances dictateMET ( Kolesar and Walker 1974 ) .
In any major emergency a typical problem is the assignment of resources to demands .
If resources are heldMET at one set of locations and the demands are at another and the costs of transportation are knownNONMET , how do we allocateNONMET the resources most efficiently ?
In a major emergency , for example , there might be a need to supplyNONMET blood products held at regional blood banks to hospitals .
This , of course , is the classic transportation problem and its solution is well knownNONMET .
As far as we knowNONMET the microcomputer- based emergency response system devisedNONMET by Belardo et al. ( 1983 ) , is the only GIS-like software to incorporateNONMET this algorithm .
In this system , the solution to the transportation problem is shownNONMET graphically on the road network , which is displayedNONMET on the computer screen .
As a last example of the potential role of operations research in GIS and disaster management we are remindedNONMET of the logistic problems that facedMET the Peel Regional Police Force  during the Mississauga evacuation mentioned previously ( Scanlon and Padgham 1980 ) .
During the early states of the phased evacuation the logistical problem facingMET the police was the street-by-street warning of the population to makeMET ready for evacuation .
Speed was of the essence and manpower was limited .
Here , then , is a familiar operations research network problem : all roads have to be traversedNONMET such that the journey length/time is a minimum .
This is the so-called Chinese postman problem , which providesNONMET a Hamiltonian circuit through the arcs ( as comparedNONMET with the travelling salesman problem which is a minimum route through the network nodes ) .

The drift was thickly overgrownNONMET , a dank tunnel out of whose bushy sides the tendrils of brambles and briar roses caughtMET at his clothes .
One of these whippedMET back at him and as he caughtNONMET at it a thorn droveMET into the fleshy pad of his finger .
That thorn had been there , festeringNONMET , for months .
A dull cool summer it had been , as different as could be from the year before .
No golden light bathedMET the red brick of the house .
It no longer lookedNONMET mellow .
Beautiful , yes , but severe somehow and , to Adam's heightened awareness , reproachful .
He foundMET himself encouraging , fostering , the scenario illusion .
Only thus , only by pretendingNONMET unreality , pretendingNONMET this was a part he actedNONMET , could he go on , crossNONMET the wild , shaggy grass , goNONMET past the black-branched cedar tree , arriveNONMET at the porch set in its four Doric columns and insertNONMET his key in the lock .
Conclusion Task analysis has not and can not be reducedMET to a set of standardised procedures which the aspiring analyst could acquireMET in a formal training course .
The techniques just describedNONMET are no more than guidelines in what remains the creative art of studyingNONMET and describingNONMET what an experienced worker is doing or will be requiredNONMET to do .
The danger in being too rigid is that justice will not be done to the flexibility and complexity of human performance .
The danger of being too flexible is that the ergonomists will have an inadequate basis from which to designMET interfaces , training courses and other operator aids .
If a comprehensive task description can be completedNONMET then it is legitimate to enquireNONMET why the task can not be allocatedNONMET to a technical device rather than a human being .
Yet without a reasonably comprehensive task description the total system performance may be unreliable or unpredictable .
There is a necessary compromise which can only be arrivedMET at in the context of a particular system .
As mentionedMET earlier there are always the twin problems of how to getMET the information and how to presentMET it .
It is sometimes easier to proceedMET on the basis of : ‘ If I were doing the job this is how I would do it ’ , but this can be delusory even for analysts who have past experience as operators .
For analysts who are designers creatingMET a new task there may be no alternative , but any task description arrivedMET at by this method should be checkedNONMET against the behaviour of real operators as they gainMET experience .
A particular difficulty about task synthesis is that there is no easy way of confirmingNONMET completeness .
A task description which is part of a design process should be fully — documented in terms of the origins of information , the assumptions made and the methods used .
The standard method of producing task descriptions is to writeNONMET all the separate sub-tasks at various levels on cards and then assembleMET the cards in a network .
There is a temptation to makeNONMET these final diagrams very large , but often it is more useful to separateMET into small units with cross-referencing .
The optimum size seemsNONMET to be A3 , this is easily copiedNONMET and circulated but is large enough to containMET considerable detail .
The procedure can be computerised , there are programmes available for the easy production , manipulation and storage of block diagrams with useful cross-referencing facilities .
There is an inherent difficulty in that often the main dividend from a task analysis is from the act of obtainingNONMET it .
Those not involvedNONMET findMET it difficult to gainMET very much from a presentation of a task description .
Like reference books , they have to be usedNONMET rather than readNONMET .
Task analysis can be very expensive in skilled manpower , but in lookingMET at cost/value it is important to includeMET in value the increase in mutual understanding which occursNONMET when a multi-disciplinary team conductsMET the analysis .
If such a team is usedNONMET the required man-hours can be optimisedNONMET by usingNONMET the Delphi method rather than a long series of group meetings .
Political , economic and social issues which ariseMET in conductingMET Task Analyses are discussedMET in the context of Job Analysis ( p. 148 ) .
Application Man-power planning The ‘ Human Resource ’ concept of man-power as the central profit­ generating asset of any organisation has madeMET some progress over the past twenty years .
There was particular interest around 1970 when companies were prosperous , stable and innovative ( IPM , 1972 , Patten , 1971 ) .
The objective is to reviseNONMET and almost reverseMET the traditional accountancy concept of man-power as a resource consuming factor requiringNONMET regular payments , overheads in the form of heated , lighted , equippedNONMET workspaces and so on .
From the narrow accountancy viewpoint , people are a cost and it is desirable to keepMET this cost as low as possible .
In these terms it is very difficult to justify , for example , sendingNONMET a member of staff on a training course .
The training requiresNONMET expenditure and so also does the replacement for the person away .
Where is the return ?
The return is actually in the improved human resource but this is not readily measurable in terms which accountants use .
There have been two attempts to reduceMET human resources to this form of measurement ( Giles and Robinson , 1972 ) .
One is to acquireMET a human asset multiplier for each level of staff .
The multiplier for manual staff might be unity but it increasesNONMET with staff level and becomesNONMET three or more for management .
The other is to addNONMET together all the personnel costs for each kind of worker from the original job advertisement through to the retirement or redundancy payments .
The first does attemptMET to obtainMET a value , the second remainsNONMET essentially a cost and not a value .
It would be unduly optimistic to assumeMET that management skills have risenMET to a level such that costs undertakenMET can be assumedMET to be equivalent to value .
A less direct measure which is applicable only to the most senior management is to observeNONMET the fall or rise of the share price when a particular executive leaves or joinsMET a company .
This can be very high , for a large company a change in market value of millions of pounds is not unusual .
The most serious consequence of the accountancy view of man-power is that high level policy decision-making does not giveMET this factor sufficient weight .
For example , the main board of a company will have complete details of cost and values of physical resources such as buildings and equipment but relatively scanty data about the man-power which is their most important asset .
Indeed it will be describedMET almost entirely as a liability because the costs will be knownNONMET .
Similarly , broad factors such as the state of morale will again only be describedNONMET by negative features such as absenteeism , stoppages , strikes , low quality output and so on .
It is obvious that company output and projects must reflectMET the man-power and its performance level , but , if this is acknowledgedNONMET at all , it is only in brief verbal terms within , for example , the chairman's annual report .
The obsession , of current management , with measurement and the reduction of every variable to numbers for ease of computer manipulation has worsenedNONMET the situation .
Unfortunately there is no easy remedy .
Human resources are too complex a variable to be easily susceptible to measurement beyond the level of counting heads and trades .
Key variables such as the quality of staff at any level and the current morale are only expressible in general verbal descriptive terms .
It is generally accepted ( p. 145 ) that ‘ hygiene ’ type variables such as pay and working conditions can , if they are inappropriately specifiedNONMET , depressMET morale and motivation but they will not in themselves result in very high levels of these parameters .
