Morale and motivation are influencedNONMET more by conditions of work in the sense of work variety opportunities and attitudes of management .
These factors are worthy of emphasis because in practice they are still dealtMET with very badly in many organisations and yet it takesMET little trouble or expertise to makeMET an enormous difference .
for example , very few senior managements takeMET the trouble to keepMET workers fully informedNONMET about policies and likely changes .
The result is excessive reliance on rumour and continuous speculation which is not only time-consuming but is also highly deleterious in morale terms .
The two human factors which can be unambiguously measuredMET are age and sex .
The age distribution of a work force is always an interesting and important source of information .
For most purposes a rectangular distribution is the most desirable because it providesNONMET the appropriate mix of youthful enthusiasm and ageing experience .
It also makesMET for regular changes as staff retireMET and are replacedMET .
Many distributions showMET a peak in a particular age group mainly associatedNONMET with taking on a large number of young people when the organisation was startedNONMET or reorganisedNONMET , this is not desirable because it leadsMET to excessive competition for promotion at particular stages .
These comments are obviously most relevant for work forces where there is little tendency to moveNONMET out , this is characteristic of a surprisingly large number of organisations in European countries and in Japan but much less so in the U.S.A. Stable work forces have their advantages in terms of familiarity with the enterprise and its peculiar needs but they do resultNONMET in problems if the market for the products is erratic or otherwise unpredictable .
This is particularly so in high technology e.g. design and construction of ships , aircraft , power stations and chemical plant , where the product unit is large and expensive and the variety of required expertise is extensive .
Some peaks of demand can be dealtMET with by usingMET consultants , but they tendNONMET to be expensive and do not always fitMET well with ill-defined but important factors such as the favoured style of the organisation .
In well ordered systems it may be possible to calculateNONMET the length of in-house experience requiredNONMET to achieveNONMET the required level of expertise in particular topics and compareNONMET this with the lead time for particular product requirements .
GivenNONMET time available to trainMET new staff it is not necessary to keepMET more than a nucleus in that particular expertise .
On the other hand , if there is usually insufficient notice of need it may be necessary to keepMET staff who have periods with little to do between projects .
It is also desirable to have the possibility of shiftingMET staff between design and operational duties .
This not only providesNONMET flexibility in the use of man-power , it also improvesNONMET communication .
These real difficulties of man-power utilisation are such as to forceMET many organisations to becomeNONMET larger and larger if they are to remainNONMET economic .
Size providesNONMET a cushion to the vicissitudes of markets but it createsNONMET other problems .
For example , difficulties of communications and in particular , how to inculcateNONMET the feeling within each individual that he and his performance are important to the organisation .
This is consideredNONMET in more detail in Chapter 3 .
Human resources should be fundamental to subjects such as ergonomics which are essentially people- centred but the concept remainsNONMET procedurally undeveloped at any level from a continent through countries , regions and companies down to particular working systems .
This is one reason why policy makers never seemNONMET to takeMET account fully of the people affectedNONMET by their decisions .
The design of procedures The increased importance of standardised informational support for both machines and operators has ledMET to the concept of procedures as a separate design issue within a system ( Fig. 1.30 ) .
Much of this information can be incorporatedNONMET in computer programs but there is also a need for extensive printed paper for the use of the operator .
This takesMET three main forms : checklists , routines and knowledge-texts .
The terminology in this field is not standardised .
Software might be restrictedMET , as in this book , to computer programs but it is sometimes used as the generic term to includeMET all sources of information .
Procedures is sometimes used for what are here calledNONMET routines and sometimes to indicateNONMET all the operator's information support except software .
The situation is further confused when some but not all the operator information support is itself computer- based .
Sometimes the term firm-ware is used .
However whatever the terminology usedNONMET there is a requirement for design effort .
The quality of procedures would be much improved if designers followed some simple guide-lines ( Table 1.16 ) .
Many documents are writtenNONMET on the implicit assumption that the reader is much like the writer in terms of expertise and style of thinking .
Similarly it is assumedMET that the conditions under which the reading will takeMET place are the same as those of writing which are usually a clean well-lit office .
They may have to be readNONMET in the open air , in rain and darkness or within a plant under oily , cramped , poorly litNONMET conditions .
The user probably has limitedNONMET expertise and he may be workingNONMET under various stress conditions .
The material on which the information is printed , the typeface used , the sequence , the structure and the format generally should reflectMET the conditions of use , ( Easterby and Zwaga , 1984 ) .
All these things can be achievedNONMET if it is acknowledged that all procedures should a validated by users under the normal conditions of use .
Checklists Checklists are usedNONMET in the pre-start mode , for routine maintenance and for fault-finding .
They normally takeMET the form of a series of questions or statements which the operator usesNONMET to guideMET and structureNONMET his inspection of the hardware and other system components .
The sequence is dictatedMET by the optimal order in which actions should be takenMET , for example in starting up an aircraft .
There are many situations when the order is of no great consequence , for example a safety audit of a new machine , and in this latter case some logical structure is neededNONMET .
As mentionedMET above , the logic of the design may not be the optimal basis if the way the operator thinksNONMET and acts is different .
Baker ( 1984 ) suggestsNONMET that four kinds of shortcoming emergeMET when checklists are validatedNONMET in the real situation .
The operator may deviateNONMET from the listed procedure because it may requireNONMET excessive moving about or because he is interrupted by the requirements of other tasks .
Systematic use of a checklist often revealsMET faults in work design such as inadequate access , visibility and labelling .
The checklist itself may be inconsistent , incomplete , imprecise or ambiguous .
Finally the checklist may have reprographic limitations such as inadequate vertical or horizontal structure , poor typefaces and insufficient linking of requirements , descriptions , remarks and tick-off points .
The International Ergonomics Association developed a general ergonomics checklist which is reproducedMET in Edholm ( 1967 ) .
There is a deceptive simplicity about such lists which requiresNONMET extensive effort to ensureNONMET a comprehensive but coherent content .
The context is , of course , the context of ergonomics as conceivedMET by the designers of the list .
Routines A routine is the most common form of instructional material .
The reader is requiredNONMET to followMET a series of steps which might , for example , introduceMET a change in the performance of a complex system .
Normally routines are single chains of instructions although it is possible to have some conditional branching .
Each step should be simple and completeNONMET in itself — preferably with some indication that successful completion has been achievedNONMET , for example the appearance or the change of colour of a signal light , or the noise of a motor starting or a change of pressure which indicatesNONMET that there has been a change in the flow of some material .
As mentionedNONMET earlier a routine can often be regardedMET as a written task description .
By definition and design intention routines are inflexible .
The user is intendedNONMET to behaveNONMET exactly according to their instruction .
No great skill or intellectual effort is required , which is one way of sayingMET that the human operator is being under-usedMET , but the purpose of a routine is usually to avoidMET common human error such as omittingNONMET a step or reversingMET steps .
In general the value of formal routines is precisely that the operator , left to himself , will not normally functionNONMET in such a systematic sequential manner .
Knowledge texts Knowledge is containedMET in documents which may varyNONMET from single sheet presentations to large manuals .
As instructional material it is indirect in that the reader is not necessarily told what to do , as in a routine .
Rather he is informedNONMET about the situation and the purpose of informingNONMET him is to provideNONMET a knowledge base from which he can work out his own actions .
Nevertheless , the relevant action remainsNONMET important and the knowledge providedNONMET should be carefully and stringently selected .
It is too easy to followMET the academic tradition and provideNONMET knowledge for its own sake .
The ‘ need to knowNONMET ’ criterion is crucial because unless it is applied , the operator can be overburdenedNONMET with unnecessary material .
Correspondingly the material should be structuredNONMET in terms of how it is most likely to be usedNONMET .
In this context the operator requiresNONMET a guide for action and not a scientific text-book .
It is invariably better to provideNONMET material diagrammatically , systematically or at least in well-structured short paragraphs rather than in flowing prose .
ConsiderMET for example how readily information about the relative position of streets is available from a map of a town centre rather than a verbal description of all the streets .
Such a map will enableNONMET the reader to work out for himself how to get from one location to another within the town .
NoteMET the enormous flexibility comparedNONMET with a routine which would tellMET him only how to getNONMET from one particular point to another .
A second important difference is that if he missesNONMET his place in a routine he will be totally lostMET , whereas if he happensNONMET to goNONMET in the wrong direction while usingNONMET a map he is still able to makeMET whatever correction is necessary .
However the map does requireNONMET more intellectual effort than does the routine not only in makingMET decisions about how to proceedMET but also in filteringMET out the required information from the massive irrelevance ( for a particular task ) which is equally available .
Thus , one would expectNONMET the use of the maps to be slower than the use of routines with the human performance being more versatile but less predictable .
With two-dimensional representations such as maps it remainsNONMET important to avoidMET too much homogeneity and provideNONMET substructure in the form of main roads and key buildings or other features such as rivers .
SeeNONMET , for example , Fig. 5.3 Manuals which may containMET maps , schematic diagrams and other materials warrantMET separate consideration .
The design of manuals A manual is usually in the form of a book or booklet which is sentNONMET with the hardware from the maker to the customer .
It is part of the communication package from the designer to the user .
Thus it is a particular form of job aid which providesNONMET the operator with information on a system and its performance .
The standard of manual design has traditionally been very low for several reasons .
For this purpose , the designer is too familiar with the product and he rarely takesMET the trouble to find out what the user really needsNONMET to knowNONMET .
Often the manual has to be providedNONMET hurriedly at the end of a project when the budget is runningMET out , and it is regardedMET as a tiresome chore still requiredNONMET after the essential design work has been completedNONMET .
The problem is particularly acute for computers .
Manuals for cars , machine tools and so on are poor but at least it is possible to observeNONMET the mechanisms and their functions .
Most computer operators do not knowNONMET or wishNONMET to knowNONMET about the mechanisms , and in any case these are not accessible to vision and manipulation .
The computer operator is entirely dependent on the manual , at least in the early stages of gainingNONMET familiarity with the system and its functions .
He is usually very badly servedMET although the principles of manual design are well knownNONMET .
For most systems the manual is best dividedMET into parts as indicatedNONMET in Table 1.17 .
The first part should be a general introduction which orientatesNONMET the readers towards the system , its purpose , its functional structure and mode of operation and its performance limits .
This should be followedMET by a separate section on how to setMET the system up in the first place and how to checkNONMET that it is workingMET properly .
If it is fairly small it may be necessary to describeNONMET how to unpackNONMET it , fixNONMET it into position , connectNONMET it to power supplies and start it up .
If it is large , the emphasis will be on the start up procedure .
The section describingMET the operation of the system should coverMET not only how the system operates but also how the user can operateNONMET it .
Extensive use of line drawings , schematic diagrams , algorithmic lists is desirable , and where prose is usedNONMET this also should be structuredNONMET into short sentences with meaningful separation into paragraphs .
The maintenance section should indicateNONMET what , if anything , the operator is expected to do and the symptoms which indicateNONMET that more specialist maintenance skills are requiredNONMET .
Tables subdivided into Faults/Reasons/ Remedies can be extremely helpful .
Parts lists including description reference numbers and sometimes drawings are necessary if the user is expected to dealMET with his own replacements .
A standard fault is to assumeMET that the reader is familiar with the jargon which the designer habitually usesNONMET .
A glossary of terms and acronyms usedNONMET can be very helpful not only to the reader but also to the writer who is forcedMET to considerMET carefully how he is usingNONMET various technical terms .
Finally , all manuals should endNONMET with an index which supplementsNONMET the table of contents at the beginning .
The School Framework A Model to Link Personality Characteristics to a Preference for Science John Head Introduction In recent years there has been a steady accumulation of evidence that personality and allied affective factors playMET a crucial role in determining subject choice and student success .
Unfortunately , this evidence has tendedNONMET to be fragmentary , a collection of separate , discrete pieces of information lackingNONMET a synthesizing theory to provideNONMET cohesion and predictive power .
The few models which have been developedNONMET to date may have been correct as far as they goMET but are clearly incomplete .
For example Roe ( 1952 ) , Eiduson ( 1962 ) and McClelland ( 1962 ) suggestedNONMET that male scientists often experienced a lonely childhood , perhaps suffering social isolation through illness or family circumstances , so that they developedNONMET a strong interest in their surrounding material world and a below average interest in other people and relationships .
Maslow ( 1966 ) and Hudson ( 1966 and 1968 ) sawMET science as providingNONMET an emotionally undemanding activity appealingMET to boys movingMET from the calm of latency to the turbulence of adolescence .
Even if these descriptions are valid they still leaveMET open a number of questions , particularly why the same mechanisms do not operateMET with girls .
ArisingMET from the evidence in the literature and from our empirical studies at Chelsea College it is now possible to offerNONMET a model which is compatible with all the evidence and which also has considerable predictive potential .
What we knowNONMET about persons choosingNONMET science The evidence for an association between personality characteristics and an interest in science has been more fully reviewedNONMET by Head ( 1979 ) .
We needNONMET now only takeMET note of the most salient features .
The most obvious one is that of sex differences .
The predominance of males , particularly in the physical sciences and engineering , throughout the Western world can no longer be satisfactorily attributedNONMET to cognitive differences , which are too small , nor to institutional factors .
Equal opportunity in education and employment has not madeMET science any more popular with women .
Furthermore , the characteristics of those students who do optNONMET for science show clear sex differences .
Male scientists , both science students and matureMET , professional scientists , tendNONMET to be emotionally reticent , dislikingNONMET overt emotional expression in others and themselves , and depending upon their partners in personal relationships to takeMET the emotional initiatives .
They will also tendNONMET to be authoritarian , conservative and controlled in their thinking .
These differences can be seenMET quite early on ; we have foundMET boys aged 14 years who were optingNONMET for science to be significantly more authoritarian than their peers .
Girls choosingNONMET science are not particularly emotionally reticent or rigid in their thinking , although they do seemNONMET to have low self-esteem in terms of being socially and sexually attractive .
We also knowNONMET that at about the age of 13 a very high proportion of boys are attractedMET to science and scientific careers .
Thereafter , there is a steady decline of interest in science and this disillusionment extendsMET right through the secondary-school years and into the undergraduate period .
In contrast , only a minority of girls expressMET an interest in science at any age but there is no obvious swing from science in the middle and late teens .
Some further evidence has comeMET from our use of sentence completion tests with secondary-school pupils as part of our research programme at Chelsea .
Analysis of these responses providesNONMET further information on sex differences and between those optingNONMET for different subjects .
For example , girls at the age of 12 and 14 years seemNONMET to takeMET a more mature attitude to personal relationships , seeingMET their complexity and reciprocal nature , while boys are more exploitative .
In relation to the sentence stem ‘ A girl and her mother … ’ , girls often produceMET responses like ‘ often goMET through a bad patch for a year but once they learnNONMET to understandNONMET each other , becomeNONMET the best of friends ’ or ‘ can helpNONMET each other with their problems ’ .
Similar questions , when askedNONMET of boys , tendNONMET to produceMET banal responses or exploitative ones , for example the parent is seenMET as the source of money .
In contrast , boys seemNONMET to have a firmer self-identity and a clearer ambition showingMET more insight in response to sentence stems such as ‘ My main problem is … ’ and ‘ He/she feltMET proud that … ’ .
Such findings giveMET us some clues about the characteristics of boys and girls of these ages .
If we compareNONMET boys of 14 years of age who optNONMET for science with other boys , we findMET that the former have very cut-and-dried views on many issues .
For example , they takeMET the view that ‘ criminals should be severely punishedNONMET ’ or that ‘ anyone who is unpopular deservesNONMET his fate ’ .
To the sentence stem ‘ When a child will not joinMET in group activities … ’ , these boys gaveMET responses likeNONMET ‘ he is selfish ’ , ‘ he must be stupid ’ , ‘ he deservesNONMET to be unpopular ’ .
In contrast , other boys and most girls ponderedNONMET the possible causes and ways of integratingNONMET the child into the group .
The science boys seemedNONMET to possessMET few doubts or uncertainties , they offeredNONMET clear-cut answers .
It was this evidence which suggestedMET the possible model for subject choice in terms of ego-identity achievement .
Ego-identity in adolescence This model was originally postulatedNONMET by Erikson ( 1965 ) and then developedNONMET by Marcia ( 1966 and 1976 ) .
Erikson suggestsMET that at different phases of life an individual facesMET a particular psycho-social problem which needsNONMET to be resolvedNONMET before movingMET on to the next phase .
For adolescents the acquisition of a clear ego-identity is the crucial task .
At the beginning of adolescence , the individual is a dependent within the family and the school .
By the end of adolescence he [ or she ] needsNONMET to makeMET choices about career , life-style , personal relationships and ideologies .
The ego-identity of that person is shapedMET by these choices .
Erikson does not suggestNONMET that the development of an ego-identity is a once-and-for-all issue .
Some problems about identity ariseMET with the young child in the context of home and school , and others occurNONMET in later life , for example on retirement .
Nevertheless , adolescence is the time when ego-identity development inevitably dominatesMET the personal development of the individual for a while .
The adolescent does not , however , need to achieveNONMET a clear ego-identity on all topics at one time .
He [ or she ] may have a clear identity in respect to his [ or her ] career but still be unresolved in regard to personal relationships and ideology .
In this article we are concerned with ego-identity achievement in respect to careerNONMET .
Marcia has putMET more detail onto the Erikson model and suggestsNONMET that in goingMET from the initial ego- diffusion condition to that of having achievedNONMET ego-identity , two processes are involvedNONMET : crisis and commitment .
Crisis in this context describesMET a period of intensive self-examination in which one's beliefs and values are re-examinedNONMET .
Commitment meansMET that the individual has acquiredMET clear and firm beliefs both about himself [ or herself ] and the world .
Figure 16.1 indicatesMET a number of possible routes to ego-identity achievements .
A person may undergoNONMET crisis and commitment simultaneously and progress by route A. An alternative is to undergoNONMET a period of considerable self-doubt and self-examination in which all one's beliefs tendNONMET to be very fluid , a period knownNONMET as moratorium , before acquiringMET beliefs for oneself and ego-identity is achievedNONMET ( route B ) .
A further possibility is that the individual may , at least for a time , hold onto beliefs and values takenMET without question from others , for example parents , teachers , peers .
This condition is knownNONMET as foreclosure .
Eventually these persons might have to face up to period of crisis , of self-examination , and so achieveNONMET ego-identity by route C. However , foreclosure does offerMET an escape route and an individual might postponeNONMET indefinitely any real self-examination by clingingMET rigidly to his [ or her ] beliefs and values ( route D ) .
Ego-identity and Choosing Science We can now makeMET the link between this model of adolescent development and subject choice in schools .
For boys at the foreclosure stage , science is likely to be appealing .
The physical sciences in particular , offerMET a conventional career choice which is likely to winMET approval from parents , teachers and peers .
They will tendNONMET to regardMET the overt expression of emotions , includingNONMET much such expression in the arts , as being soft and feminine .
Science , with its masculine image , makesMET little emotional demand on an individual and seemsNONMET to offerMET clear , precise answers to problems .
OptingNONMET for science will permitMET and possibly reinforceMET emotional reticence .
For a girl at the foreclosure stage the situation is very different .
There is evidence that girls tendNONMET to be socializedNONMET into adult roles more through their potential of becomingNONMET a mother and housewife than through their career ( Douvan and Adelson , 1966 ) .
Furthermore , these girls will tendNONMET to goMET into a career with a feminine image , one which already attractsMET many girls .
Consequently , very few girls at the foreclosure stage will enterMET science unless they receiveNONMET considerable encouragement and a model to do so from their parents and their school .
Neither boys nor girls at the moratorium stage are likely to be attractedMET to the science that is usually presentedMET in our schools .
They are at a stage when they are likely to be concerned with a variety of complex issues ; the meaning of life , the existence of God , ideologies , their emerging sexuality , their future career and life-style — too often science is seenMET as being purely instrumental with nothing to contributeMET to these debates .
Science , somehow , seemsNONMET to be scarcely relevant to the most important issues in our life .
A proportion of both boys and girls at ego-identity achievement stage will chooseMET science .
In fact , most girls enteringMET science are probably at this stage as they will needNONMET some self-examination and sense of commitment to makeMET this unconventional choice .
However , only a minority of adolescents will have reachedMET the ego-identity achievement stage at the age when most pupils have to makeMET crucial decisions about subject choice at school .
This model seemsNONMET to explainMET our observations .
A large number of boys , particularly at the foreclosure stage , are initially attractedMET to science but there is a drift away throughout later adolescence as they undergoNONMET some crisis .
The preponderance of boys at the foreclosure stage will yieldMET the rigid , authoritarian attitudes often associatedNONMET with scientists .
The few girls who enterMET science will not usually showNONMET these foreclosure characteristics .
Effects of Curriculum Changes The real use of this model linkingMET personality development to subject choice is that it allowsMET us to makeMET predictions about how pupils might reactMET to changes in school science curriculum and school organization .
We can considerMET three possible changes : 1 Delaying subject choice : Britain is unusual in askingNONMET pupils to makeMET crucial choices about subject options in the 13–16 age range .
These decisions can only be reversedMET with great difficulty .
What effect would delaying the choice makeMET ?
In the development through the years of adolescence the number of foreclosure pupils will diminishNONMET , hence the recruitment of boys into science would be cutMET .
More boys and girls will have reachedMET the ego-identity achievement stage and a proportion of these will goMET into science .
Overall there would be a reduction in the number of students choosingNONMET science , but those who do so chooseNONMET will be more likely to stayMET happily in the subject and to possessNONMET more flexible minds .
The quantitative loss would be metMET by a qualitative improvement .
2 GivingMET science a more feminine image : It is sometimes arguedNONMET that science textbooks are sexist in showingMET illustrations of boys , rather than girls , doing practical work in the laboratory , and so forth .
What effect would a deliberate attempt to changeMET this image have ?
It might makeMET it easier for girls at the foreclosure stage to acceptNONMET science so recruitment might increaseNONMET .
Some of these girls might , however , driftMET away again when they reachMET their crisis period .
Unless the change in image was immense , boys would probably not be affectedNONMET , science would still be an obvious , acceptable choice for a boy .
Overall there would be some increase in the recruitment of girls , but no qualitative improvement .
3 EmphasizingMET the applications and relevance of science : To obtainNONMET a major qualitative improvement to recruitment in science with more girls and with students possessingMET imaginative , flexible minds it would be necessary to makeMET science appealing to boys and girls at the moratorium stage .
In that event science must be seenMET to be relevant to the issues which concernNONMET them .
The probable implication is that science would needNONMET to be presentedMET in the context of the needs of society and individuals .
Probably a case-study approach involvingNONMET the application of science , and the interaction with other disciplines , would be neededNONMET .
Our knowledge about the girls ' concern with personal relationships suggestsMET that the  introduction of some elements of the social sciences into the case studies might proveNONMET attractive .
Is it possible to changeMET school science in this fashion and still preserveMET the essential character of science itself ?
Clearly there would needNONMET to be some drastic pruning of content .
Perhaps science teachers should not attemptNONMET to coverMET their subjects so comprehensively .
A history teacher is content to coverMET the history of one country or continent over a few decades .
Perhaps we must makeMET similar choices .
It is interesting to noticeNONMET that the Association for Science Education ( 1979 ) policy statement in Britain and the proposals on school physics comingMET from the Institute for Science Education ( IPN ) in Kiel are advocatingMET such changes .
The difference is that we are now offeringNONMET a formal psychological model to suggestNONMET that if we wantNONMET to reduceMET the current encapsulation of science , if we wantNONMET to recruitMET a different sort of student , then certain curriculum changes are neededNONMET .
Girl Friendly Science and the Girl Friendly School Judith Whyte Approximately three times as many boys as girls takeMET O level physics and approximately four times as many takeMET CSE physics .
Over 90 per cent of entries in all technical subjects are from boys .
This meansMET that schoolgirls are ineligible for a wide range of courses in further and higher education and for entry to occupations requiringNONMET a scientific or technical base .
Female exclusion from science and technology , even if it is apparently by girls ' own choice , also meansMET that as citizens their ability to understandNONMET and controlMET their environment is limited .
Nevertheless , most schools considerMET they are already providingNONMET equal opportunities by neutral treatment  of the two sexes ( Bloomfield , 1984 ) .
In effect , ignoringNONMET the effects of gender in this way merely reinforcesMET stereotyping because it does nothing to challengeMET the definition of certain aspects of the curriculum as masculine or feminine .
Girls  Into Science and Technology ( GIST ) was the first major schools-based project addressingMET problems of sex stereotyping at school , and was an example of ‘ action research ’ in education ; the project simultaneously tookMET action to improveNONMET girls ' achievement in science and technology and investigatedMET the reasons for their under-achievement .
The project team collaboratedMET with teachers in eight co-educational comprehensive schools in the Greater Manchester area to deviseNONMET and implementNONMET intervention strategies designedMET to improveNONMET girls ' attitudes to the physical sciences and technical subjects .
Two other schools were involvedNONMET as controlsMET where attitude testing but no interventions tookMET place .
[ … ] The approach was collaborative : teachers were invitedNONMET to workNONMET with the team as equal partners in the attempts both to investigateNONMET and findMET solutions to the GIST problem .
However , very few of the teachers even recognized the issue as one of professional concern at the start of the project , and most of the first two years was spentMET in establishingNONMET the educational importance of the issue and workingNONMET towards the  development of feasible intervention strategies .
The project and its outcomes have been fully describedNONMET elsewhere ( Smail et al .
, 1982 ; Kelly , Whyte and Smail , 1984 ; Whyte in press ) .
GIST had more success in alteringNONMET children's attitudes than their subject choices , suggestingNONMET that it is easier to changeMET attitudes and beliefs than actual behaviour .
Pupils in action schools becameNONMET markedly less stereotyped than pupils in control schools .
They also had slightly more positive attitudes towards science and scientists and were less likely to defineMET them as exclusively masculine .
Despite some evidence of change in teachers ' attitudes and behaviour , they themselves were reluctant to admitMET that the project had influencedNONMET them .
According to an evaluation report this may reflectMET an unwillingness to admitMET that in the past schools have been sex biased ( Payne , Cuff and Hustler , 1984 ) .
The GIST hypothesis was that female under-achievement in science and technology is at least partly socially constructedMET by the school , an hypothesis basedMET on research evidence as well as critical feminist analysis ( seeMET , for example , Kelly , 1981 ) .
During the project there was a shift away from locatingMET the issue as one of girls ' motivation towards attempts to changeMET the nature of school science .
One of the main gains from the GIST project has been the clarification of what is meantMET by a ‘ girl friendly ’ , science , that is a science which will appealMET equally to the interests and concerns of girls as well as boys .
[ … ] MakingMET Science More Girl Friendly Several interventions were designedMET to makeMET science more girl friendly .
Schools and teachers triedMET curriculum development to buildMET on girls ' science interests , changing patterns of classroom interaction , single sex groups and classes .
The largest scale intervention was the VISTA programme , which consistedNONMET of women scientists and technologists visiting schools to talkNONMET to children about an aspect of their jobs already being coveredMET in the school science syllabus .
VISTA madeMET science more girl friendly in two ways : both boys and girls were offeredNONMET an attractive image of a competent woman scientist , and talks concentrated on social and industrial applications of science , an element too often missing from science at school .
One school was so impressed by the children's positive reactions that they completely revamped the science work in the first two years to includeMET more social and human applications of science .
The survey of children's attitudes helped here : research such as Ormerod's ( 1971 ; Ormerod and Duckworth , 1975 ) had shownMET that girls were interested in the social implications of science , but did not tellNONMET teachers what the desirable teaching approach might be in practice .
Would science in the home be a starter ?
A question from our survey askedMET children whether they would likeNONMET to knowNONMET more about how a vacuum cleaner works ; hardly anyone did , and girls were even less curious than boys .
This toldMET us that any simplistic assumptions about featuringNONMET ‘ female ’ domestic interests in science would probably meetMET with failure .
The rest of the questionnaire about science curiosity showedMET that all the children were enthusiastic about learning science , and that girls were keen to knowNONMET more about nature , the environment and medical science .
Over 50 per cent , and in some cases over 60 per cent saidNONMET they would likeNONMET to learnNONMET about the human heart , germs and illnesses , how our muscles work , what food is good for you , life in the sea , what makesMET a rainbow appearNONMET and how a record is madeNONMET .
It was helpful that these topics also interested boys .
At present the science curriculum is structuredMET around physical science interests , on which boys are keener ( how motor cars work , atoms and molecules ) ; we were able to recommendNONMET that teaching build on the overlapping interests of the two sexes , because girls as well as boys wantNONMET to knowNONMET more about human biology and spectacular features of the environment ( animals in the jungle , volcanoes and earthquakes , acids and chemicals ) .
The less immediately attractive parts of science could be approachedMET through these interests , for instance teaching ‘ forces ’ by beginningNONMET with the action of muscles in the human arm , and ‘ light ’ via the dissection of a bull's eye .
When women scientists employNONMET such approaches , and describeNONMET their own work , as happenedNONMET during the VISTA programme , girls are receivingNONMET double encouragement .
These examples indicateMET some of the features of girl friendly science : it buildsMET on girls ' interests , not just boys ' ; it explicitly encouragesMET girls to seeMET themselves as potential scientists , and it includesMET some of the social and human implications and applications of science .
Other GIST Interventions All the GIST schools were mixed comprehensives , and at first teachers were most unwilling to separateNONMET boys and girls at all , on the grounds that it ranMET counter to their co-educational comprehensive philosophy .
Then certain teachers were particularly struckMET by the evidence of large differences in the interests and experience children broughtMET with them to school .
Girls had far less ‘ tinkering ’ experience than boys and the connection with their lesser interest in topics like ‘ how electricity is producedNONMET ’ seemedNONMET obvious .
Several special science or craft clubs were organizedNONMET in the lunch hour for girls only and in two schools teachers planned single-sex teaching .
As we shall seeMET , it was in these two schools that the largest measurable changes of attitude and option choice occurredNONMET .
For a more girl friendly science , it seemsNONMET vital that teachers should comeMET to seeMET that when all the masculine packaging , evident in textbooks and resources as well as teachers ' and boys ' behaviour in the classroom , is removedMET , girls can be very enthusiastic about science .
[ … ] Alison Kelly seesMET at least four distinct senses in which it can be arguedNONMET that science is masculine .
First , the pupils , teachers and practitioners of science are overwhelmingly male in terms of numbers ; second , school science is packagedMET and presented to appealMET to boys , not girls ; third , classroom behaviours and interaction operateMET to reconstructMET science as a male activity , and finally it has been suggestedNONMET that ‘ scientific ’ thinking embodiesNONMET an intrinsically masculine world view .
The GIST interventions describedNONMET above relateNONMET to three of these : VISTA women , albeit briefly and temporarily , redressedNONMET the numerical balance by offeringNONMET female role models of practising scientists ; VISTA and the curriculum development which followedMET involved a limited ‘ repackaging ’ of science to removeMET its exclusively masculine appeal , and the single-sex classes and classroom observation showedMET how science comesMET to be definedMET as ‘ masculine ’ in the mixed school .
The fourth point , the idea that science is intrinsically masculine , can be sustainedMET only by clinging to an irredeemably narrow conception of science and scientific thinking .
The industrial and social impact of science on health , on people , on the environment , a focus on the beauty and complexity of the natural world , are notable omissions from the school science syllabus .
Girls are not uninterested in science , they are bored by the limited version of it they meetMET in school .
One of the purposes of an extended period of single-sex science teaching might be to letNONMET teachers seeMET how girls approach scientific matters , and to discoverMET , what may well be the case , that girls are just as capable of ‘ scientific thinking ’ as boys .
Margaret Spear , in a different study from the one reported in this volume , foundMET that for identical work boys were markedNONMET higher than girls for supposed understanding of principles , aptitude for science and O level suitability ( Spear , 1984 ) .
AttemptingNONMET to integrateNONMET under fives Policy in Islington , 1983–8 Margaret Boushel , Clare Debenham , Lisa Dresner and Anna Gorbach During the 1980s Margaret Boushel , Claire Debenham , Lisa Dresner and Anna Gorbach workedNONMET in the London borough of Islington within social services for pre-school children .
This chapter is an account of the way they perceivedMET attempts to  developNONMET integrated provision for under fives and the barriers in attitudes and systems which were encounteredMET .
The first section providesMET an overview of provision and services in 1983 .
The next section describesMET attempts to createNONMET a clear under policy .
The third section looksMET at the faltering progress towards integrated services .
The fourth section examinesMET the formidable barriers that were posedNONMET by reorganisation of social services , local authority cuts and the demise of the Inner London Education Authority .
The chapter concludesMET with a mixture of resignation and determination .
BACKGROUND : UNDER- SERVICES IN ISLINGTON , 1983 Islington is a multi-ethnic , inner city London borough with a child population of 29,000 .
In 1982 , 44 per cent of under fives in Islington had the use of an under facility , 29 per cent on a full-time and 15 per cent on a part-time basis .
Between 1982 and 1988 provision gradually increasedNONMET , so that by 1988 there were 12 children's day centres , about 70 playgroups and 350 assisted child-minding places fundedNONMET partially or totally by the Social Services Department , and 1,075 full-time and 824 part-time places in nursery schools fundedNONMET by the Inner London Education Authority .
The Beacon Nursery , a local Mencap project , offered care five days per week to children over one year of age categorised as having severe learning difficulties .
Unlike council day centres , playgroups or community nurseries , the Beacon Nursery was free .
Children were collectedNONMET from home by special bus and places were available on demand .
The Beacon had been in existence for many years and in the past had cateredNONMET for up to thirty children with a wide range of disabilities and needs .
By 1983 it had half that number on roll .
Since 1983 numbers at the Beacon continuedNONMET to fallMET as it was increasingly seenMET as a resource for children with severe and multiple disabilities .
In addition the Elfreda Rathbone organisation , a voluntary organisation helping people with learning disabilities , ranMET a free day nursery in the borough for a small number of children with learning difficulties .
Some integrated services emergedMET in the early 1980s — one playscheme was  developedNONMET through a parent's initiative , and an integrated adventure playground was establishedNONMET by a voluntary organisation .
Workers from the integrated playscheme subsequently supported a local special school in integratingNONMET under fives into a playgroup .
In addition to its mainstream schools , the borough includedNONMET five special schools providingNONMET primary and secondary education to children with special needs from Islington and neighbouring boroughs — one for children with moderate learning difficulties , one for children with severe learning difficulties , one for children with emotional and behavioural difficulties , one for autistic children , and one for children with physical disabilities .
In 1983 three of these offered nursery places to children from the age of 2 .
The children usingNONMET all of these services cameNONMET from a wide range of ethnic backgrounds , though rarely was this actively and positively reflectedMET in the type of care providedNONMET or the ethnic background of their carers .
Residential units By 1983 residential services were designedMET with ‘ care in the community ’ in mind , but most were basedNONMET in specialist settings .
For example , Field End House had been open for three years as a specialist unit for children with learning difficulties , and was designedMET to offerNONMET respite ‘ round the clock ’ care .
Parents had foughtMET for this as a local resource to preventNONMET the need for children to be placedNONMET in long-stay placements far from home .
By 1988 Field End had been joinedNONMET by another specialist children's respite care unit at Leigh Road .
The Social Services Department also provided thirteen short-term and long-term residential units for children in care ( by 1988 their number had been reducedMET to eleven ) , none with wheelchair access and only one with any experience of caring for children with learning difficulties .
The Community Health Team The Community Health Team had major responsibility for assessingNONMET children and recommendingNONMET provision .
It includedNONMET physiotherapists , occupational and speech therapists , doctors , psychologists and a specialist health visitor .
They were joinedNONMET in the network by specialist teachers , fundedNONMET by the ILEA and basedNONMET in the special schools , who visitedNONMET children at home before they were due to startNONMET school .
This group of people met on a regular basis to coordinateMET services and discussNONMET professional issues .
Discussion of services to individual children also tookMET place .
This includedNONMET decidingNONMET between day care or school , and parents ' attitudes to different options .
Often a member of the group was delegatedNONMET to adviseNONMET parents on a course of action .
The Community Health Team aim was to ensureNONMET a place of treatment for children from the earliest possible age , to enableNONMET them to developNONMET to their fullest potential .
They were , however , an all-White group , operatingMET without directly involvingNONMET parents and were generally committedNONMET to specialist care in the community .
They gaveMET support to the Beacon and Elfreda Rathbone nurseries and most members sawMET these settings as the best places to ‘ treatNONMET ’ children .
Because of their early contact with parents they often had considerable influence in steering parents towards specialist provision .
The Special Services Team In the early 1980s social workers were fundedNONMET jointly by the ILEA and Islington Social Services Department to workNONMET with children attendingNONMET two special schools and two specialist units for ‘ partially hearingNONMET ’ children .
These social workers were basedNONMET in the borough's Special Services Team .
They all workedNONMET with some under fives attendingNONMET the schools they coveredMET .
They were aware of a number of pre-school children who did not have adequate access to resources or support when parents and professionals were becomingNONMET aware of the possible extent and implications of the disability .
When a vacancy aroseMET within this group of social workers in 1983 it was decidedNONMET to appointNONMET someone specialisingNONMET in work with under fives with special needs .
This might have had the effect of drawing families into the specialist system at an earlier stage .
Instead , for a number of reasons , it provedNONMET to be a key step in the development of the debate about integration in Islington .
First , the post was not attachedMET to any specialist institution .
There was an expectation but not a contractual obligation that the postholder would workNONMET closely with the Beacon Nursery .
Second , the worker had an alternative peer group of under workers who were key figures in controlling access to all other under- facilities .
Third , the worker was committedNONMET to the idea that treatment of a medical or disabling condition should not takeMET precedence over the child's social , emotional and cultural needs .
There was now a new worker in the network who also madeMET an early relationship with families but who could presentNONMET a broader choice of day care to parents .
ATTEMPTINGNONMET AN INTEGRATION POLICY The Labour Council , electedNONMET in 1982 , had as a stated policy aim that every child whose parents so wishedNONMET was entitled to a pre-school place of some sort .
This ledMET to the initiation of an under- review .
The review team , setMET up under the auspices of the Social Services Committee , includedNONMET councillors , senior departmental management and representatives of the children's day centre organisers and under social workers in its membership .
It proposedNONMET a network of under- centres throughout the borough — an idea which the under- workers had been anxious to promoteNONMET for some time .
Day care in each area would be organisedNONMET and coordinated through the children's day centres which would also provideNONMET information , support and resources to parents .
The review had madeMET no mention of children with special needs .
The specialist social worker and another under- worker with a personal interest in the issues undertookNONMET a supplementary review to examineNONMET resources for these children .
They interviewedNONMET parents , specialist professionals and mainstream day-care workers and they designedMET a questionnaire which was completedNONMET by workers in a large proportion of mainstream council services and voluntary organisations , as well as by some child-minders .
Broadly , the survey confirmedMET that parents of children with special needs had not been givenMET a real choice of placement , and that they had to fightMET hard for mainstream provision if this was their choice .
Parents wanted to be part of the decision-making and did not feelMET that they were .
Many commented on lack of information about the range of facilities on offer .
One Afro-Caribbean woman described how she feltMET that she was never givenMET a choice of provision for her son , and objected to being toldNONMET he should be in a specialist nursery for his own good .
She foughtMET hard to getMET him a part-time playgroup place in the group his older brother attended .
Because the group had knownNONMET her and her children for some time they agreedNONMET to ‘ have a go ’ and the placement wentMET ahead .
She commentedNONMET : I had to fightMET every step of the way for this .
No one toldNONMET me about it , and no one wantedNONMET him to have it .
I knewNONMET it was right for him — this is where he learntNONMET to join in and be like other children .
It doesn't matterNONMET that he's not like them .
I knowNONMET what is right for my child , but I'm not supposed to sayNONMET .
Parents also wanted an increased availability of specialist ‘ therapy ’ time , but wantedNONMET it to be usedNONMET in a more flexible way .
Some parents were very worried that more integrated settings would leadMET to lack of attention for children with special needs .
Definitions of ‘ special needs ’ varied widely in the questionnaire responses — some definingNONMET it as children with disabilities , some including children with behavioural and emotional problems and some including children whose first language was not English .
This madeMET the survey difficult to interpretNONMET .
The findings were documentedNONMET in a report A Place For All Our Children ( CCUF 1983 ) and an analysis was preparedNONMET of the practical and bureaucratic problems in gainingNONMET an ordinary childcare place for a child with special needs , with suggestions for how these might be overcomeNONMET .
These ideas were informedMET by a paper which had already been producedMET by an active member of the local Mencap group , who had previously triedNONMET to generateMET the debate within the Community Health Service through the Mencap committee .
The conference : ‘ A place for all our children' As a result of this work the Coordinating Committee for Under Fives ( CCUF ) , an umbrella organisation of statutory and voluntary sector groups and individuals providingNONMET a service to under fives , decided to organiseNONMET a conference to lookMET at the issues of integration of special needsNONMET children within mainstream provision .
Prior to the conference various groups met to produceMET short contributions to the debate .
These includedNONMET parents , under- workers , specialist workers , children's day centre organisers and playgroups organisers .
Each of these groups cameMET up with a list of proposals which were sentNONMET to everyone attendingNONMET .
About 230 people attendedNONMET the conference , held in April 1985 .
Workshops facilitatedNONMET by the speakers and the conference organisingNONMET group examined integration policies , overcomingNONMET practical problems for children in integrated provision and available sources of information .
The conference madeMET the following recommendations : 1 For a formal , universal information system , coveringMET local and specialist resources .
2 For children's needs to be consideredMET with parents and their wishes acknowledged and recognised .
3 For employment of extra staff where neededNONMET , and employment of peripatetic special needsNONMET workers .
4 For availability of money for equipment , toys and adaptations .
5 For enhanced payments to child-minders caringNONMET for children with special needs .
6 For priority status for children with special needs in order to facilitateNONMET access to ordinary provision .
7 For training facilities for staff in ordinary provision , specialist provision and child-minders .
8 For greater communication and sharing of resources between ordinary and specialist provision .
9 For therapeutic and professional staff to reflectMET the cultural backgrounds of the children , and that for all children , including those with special needs , their day-care environment and activities to expressMET a consciousness of the multicultural society in Islington .
It was madeMET clear that all of the above areas needed fundingNONMET from health , education and social services before they could be implementedNONMET .
Finally , it was feltMET that unless the attitudes of advisers and information-givers becameNONMET more positive towards integration , none of the recommendations could be effective .
II THE FIRST CRITIQUE Unity had been easy during the Resistance , because relationships were almost always man-to-man .
Over against the German army or the Vichy government , where social generality ruled , as it does in all machines of state , the Resistance offeredMET the rare phenomenon of historical action which remained personal .
The psychological and moral elements of political action were almost the only ones to appearMET here , which is why intellectuals least inclined to politics were to be seenMET in the Resistance .
The Resistance was a unique experience for them , and they wantedNONMET to preserveMET its experience in the new French politics because this experience brokeMET away from the famous dilemma of being and doing , which confrontsMET all intellectuals in the face of action … .
It is only too obvious that this balance between action and personal life was intimately bound up with the conditions of clandestine action and could not surviveMET it .
And in this sense it must be saidMET that the Resistance experience , by makingMET us believeNONMET that politics is a relationship between man and man or between consciousnesses , fosteredMET our illusions of 1939 and masked the truth of the incredible power of history which the Occupation taughtMET us in another connection .
If by 1945 Merleau-ponty had here already indicated the historical basis for what was to becomeNONMET Sartre's project in the Critique , the theoretical problem that followedMET was how to uniteMET orthodox Marxist concepts of economic determinism and historical necessity with the individualism of Sartre's earlier work , that is the existentialist notion of the authentic self and the possibility of choosingNONMET one's own freedom : how to relocateMET human practice within historical determinism , to reconcileMET the individual with the social , the idea of agency with that of necessity , or freedom with history ?
For Marxist or Hegelian thought , such an age-old contradiction ought to be resolvable through the operations of dialectical logic .
CitingNONMET Marx's famous remark in The Eighteenth Brumaire , ‘ Men makeMET their own History … but under circumstances … given and transmitted from the past ’ , Sartre suggestedNONMET that this impliedNONMET ‘ the permanent and dialectical unity of freedom and necessity , ( I , 35 ) .
Accordingly , he attemptedNONMET to shiftMET Marxism away from orthodox theories of an absolute determinism towards the primacy of a concept of ‘ History ’ which , while still a totality as it had been for Lukács , a process with a determinate meaning and end , could also includeMET a concept of human agency and thus articulateMET the individual with the social , freedom with determinism .
Today , Sartre's voluntarism is to some extent returningMET to favourNONMET as the result of a desire to retrieveMET the categories of agency and the subject , which goesMET together with the wish to getMET out of the apparently totalizing systems of Adorno , Althusser or Foucault .
Sartre's stress on the role of the subject also findsMET approval because many of those no longer preparedMET to argueNONMET for a general theory of history as the progress of a single narrative of class- struggle , have begunNONMET to argueNONMET instead for a return of its correlative , the subject , almost as if it was the next best thing in the absence of history itself .
But it still leavesMET us with the crucial problem that Sartre had to solveNONMET , namely how to linkMET human consciousness with the processes of history so that the former can be saidNONMET to be the agent of the latter .
How could this takeMET place ?
As Sartre had putMET it in What is Literature ?
: ‘ Never has homo faber better understood that he has madeMET history and never has he feltMET so powerless before history ’ .
How can man make history if at the same time it is history which makesMET him ?
Sartre consideredMET that orthodox dialectical materialism takesMET the easy way out by merely eliminatingMET the first in favour of the second , makingMET man a passive product entirely determinedNONMET by economic circumstances .
Unwilling to followMET Merleau-Ponty by droppingMET the second in favour of the first , Sartre arguedNONMET that it was possible for man to be both at once through the movement of praxis , that is intentional actions which produceMET material effects .
Its corollary , whereby praxis becomesNONMET determining history , he calledNONMET the ‘ practico- inert ’ , by which he meantNONMET the material circumstances that have themselves been createdNONMET by previous praxes and which form the conditions for new praxis .
The individual is thus both totalizer and totalizedNONMET , deftly uniting freedom with necessity .
Though this neatly solvesMET the problem of how man can makeMET history while at the same time history makesMET him , it does not answerMET the larger question of how a multiplicity of the products of individual acts , ‘ totalizations ’ , can themselves be totalizedNONMET into the overall totalization requiredNONMET by the logic of dialectical rationality — rather than being the arbitrary , blind and self-cancelling movements of , sayMET , Hardy's immanent will .
Sartre's fundamental thesis , that ‘ History continually effects totalisations of totalisations ’ ( I , 15 ) , does not in itself answerMET what Ronald Aronson has rightly characterizedNONMET as the question for Sartre : ‘ how do separateMET , antagonistic actions yieldMET a history ; how do individual totalizations leadMET to Totalization ( and also progress , the direction of history , its truth and its meaning ) ?
’ For the whole basis of Sartre's argument is that the dialectic of history is not a metaphysical law , ‘ some powerful unitary force revealingMET itself behind History like the will of God ’ , but the continuously producedMET effect of individual conflicts ; each action is in its turn subsumed as a part of the whole in an ever broader , developing totalization ( I , 37 ) .
What Sartre needsNONMET to demonstrateNONMET , therefore , is that if the law of the dialectic worksMET from the individual level , overall it producesMET nothing less than the intelligibility or the meaning of History as such : The dialectic is the law of totalization which createsNONMET several collectivities , several societies , and one history — realities , that is , which imposeMET themselves on individuals ; but at the same time it must be wovenMET out of millions of individual actions .
We must showMET that it is possible for it to be both a resultant … and a totalizing force … how it can continually bring about the unity of dispersive profusion and integration .
( I , 36 ) But what producesMET the overall direction of History ?
How does it ‘ continually bring about the unity of dispersive profusion and integration ’ ?
Sartre does not attemptNONMET to answerNONMET this question , shiftingMET rather to the notion of a lack of self-consciousness .
The dialectic is the law that remainsNONMET hidden .
At the moment , ‘ history is madeMET without being knownNONMET ( l'histoire se fait sans se connâitre ) ’ — history constitutesNONMET , we might sayNONMET today , a political unconscious .
‘ Marxism ’ , on the other hand , Sartre claims , ‘ is History itself becomingNONMET conscious of itself ’ ( I , 40 ) : as for Lukács , it is by becomingNONMET conscious of itself as the subject of history that the working class will understandMET history's meaning — and so recognizeMET itself as the meaning of history .
While he suggestsMET in apocalyptic tones in The Problem of Method that this process of self-consciousness is at last beginningNONMET to takeMET place , and that civil , foreign and colonial wars are becomingNONMET apparent as different forms of a single class struggle , Sartre also admitsMET that the divorce between theory and praxis which ensuedNONMET under Stalinism has generally preventedNONMET any clear self-consciousness among the masses .
The ‘ detour , of Stalinism is thus formalizedNONMET as Marxism's own descent into its unconscious , resultingNONMET in a dream-work of heterogeneous histories that have eludedMET systematization and subsumption into the single meaning of Marxism's own reading of history .
It is therefore , Sartre arguesNONMET , our historical task to makeMET it known , promotingNONMET not just the historical process as such , but also the general recognition whereby the plurality of the meanings of individual histories can be seenMET to combineMET to makeMET one history , with one meaning — the ‘ Truth of humanity ’ ( I , 822 ) .
Sartre's account thus setsMET up the articulation of history , univocal meaning , and totality as the indissoluble set of elements requiredNONMET for the validation of Marxism , necessary in order to saveMET it from its detour from itself .
The problem , however , remainsMET how such universals are producedMET from the multiplicity of initiatingMET individual praxes .
If History is a history of conflict , how could it be both one and internally diversifiedNONMET without the inner moving principle of the dialectic ?
How can History be a unity if it is also conflictual , if each action is aimedMET at destroyingMET the other and results in a double negation in which the original aims of each action have been destroyedMET by the other ?
If each action negatesNONMET the aim of the other , where is the ‘ unity ’ totalizedNONMET in the conflict ?
How does History constantly totalizeNONMET itself ?
( I , 817 — 18 ) Sartre arrivesMET at what he callsNONMET ‘ the real problem of History ’ , that is how there can be totalization without a totalizer , only at the very end of Volume I. It is not until the next volume , however , that he intendsNONMET to showMET how individual actions , separate multiplicities , makeMET up ‘ one human history , with one truth and one intelligibility ’ ( I , 69 ) .
Throughout , Sartre has nevertheless takenMET it ‘ for grantedNONMET that such a totalisation is constantly developingNONMET both as History and as historical Truth ’ ( I , 822 ) .
His History , therefore , is always in process : but its teleology of a final totalization always has to be assumedMET .
He thus assertsNONMET the Truth of History while constantly projecting forwards and deferringNONMET its proof .
But when the proof comesMET it also turnsMET out to restMET on the assumption that it is already true .
III THE SECOND CRITIQUE : ‘ We are tryingNONMET to establishNONMET the Truth of History' Sartre producesMET a persuasive formulation of the relation of the individual to the determining historical circumstance through his concepts of praxis and the practico- inert ; it is also obvious to him how the larger question of History ought to be solvedNONMET .
He assertsNONMET it often enough : ‘ History continually effects totalisations of totalisations , ( I , 15 ) .
But in Volume I of the Critique , as we have seenMET , he continually defersNONMET the demonstration of his proof .
For the ‘ dogmatic dialectic ’ , as he describesNONMET dialectical materialism , the whole question naturally poses no problem , for each person or group simply constitutes a partial moment of an already operative movement of totalization that producesMET them and then goesMET beyond them .
But Sartre's dispensing with all historicist schemas createsNONMET the problem of how , between two autonomous and contradictory totalizations , there could be ‘ one dialectical intelligibility of the ongoing process ’ ( II , 13 ) .
He attemptsNONMET to solveNONMET this through matchingMET his account of contradiction with a new concept derivedMET from the conjunction of work and labour : ‘ anti-labour ’ ( anti-travail ) , a category of negation .
The products of a conflict , as well as its residues , may seemNONMET incomprehensible insofar as they differNONMET from the original intentions of any of the combatants .
Nevertheless they constituteNONMET the basis and conditions for further actions and history .
Dialectical reason encountersMET such products as undecidablesNONMET : aporias — because they seemNONMET to be at once the results of a communal enterprise while at the same time bearingMET witness to the fact that this enterprise never existed except as the inhuman reverse side of two opposed actions in which each aimsMET to destroyMET the other .
In the dialectical perspective , we encounterMET these objects as productions which are human and providedNONMET with a future … thus they seemNONMET by themselves to be totalizations in process .
( II , 20 ) This meansMET that first , they leadMET to unforseeable results , and second , that the internal structure of social objects containsMET ‘ the double negation of themselves and of each constituent part by the other ’ ( II , 22 ) .
There is , therefore , before any understanding of historic agents and movements , a certain aporia in all social ensembles : from afar they may appearMET whole , but close to , they can be seenMET as riddled with holes .
This increasingly comesMET to resembleNONMET nothing so much as Sartre's own account of History .
In the context of the negativity of this formulation , Sartre is obliged to poseNONMET once again the problem of whether there can be a totalization , without any independent totalizer or totalizing force such as the dialectic , or whether the structure of negation that he has describedNONMET meansMET that , as for Adorno or Bakhtin , history does not developNONMET positively but , rather , negatively , and is therefore instead detotalizingNONMET : Marxism is rigorously true if History is totalization ; it is not so any more if human history decomposesMET into a plurality of particular histories , or if , in any case , within the relationship of immanence that characterizesNONMET struggle , the negation of each adversary by the other is on principle detotalizing .
Certainly , we have neither the design nor the actual possibility of showingMET here the full truth of dialectical materialism … Our goal is solely to establishNONMET whether , in a practical ensemble tornMET apart by antagonism ( whether there are multiple conflicts or whether they are reducedMET to one ) the breaks themselves are totalizingNONMET and carriedMET along by the totalizing movement of the ensemble .
( II , 25 ) At this point Sartre confrontsMET the possibility that the whole project of the Critique , stated so confidently on its very first page — ‘ it must be provedNONMET that a negation of a negation can be an affirmation ’ ( I , 15 ) — may breakMET down .
perhaps the Truth of History can not be provedNONMET ; its direction can not be discernedMET .
Sartre's reaction to the threat that the negation of a negation may produceMET a detotalizing effect is to introduceMET a new category , a unifying force of a ‘ singularization ’ which incarnatesMET the universal : ‘ If totalization really is an ongoing process ’ , he writesNONMET , ‘ then it operatesMET everywhere .
That meansNONMET both that there is a dialectical meaning of the practical ensemble … and that each singular event totalizesNONMET in itself the practical ensemble in the infinite richness of its singularity ’ ( II , 26 ) .
Unlike Lukács ' insignificant event from which the universal is precariously drawnMET out through the narrative , Sartre's singularity worksMET synecdochally in a conventional antinomy with the universal , the relation between the two structured according to the familiar nineteenth-century model of organic growth or process in which each singular event makesMET up the whole while , as he putsMET it , ‘ the whole is entirely present in the part as its present meaning and as its destiny ’ .
Sartre's ‘ singular universal ’ , therefore , begsMET the question , for it is predicatedNONMET on the assumption that , if there is not a totality as such , then there already is an overall totalization : ‘ If totalization really is an ongoing process … ’ .
That developing process is itself totalizedNONMET through Sartre's assertion that each totalization is the totalization of all struggles , as it must be if the singular is to incarnateMET the universal .
The concept of the singular universal thus facilitatesNONMET a circularity in the argument whereby Sartre can avoidMET the question which he beganNONMET by posingNONMET .
So the singular universal presumesMET the totalization he can't ( yet ) proveNONMET .
This strategy marksMET a structure of repetition in Sartre's text : each time he posesNONMET the question of how there can be totalization of History without a totalizer , he retreatsMET to a more limited example whose unity is already evident , but which in the end only bringsMET him back to the original question again .
In this case Sartre demonstratesMET how the singular universal works , by appealing to the concrete example of a boxing match — a random exemplification that just happensNONMET to reproduceMET the single adversaries of the master/slave dialectic .
Its totalization takesMET place through its incarnation , as part of the totality of boxing , in the overall framework within which each individual fight occursNONMET .
Each boxing match , Sartre claims , must be both a unique event and also in some sense the incarnation of all boxing , whose rules and conventions it followsMET , and whose past and future history it setsMET itself against .
But it is also apparent that that totality is not completely knownNONMET , nor is its future shape even presumedNONMET .
By totalization , therefore , Sartre does not here meanNONMET anything like a predetermined end or final closure of a totality but rather a process of mediation among the parts , where each is determinedNONMET by the other .
No one can predictNONMET the future of boxing , either at the level of particular victories or defeats , in effect a structure of repetition , nor at the more general level of possible modifications or developments of the sport .
Yet each individual bout articulatesMET itself within the framework of the history of boxing , known and unknown .
This allowsMET Sartre to includeMET chance and contingency in his scheme .
Since it can not be knownNONMET as a concept that will realizeMET itself in the future , Sartre arguesNONMET instead that the totality only producesMET itself in the moment : ‘ The incarnation as such is at once unrealizable except as totalization of everything and irreducible to a pure abstract unity of that which it totalizesNONMET ’ ( II , 58 ) .
The universal , the totality , can only be knownNONMET through the singular .
But its future direction remainsNONMET unknown and indeterminate .
At the same time Sartre makesMET a larger , though less persuasive claim that the boxing-match also worksMET synecdochally and re-exteriorizesNONMET a more fundamental violence , namely the interiorized condition of scarcity that he considersMET to be the basis of conflict in general .
The boxing match ‘ is the public incarnation of all conflict ’ ( II , 32 ) , totalizingNONMET in its own struggle the whole of ‘ contemporary irreducibilities and fissures ’ ( II , 26 ) : thus one can and must sayNONMET … that each fight is the singularisation of all the circumstances of the social whole in movement and that by this singularisation , it incarnatesMET the enveloping totalization which the historical process is .
( II , 58 ) But then he addsNONMET , ‘ I have saidNONMET and I repeat that we have not yet provedNONMET that this enveloping totalization existsNONMET ’ .
So , although it is possible to conceiveMET of any event as an incarnation of the totality , insofar as it must itself makeMET up a part of that totality in its determination , unlike the case of the boxing match , where we can defineMET the overall entity ‘ boxing ’ , it still remainsNONMET unproven that an overall entity , ‘ History ’ , can be saidNONMET to existNONMET at all .
For all his use of the model of the boxing match , Sartre has really gotMET no further with the fundamental question of how there can be totalization without a totalizer .
It is simple enough for him to showMET that a boxing match takesMET place within a general totality of ‘ boxing ’ , which is itself only ever present in any individual incarnation , for as a game each match is both an individual bout and something conducted according to general rules and a specific social tradition .
But what about those conflicts that do not takeMET place within such a constituted social system , such as conflictual bourgeois societies which can not be saidNONMET to be unifiedNONMET , except , as Sartre suggestsMET dismissively , by appeal to a lost paradise before the class struggle ?
Such societies makeMET the conflicts of history irreducible to Sartre's logic unless , like the boxing match , they can be shownMET to takeMET part in a larger totalizable category .
However , when he posesNONMET the question of whether his method could workMET as well for the class struggle as for the boxing match , Sartre admitsMET that he findsMET it impossible to answerNONMET and returns instead to the much easier case of sub-groups .
Once again he backtracksMET and assumesMET a larger unity in which conflict takesMET place .
The major question thus always remainsNONMET unanswered in the Critique : every time that Sartre announcesMET that he is about to proceedMET with the fundamental problem of how History can be a totalization without a totalizer , he turnsMET back to a previous , more easily intelligible stage on the way .
His difficulty is accompaniedMET by a no doubt symptomatic increasing distrust of universals so that , in championingNONMET specificities against them , he seemsNONMET to give up the attempt to validateNONMET the universals — History as Totalization — that originally formed the object of his project .
At this point a further contradiction in Sartre's whole enterprise beginsNONMET to openMET up : for someone so deeply distrustful of universals it seemsNONMET curious that he has involvedNONMET himself so emphatically with the notions of totality , History , and the dialectic .
As Sartre insistsNONMET more and more upon the virtues of specificity ( II , 200 — 05 ) , such is his distaste for Marxist or any other universalizing categories that he refusesNONMET even to countenanceNONMET them , attemptingNONMET to replaceMET concepts with specificities , universals with singulars .
His scepticism goesMET to the extent of even denyingNONMET the existence of ‘ society ’ or ‘ the nation ’ as such ( II , 24 , 61 ) — the very totalities which his own general argument for totalization requiresNONMET .
Here certain similarities with later ‘ post-Marxist ’ theorists such as Foucault or Lyotard , beginNONMET to becomeNONMET apparent .
But if Sartre anticipatesNONMET such later thinkers we should not assumeMET too quickly that they have simply takenMET his insights further .
For Sartre's singular universal could never be expectedNONMET to solveNONMET the formal theoretical problem of how individual existential existence can be relatedNONMET to History insofar as it simply renamesNONMET , in one oxymoronic category , the original antithetical terms .
Without an adequate theory of their articulation , they simply beginNONMET to separateMET again .
( d ) Warfare and crusades The poet Marbod of Rennes celebratedMET ( in Latin ) the vengeance which would befallNONMET a wicked castellan and his troops : The poem highlightsMET two important twelfth-century developments : the use of force in punishing aristocratic crime ( the fruit of princely peace-keeping ) , and the increasing significance of siege-engines in warfare .
Intellectuals claimedNONMET a formative influence in the second too : John of Marmoutier declaredNONMET that monks from his own monastery had readNONMET Vegetius ' De Re Militari to Geoffrey le Bel when he was investingNONMET the castle of a rebellious castellan , and ascribed his success to their advice on firebombs .
But common sense may have been more important than learning in perceivingNONMET the vulnerability of most castles to — battering-rams and catapults ; for even in 1100 they were , as a rule , primitive structures .
