Siege-engines demanded on the one hand skilled operators , and on the other a plentiful supply of unskilled labourers to moveNONMET the necessary materials .
This effectively restrictedMET their use to the wealthy and to those whose claim to assistance under the ban was incontrovertible .
Equally , the improvements in fortification neededNONMET to withstandNONMET their effects — thick stone walls , inner as well as outer defences — required incomes greater than those of simple lords .
The net effect was that , given dedication , princes — Louis VI , Geoffrey le Bel , Alphonse-Jourdain — could subdueNONMET rebellious castellans within their own demesnes , and could buildNONMET castles of their own which were impregnable to all but lengthy and sustained attack .
Henry II's castle at Chinon , where the treasury of Anjou was situatedNONMET , was the model for its generation , with its halls , upper chambers , tower , and curtain walling , set on a high point above a strategic crossing of the Loire .
It could be copiedMET only either by those of nearly equal wealth or by those who could concentrateNONMET their resources chiefly on defence — princes , great bishops or , in the south especially , towns .
All others becameNONMET vulnerable .
John of Salisbury's comment that not only the towns but also the fortresses of Gaul fearedMET Henry I of England was revealing of the new situation .
Similarly , campaigningNONMET in the field imposedNONMET an increasing financial burden .
The treaty between Robert II of Flanders and Henry I of England , renewedNONMET by their successors , stipulatedNONMET that each knight supplied to the English king should bringNONMET three horses with him — this at a time when a horse representedNONMET a major investment .
Then knightly armour grewMET more elaborate and costly throughout the century .
And though some knights might be suppliedNONMET free by feudal service , household ones had to be maintainedMET by their lords , mercenary ones needed pay , and those with money-fiefs constitutedNONMET a regular charge on the treasury .
Besides , away from their home base , knights were useless on their own .
In open battle and in the plundering expeditions that constitutedNONMET the normal form of aggressive warfare , they neededNONMET the backing of archers , both mounted and on foot , and of numerous infantrymen .
The usual source of supply was town militias — Suger mentionsNONMET those of Rheims , Châlons , Laon , Soissons , Orléans , Etampes , and Paris in the royal army of 1124 .
But they might have to be supplementedNONMET by mercenaries from Flanders and the Low Countries , where the rapidly expanding population forced large numbers of young men into military careers .
In the eyes of the faithful , these ‘ Brabanters ’ , with their freebooting and lack of discipline after the end of campaigns , were as dangerous as heretics ; in 1171 Frederick Barbarossa and Louis VII agreedNONMET to expelNONMET them from their lands .
Their value in battle , as shields behind which the knights could shelterMET before they launchedMET their charge , ensuredNONMET their continued employment by those who could affordNONMET them — notably Henry II of England .
But the hatred they arousedNONMET meant that they were liable to be brutally slaughteredNONMET if capturedNONMET afterwards .
Inevitably , therefore , war on the grand scale as foughtNONMET by princes boreMET little resemblance in practice to the feuds of lesser men .
The divergence was sharpenedMET by the application of a theoretical distinction , the fruit of Augustinian theology , amplified as the century wentNONMET on by canon and Roman law reference ; princes pronouncedNONMET their campaigns just wars ( foughtNONMET against aggressors with the aim of re-establishingNONMET peace ) or public wars ( declaredNONMET by a competent authority in the public interest ) , while they condemnedNONMET the wars of lesser men as infractions of the peace .
Geoffrey Martel had perceivedMET the propaganda potential of public war as early as the mid eleventh century ; later it enabledNONMET Henry the Liberal of Champagne to claimNONMET the military service of all lords within his county , a reapplication of the Carolingian ban .
So it could be a powerful weapon .
Yet the logic of the definition suggestedMET that it would benefitNONMET especially kings , whose competence to declareNONMET war could not be impugnedNONMET : thus Thibaud of Blois failedNONMET to persuadeNONMET the monks of Marmoutier that they owedNONMET him service when he foughtNONMET against Louis VI ; they claimedNONMET discretion in the matter ; and in 1184 , the mighty Philip of Alsace hesitatedNONMET to commitMET to battleNONMET the army he had summonedNONMET against Philip Augustus , through fear that its ranks might meltMET away .
The contrast with the united front Louis VI and his troops presented to the emperor Henry V in 1124 was marked .
A royal banner now bestowed respectability on a cause ; kings ' wars were assumedMET to be for the sake of peace , even when cripplingly expensive and increasingly savage .
This goesMET some way to explainingNONMET why the complicated campaigns within Toulouse in the second half of the century were largely fought out under the banners of the Angevin , Aragonese , and French kings ; and why the revolts of Henry II's sons had widespread ramifications .
The twelfth century was characterizedNONMET , therefore , by fewer but more protracted wars , which smoulderedMET for long periods between short , sharp bouts of conflict , like the war that coveredMET must of the reigns of Henry I of England and Louis VI of France , the one inauguratedMET by the great rebellion of 1173 , which outlivedMET both Louis VII and Henry II , or that against Catalan claims in the south .
Into these large numbers of local conflicts were subsumedNONMET .
The pattern caused problems , in that the circumstances which might triggerNONMET off renewed fighting were unpredictable ; yet the moment an opportunity offered , princes had to be preparedNONMET for invadingNONMET their enemies ; there was no time for lengthy preparation .
The usual tactic was to marchNONMET troops across the enemy's territory , plunderingNONMET and looting ; to takeMET fortified places if the task was easy ; to obtainNONMET allies among the lords of the locality ; and to retreatNONMET without fightingNONMET a battle if at all possible — in effect an application to a wider canvas of the some technique of warfare which had earlier madeMET castellans formidable in the immediate environs of their castles .
It necessitatedNONMET the rapid mobilization of auxiliaries to joinMET a core of highly-trained troops kept constantly , at the ready — the princes ' military households , which becameNONMET the linch pin of the system .
John of Marmoutier's life of Geoffrey le Bel offersMET a glimpse of how strong bonds were createdNONMET between the prince and his followers within the household , and how a high level of training was maintainedMET at all times .
Geoffrey was broughtNONMET up from infancy with the sons of neighbouring Angevin lords , on whose companionship he reliedNONMET .
When it cameMET time for him to be knightedNONMET by Henry I in Rouen , he setNONMET off for Normandy with a crowd of these young men about him .
In Rouen , the occasion was celebratedNONMET with pomp , elaborate dress , and a great feast , and then the youths all demonstratedNONMET their military skill at a grand tournament , at which Geoffrey naturally won the highest honours .
It was within this kind of environment that chivalry flourishedMET , that young men learned to identifyNONMET , their vassalage towards their lord as a symbol of their honour , that they debatedMET the relative merits of Roland's and Oliver's way of displayingMET loyalty ; and that they learnedNONMET the finer points of jousting .
Tournaments were disapprovedNONMET of by ecclesiastics , for they could be both bloody and dangerous .
Yet they suppliedNONMET real needs : .
that of an instruction in the martial arts compatible with the maintenance of a prince's peace ; that of an outlet for competitive instincts within the claustrophobic confines of a court ; and that of display to maintainMET princely social status .
So they flourishedMET everywhere .
They offeredMET opportunities for men of skill to acquireNONMET great position in the world — Arnoul of Ardres caughtMET the eye of Countess Ida of Boulogne through his exploits ; and they also conferredNONMET lustre on the great — Geoffrey le Bel and Philip of Alsace were renowed throughout France for their distinguished performances in these show battles .
All this formed a background to the first century of crusading ; and it goesMET some way to explainingNONMET the more secular aspects of the magnetism which drewMET French knights to takeMET up the cross in their thousands .
Urban II , launchingMET the First Crusade at Clermont in 1095 , presentedMET it as a natural evolution of the peace movement : warriors were to forgetNONMET their petty feuds and squabbles in a campaign to promoteMET the interests of Holy Church .
The war , declaredNONMET by one whose moral authority was unimpeachable , was to freeMET the Eastern churches , to endNONMET Muslim guardianship of the holy places , to restoreMET Jerusalem to its proper state .
As princes sawMET it , it was a just war in the fullest sense of the term ; those who were slaughteredNONMET in its battles were regardedMET as among the martyrs of the church .
When Raymond of Toulouse , Robert II of Flanders , Robert Curthose , Stephen of Blois , and Hugh of Vermandois respondedMET to the call , past and present members of their military households fellMET almost automatically into rank behind them , to testNONMET themselves against terrible dangers , but also to enjoyNONMET the companionship in arms , the adventure , the deeds of daring which were the stuff of the chansons de geste .
That they sharedMET , along with all other participants in the crusade , a fervent devotion , a conviction that their sins would be forgivenNONMET , is certain .
Yet for them crusading necessitated no large leap of the imagination , no millenarian vision ; it was simply a challenging and a deserving extension of their everyday activities .
In French eyes , the hero of the First Crusade was Robert II of Flanders .
While Raymond of Toulouse remainedNONMET in Outremer , Stephen and Hugh disgracedNONMET themselves in escapingNONMET from the siege of Antioch , and Robert Curthose , no matter how gallant , at least in his lifetime failed to impressMET , Robert II's prestige soaredMET to the skies .
He becameNONMET Robert of Jerusalem to his contemporaries ; his deeds were recordedNONMET in the Song of Antioch ; his pious bravery totally expungedMET the memory of Robert the Frisian's usurpation ; and after his death his son Baldwin VII harpedMET on his father's achievement to justifyNONMET his substantial use of coercion against the enemies of the church .
Outside Flanders , Robert's sister's marriage to Roger of Sicily was a mark of his new position in the world ; like Louis VI's sister's marriage to Bohemond of Antioch , it stretchedMET French kinship connections into the new Norman colonies , ensuringNONMET that travellers from the homeland would findMET a welcome in those distant parts .
Robert's example was a potent one .
After the next change in dynasty , Thierry and Philip of Alsace strengthenedMET their shaky claim to the comital position by attainingNONMET for themselves the prestige attachedMET to being the outstanding crusaders of their generation .
Thierry's remote connection with the family of Godfrey de Bouillon , along with his marriage with Sybilla of Anjou , Fulk V's daughter , gaveMET him some claim to the throne of Jerusalem ; as a consequence , the aristocracy of Outremer viewedMET him and Philip with mixed feelings , expectingNONMET much of them , yet fearingNONMET their ambitions .
In the end , it was not in Outremer but in the newly conquered Byzantine empire that the Flemish crusading achievement was crownedMET with the elevation of Count Baldwin IX to the imperial throne in 1204 .
But in the twelfth century , the house of Alsace could affordNONMET the high costs of their expeditions — Thierry wentNONMET to Jerusalem four times , Philip twice — and the counts ' repeated absences in fact promotedMET administrative reform ; the baillis and the Grote Bref were as much the products of crusading as the English and Norman judicial system and exchequers were the product of the king-duke's divided attentions .
But if , on balance , the Flemish counts benefited materially from crusadingNONMET , — as , arguably , did the Angevin — they were far from typical .
For other French houses a commitment to Outremer often represented a sacrifice of domestic political interest .
The achievements of Raymond IV St Gilles in consolidatingNONMET his authority within Toulouse were threatenedMET by his departure in 1095 , especially since it was knownNONMET that he had no intention of returningNONMET home .
Then his example luredMET his elder son Bertrand to Tripoli in 1112 , and his younger son Alphonse Jourdain there in 1147 .
Had not his grandson Raymond V fulfilledNONMET his crusading obligation in his early youth , thereby freeingMET himself from the necessity of interruptingNONMET his career in the county , the principality of Toulouse might have disintegratedMET altogether .
William IX's crusade of 1101 broughtNONMET about serious financial problems in Aquitaine which causedNONMET rapid devaluation in the hitherto stable currency ; and Robert Curthose's decision to mortgage Normandy to William Rufus in order to coverMET his crusading expenses exacerbatedNONMET a conflict over the duchy which was not settledMET until the death of his son William Clito in 1128 .
All in all , it was not surprising that Suger , mulling over the precedents of early crusading , triedMET to dissuadeNONMET Louis VII from embarkingMET on his Jerusalem journey in 1145 .
Yet the appeal of crusading was , if anything , even stronger to those aristocratic houses just below the level of the princely : it was , after all , the house of Boulogne which producedMET the first two rulers of Jerusalem .
The counts of Nevers , the lords of Montpellier , the lords of Amboise and Lusignan , the Trencavels , were fervent devotees of the ideal ; so the problems of absences , shipwrecks , death abroad plaguedNONMET them as much as their princes .
On occasion , their determination to sacrificeMET for Christ playedMET directly into their overlord's hands , as when the count of La Marche , who had no direct heir , soldNONMET his county to King Henry II in 1177 .
When it did not , accompanyingNONMET their princes in a joint crusading venture , as the lord of Amboise accompaniedNONMET Fulk V or Hugh VI de Lusignan William IX , created new personal links .
The political spin-offs from crusadingNONMET are therefore more difficult to calculateMET than at first glance they might appearMET .
Nevertheless it is clear that the chief gainer was Louis VII .
The irony of this layMET in the fact that the Second Crusade was counter-productive in Outremer , embittered relations with Byzantium , and resulted in the deaths of enormous numbers of its participants , particularly those drawnMET from the non­aristocratic classes .
Yet it consolidatedNONMET the king's position within France , partly through the skilled regency of Suger , but also because , in takingNONMET on himself the leadership of the expedition , Louis re-NONMET emergedMET as a credible ruler of men .
His noble gesture appeasedNONMET those churchmen who had been appalled by his early obstinacy over the archbishopric of Bourges .
The disasters that befellNONMET his army paradoxically heightened his personal charisma : even the barons of Outremer continuedNONMET to lookMET on him as their one potential saviour .
His friendship with Raymond V of Toulouse , a fellow warrior , reversedMET the trend of history since the middle of the tenth century , in bringingMET the princes of the far south back into the king's mouvance .
The crowds of Burgundians who accompaniedNONMET the king learned to respectNONMET him ; on their return , they soughtNONMET the arbitration of the royal court in their disputes , and they welcomedNONMET Louis's intervention within the counties that fringedNONMET the duchy of Burgundy .
As William of St Denis putMET it , Even as early as 1147 it was apparent that the crusading movement had providedNONMET a new sense of aristocratic cohesion in the realm .
The great joint expeditions , the combined leaderships , although not without friction , had been justifiedNONMET by their outstanding achievement , the conquest and maintenance of Jerusalem .
They were the Gesta Francorum , the deeds of the Franks , or the Gesta Dei per Francos , God's deeds performed through the Franks , as two of their earliest chroniclers entitledNONMET them .
But what was missingMET before 1147 was a clear sense of who the Franks were .
The Second Crusade , however , was launchedMET with St Bernard's ringing appeal to the count and barons of Brittany : In takingMET his place at the head of the Second Crusade , the Rex Francorum decisively hastened the transformation of the Franks into the French .
5 The Philosopher's Child Judith Hughes SOME OF OUR CHILDREN ARE MISSING Children have servedMET philosophy very well .
That is the first thing which anyone surveyingMET the literature would noticeNONMET .
Along with a selection from a list including women , animals , madmen , foreigners , slaves , patients and imbeciles , children have servedMET in that great class of beings , the ‘ not-men ’ , in contrast with which male philosophers have definedMET and valuedMET themselves .
Unlike the others who appearMET and disappearMET as fashion and progress dictateMET , children occupyMET a permanent place in the list partly because of their continuing presence as a potential sub , partly because they have never protestedNONMET and mainly because it is assumedNONMET that in favourable circumstances they will becomeNONMET men and therefore requireNONMET attention .
They have receivedNONMET it in the shape of detailed educational theory carefully worked out to seeMET them through the maturation process from infancy to adulthood .
Generations of philosophers have documentedNONMET this process .
Perhaps the best known version is Shakespeare's seven ages of man which is a poetic statement of what had already been receivedNONMET wisdom for centuries and was to remainNONMET so for centuries to comeMET .
Education was to guideMET the infant through the transition to manhood including such stages as childhood , boyhood and youth .
That is the second thing to noticeNONMET ; the philosopher's children are boys .
The fact that at least half of the world's children would not actually goMET through this process beyond the first two stages is conveniently forgottenNONMET or ignored and , no doubt , the reasons for this were largely social .
But the neglect of girl children through the centuries of theorising is more than a social injustice , though many might thinkNONMET this real and bad enough .
Education has an end .
Although it is fashionable to talkNONMET about its value ‘ for its own sake ’ , what promptsMET the theorising is the strong and well-founded belief that the experiences of childhood affect the kind of adult which the child turnsMET out to be .
Where the end is person- rather than role — that is , where the end is the development of the human mind and spirit rather than the production of , sayNONMET , information technologists — then education is valuedMET in relation to some conception of worthwhile human existence which it is meantNONMET to serveMET .
Such an ideal does not standMET isolated from the practices which striveMET towards it but interactsMET with those practices , helpsMET to constructMET them , and is in turn constructedMET by them .
The great philosophers have always producedMET such a person-oriented account at least for those whose education was thoughtNONMET to matterNONMET .
Education has been directedMET at the production of the rational , the free , the independent of mind , the dignified , in short , the autonomous human being .
Yet because the philosopher's adult has traditionally been male , his children boy children , and his educational programmes designedMET to facilitateNONMET the transition between them , the ideal of the fully human person has been masculinisedNONMET to the point where otherwise thoughtful and sometimes good and wise men have unashamedly admittedMET that this defining ideal is not applicable to half the species .
Rationality turnsNONMET into narrow intellectualism , freedom into licence , independence into isolationism , dignity into selfish pride ; the autonomous human being turnsMET out to be no more than a social atom after all .
The degeneration occursMET , not because men are congenitally or even incorrigibly narrow , libertine , isolated or selfish , but because in definingMET themselves as autonomous beings in opposition to other human beings they have had to seekNONMET what separatesMET them as a group from others .
It is a curiously paradoxical foundation upon upon which to buildMET a theory of autonomy .
Moral autonomy is concerned with individuals not with groups ; a conception of autonomy which dependsNONMET upon group membership displaysMET its own contradiction .
This paper is partly about the rejection of certain accounts of autonomy though not with the rejection of the ideal of autonomy itself .
It is also about children .
WOMEN PHILOSOPHERS AND GIRL CHILDREN Why should women in general and women philosophers in particular be specially interested in the nature and status of children ?
There are , of course , the familiar and obvious reasons connectedMET with women's traditional role in child-rearing but there are less obvious reasons too .
When philosophers dismissMET women as ‘ not-men ’ they frequently do more than simply lumpNONMET them together with children or lunatics .
Explicitly or implicitly the suggestion is that women are children or lunatics or whichever other company they keepMET .
It would be well to knowNONMET just what this entailsMET .
Schopenhauer saidMET that women remainNONMET big children all their lives ; it would be interesting to knowNONMET what he thoughtNONMET children were like .
A common result of this is that when the philosophers denyNONMET autonomy to women , they do so for the same sorts of reason that they denyNONMET it to children and citeNONMET lack of rationality , capriciousness and vulnerability among their characteristics .
We can do more than to rejectNONMET such descriptions of ourselves ; we can askNONMET further questions : are children like this ?
is this why children are not autonomous ?
Again , women well knowNONMET what it is like to be treated as children and they findMET it offensive .
It would therefore be reasonable to considerMET whether children findMET it offensive to be treated like children .
Is being treated as a child an intrinsically humiliating and self-denying experience ?
What is it to be treated as a child ?
Women philosophers are in a special position to considerMET such questions for in the image of the philosopher's child they seeMET themselves .
It is no accident that the liberation of women , such as it is , should formMET part of a wider movement of liberation in general ; liberation for one part of the ‘ not-men ’ is boundMET to have a knock-on effect when your fellow groups are sometimes quite literally identifiedNONMET with you .
The assumption that all groups in the ‘ not-men ’ class are identical with each other is so firmly rooted that , as we shall seeMET in the fourth section , it is readily assumed even by modern libertarian thinkers that showingMET that , for example , some ground for distinguishingMET between men and women is false or irrelevant , immediately commitsMET us to the view that the same ground is irrelevant in distinguishing men from children .
‘ That's what they used to sayMET about women ’ is not a proof that sayingMET it about a child is false .
But it should makeMET us very suspicious .
That when women are givenMET the vote it followsMET that children should be givenMET it too is no argument at all , but a version of it occursMET in modern debates over the justice or injustice of Mill's famous disclaimer in his essay On Liberty .
Having deniedNONMET that we may ever legitimately interfereNONMET with the liberty of another except on the grounds of self-protection , Mill ( 1910 ) assertsMET : this principle is meantNONMET to applyMET only to human beings in the maturity of their faculties .
We are not speakingMET of children or of young persons below the age which the law may fixMET as that of manhood or womanhood .
Those who are still in a state to requireNONMET being takenMET care of by others must be protectedNONMET against their own actions as well as against external injury .
( p.73 ) This view , as we shall seeMET , has been attackedMET on the grounds that it restsMET on the false assumption that the distinction between adults and children is identical with the distinction between rational and non-rational beings .
The attacks are basedMET on empirical observation ; most women and older children are actually quite as rational as most men while some men are actually less rational .
If we agreeNONMET that in that case women should be embracedMET by the liberty principle then so should children .
I shall suggestNONMET that this does not followMET because rationality is not in fact the grounds for the distinction in the first place .
Partly to redressNONMET the balance and partly because talkingMET about ‘ children ’ coversMET such a wide range of potential images , I shall tryNONMET to keepMET before my mind an ordinary 10-year-old of our society .
She is the child of this paper unless I indicateMET otherwise .
Throughout we should askNONMET ourselves , does this ( whatever is being saidMET ) applyMET to her ?
First of all , letNONMET us remindNONMET ourselves of the traditional picture of children drawnMET for us by some great philosophers of the past .
One thing they are all quite sure about is that children are not like adults ; in particular they agreeNONMET that children lackNONMET some capacity for rational thought which adults have .
NOW WE ARE 6 — OR 10 — OR 18 … .
the slave has absolutely no deliberative faculty ; the woman has but its authority is imperfect ; so has the child , but in this case it is immature .
( Aristotle , 1959,1260A ) Children … are not enduedMET with Reason at all , till they have attainedNONMET the use of speech but are calledMET Reasonable Creatures for the possibility apparent of having the use of Reason in time to comeMET .
( Hobbes , 1914 , p. 21 ) [ Children ] … love to be treated as Rational Creatures sooner than is imagined … [ by which ] … I meanNONMET , that you should makeMET them sensible by the Mildness of your carriage , and the composure even in your correction of them , that what you do is reasonable in you and useful and necessary for them .
( Locke , 1968 , p. 181 ) In training for youth , the child must be given reasons ; in the training of the infant for childhood this can not be done .
Young children ought merely to have things shownMET to them as they are , or they getNONMET puzzled and askNONMET question after question .
But as we approachMET the age of youth reason appearsMET .
At what age ought the education for youth to beginMET ?
Roughly at the age of ten years , when by nature the child entersMET the stage of youth and beginsNONMET to reflectMET … The youth … is capable of having principles ; his religious and moral ideas can be cultivatedMET , and he is able to attendNONMET to his own refinement .
( Kant , 1930 , pp. 250–1 ) If a society letsMET any considerable number of its members grow up mere children , incapable of being actedNONMET on by rational consideration of distant motives , society has itself to blameMET for the consequences .
( Mill , 1910 , p. 139 ) What are the philosophers ' children likeNONMET ?
They have an ‘ immature ’ deliberative faculty ( Aristotle ) , are not ‘ enduedMET with Reason ’ ( Hobbes ) , until roughly the age of 10 ( Kant ) and are ‘ incapable of being actedMET upon by rational consideration of distant motives ’ ( Mill ) .
But they are not completely lost causes .
The immature deliberative faculty will matureMET ; children have the ‘ possibility apparent ’ of turning into rational beings ( Hobbes ) ; they loveNONMET to be reated as though they were rational though they are not so yet ( Locke ) ; you can giveMET the prerational child reasons for actingNONMET in certain ways and he will turnNONMET into the youth who is capable of having principles ( Kant ) .
Until the time when these things happenNONMET then Mill's disclaimer comesMET into operation .
Children must be takenMET care of by others and protected from external injury and against their own actions .
The traditional view is encapsulatedMET in the claim that children are not autonomous ; that is , on a standard interpretation , they lackNONMET the capacity to actNONMET rationally in pursuit of their own self-chosen goals .
It is then a matter of preference whether you sayMET that they can not chooseNONMET the goals or that they can not formMET strategies to achieveNONMET them or both .
In either case , the political implication is that denyingNONMET rights to children is entirely justified , and there the matter rests .
In all this , there are perhaps a couple of things which lookMET plausible when we compareNONMET the philosopher's child with our mental picture ; Aristotle's observation that children are immature and Mill's suggestion that they might needNONMET protection .
Beyond that , the similarities seemNONMET remote .
There is obviously something wrong with a portrayal of children as totally lackingNONMET in reason until they leapNONMET out of bed on their tenth birthday announcingNONMET that they are now able to actNONMET on principle .
Apart from being false , such an account leavesMET no room in our thinking about children for things like teaching and learning , or development in understanding and character and all those other concepts which referMET to processes and not to states .
The tension between these theoretical views of children as non-rational , non- autonomous beings and the practical knowledge of real children is evident in those quotations from Hobbes and Locke and Kant and Mill .
Children , according to Hobbes , have the ‘ possibility apparent ’ of becomingNONMET reasonable .
In what does the possibility consistNONMET ?
Hobbes is not usingNONMET an inductive argument here ; the ‘ possibility apparent ’ is not an inductive argument from observations about past children but is meantNONMET to referMET to some discernible feature of present ones .
But what ?
Hobbes does not tellMET us , but whatever it is it had better be something which a monkey does not have .
It is not language since Hobbes is here talkingMET about the prelinguistic child .
Perhaps it consistsNONMET in the ability to respondMET intelligently to the language of others .
But then , either Hobbes has failedNONMET to distinguishMET the child from at least the higher and domesticated animals or the force of ‘ intelligently ’ must be explainedNONMET in such a way as to excludeMET animals .
In any case , if such a qualification is calledMET for it is hard to seeMET how a creature with no rationality at all could possessMET it .
Locke's remarks are just as puzzling .
Children are definitely not rational but loveNONMET to be treated as if they were .
How is this possible ?
Apparently they likeNONMET having things explainedNONMET to them without understanding either the explanation or even what an explanation is .
Perhaps he just meansNONMET that they likeNONMET the sound of my voice ?
Well , maybe they do , but makingNONMET any old noises is clearly not sufficient to enterMET the rationality stakes ; I must at least sayMET something .
Is it just that I talkNONMET to them that they loveNONMET ?
Maybe , but I can also , if I likeNONMET , talk to my car , but yellingNONMET at it in the approved Basil Fawlty manner is hardly treating it as rational .
Lockean children have the added amazing ability to recogniseMET reason in you without possessingMET any themselves , while Kantian kids , two stages back from rationality , have the disconcerting habit of gettingNONMET puzzled and askingNONMET questions .
Mill's minors are a little more complicated .
Part of the time he seesMET them in the familiar way as creatures who lackNONMET rationality to at least some degree .
But in the disclaimer his children needNONMET above all to be protectedNONMET from the ghastly consequences of their own actions .
Their problem seemsNONMET to be not one of the inability to chooseMET goals or to formMET strategies for achievingNONMET them , but an incorrigible propensity to chooseMET the wrong ones and an awesome efficiency in achievingNONMET them unless adults interveneNONMET .
All in all , it is a pretty unconvincing picture .
If you sayMET that children are completely non-rational then you have to accountNONMET for the fact that they becomeNONMET rational , and to do that it appearsNONMET from these examples that you have to assumeNONMET that they already are .
If , on the other hand , you allowMET rationality to children , then you can not useNONMET their lack of it as a criterion to distinguishMET them from adults .
Hobbes et al .
are not aware of the unreality of their original pictures which is why , often in the same sentence , they produceMET these contradictions .
The one thing they do not do is to re-examineNONMET the original for the tell-tale signs of forgery .
ILLEGITIMATE INFERENCES The recognition that children can not simply be writtenMET off in the rationality stakes and can not therefore be denied autonomy on this account has ledMET some writers to concludeNONMET that they can not , therefore , be deniedNONMET it on any account .
We should noticeMET that this view is not just a flight of fancy from the loony left , the pederast lobby or children themselves .
It is also to be foundMET in stronger or weaker versions of more cautious academic thought .
In Escape from Childhood ( 1974 ) , John Holt notesMET that children are , in fact , capable of a great deal more than modern society allowsMET them to be .
He seesMET childhood as a fairly modern invention designed to fitMET adult rather than children's needs , and an oppressive invention at that .
He suggestsNONMET that children should be givenMET a comprehensive range of civil and legal rights including the right to voteNONMET , to manageNONMET their own financial affairs , to directMET and manageNONMET their own education and to controlMET their own sex lives and to makeMET and enterMET into , on a basis of mutual consent , quasifamilial relationships outside one's immediate family — i.e. the right to seekNONMET and chooseNONMET guardians other than one's own parents and to be legally dependent on them .
( Holt , 1974 , p. 16 ) This is also the view put forward by John Harris , though in less specific terms .
Like Holt , Harris believesNONMET that the so-called incompetence of children is an adult invention imposed on children for adults ' convenience .
He makesMET a firm proposal that the age of majority should be gradually reducedMET to 10 years , and  remarks : We must rememberNONMET that to denyNONMET someone control of their own lives is to offerNONMET them a most profound insult , not to mentionNONMET the which the frustration of their wishes and the setting at naught of their own plans for themselves will addMET .
Perhaps we should conductMET annual examinations from an early age to be sure that we do as little of this sort of damage as possible ?
( Harris , 1982 , p. 49 ) Now Holt and Harris both have many wise , enlightened and humane observations to makeMET about some of the injustices which we inflictNONMET upon children , but as these remarks show , puttingMET them right without inflictingNONMET equally grave injustice is no easy matter .
Both of them appearNONMET to sufferMET from a form of mental myopia in imaginingNONMET the consequences of such proposals , and I am not here referringMET only to Mill-type consequences of harm brought about by unwise decisions .
What , we may askNONMET Holt , happensNONMET to the child who , dissatisfied at home , seeksNONMET in vain for guardians who would suitMET him ?
What if no one wantsNONMET him ?
Our papers are currently full of ‘ hard ’ children in local authority care advertising for foster or adoptive parents .
In such a situation the skilled care of social workers is crucial to ensuringNONMET that an unwanted by-product of success for some children is not the total destruction of self-esteem for others .
What , we may askNONMET Harris , happensNONMET to the child who repeatedly failsNONMET his annual examination ?
To imposeNONMET such a test on children would be a particularly invidious way of discriminating against them , unless Harris has in mind that we should all undergoNONMET such examination .
He might then be open to bitter objections from many adults .
These two suggestions , far from being enlightened liberation of all children , are actually oppression of a deeply damaging kind to at least some , and Harris's suggestion containsMET a capacity criterion in disguise .
In any case , it would be dishonest to pretendNONMET that Mill-type consequences are not relevant here .
SupposeNONMET Holt's 6-year-old does optNONMET out of school ?
What happensNONMET to her then ?
What happensNONMET if her father is unwilling or unable to stayNONMET at home with her ?
Is it any better to obligeNONMET her to goNONMET abseiling or butterfly-catching instead ?
However much she may enjoyNONMET such pursuits , there will be times when she would actually rather wanderNONMET the streets unaccompanied .
Given that Holt is presumably not volunteeringNONMET himself to takeMET care of her , who will ?
His view that lettingNONMET children runNONMET in and out of busy airports smartly avoidingNONMET the traffic is perfectly reasonable dependsNONMET upon a conception of a child which is far narrower than even the sex divide .
Holt's child is actually the Artful Dodger ; mercifully , not all children are .
There are other difficulties too .
It is not clear whether or not Harris thinksNONMET that children of 10 should be obliged to take on full political status whether or not they wantNONMET to , but Holt clearly does not .
He proposesNONMET that ‘ the rights , privileges , duties , responsibilities of adult citizens be madeMET available to any young person , of whatever age , who wantsNONMET to makeMET use of them ’ ( Holt , 1974 , p. 15 ) .
If Holt thinksNONMET that this proposal would removeMET an arbitrary boundary line between adults and children , then he is mistaken .
The point about an adult citizen is that he has these rights , privileges , duties and responsibilities whether or not he wantsNONMET them .
He may not exerciseMET his rights or he may shirkNONMET his duties , but he can not forgoNONMET them .
They are not just available to him , they are his .
That is what being a citizen involvesMET .
Rights and privileges do not poseNONMET any particular problems in the case of children .
Holt can and does believeNONMET that children should have them as adults do , and then leavesMET it up to the child to decideNONMET whether or not to exerciseMET them .
But the same can not be saidMET for duties and responsibilities .
Failure to exerciseMET one's rights may be morally neutral ; failure to carry out one's duties is not .
It would be perfectly possible to giveMET the rights to children without imposingNONMET the duties on them , the one does not entailMET the other , but we would then still be distinguishing between adults and children as citizens .
Children still would not have full political status .
Duties and responsibilities are not merely available to a citizen ; they are an integral part of being a citizen .
Holt does not wantNONMET children to be obliged to take on any of these responsibilities and he managesMET to makeMET his point by concentratingMET solely on the rights so that he can remarkNONMET : I do not sayMET , either , that these rights and duties should be tiedMET into one package , that if a young person wantsNONMET to assumeNONMET any of them , he must assumeNONMET them all .
He should be able to pickMET and chooseNONMET .
( Holt , 1974 , p. 16 ) If he can ‘ pickMET and chooseNONMET ’ , I suggestNONMET , he is not a citizen , he does not have full political status and he is quite distinguishable on these grounds alone from the adults around him who do not have this option .
Holt and Harris both , in the end , faceMET the same problem .
They attackMET the status quo by pointingMET out that the reasons givenMET for denyingNONMET rights to children are bad reasons , and then explicitly or implicitly denyNONMET them duties for no reason at all .
Whatever else such a strategy may achieveMET , it certainly does not manageMET to produceMET a situation in which children are politically indistinguishable from adults and it restsMET on premises which , unless they can be defendedMET , gainMET nothing for any defence to the charge of arbitrariness .
WHEN IN DOUBT , GOMET BACK TO ARISTOTLE The trouble with all the views which we have lookedMET at is that they tieMET the notion of autonomy firmly and solely to that of knowledge interpreted in either a broad or narrow sense .
That it is firmly tiedMET must be correct ; the inhabitants of Brave New World are not autonomous precisely because they are denied access to relevant information .
Relevant knowledge is a precondition of autonomy but it is not synonymous with it .
Aristotle saidMET something very interesting in that extract from the Politics which I quotedNONMET earlier ; he saidMET that women have a deliberative faculty but that it lacksNONMET full authority .
What did he meanNONMET ?
Revival under Law , 1911–1914 Few contemporaries would have expectedNONMET Balfour's retirement to leadMET to a Unionist recovery .
The party was in a mutinous condition in November 1911 and there was no apparent successor who would have even half of Balfour's political gifts .
Nor was it clear that Balfour's departure was universally desiredNONMET : at the National Union Conference a few days later , Leo Maxse was booedNONMET off the platform , and constituency parties everywhere passed resolutions regrettingMET Balfour's decision .
A great many crocodile tears were shedMET , for , since Unionists had such an elevated view of the principle of leadership , they were unable to acceptNONMET that they had just drivenMET their own leader from office .
The shock causedNONMET by Balfour's going thus did something to steadyMET the party and it certainly producedMET a real determination to settleMET the affairs of the party with less friction than had been fashionable of late .
The main contenders for the leadership were Austen Chamberlain and Walter Long , representingNONMET the two different establishments of the Edwardian Unionist party — the opposite worlds of Birmingham and Wiltshire — but the situation was complicated by the intervention of two outsiders , Edward Carson and Andrew Bonar Law .
Two strong groups emergedMET behind Long and Chamberlain , about equal in numbers , but there were few backers for Carson or Law .
Carson thereupon fellMET out of the contest — or rather announced that he was not standingMET , for no official nominations had been madeMET .
The party officers and Whips were solidly behind Chamberlain , but Law drewMET off some of his support among tariff reformers and , urged on by Edward Goulding and Max Aitken , he refusedNONMET to withdrawMET unless his continued candidature would allowMET Long to winNONMET .
Against Chamberlain it was rememberedNONMET that he was a Liberal Unionist ( as was Lansdowne , who ledMET the Unionists in the Lords ) and that he had not been entirely loyal to Balfour since the referendum pledge .
Long was supportedMET by the bulk of the English county members but by few of the party's men of talent .
By the morning of Friday 10 November it was clear that neither Chamberlain nor Long would secureMET a majority and that some supporters of each of them would not contentedly followMET the other .
A party meeting was to be heldMET on the following Monday and the Whips were makingMET preparation for a vote to be takenMET .
Chamberlain providedNONMET the way out by suggestingNONMET to Balcarres that both he and Long should withdrawMET and so allowNONMET Law to be electedNONMET unanimously ; he also turnedMET down Balcarres's remarkable advice that he should allowNONMET Long to be electedNONMET since Long would makeMET such a mess of things that Chamberlain would be boundMET to succeedNONMET within the year .
FacedMET with Chamberlain's proposition , and without a majority of his own , Long had no option but to agreeNONMET .
Bonar Law , backedMET by fewer MPs than any of the other three contenders at the beginning of the week was now to be the unanimous choice .
Robert Sanders reportedNONMET the " election " meeting on 13 November with evident satisfaction : The Carlton meeting on Monday wentMET off quite admirably .

A good many men cameNONMET into the room by no means inclined to acquiesceNONMET in the proposed arrangement .

So within a few days of his grudging acceptance by his parliamentary colleagues , Law's leadership was ratifiedMET by the throng of party notables at Leeds ; here he receivedNONMET a reception more typical of what was to comeMET in the future .
In 1911 Law was knownNONMET — in so far as he was knownNONMET at all in the parliamentary party — as a spirited debater .
A. ) .
P. Taylor has notedMET that Law was trainedMET , if he was trainedMET for anything in his early career , to be a debater .
In Glasgow he had pickedMET up many of the skills that a more highly-born politician might have acquiredMET in the Oxford Union or at the Bar , but skills that were very different in appearance .
His concern was solely with effectiveness rather than style ; he rarely spokeNONMET with more than brief notes and leftMET it to the occasion to furnishMET the words .
( When he becameNONMET Chancellor of the Exchequer this practice caused consternation at the Treasury , when he usedNONMET only a page of notes to assistMET him in movingMET complicated resolutions on wartime finance ; he reliedNONMET successfully on his memory to provideNONMET details and figures .
) As an extempore speaker he was able to tailorNONMET his words to his audience's reactions and so conveyMET the impression of personal conversation even when addressingNONMET thousands .
In parliament he was wont to abandonMET an argument half-completed if he sensedNONMET that his point had been madeMET ; the speeches that appearMET in Hansard were touchedMET up by his staff , and his speeches in the country were givenNONMET to the press in advance .
In debate he was a formidable opponent , and one that Asquith was never able to masterNONMET , for all his forensic skills .
Again Law succeededNONMET by unorthodoxy ; he was quick to graspMET the essentials of an opponent's argument and quite prepared to be rude or direct if the situation demandedMET it .
In the long debates over Marconi in 1913 and over the Curragh " mutiny " in 1914 Law was able to nailMET Asquith's evasions where a more polished stylist might have been foiledNONMET .
Occasionally , in the onrush of pursuit , he gaveMET commitments that were later regretted , but these were a small price to payMET .
The Unionist recovery was builtMET around Law's leadership , but what Asquith calledNONMET the " new style " of obstruction , threats and offensive behaviour did not originateNONMET with Law .
The beginnings are to be foundMET in the diehard campaign against the Parliament Bill .
It was in June 1911 that the first scenes of disorder were mountedMET in the House of Commons , ledMET by Lord Hugh Cecil .
In August 1911 the diehard peers used language as violent as any that Law was to useNONMET later , and in the crucial decision on the House of Lords Law sided with the hedgers rather than the ditchers .
Ulster's opposition to Home Rule long pre-datedNONMET Law's leadership and he had rarely even spokenNONMET on Irish affairs in parliament before becomingNONMET leader .
Before he succeededNONMET Balfour then , Law was not associatedNONMET with any of the features that were to characterizeMET his party leadership ; his contribution was to useNONMET the leadership in the service of all of these causes , to makeMET himself the spokesman for the most spirited sections of the party .
Law conceived of the role of the leader in an exactly opposite sense from Balfour : he soughtMET to fosterMET unity by placingMET himself at the head of the discordant elements where Balfour had thrownMET the leadership on the side of restraint .
Their respective positions explainMET this in part : as ex-Prime Minister and a considerable figure in his own right , Balfour had the confidence to believeNONMET in his own judgement even when isolatedMET from the bulk of the party ; as the tertium quid in the recent contest , Law had neither the weight nor the confidence to takeMET such a detached view .
His strategy was rather to canalizeMET the enthusiasm of the diehards into party channels , to articulateMET their views , and to createNONMET unity from the sense of movement .
In his characteristic phrase , " I am their leader , I must followMET them " — but he determinedNONMET to followMET them from the front .
As a result of this he was labelledMET as a diehard and a bigot , when he actually distrustedNONMET the diehards and was himself distrustedNONMET by the bigots .
Much of his leadership was thus a form of pragmatic extremism , extreme action and the threat of more extreme action to comeMET , but used in the cause of more limited objectives .
He certainly heldMET deep convictions as to the absolute wrongness of the Liberal policies that he opposedNONMET , but at least a part of his apparent hostility was assumedMET for the occasion , a hard line that might secureMET a better compromise in the end .
So in his first major speech as leader in parliament he wastedNONMET little time on the customary compliments and warnedMET the government that he intendedNONMET to playMET hard .
In private conversation he toldNONMET Asquith " I am afraid that I shall have to showMET myself very vicious Mr Asquith this session .
I hopeNONMET you will understandNONMET .
" In later conversations about Ulster , Law was frank enough to pointMET out that bloodshed in Ulster would be the best way of ensuringNONMET an electoral landslide for the Unionists .
There was then an open toughness about party tactics ; before the Buckingham Palace Conference in 1914 he had Central Office work out the electoral effects of excludingMET nine , six or four counties of Ulster from an independent Ireland the concern of a calculating pragmatist not of a bigot .
From the party viewpoint Law's methods were successful but dangerous ; expectations raised when the party was in full cry were not easily setMET aside for an eventual compromise , and the only outcome that would fully vindicateNONMET the methods was the recovery of power .
The basis of recovery was then Law's fighting capacities as leader .
In parliament there would be a carefully organized campaign of resistance that would at least slowMET the government down and raiseMET Unionist morale .
Improved morale would also makeMET possible organizational advances outside parliament , all linkedMET to the issue of Ulster , and with the sights fixedMET firmly on the next election , an election that would makeMET or breakMET the Union , the Empire and Law's leadership of the party .
All was linkedMET to the sense of a new departure , a " new style " , a " new regime in politics " and a new team at the helm : as well as a new leader , the party had by the middle of 1912 a new Chief Whip , Party Chairman , party treasurer , principal agent , press adviser , and an almost entirely new team of Whips and organizers .
Party organization provided the easiest advances because it was the only area entirely under the party's control .
No general election was foughtMET by the organization set up after 1911 , but there is little doubt that there was a massive improvement ; criticisms that were commonplace in 1910 were not to be heardMET by 1913 .
The space available to Central Office was increasedNONMET by the acquisition of St Stephen's House as well as St Stephen's Chambers , which had been occupiedNONMET since 1874 ; the new office costNONMET $3,000 a year in rent alone .
The quality of the senior staff was improvedNONMET by the appointment of three specialists .
John Boraston took over as Principal Agent in 1912 , having been a professional organizer all his career and latterly chief agent to the Liberal Unionist Council .
He joinedMET William Jenkins , appointed chief organizing agent in 1911 and previously district agent for the Midlands Liberal Unionists .
The party was indeed handed over to Birmingham .
Finally , Malcolm Fraser , ex-editor of the Standard and of the Daily Express becameNONMET first honorary press adviser and subsequently was employedNONMET to runMET the press bureau at the colossal salary of £1,200 .
Steel-Maitland , Boraston , Jenkins and Fraser made up a team of experts , all of sufficient status to dealMET with politicians who might callNONMET into the office ; the work of the office was departmentalizedNONMET for the first time and the heads of department brought together into a supervising board .
The influence of Central Office toned up the rest of the organization .
A new canvass system was introducedMET in 1911 so that all county constituencies would operateMET the same system and so that duplicate records could be keptMET at area level .
This was important at a time when outvoters were a larger group in many constituencies than the size of the majority and when the outvoters were overwhelmingly Unionist .
In 1914 a register of car owners was compiledNONMET , also important when some voters could castMET several votes in an election when polling wentMET several days .
By November 1912 only fifty-one constituencies in Great Britain were without candidates , a much better position than the position at dissolution in either 1909 or 1910 ; few of these fifty-one constituencies were winnable , but in any case most of them had candidates by the end of 1913 .
A programme of speakers for a general election was also ready by 1913 , with both constituencies and politicians told in advance what they might expectMET .
The financial mismanagement that had reignedMET before 1911 was endedNONMET with the employment of professional accountants .
Expenditure on Central Office , district offices and the London office doubled from £32,466 in 1909–10 to $68,957 in 1913–14 ; the total expenditure of the party organization from central funds also doubledMET from $73,000 to over £150,000 .
To payNONMET for this outpouring , a great drive was mountedMET for additional income -by Farquhar and Steel-Maitland .
In 1912 ordinary subscriptions still broughtMET in only £12000 a year and it provedNONMET difficult to raiseMET them to anything like what was neededNONMET .
The method adoptedMET was to canvassNONMET for capital donations that could then be investedNONMET to bringMET in a regular income , and both Balfour and Law were usedNONMET to raiseMET the wind .
Steel-Maitland toldNONMET Balfour that " Farquhar and I are endeavouringNONMET to raiseMET more money .
I thinkNONMET we are likely to succeedNONMET — thanks in part to the very generous example setMET by Lord Rothschild .

Systematic collections were madeMET from peers and from the City ; by the outbreak of war the invested funds amountedNONMET to $671,000 — twice the sum in 1911 and worth four years " expenditure — and there was a special cash deposit of £120,000 for the coming election .
In three other areas , as much political as organizational , advances were madeMET towards the management of the press , the coordination of the heterogeneous collection that made up the party , and the fostering of modern attitudes in the local parties .
Under Malcolm Fraser the party beganMET to makeMET effective use of its support in Fleet Street .
It had been recognizedMET that Liberals had been more adept at handlingMET the press because they were more ready to stoopMET to newspaper practices , as Sandars had reportedNONMET in 1909 : I toldNONMET Northcliffe that if his people would makeMET enquiries at our Central Office , he would findMET that our nightly regiment of speakers was at least as well worth reporting as the Radical contingent , but that I realizedNONMET that from the Press point of view , no doubt , our speakers did not play up to the reporters by> handingMET them their speeches in advance , and by other tricks of the kind to which the Radical orators have recourse .
This was the essence of the problem : the press could only be managedMET by someone who knewNONMET their methods and who would not expectNONMET them to come round to Central Office to searchMET for news .
The UOC foundMET that " it is patent that some feeling existsNONMET among the Unionist Press that , while in the past they have done much for the Party , the Party has not assistedMET in their work .

" He wentMET on to quoteNONMET the response that had been receivedNONMET from editors : Manchester Dispatch : I hopeNONMET you will continueNONMET this form of enterprise .
You fully knowNONMET as an old pressman the difficulty of dealingMET with a big speech late at night … Daily Express : I am much obliged to you for the precis of Mr Bonar Law's speech last night .

The speech cameMET over the wires so late and the sheets were so confused by the Post Office — which is usual in these cases — that without the precis we could not possibly have gotNONMET the leader through in time for the first edition .
So in the supply of information to newspapers predisposedMET to supportMET the party , much was achievedNONMET merely by employingNONMET a specialist .
The other side of press management , depending on informal contacts , is less easy to assessMET .
In 1911 Steel-Maitland invitedNONMET Blumenfeld of the Daily Express to Central Office for a two-way exchange of ideas and advice .
He also usedNONMET Law himself to impressMET editors who were on less familiar terms with Fraser , as with Marlowe of the Daily Mail , and Law tookMET a direct interest in negotiations with the most difficult of all the Unionist editors , J. L. Garvin of the Observer .
Law personally conducted the negotiations with Gardner Sinclair over the sale of the Observer and the Pall Mall Gazette in 1914 ; this negotiation also demonstratesMET that , as well as producing information and nursing editors , the party had to workMET hard to keepNONMET some of the newspapers in business .
Sinclair did buyNONMET the Observer and the Pall Mall in the end , but not before he had been givenMET a $45,000 guarantee from party funds .
Such investments had a double purpose , for they could bringMET in income and provideNONMET a political bonus .
One such scheme involvedNONMET the purchase of the Daily Express by Max Aitken with party funds , but the party was also proppingMET up the Globe , the Standard , and a wide range of provincial dailies .
All these transactions were secret , for there would be little use in keepingNONMET a paper alive if it were knownNONMET to be ownedMET by a political party .
The papers were therefore boughtNONMET through nominees or bank loans backedMET with party capital .
It was usual to extractMET some form of guarantee in exchange for party support but the secrecy prevented such undertakings from being enforcedNONMET .
Sinclair thus gaveMET an undertaking that his papers would always remainNONMET Unionist , but Steel-Maitland doubtedNONMET if such a promise had any value .
The later history of the Daily Express suggestsMET not : when the Express becameNONMET hostile in the 1920s , Younger ragedNONMET " when I thinkNONMET of the large sum of money this office has putMET into that gutter print it makesMET my blood boil " .
The justification for pouringMET out large sums without a certain return was the even greater cost of any real alternative .
The support for the Express in 1912 " providesNONMET for the introduction of £50,000 or $60,000 to retainNONMET the only half-penny paper the Party possessesMET in London , and no less a sum than $700,000 to £1 , 000,000 would be necessary to startNONMET a similar paper if the Daily Express were allowedMET to goMET .
The struggle therefore wentMET on to keepNONMET the Unionist press alive , and in 1912 and 1913 both Aitken and Northcliffe stoodMET by the party and gaveMET valuable support in their papers .
The coordination of competing party bodies was carried out with surprising ease .
The National Union was mergedNONMET with Central Office in 1911 and fusion with the Liberal Unionists followed in 1912 .
Joseph Chamberlain retainedNONMET his preference for independence but allowedNONMET himself to be overruledMET by Austen and by the overwhelming wishes of the Liberal Unionist Council to mergeNONMET .
To caterMET for all susceptibilities , the party becameNONMET the " National Unionist Association of Conservative and Unionist Associations " — a decision that allowedMET some local parties to goMET on callingNONMET themselves Conservative , but the name " Liberal " was at last droppedMET .
The Liberal Unionists were admittedMET to the Carlton Club and a longstanding source of tension was eradicatedNONMET .
This was in itself a striking commentary on what had already been done : Liberal Unionists who had resistedMET amalgamation under Balfour and Acland-Hood in 1911 acquiescedNONMET meekly under Law and Steel-Maitland in 1912 .
Other organizations could not be absorbed but could still be broughtMET within the Central Office orbit .
So in 1911 Steel-Maitland offeredNONMET to joinMET the Halsbury Club in order to guideMET it on to safer lines — and was immediately accusedNONMET of disloyalty by Walter Long .
Long helpedNONMET though by placingMET both Steel-Maitland and Boraston on the Executive Committee of the Union Defence League for the same purpose .
Steel-Maitland also explainedNONMET to Lord Robert Cecil that " it has been arrangedMET that the National Conservative Union should sendMET out leaflets producedNONMET by several of the ancillary organizations , such as the Tariff Reform League , the Anti-Socialist Union , the Primrose League , the London Municipal Society etc .
" The Central Office attitude was flexible , for outside bodies would always existNONMET and could even be madeMET use of : They representMET a time when either their objects were not the same as those of the official organization , or the CCO was not enterprising enough to suitMET them .
But some caution should be observedMET .
It may be wise , while retainingNONMET or regainingNONMET control , to tradeNONMET under different names .
In some cases additional subscriptions may be obtainedNONMET , in others full responsibility may be avoidedMET .
With open allies like the Primrose League , the case for collaboration was strong ; for the first time in thirty years of existence the Primrose League formally linkedMET itself with the party in 1914 .
On the other hand , the independence of the Tariff Reform League was a positive advantage : after January 1913 the party supportedMET the tariff policy but was not includingNONMET them in its immediate programme , so that Central Office could continueNONMET to distributeMET tariff propaganda from the TRL without compromising party policy .
In general , efforts to ensureNONMET better coordination were a matter of the patient building up of contacts , although the improved party morale and the greater efficiency of Central Office had removedMET their justification for existence .

3.3 Pinch effect ( J , H , B ) In contrast to our previous example we shall now investigateMET a cylindrical beam consistingNONMET of two kinds of charge carriers : negative electrons and some positive particles , which I do not wishNONMET to be more precise about at the moment .
We shall assumeMET that the two kinds of particles have equal densities and move in opposite directions .
As a result there is no net space charge and hence no electric field .
The currents , on the other hand , do not cancelMET because they representNONMET opposite charges movingNONMET in opposite directions ( rememberNONMET , minus one timesNONMET minus one is equal to plus one ) .
The magnetic field strength is givenMET again by eqn ( 3.27 ) ; we only needNONMET to substituteMET for the current In + Ip where the subscripts n and p referMET to negative and positive particles respectively .
Hence the magnetic force on the electron at the edge of the beam ( at R = a ) is [formula , and on the positive particle is [formula .
NoteNONMET that the force is inwards , and in the same direction for both particles .
LetNONMET us distinguishNONMET two cases .
Both particles are mobile In that case both of them will moveNONMET inwards under the effect of magnetic force .
But if the diameter of the beam is reducedNONMET , eqns ( 3.33 ) and ( 3.34 ) tellMET us that the forces are even larger .
What happensNONMET then ?
If everything was uniform then the beam diameter would goMET on decreasing .
In practice however the beam is not uniform and does not possessMET perfect cylindrical symmetry .
Under these conditions the motion of the particles is fairly complicated , and of course our model is unable to predictMET the detailed behaviour of the particles .
Nevertheless a few qualitative conclusions may be drawnMET without doing any further mathematics .
If the cross-section happensNONMET to be smaller at a certain place , then the forces are larger there than at the neighbouring cross-sections , so the beam will be further constricted , etc. , leadingMET to the so-called sausage instability ( Fig. 3.3(a) ) .
If the magnetic field happensNONMET to be larger at one side than at the other side , then the beam will be deflectedNONMET towards the weaker field which makesMET the field even weaker , etc. , leadingMET to the so-called kink instability ( Fig. 3.3(b) ) .
The positive particle is immobile In practice this meansNONMET that the positive ions are part of the crystal lattice .
There is then no magnetic force on the ions , only on the electrons .
So the electrons wantMET to moveNONMET inwards but can not because the ions holdMET them back by virtue of their electrostatic attraction .
Naturally , if the ions attractNONMET the electrons the converse is true as well , i.e. owing to the magnetic force on the electrons , there is also an inward force upon the ions .
So the whole crystal structure triesMET to contractNONMET or in other words the material is under pressure ( seeNONMET Example 3.2 ) .
In any practical situation this pressure is small and can be neglectedNONMET when calculatingNONMET the forces on current- carrying conductors .
